<p> In these cases where eating any food causes sweating, it is most likely due to nerve damage in or around the parotid gland, the gland in the cheek that produces saliva. When this occurs, it tends to happen on one side of the face and is known as Frey’s syndrome. </p>
<p> In some rare cases, people with diabetes mellitus may experience bilateral gustatory sweating, with sweating on both sides of the face. </p>
<p> In this article, we compare gustatory sweating with regular sweating and look at what can be done to treat or prevent cases of gustatory sweating. </p>
<p> Gustatory sweating is similar to Frey’s syndrome, and the two terms are often used interchangeably. </p>
<p> It is not uncommon for people to sweat during or after eating. For most people, sweating occurs on the face, scalp, or neck when they are eating spicy or hot foods and drinks. </p>
<p> In these cases, the person’s body is responding naturally to stimulation of a rise in body temperature through sweat. This is a normal reaction and not a cause for concern. </p>
<p> A person with Frey’s syndrome has a problem with their parotid gland and may start to sweat and flush on the scalp, face, ears, and neck after eating any food. However, foods that make people produce a lot of saliva are most likely to trigger the reaction. </p>
<p> Typically, a person develops Frey’s syndrome as a result of surgery near the parotid gland. However, other people may experience Frey’s syndrome due to another injury or illness that affects the parotid gland. </p>
<p> In an attempt to heal themselves, damaged nerves sometimes get mixed up with other nerves, causing a person to produce sweat instead of saliva. </p>
<p> Typically, Frey’s syndrome occurs on just one side of the face. Although both cheeks have a parotid gland, only one may have been damaged. </p>
<p> Gustatory sweating can occur for no apparent reason or as a result of an underlying condition, such as diabetes or Parkinson’s disease. These diseases can also cause damage to the nerves in the mouth. When the nerves become injured, they can become confused and cause sweating. </p>
<p> Unlike Frey’s syndrome, other types of gustatory sweating often occur on both sides of the face. Unlike regular sweating due to eating spicy or hot foods, gustatory sweating causes a person to sweat and flush after eating, thinking, or even talking about food. </p>
<p> This sweating and flushing may occur around the temples, cheeks, neck, forehead, chest, or lips. </p>
<p> Gustatory sweating may cause some people distress, as thinking about food can trigger the reactions of sweating. Since there is often an underlying cause, a person should talk to their doctor to find out what may be causing the sweating. </p>
<p> Frey’s syndrome is triggered by eating food, but it can also occur even while thinking or talking about food. It develops on one side of the face in the area of the affected parotid gland. </p>
<p> Gustatory sweating is often the result of an underlying condition. Some of the more common conditions that may cause gustatory sweating include: </p>
<p> diabetes melliltus </p>
<p> a viral infection affecting the face, such as Bell’s palsy or shingles </p>
<p> People do not necessarily need to see a doctor after sweating from eating food. Those who only sweat while eating either very hot or spicy foods have no reason to be concerned. </p>
<p> Some people who experience Frey’s syndrome may consider it to be a nuisance but do not consider it significant enough to seek help. </p>
<p> However, those people who sweat profusely after tasting, smelling, or talking about food may wish to see a doctor. A doctor can diagnose Frey’s syndrome or another type of gustatory sweating by: </p>
<p> noting the characteristic symptoms </p>
<p> taking a medical history </p>
<p> carrying out the minor iodine-starch test </p>
<p> The minor iodine-starch test involves swabbing the area of the body where the sweating occurs with an iodine solution. The doctor will then apply a starch, such as corn starch, over the iodine. </p>
<p> When the starch and iodine are in place, the doctor will stimulate the mouth, often with an acidic food. A person with Frey’s syndrome or other gustatory sweating will show a discoloration where the sweat forms. </p>
<p> Once diagnosed, a doctor can help a person identify the underlying cause. In some cases, it may be due to surgery or another known condition that the person has. In others, the doctor may wish to carry out further testing to find out what might be causing the problem. </p>
<p> Knowing the cause helps the doctor know how to treat the sweating. </p>
<p> Treatment for gustatory sweating depends on what is causing it. </p>
<p> A doctor treating Frey’s syndrome typically focuses on the symptoms. There is often little that can be done to fix the damaged nerves. Surgical procedures are available to replace affected skin, but they are risky and not often advised. </p>
<p> A doctor may prescribe medicines and topical creams that help block undesired activities of the nervous system, such as sweating. </p>
<p> One medication that has proved quite successful to treat sweating associated with Frey’s syndrome, however, is botulinum toxin type A (Botox). The medication is injected into the affected area to stop the sweating, and there are minimal side effects. </p>
<p> One disadvantage of botulinum toxin is that the effects are temporary. Research shows that people tend to need repeat injections after 9–12 months. The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) do not currently approve the use of Botox for treating gustatory sweating, however. </p>
<p> Treating gustatory sweating when it is not the result of injury or surgery often requires treating the underlying disease or disorder if it is known. </p>
<p> People who suspect that their gustatory sweating is a result of an underlying condition should speak to their doctor about any other symptoms they experience. </p>
<p> Gustatory sweating is considered to be a harmless condition. Some people find that they can deal with the symptoms with no need for medical intervention. </p>
<p> Where the sweating is profuse and a cause for embarrassment, people may want to treat their symptoms. </p>
<p> It is also important that people seek medical attention if profuse sweating is unexplainable, as it could indicate an underlying condition. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599648" filename="321189" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/321189">
<p> Why do I cough after I eat? </p>
<p> It is not uncommon to cough after eating. Coughing is a typical reaction of the body trying to clear irritants from the airways. Irritants are sometimes introduced into the body when eating, and this can lead to coughing. </p>
<p> If coughing after eating happens frequently, people should consult a doctor to determine a cause. Once the cause is known, a person can make some lifestyle changes or take medications to treat it. </p>
<p> Some of the most common causes include the following: </p>
<p> There are many potential causes of coughing after eating: </p>
<p> Food allergies </p>
<p> Allergies are a common cause of coughing after eating. They can develop at any age but typically develop during childhood. </p>
<p> When someone has a food allergy, their body’s immune system is overreacting to what it believes is a harmful substance. People may also experience: </p>
<p> People can have an allergy to one or more foods. If a person coughs because of a food allergy, it is essential that they find out what foods trigger the coughing. </p>
<p> A doctor can help pinpoint the foods causing the reaction. </p>
<p> Asthma </p>
<p> Asthma affects the airways and develops after exposure to an irritant, which can include food. </p>
<p> Sulfite is a common additive found in many drinks and food that often cause asthma symptoms. Foods that contain sulfites and should be avoided include: </p>
<p> However, any food that causes a person to experience an allergic reaction may trigger an asthma attack as well. </p>
<p> In addition to coughing, a person may experience: </p>
<p> wheezing </p>
<p> tightness in the chest </p>
<p> trouble breathing </p>
<p> Dysphagia </p>
<p> Dysphagia causes difficulty when swallowing. When dysphagia occurs, a person’s body has great difficulty moving food and drink from the mouth to the stomach. It can result in pain or discomfort. </p>
<p> Dysphagia may make a person feel as if food has become lodged in the throat. This feeling can lead to gagging or coughing after eating as the body tries to clear the perceived blockage from the throat. </p>
<p> Conditions such as acid reflux often cause dysphagia. A doctor can determine the underlying cause. </p>
<p> Acid reflux </p>
<p> Acid reflux occurs when acid from the stomach travels up the food pipe. The acid may make its way into the upper food pipe or throat through the opening of the stomach, known as the lower esophageal sphincter. </p>
<p> When a person is eating, the sphincter relaxes to allow food to travel to the stomach. In some cases, the sphincter does not close entirely. The resulting gap allows acid from the stomach to travel upward. </p>
<p> The acid can irritate the food pipe, causing coughing. People may also experience: </p>
<p> GERD is a chronic condition that causes a more severe form of acid reflux. When someone has GERD, they are very likely going to experience a cough as well as: </p>
<p> wheezing </p>
<p> nausea vomiting </p>
<p> reflux occurring two or more times a week </p>
<p> LPR does not have the same symptoms of GERD. When it occurs, stomach acid may travel as far up as the nasal passages. Similarly to GERD, it can cause coughing as well as: </p>
<p> post nasal drip </p>
<p> hoarseness </p>
<p> need to clear throat </p>
<p> A doctor can treat these two conditions with medications. A person can also control these conditions with diet modifications. However, there is no cure for them. </p>
<p> Aspiration pneumonia </p>
<p> It is possible to inhale small particles of liquid or food when eating. In healthy people, the lungs will expel these particles through coughing. </p>
<p> Sometimes, the lungs may not be healthy enough to remove the tiny particles. When this occurs, bacteria from the food may become trapped in the lungs, resulting in aspiration pneumonia. </p>
<p> People are at an increased risk for developing aspiration pneumonia if they have acid reflux or trouble swallowing. </p>
<p> When someone experiences these symptoms, it is essential they speak to a doctor. Aspiration pneumonia can cause serious medical problems, such as respiratory failure or lung abscess. </p>
<p> Infections </p>
<p> People might experience a cough caused by an infection in the upper respiratory system. If a cough does not clear up properly, it can lead to a person coughing immediately following eating or drinking. </p>
<p> This type of cough is difficult to treat as it irritates the throat, causing the person to cough more and preventing healing. </p>
<p> It is possible to develop an infection in the food pipe or larynx. This type of infection may be caused by a virus, fungus, or bacteria. The throat may become inflamed and irritated when infected. The inflammation causes a person to cough, particularly following meals. </p>
<p> Not everyone who experiences a cough after eating will need to see a doctor. However, it is a good idea to see a doctor for a post-eating cough when: </p>
<p> it occurs frequently </p>
<p> it lasts longer than 2 weeks </p>
<p> the reason for the cough is unknown </p>
<p> there is blood in the mucus </p>
<p> the person experiencing the cough is an active smoker </p>
<p> Treatment will vary based on the cause. Treatment may be as simple as avoiding trigger foods or treating the condition with medications. </p>
<p> Treatment often focuses on prevention. Steps to prevent coughing following eating or drinking include: </p>
<p> slow down when eating </p>
<p> drink more water during meals </p>
<p> track foods to help determine which cause coughing </p>
<p> People can often avoid coughing following eating with some simple prevention strategies. </p>
<p> Avoiding foods that trigger coughing is often a good first step. However, people should remain aware of changes in their cough, other symptoms, and how frequent and long the cough is lasting. </p>
<p> People should see a doctor if they have any concerns or doubts. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599628" filename="321204" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/321204">
<p> Why do I get a pain in my back after eating? </p>
<p> Back pain after eating is often the result of referred pain. This is pain that originates in one area of the body and radiates to another. Several problems can cause back pain after eating, ranging from poor posture to ulcers. </p>
<p> Read on to learn more about back pain after eating and a variety of treatments. </p>
<p> The following issues can lead to back pain after eating: </p>
<p> 1. Allergies and intolerances </p>
<p> People with allergies or intolerances to certain foods may experience inflammation after eating them. If they already have back pain, the inflammation can make symptoms worse. </p>
<p> Examples of foods that may trigger inflammation and back pain include: </p>
<p> dairy </p>
<p> gluten </p>
<p> peanuts </p>
<p> Some foods can aggravate underlying conditions, resulting in back pain. For example, very spicy foods can cause heartburn, making back pain worse. </p>
<p> 2. Gallbladder inflammation and gallstones </p>
<p> The gallbladder is a pear-shaped organ that sits below the liver. It stores and releases bile, a fluid that helps the body to digest fats. </p>
<p> The gallbladder can become inflamed, especially if hard deposits known as gallstones are present. Eating fatty foods can trigger a gallbladder attack, in which the organ becomes inflamed and causes pain. </p>
<p> Typical symptoms of a gallbladder attack include nausea and severe pain in the upper abdomen. This pain may radiate to the back. </p>
<p> 3. Heart attack </p>
<p> Back pain can signal a heart attack, especially if accompanied by symptoms such as: </p>
<p> lightheadedness </p>
<p> nausea </p>
<p> pain in the arm, jaw, or neck </p>
<p> According to the American Heart Association, women are more likely than men to experience atypical heart attack symptoms. These may include: </p>
<p> pressure in the upper back </p>
<p> dizziness </p>
<p> pain in the abdomen </p>
<p> It should be noted that women do not always have chest pain when experiencing heart problems. </p>
<p> 4. Heartburn </p>
<p> Back pain after eating may result from heartburn, a digestive condition characterized by burning pain in the chest. It is estimated that over 15 million Americans experience heartburn every day. </p>
<p> Other symptoms may include a sour taste in the mouth, a sore throat, and a cough. Certain foods may trigger heartburn symptoms, including: </p>
<p> caffeine </p>
<p> chocolate </p>
<p> spicy foods </p>
<p> Experiencing heartburn more than twice a week may indicate gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can lead to ulcers if not properly managed. </p>
<p> 5. Kidney infection </p>
<p> Symptoms are typically present throughout the day, though some people may notice them more after eating. Anyone who suspects that they have a kidney infection should seek medical attention to prevent complications. </p>
<p> 6. Pancreatitis </p>
<p> The pancreas is an organ that participates in digestion and blood sugar regulation. Inflammmation of the pancreas is known as pancreatitis. Symptoms include: </p>
<p> Authors of a 2013 study report that approximately 70 percent of pancreatitis cases are caused by long-term, heavy alcohol consumption. </p>
<p> 7. Poor posture </p>
<p> Bad posture is a common cause of back pain. A person who is hunched over during meals may experience this pain after eating. </p>
<p> Poor posture while sitting, standing, or working at a desk can also lead to back pain at any time of the day. </p>
<p> 8. Ulcer </p>
<p> An ulcer in the stomach or esophagus may lead to pain that radiates to the back. Other ulcer symptoms include: </p>
<p> feeling full after eating </p>
<p> Infection with Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) often causes ulcers. They may also be caused by long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). </p>
<p> Spicy or acidic foods can make ulcer symptoms worse. </p>
<p> Treatment for back pain after eating depends on the underlying cause. Common treatments are listed below. </p>
<p> Dietary changes </p>
<p> If back pain results from heartburn, ulcers, or food intolerances, it may be helpful to remove trigger foods from the diet. </p>
<p> Trigger foods vary from person to person, but common culprits include: </p>
<p> To identify trigger foods, it may be helpful to keep a food diary or work with a dietitian. </p>
<p> Medications </p>
<p> Medications used to treat back pain after eating will vary significantly, depending on the problem. For example: </p>
<p> Antibiotics can treat kidney infections and H. pylori infections. </p>
<p> Pain relievers may control symptoms of pancreatitis and gallbladder inflammation, when these cases are mild. </p>
<p> Proton pump inhibitors and acid blockers can help to treat heartburn, GERD, and ulcers. </p>
<p> Physical therapy and exercise </p>
<p> Physical therapists are able to correct poor posture. They may recommend stretches and exercises to help strengthen the core muscles and support the back and spine. </p>
<p> Exercises practiced in yoga, Pilates, and tai chi may be particularly beneficial. </p>
<p> Other treatment </p>
<p> If a doctor cannot identify the cause of back pain after eating, try common remedies for generalized back pain. These include resting, applying ice and taking pain relievers. </p>
<p> Here are some tips to prevent back pain after eating: </p>
<p> exercising regularly, to keep muscles strong and prevent poor posture </p>
<p> sitting up straight when eating or sitting at a desk, and use lower back support if necessary </p>
<p> avoiding foods that trigger heartburn and intolerances </p>
<p> reducing stress to avoid irritating ulcers and contributing to muscular tension </p>
<p> limiting alcohol consumption </p>
<p> avoiding fatty, spicy, or sugary foods </p>
<p> addressing underlying medical conditions and infections without delay </p>
<p> Anyone with persistent or worsening back pain should speak to a doctor. </p>
<p> Seek prompt medical treatment if the pain is accompanied by symptoms such as: </p>
<p> burning pain while urinating, or other urinary symptoms </p>
<p> black or tarry stools, which suggest an ulcer </p>
<p> Contact emergency services if back pain is accompanied by any of the following symptoms of a cardiac event: </p>
<p> Back pain after eating is usually the result of referred pain from another area of the body, and it is not always a cause for concern. </p>
<p> However, if the pain persists or is accompanied by other symptoms, it is important to see a doctor. </p>
<p> Most causes of back pain after eating can be easily treated with medication, lifestyle changes, and dietary modifications. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599606" filename="321318" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/321318">
<p> Why do I feel sick after I eat? </p>
<p> We include products we think are useful for our readers. If you buy through links on this page, we may earn a small commission. Here’s our process. </p>
<p> Stomach pain or discomfort after eating has many causes. If stomach pain happens after eating and then goes away, it is usually caused by food. </p>
<p> If a person has other symptoms or ongoing discomfort despite making changes to their diet, it may be a medical condition. </p>
<p> Stomach pain can be prevented by an individual eating a balanced, healthful diet with fresh fruits and vegetables. Not eating spicy or fatty foods and cutting down on sugary drinks or caffeine, may also help. </p>
<p> In this article, we list 21 reasons why a person’s stomach may hurt or feel uncomfortable after they eat, including food and medical causes. </p>
<p> For many different reasons, the food that a person chooses to eat may lead to their stomach hurting afterward. </p>
<p> 1. Food poisoning </p>
<p> One of the key symptoms of food poisoning is stomach pain. Other symptoms include: </p>
<p> Symptoms can appear a few hours after eating, but they may take days or weeks to surface. </p>
<p> Food poisoning normally only lasts a few days. It can usually be treated at home with rest and fluids. </p>
<p> 2. Acidic foods </p>
<p> Acidic foods that can irritate the stomach include fruit juices, processed cheese, and tomatoes. </p>
<p> Finding alternatives, such as replacing fruit juices with water or tea, may help to cut down on stomach pain. </p>
<p> 3. Trapped wind </p>
<p> Trapped wind in the digestive tract can cause discomfort. The stomach may feel stretched and uncomfortable, or there may be a sharp pain. </p>
<p> Sugary drinks and certain foods can cause bloating and wind. These include: </p>
<p> When someone chews gum, sucks sweets, or eats with their mouth open, it can lead to them swallowing air. This can be another cause of wind. </p>
<p> 4. Spicy foods </p>
<p> Chili peppers are often used to flavor spicy food. They contain capsaicin, a chemical that causes the hot or burning sensation. Capsaicin may irritate sensitive parts of the body, including the stomach. </p>
<p> 5. Indigestion </p>
<p> A person can suffer indigestion after eating or drinking. As well as stomach ache, they may feel bloated or sick. </p>
<p> The stomach contains acid to break down food. Sometimes, this can irritate the stomach lining and cause indigestion. </p>
<p> Rich or fatty foods, caffeine, sugary drinks, and alcohol can make indigestion worse. </p>
<p> Over-the-counter medication, which is available online and known as an antacid, may help if cutting out certain foods and drinks makes no difference. </p>
<p> 6. Caffeine </p>
<p> Caffeine is a stimulant found in tea and coffee. It can irritate the stomach and cause discomfort for some people. </p>
<p> People can choose alternatives and still enjoy hot drinks. Decaffeinated tea and decaffeinated coffee are available online. Fruit teas or hot water with a slice of lemon are also healthful to help people stay hydrated during the day. </p>
<p> 7. Alcohol </p>
<p> Alcoholic drinks can cause bloating. This is especially true if they are carbonated, such as beer or sparkling wine. They may also make heartburn worse. </p>
<p> If someone cuts down on the amount of alcohol they drink, it can have many health benefits. Drinking a soft drink or water between alcoholic ones or choosing alcohol-free wine or beer are ways to reduce alcohol consumption. </p>
<p> 8. Food allergy or intolerance </p>
<p> Some people may be allergic to certain foods. These can irritate the stomach and may cause pain after eating. </p>
<p> An intolerance is a milder form of an allergy. Both allergies and intolerances can be caused by many different foods. </p>
<p> Common intolerances include gluten, wheat, and lactose. </p>
<p> People can keep a food diary if they think they might have an allergy. </p>
<p> A food diary is a written record of what they have consumed at each meal, including drinks and snacks. They should also include a note of when their stomach hurts. </p>
<p> Keeping a diary can help determine the foods causing an issue. People can then cut this food out of their diet. </p>
<p> 9. Eating too much </p>
<p> Overfilling the stomach on a regular basis is not good for health. Discomfort after eating may be a sign that a person is eating too much. </p>
<p> Here, we give some of the medical conditions that can also make someone’s stomach hurt after eating. </p>
<p> 10. Gastritis </p>
<p> Gastritis causes the lining of the stomach to become inflamed. It can cause stomach pain, sickness, vomiting, and indigestion. </p>
<p> Mild gastritis can be treated at home with medication and changes to diet. Cutting out acidic foods and eating smaller meals throughout the day can help. </p>
<p> 11. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) </p>
<p> IBD causes the gut to become inflamed. IBD can lead to a range of symptoms, with one being stomach pain. </p>
<p> IBD is a long-term condition that requires treatment with medication and lifestyle changes. </p>
<p> 12. Stomach ulcer </p>
<p> A stomach ulcer is a sore that develops on the stomach lining. It will cause a burning pain in the middle of the stomach. </p>
<p> Stomach ulcers are often caused by an infection. They can also be the result of medications that include aspirin if it is frequently taken over a long period. Treatment is with acid-suppressing medication, with or without antibiotics. </p>
<p> 13. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) </p>
<p> IBS is a condition affecting the digestive system. As well as constipation and diarrhea, it can cause stomach cramps and bloating. </p>
<p> Symptoms can last for days, weeks, or months, and may not always happen after eating. </p>
<p> Although there is no cure, lifestyle changes can help. These include: </p>
<p> eating slowly </p>
<p> avoiding fatty and processed foods </p>
<p> getting plenty of exercise </p>
<p> cutting out alcohol and sugary drinks </p>
<p> eating meals at regular times and not skipping meals </p>
<p> 14. Gallstones </p>
<p> Gallstones are hard pieces of material that form in the gallbladder. If they block a bile duct, they can cause sharp, sudden pain. </p>
<p> Treatment is with medication or surgery, depending on the severity of the condition. </p>
<p> 15. Heartburn </p>
<p> Heartburn is known as gastroesophageal reflux (GER) in medical terms. It can also be called acid reflux. </p>
<p> GER is caused by acid coming up from the stomach into the food pipe. It feels like a burning sensation in the chest and throat. It can also cause a burning feeling in the stomach. </p>
<p> Eliminating alcohol, spicy foods, and losing weight if needed can help control heartburn. </p>
<p> 16. Overactive thyroid </p>
<p> The thyroid gland produces hormones that tell the body how to work. An overactive thyroid can cause medical problems that may affect the bones, muscles, and heart. </p>
<p> One symptom of an overactive thyroid is stomach pain and diarrhea. Other symptoms include trouble sleeping, weight loss, and a rapid heartbeat. </p>
<p> 17. Celiac disease </p>
<p> Celiac disease is a disorder of the digestive system. It is caused by an allergy to gluten, found in rye, barley, and wheat. </p>
<p> Symptoms include stomach pain, constipation, diarrhea and bloating. Cutting gluten out of the diet can stop the effects of the condition. </p>
<p> Lastly, there are several other lifestyle and health reasons why someone’s stomach can hurt after eating. </p>
<p> 18. Stress </p>
<p> Stress can cause muscles to become tense, which can create pain or discomfort in the stomach. </p>
<p> A few slow, deep breaths before eating can relax the muscles. Eating slowly and calmly can help to avoid stomach pain. </p>
<p> 19. Being overweight </p>
<p> Being overweight can mean that a person is more likely to develop conditions such as heartburn or a stomach ulcer. </p>
<p> When an individual loses some excess weight, it can help avoid their stomach hurting after eating. </p>
<p> 20. Constipation </p>
<p> Not having enough bowel movements or having stool that is hard and difficult to pass is likely to be caused by constipation. Stomach pain and bloating are other common symptoms of constipation. </p>
<p> People can treat constipation by eating a diet that is high in fiber and drinking plenty of fluids. </p>
<p> 21. Blood pressure medication </p>
<p> Medication used to treat blood pressure can cause side effects. These include constipation and sometimes stomach pain. </p>
<p> If a person experiences side effects from this medication, they can speak to their doctor about switching to an alternative type. </p>
<p> If someone has any symptoms of the medical conditions listed here, they should seek medical advice. </p>
<p> If stomach pain after eating continues for a long time, and lifestyle and diet changes do not work, people are advised to see a doctor. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599836" filename="323907" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/323907">
<p> What is a pescatarian diet? </p>
<p> In the pescatarian diet, a person’s main source of animal protein comes from fish and other seafood, such as shrimp. </p>
<p> Eating a diet consisting mainly of plant-based foods has a variety of health benefits, which the addition of fish and fish products may enhance. </p>
<p> However, some types of fish may absorb mercury from their environment, so certain people may need to limit their intake. </p>
<p> In this article, we look at the potential health benefits of a pescatarian diet and what people can eat on this kind of diet. </p>
<p> The pescatarian diet has many health benefits. Below, we cover some of these benefits. </p>
<p> Heart health </p>
<p> Eating fish, especially fatty fish, provides increased long-chain omega-3 fatty acid intake. An omega-3 fatty acid is an unsaturated fat that can be beneficial to people, and some omega-3s are integral for healthy living. </p>
<p> People who eat fish have lower blood pressure, a lower risk of abnormal heart rhythms, and fewer fatal heart attacks than those who do not include fish in their diet. </p>
<p> Apart from fish, the pescatarian diet consists mainly of plant foods. According to one 2017 analysis, people who have a diet high in vegetables and other plant foods have a reduced risk of coronary heart disease. </p>
<p> The study authors say that the heart health benefits of a plant-based diet include improved blood lipids and lower blood pressure. </p>
<p> The same research concludes that a vegetarian diet could reverse atherosclerotic plaques when combined with exercise and stress management. </p>
<p> Atherosclerosis occurs when plaque builds up in the arteries. This causes the arteries to harden, narrow, and restrict the blood flow. </p>
<p> Cancer </p>
<p> A pescatarian diet may also protect people against colorectal cancers, or cancers that affect the colon and rectum. </p>
<p> According to a 2015 study, colorectal cancers are the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States. </p>
<p> The study used data from a cohort of over 77,650 people and found that the pescatarian diet had a strong protective effect against colorectal cancers. </p>
<p> Diabetes and inflammation </p>
<p> There is also evidence that omega-3s present in fatty fish may reduce inflammation, though this evidence comes from trials of supplements. </p>
<p> Plant-based diets are high in anti-inflammatory and antioxidant agents, such as flavonoids. These are natural compounds present in plants. Flavonoids have a range of anti-inflammatory and antidiabetic properties. </p>
<p> A 2016 study, again looking at different dietary patterns among more than 77,000 people in the U.S., found that people following a pescatarian diet had the highest flavonoid intake of all those taking part. </p>
<p> Some people choose vegetarian diets because they disagree with factory farming practices or killing animals for food. </p>
<p> For people concerned about animal welfare, the pescatarian diet may be a little more suitable. This is because some scientists argue that fish cannot feel pain. A 2015 study concluded that although fish can experience psychological stress, they lack the neural network necessary to experience pain. </p>
<p> The pescatarian diet may also appeal to those who want to eat foods from what they perceive to be sustainable farming practices. </p>
<p> Is a pescatarian diet sustainable? </p>
<p> The pescatarian diet is more sustainable than factory farming of mammals or birds, but it does have some environmental issues. </p>
<p> Some people believe that the farming of pigs and ruminants, such as cattle, sheep, and goats, can harm the environment. Both groups emit greenhouse gases, with ruminants producing methane gas and pigs producing ammonia. </p>
<p> On a global scale, these gases contribute to global warming. Also, large-scale deforestation for grazing and agriculture makes the greenhouse gas issue worse. </p>
<p> Although fish do not produce greenhouse gases, fishing and fisheries represent a challenge to water ecosystems. </p>
<p> For example, eating wild line-caught fish is not necessarily better for the environment than eating farmed fish, and the trawlers used to catch trawler-caught fish can affect ocean ecosystems in many ways. </p>
<p> Some people see farming fish as a solution to over-fishing and depleted fish stocks, and the practice has grown rapidly over the past few years. </p>
<p> However, in certain circumstances, fish farming can: </p>
<p> introduce invasive species </p>
<p> use wild fish for feed </p>
<p> cause overcrowding </p>
<p> The pescatarian diet may also be expensive or difficult to maintain when people live some distance from coastlines or fresh waterways. Some people may also find it hard to access sustainably sourced tinned fish. </p>
<p> Listed below are some suggestions for sources of fish that a person on a pescatarian diet can eat: </p>
<p> canned tuna </p>
<p> fish sticks </p>
<p> pseudo grains, such as quinoa and buckwheat, which are gluten-free </p>
<p> legumes, including kidney beans, pinto beans, and peas </p>
<p> legume products, including tofu and hummus </p>
<p> nuts and nut butters </p>
<p> seeds, such as flaxseeds, hemp seeds, and chia </p>
<p> eggs and dairy, if lacto-ovo-vegetarian </p>
<p> If a person follows a strict pescatarian diet and avoids consuming eggs and dairy, they might need to check their calcium intake and consider taking supplements. </p>
<p> Here, we give examples of recipes for meals that a person might consider when choosing a pescatarian diet: </p>
<p> Sardines are an excellent source of omega-3s. Using spinach to make a pesto spread on the crostini provides a source of vitamin C and vitamin A. The vitamin C helps increase the amount of iron a person absorbs. </p>
<p> This recipe uses canned sardines, but it is also possible to use fresh sardines or anchovies. Starting the day with protein increases the feeling of fullness, and the pesto adds healthful greens that are a source of iron. </p>
<p> Tahini is good source of plant protein and omega-3s. Chickpeas are also a good source of plant protein and fiber. Add a healthful Mediterranean salad to this recipe to create a filling lunch. </p>
<p> Strong-flavored fish go very well with citrus fruits such as grapefruit. The addition of grapefruit to this recipe also adds vitamin C and fiber, and it counts toward the 2 servings of fruit that a person should eat per day. </p>
<p> Heavy metal and pollutants in marine fish is a global issue. With 92 percent of fish consumed by humans being marine fish, mostly from coastal fisheries, there is a risk of contamination. </p>
<p> Mercury is present in the atmosphere and bodies of water and, because of this, nearly all fish may be a source of mercury. </p>
<p> For most people, the mercury present in fish is not a risk, explain the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). </p>
<p> However, they advise women considering becoming pregnant, women who are pregnant, nursing mothers, and young children not to eat specific fish. </p>
<p> A pescatarian diet may be healthful and carries health benefits, as long as people avoid fish with high levels of mercury. However, this diet may not be as sustainable as some people think. </p>
<p> Plant-based diets can help a person maintain a healthy weight, and they also may help with weight loss when necessary. A pescatarian diet may also be more healthful than some diets that rely on calorie deficits to reduce weight. </p>
<p> People may find that canned tuna and sardines, as well as smoked fish, are the easiest foods to obtain and eat. These are full-flavored options, but frozen white fish and fish sticks are more delicately flavored options. </p>
<p> Where possible, people may wish to try to buy fresh fish from sustainable sources. A useful website that can help is Seafood Watch. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599534" filename="325319" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/325319">
<p> The health effects of eating maggots </p>
<p> Medically reviewed by Elaine K. Luo, M.D. — Written by Charlotte Lillis on May 29, 2019 </p>
<p> A person may accidentally ingest maggots if they eat spoiled food that has become contaminated with fly larvae. Accidentally eating maggots is generally not a cause for concern, but it can sometimes lead to health complications, such as bacterial poisoning. </p>
<p> A maggot is the larva of the common housefly. Maggots are around 3–12 millimeters in length, have no legs, and are white or cream. </p>
<p> An adult female housefly can lay up to 130 eggs at a time, and each one of these will develop into a single larva. Flies lay their eggs in decaying organic matter, such as spoiled food and animal waste, which serves as food for the developing larvae. </p>
<p> In this article, we explore some of the potential health effects of eating maggots and explain what to do and when to see a doctor after accidentally ingesting them. We also discuss whether people eat maggots intentionally and if it is safe to do so. </p>
<p> Flies can visit multiple food sources throughout the day, and they may carry harmful bacteria that they have picked up from human or animal waste. They can transmit these bacteria to foods that people eat. </p>
<p> Larvae that develop in the contaminated food can ingest these bacteria. People who eat this contaminated food or the larvae will also get exposure to the bacteria and may become unwell. </p>
<p> Salmonella </p>
<p> Salmonella is one of the most common causes of foodborne illness. Symptoms of Salmonella infection can include: </p>
<p> Symptoms typically begin between 12 and 72 hours after a person ingests the bacteria, and the illness usually lasts for 4 to 7 days. </p>
<p> People with Salmonella poisoning often get better without treatment. However, frequent vomiting and diarrhea can lead to severe dehydration and, sometimes, hospitalization. It is, therefore, important for people with Salmonella poisoning to drink plenty of liquid, including clear broths and fruit juices, to replace lost fluids and electrolytes. </p>
<p> E. coli poisoning </p>
<p> There are many different strains of E. coli. Although most strains are harmless, some can cause a person to become very sick. </p>
<p> These symptoms usually develop between 1 and 10 days after ingesting the bacteria and may last for 5–7 days. </p>
<p> An E. coli infection can range in severity from very mild to severe, and it can sometimes even be life-threatening. As with Salmonella poisoning, it is essential for people to drink plenty of liquid to prevent dehydration. </p>
<p> Myiasis occurs when a person becomes infested with fly larvae. The larvae live on or inside the person and survive by feeding off their tissues. </p>
<p> Intestinal myiasis is a type of myiasis that can occur when a person ingests larvae that survive inside the gastrointestinal tract. Some people with intestinal myiasis do not experience any symptoms and may only realize that they have an infestation after noticing larvae in their stools. </p>
<p> However, symptoms of intestinal myiasis can include: </p>
<p> Myiasis is not common in the United States and mainly tends to occur in tropical and subtropical countries, including some of those in Africa and South America. However, people can get myiasis from traveling to these countries. </p>
<p> Accidentally ingesting maggots does not generally cause any lasting harm. However, if a person has ingested maggots through eating spoiled food, they may be at risk of food poisoning. Symptoms of food poisoning can range from very mild to serious, and they can sometimes last for several days. </p>
<p> People with a higher risk of developing food poisoning include: </p>
<p> young children </p>
<p> older adults </p>
<p> those with weakened immune systems, such as people living with HIV or those undergoing an organ transplant </p>
<p> It is essential for people who develop severe vomiting and diarrhea from food poisoning to drink plenty of fluid to prevent dehydration. </p>
<p> A person should see a doctor if any of the following signs and symptoms occur after ingesting maggots: </p>
<p> visible larvae in stools </p>
<p> persistent abdominal pain </p>
<p> symptoms of bacterial poisoning that worsen or do not get better </p>
<p> Many people in countries outside of Europe and North America eat insects. Scientists estimate that there are close to 2,000 species of edible insect. As well as the insects themselves, the eggs and larvae of certain species are edible. </p>
<p> Casu marzu is a Sardinian cheese that contains thousands of maggots. In the early stages of cheese production, the cheesemaker removes the outer crust, which encourages flies to enter and lay their eggs. Over several months, the larvae eat the rotting cheese. Excrement from the larvae gives the cheese its unique, pungent flavor. </p>
<p> Due to the health risks of eating live maggots, the European Food Safety Authority have banned the sale of casu marzu. However, a small number of Sardinian farmers continue to make the cheese for personal consumption. </p>
<p> Maggots are particularly high in protein and fat. As such, scientists are currently investigating the possibility of growing, harvesting, and processing black soldier fly maggots for human consumption. </p>
<p> Scientists have suggested heating, drying, and microwaving the larvae to reduce the risk of bacterial contamination. At present, however, there is no guaranteed risk-free way to consume maggots safely. </p>
<p> For most people living in milder climates, such as the U.S., accidentally ingesting maggots is unlikely to cause harm. </p>
<p> People may experience a temporary bout of food poisoning from eating either the contaminated maggots or the spoiled food containing them. However, most cases of food poisoning resolve without treatment after several days. </p>
<p> People should visit a doctor if they experience severe or concerning symptoms after accidentally ingesting maggots. </p>
<p> Medically reviewed by Elaine K. Luo, M.D. — Written by Charlotte Lillis on May 29, 2019 </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599607" filename="326873" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/326873">
<p> What causes people to poop right after eating? </p>
<p> People may sometimes feel the urge to poop immediately after eating. When this happens, the person may feel as though the food is passing straight through them. However, this is not the case. </p>
<p> In fact, it can take 1–2 days before food finishes its journey through a person’s digestive tract. Therefore, a person who poops shortly after eating is likely to be passing food that they ate a day or two earlier. </p>
<p> The most likely cause of needing to poop right after eating is the gastrocolic reflex. This reflex is a normal involuntary reaction to food entering the stomach. However, the intensity of the gastrocolic reflex can vary among individuals. </p>
<p> In this article, we outline what happens during the gastrocolic reflex and discuss the conditions that can increase its intensity. We also explain the dietary and lifestyle factors that can help reduce the urge to poop right after eating. </p>
<p> The gastrocolic reflex, or gastrocolic response, is a normal involuntary reaction to food entering the stomach. </p>
<p> When food enters this organ, the body releases a hormone that causes the colon to contract. These contractions move previously eaten food further through the digestive system, which can result in the urge to pass stool. </p>
<p> For some people, the gastrocolic reflex is mild, causing no symptoms. For others, the gastrocolic reflex is intense, and the urge to poop after eating can be particularly severe. </p>
<p> Certain health conditions can affect the gastrocolic reflex. For example, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can cause a person’s digestive tract to move food through their system at a much faster rate. </p>
<p> Other conditions that could cause a person to pass stool more quickly than average include: </p>
<p> Each of the above conditions may increase the intensity of the gastrocolic reflex, resulting in an urge to poop soon after eating. They may also give rise to additional digestive symptoms, such as: </p>
<p> Another potential cause of feeling the urge to poop is fecal incontinence. The condition may range in severity from mild to a complete loss of bowel control. </p>
<p> Fecal incontinence is relatively easy to differentiate from the effects of an intense gastrocolic response to food. Specifically, fecal incontinence can occur at any time. It does not only occur after eating. </p>
<p> A person may develop fecal incontinence for several different reasons, including: </p>
<p> People who are concerned that they may have fecal incontinence should visit their doctor for a diagnosis. A doctor can explain the many different ways to treat and manage fecal incontinence. </p>
<p> An episode of diarrhea following a meal is unlikely to relate to the person’s gastrocolic reflex. </p>
<p> Diarrhea is a common condition that typically only lasts a day or two. However, diarrhea that lasts for a week or more could indicate an underlying health issue. </p>
<p> Some common causes of persistent diarrhea include: </p>
<p> excessive consumption of artificial sweeteners and other laxatives </p>
<p> food intolerances </p>
<p> The gastrocolic reflex is a normal reaction to food entering the stomach. In most cases, feeling the urge to poop after eating does not warrant a visit to the doctor. </p>
<p> However, a person should see their doctor if they experience the following: </p>
<p> intense and frequent gastrocolic responses to food </p>
<p> diarrhea lasting longer than 2 days </p>
<p> additional gastric symptoms </p>
<p> The above symptoms could indicate a possible underlying health issue. </p>
<p> As the gastrocolic reflex is a normal bodily reaction, it does not technically require treatment. However, there are steps that people can take to help reduce the intensity of the gastrocolic reflex and the associated urge to poop. </p>
<p> Seek treatment for underlying digestive conditions </p>
<p> People should see a doctor if other gastric symptoms accompany the urge to poop after eating. </p>
<p> Depending on the duration and severity of these symptoms, a doctor may carry out tests to diagnose any underlying health conditions. </p>
<p> If a condition is present, treating it may help reduce the intensity of the gastrocolic reflex. </p>
<p> Changing the diet </p>
<p> Some foods are more likely than others to cause an intense gastrocolic response. These include: </p>
<p> fatty or greasy foods </p>
<p> dairy products </p>
<p> foods high in fiber </p>
<p> Keeping a food diary can help a person identify foods that may be intensifying their gastrocolic response. The diary should contain a record of the foods that the person eats, as well as their digestive response to the foods. </p>
<p> Once the person has identified a possible trigger food, they should temporarily avoid the food to see whether their symptoms improve. </p>
<p> Managing stress </p>
<p> For some people, stress can increase the intensity of the gastrocolic reflex. These individuals may benefit from activities that help reduce stress. Examples include exercise and meditation. </p>
<p> Passing stool immediately after a meal is usually the result of the gastrocolic reflex, which is a normal bodily reaction to food entering the stomach. </p>
<p> Almost everyone will experience the effects of the gastrocolic reflex from time to time. However, its intensity can vary from person to person. Certain lifestyle factors can help reduce the urge to poop following a meal. </p>
<p> People should see a doctor if they frequently experience diarrhea or other gastric symptoms following a meal. These symptoms could indicate an underlying health issue that requires medical attention. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599754" filename="351598-is-eating-fruit-for-breakfast-healthy" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.livestrong.com/article/351598-is-eating-fruit-for-breakfast-healthy/">
<p> Is Eating Fruit by Itself a Healthy Breakfast? </p>
<p> By Jody Braverman Updated November 27, 2018 </p>
<p> Reviewed by Sylvie Tremblay, MSc </p>
<p> ABOUT THE REVIEWER </p>
<p> Sylvie Tremblay, MSc </p>
<p> Sylvie Tremblay holds a Master of Science in molecular and cellular biology, and has years of experience as a cancer researcher and geneticist. </p>
<p> ABOUT THE AUTHOR </p>
<p> Jody Braverman is a professional writer and editor based in Atlanta, GA. She received a Bachelor of Arts in English from the University of Maryland, and she is a certified personal trainer, fitness nutrition specialist, and yoga teacher. She has written for various online and print publications, including Livestrong.com, SFGate, Healthfully, and Chron.com. Visit the writer at www.JodyBraverman.com. </p>
<p> When you're looking to upgrade your diet, breakfast is a good place to start. Many typical breakfast foods — pancakes, muffins, waffles and bacon — are high in fat, sugar and simple carbs that give you an immediate rush of energy but leave you feeling flat by mid-morning. Fruit, on the other hand, is a rich source of carbohydrates, fiber, vitamins and minerals that fill you up and give you energy. Pair fruit with a source of lean protein for a day that's off to a great start. </p>
<p> Fruit in the Morning </p>
<p> The secret to a satisfying breakfast that ticks all the nutritional boxes and keeps you going until lunch is choosing a combination of foods that provide: </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Complex carbohydrates, which provide long-lasting energy as well as fiber to fill you up </p>
<p> Fruit is a healthy way to get complex carbs. Although fruits are rich in naturally occurring sugars, they're considered complex carbs — not simple carbs — because they contain dietary fiber. Fiber is the parts of plants that pass through your system mostly undigested. Fiber adds bulk to foods and slows digestion and absorption of the fruit sugars to provide long-lasting energy. </p>
<p> Nutrition of Various Fruits </p>
<p> Eating fruit will help you meet your daily nutrition goals. Along with dietary fiber, fruit is also a rich source of vitamins A and C and the mineral potassium. Vitamin C is important for the health of your immune system and the growth and repair of cells; vitamin A boosts skin and eye health and fights infection; and potassium helps control blood pressure. </p>
<p> According to the Institute of Medicine, men need 38 grams of fiber and women need 25 grams of fiber each day. One cup of fresh blueberries contains only 84 calories and 3.6 grams of fiber — 9 to 15 percent of your daily fiber needs. One medium apple with skin contains even more fiber — 4.4 grams — and one medium banana provides 3.1 grams. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> The recommended daily intake of vitamin C is 90 mg for men and 75 mg for women. One cup of blueberries provides 14.4 mg; one medium apple has 8.4 mg; and one medium banana contains 10.3 mg. You'll get between 9 and 19 percent of your daily vitamin C depending on the fruit you choose and whether you're male or female. </p>
<p> For vitamin A, the recommendation is 700 mcg for women and 900 mcg for men. A cup of blueberries provides 80 mcg; a medium apple offers 98 mg; and a medium banana contains 76 mcg. </p>
<p> All adults need 4,700 mg of potassium each day. Bananas are one of the best sources of potassium, and one medium banana provides almost 10 percent of the daily requirement. A medium apple contains 195 mg, and a cup of blueberries offers 114 mg. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> A Low-Calorie Addition </p>
<p> Many fruits are low in calories compared to the volume of food they provide. Strawberries, grapefruit, peaches, papaya and cantaloupe all provide fewer than 60 calories per serving. You can indulge in these sweet treats each morning without going over your breakfast calorie budget. </p>
<p> Other fruits are higher in calories, which is good to know if you're watching your weight. Mangos, grapes, cherries and bananas have more calories and sugar and should be eaten in moderation. A whole mango, for example, provides 45 grams of sugar. Although it's natural sugar, it still adds to your total calorie intake for the day. </p>
<p> The Perfect Pairing </p>
<p> Some delicious fruit combinations include strawberries, raspberries and blueberries; grapefruit, kiwi and strawberry; and blackberries, papaya and cantaloupe. Slice up your favorites and serve them topped with plain Greek yogurt packed with protein, a piece of whole-grain toast with unsweetened nut butter or an egg any way you like it. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599833" filename="355883-if-i-eat-only-chicken-vegetable-fruits-will-i-lose-weight" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.livestrong.com/article/355883-if-i-eat-only-chicken-vegetable-fruits-will-i-lose-weight/">
<p> If I Eat Only Chicken, Vegetables & Fruits, Will I Lose Weight? </p>
<p> By Andrea Boldt Updated July 24, 2019 </p>
<p> Reviewed by Jill Corleone, RDN, LD </p>
<p> ABOUT THE REVIEWER </p>
<p> Jill Corleone, RDN, LD </p>
<p> Jill Corleone is a registered dietitian with more than 20 years of experience. She graduated with honors from New York University and completed her clinical internship at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. </p>
<p> ABOUT THE AUTHOR </p>
<p> Andrea Boldt has been in the fitness industry for more than 20 years. A personal trainer, run coach, group fitness instructor and master yoga teacher, she also holds certifications in holistic and fitness nutrition. </p>
<p> You need to consume less calories if you want to lose weight. </p>
<p> Image Credit: from_my_point_of_view/iStock/GettyImages </p>
<p> Losing weight requires you to eat fewer calories than you burn. Choosing healthy foods and moderate portions keeps your calorie intake in check. Chicken, fruits and vegetables are healthy, as long as they're not fried or drenched in a creamy or sugary sauce. If you stick to these foods and control your portions, you may lose weight. </p>
<p> However, you may may miss out on some valuable nutrients offered by dairy, whole grains and healthy fats, so including a variety of foods and tracking your intake on an online calorie counter, is a better option for a healthy weight-loss plan. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Tip </p>
<p> You may lose weight eating a chicken, vegetable and fruit focused diet, but only if you're consuming fewer calories than your burn. These foods don't contain magical nutrients to melt those unwanted pounds. </p>
<p> Weight Loss 101 </p>
<p> Creating a moderate caloric deficit causes your body to use fat for energy, resulting in weight loss. The deficit occurs when you eat less and move more. When the deficit is equal to 250 to 1,000 calories daily, you lose between 1/2 pound and 2 pounds per week. </p>
<p> Figure out your daily calorie needs by using an online calculator like MyPlate, or consulting with a health care provider. This number equals the number of calories you must consume to maintain the weight you have now. You need to increase your calorie burn through exercise, reduce your daily calorie intake, or combine these two strategies to successfully drop pounds. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> An intake between 1,200 and 1,600 calories is considered low, and will most likely help you lose weight. Consuming fewer calories is not advised, as you will accelerate the loss of muscle mass, stall your metabolism and miss out on important nutrition. </p>
<p> Aim to consume 45 to 65 percent of your calories from carbohydrates, 10 to 35 percent from protein and 20 to 35 percent from fat, minimizing saturated fat as much as possible. At least 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity exercise, such as brisk walking, supports healthy weight goals. </p>
<p> Choosing Chicken for Weight Loss </p>
<p> Foods that contain lots of saturated fat, sugar and refined grains are discouraged on a weight-loss plan, because they contain excessive calories and usually don't have a lot of nutritional value. White-meat chicken, fresh vegetables and fresh fruit make sense as part of many weight-loss menus, because they're low in these diet saboteurs. However, these foods aren't free of calories. If you eat too much of any of them — or if you always choose dark-meat chicken with the skin — you could go over your calorie allotment, which would stall your weight loss efforts. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> A cup of roasted, light-meat chicken contains 214 calories, 6 grams of fat — with 2 grams of saturated fat — and 38 grams of protein. A chicken drumstick with the skin -- which is actually a smaller serving than the cup of light-meat — contains 232 calories, 12 grams of fat, with 3 grams of that as saturated fat, and 32 grams of protein. While the calorie count seems reasonable, you'll likely eat several servings per day. </p>
<p> Grilled, roasted, baked or broiled chicken breast are optimal choices. Sauteed chicken, crisped patties or fried breasts have considerably more calories and saturated fat. One fried chicken breast contains 490 calories and a chicken Parmesan entree at a restaurant offers up 614 calories — and that's without the pasta. Butter or cream sauces and barbecue-sauce calories can also add up quickly. For example, a mere tablespoon of barbecue sauce adds 30 calories and 6 grams of sugar. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Vegetables and Fruits </p>
<p> Watery, fibrous vegetables such as leafy greens, celery and cucumbers are inherently low in calories, but fruit calories can add up quickly. One serving of some fruits have almost three times the number of calories as non-starchy vegetables. A medium banana contains 105 calories, a cup of pineapple has 83 calories. Avocado is probably this highest-calorie fruit with 240 calories per cup, cubed. Although fruits add important nutrients to your diet, their calorie density may become an issue if you eat them as if they are "free" foods. Enjoy fruits as part of your weight-loss diet, just limit your servings. </p>
<p> Starchy vegetables are higher in calories than leafy greens, but they contain valuable nutrients and fiber. Consume 4 to 5 cups per week to balance your diet, advises the U.S. Department of Agriculture ChooseMyPlate.gov website. Watch your servings, though, because a large baked potato contains 290 calories and a cup of corn has 143 calories. Compare this to the 7 calories in a cup of raw spinach or the 54 calories in a cup of boiled broccoli. </p>
<p> Also consider how you dress up your vegetables. A tablespoon of butter increases your calorie intake by 100 calories and adds 11 grams of fat. Ranch dressing poured over a salad costs you 63 calories per tablespoon and 7 grams of fat. Fresh herbs, citrus juice, balsamic vinegar and small amounts of olive oil are better options. </p>
<p> Variety Is Best for Dieting </p>
<p> While you can keep calories in line by eating only fruit, veggies and chicken, no single fruit or vegetable offers all the nutrients you need, so be sure to eat a wide variety. For example, don't always stick to Romaine lettuce, tomatoes and carrots. Other options such as cooked tomatoes, dark leafy greens, orange and red vegetables, and dried beans and peas offer variety to your weekly menu. </p>
<p> Eliminating all dairy or dairy alternatives from your diet puts you at risk of being deficient in vitamin D and bone-building calcium. If you don't drink cow's milk or fortified soy, almond or coconut milk, be sure to include kale, broccoli and Chinese cabbage regularly. Fish with soft bones, such as sardines and salmon, could be a protein alternative to chicken that provides calcium and other important minerals. Fish also offers omega-3 fatty acids that you need for brain health. Other sources of omega-3 fatty acids include walnuts and flax seeds, which could embellish your salads. </p>
<p> Skipping grains — especially whole grains such as quinoa and brown rice — can also leave you without certain valuable nutrients. Although fruits and vegetables contain fiber, whole grains can helps contribute to the 25 to 38 grams you need daily for good digestive health. Grains are also an important source of zinc, iron and B vitamins. Consider including at least 1/2 to 1 cup of grains at most meals. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599646" filename="364550-why-does-my-blood-glucose-drop-after-eating" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.livestrong.com/article/364550-why-does-my-blood-glucose-drop-after-eating/">
<p> Why Does My Blood Glucose Drop After Eating? </p>
<p> ABOUT THE AUTHOR </p>
<p> A registered nurse with more than 25 years of experience in oncology, labor/delivery, neonatal intensive care, infertility and ophthalmology, Sharon Perkins has also coauthored and edited numerous health books for the Wiley "Dummies" series. Perkins also has extensive experience working in home health with medically fragile pediatric patients. </p>
<p> When you feel hungry, eating should make you feel better. But for some people, eating makes them feel worse, due to a drop in blood sugar that occurs within one to three hours after they eat certain types of meals, according to Frank Jackson, M.D. of Jackson/Siegelbaum Gastroenterology. This reaction, called reactive hypoglycemia, can cause a number of unpleasant side effects. Reactive hypoglycemia can also indicate insulin resistance, often considered a forerunner of diabetes, the National Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Disorders states. </p>
<p> Mechanism </p>
<p> Glucose is essential for energy; your body breaks down the foods you eat into glucose, which must be absorbed into the cells. When glucose enters the bloodstream, your body releases insulin to facilitate its absorption into the cells. In some people, too much insulin is released in response to glucose. The insulin removes too much glucose from the bloodstream, and blood sugar levels drop. People with insulin resistance have higher than normal amounts of circulating insulin because their cells have become resistant to the effects of insulin; it takes a larger amount of insulin to get the cells to respond and remove glucose from the bloodstream. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Glycemia Load and Glycemic Index </p>
<p> Foods that have a high glycemic index, which means that they break down more rapidly into glucose after being eaten, raise blood sugar very quickly. Generally speaking, carbohydrate foods high in refined sugars or simple sugars have a high glycemic index. The sudden influx of glucose causes the release of large amounts of insulin, which removes too much glucose and causes blood glucose to drop. Eating foods with a low glycemic index helps avoid dropping blood sugar levels after eating. Glycemic load, which considers the amount of carbohydrates in a food along with its glycemic index, determines a food's effect on your blood sugar. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> What to Eat </p>
<p> Foods high in carbohydrates have a bigger immediate impact on your blood sugar levels than proteins or fats. But not all high-carbohydrate foods have a high glycemic load. Fruits, for example, which consist of simple sugars, have a low glycemic load because they contain fewer carbohydrates than some other foods and they're also high in fiber. High fiber foods like fruits and vegetable slow food breakdown, which helps stabilize blood glucose levels. Soda, which contains a lot of carbohydrates and simple sugars, has a much higher glycemic load and can cause your blood glucose to rise quickly right after drinking. Refined grains have a higher glycemic load than whole grains. Eating protein and some fat with a meal slows food digestion, which also results in a slower rise in blood glucose. Registered dietitian Joanne Larson recommends following a diet made up of 20 percent protein, 30 percent fat and around 130 grams of carbohydrates per day if you have hypoglycemia. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Symptoms and Treatment </p>
<p> Symptoms of hypoglycemia include sweating, shakiness, weakness, lightheadedness, confusion, difficulty speaking and possibly fainting. When you first feel symptoms of hypoglycemia, eat a protein-based food such as cheese or a piece of meat along with a small amount of carbohydrate, such as a piece of fruit. Do not eat a piece of candy, as is often recommended for diabetics with hypoglycemia, Larson warns. Simple sugars will raise your blood sugar quickly, but another large insulin release could cause rebound hypoglycemia. Preventing symptoms from developing by following a diet low in refined carbohydrates helps prevent reactive hypoglycemia from developing. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599488" filename="366512-a-list-of-foods-that-you-can-eat-with-gastritis" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.livestrong.com/article/366512-a-list-of-foods-that-you-can-eat-with-gastritis/">
<p> A Gastritis Diet to Ease Your Symptoms </p>
<p> By Wyatt Myers Updated December 22, 2020 </p>
<p> Medically Reviewed by Dayle Davenport, MD </p>
<p> ABOUT THE REVIEWER </p>
<p> Dayle Davenport, MD </p>
<p> Dayle Davenport is an Associate Professor of Rush Medical College and works as an Emergency medicine physician in Chicago. She is a graduate of Harvard Medical School. </p>
<p> ABOUT THE AUTHOR </p>
<p> Wyatt Myers is a health and fitness writer in Olathe, Kansas. For over 20 years, Wyatt has contributed to dozens of books, magazines and websites, including Men’s Health, Prevention and more. </p>
<p> Eating the right foods can help you manage your gastritis symptoms. </p>
<p> Image Credit: Sinenkiy/iStock/GettyImages </p>
<p> Gastritis is the umbrella term for a number of medical conditions that all cause a common symptom: inflammation of the stomach lining. While the causes and other symptoms of gastritis can vary widely, one factor worth taking a look at is what you're eating. Yes, a gastritis diet may help. </p>
<p> It can also occur in reaction to medications like NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, like aspirin or ibuprofen) or to excessive alcohol (called reactive gastropathy), to attacks from the body's own immune system (autoimmune gastritis) or problems due to low blood flow to the stomach lining (stress gastritis). </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> "Gastritis can be either acute — it happens all of a sudden — or chronic — it happens over time," says Kellie Gragg, MPH, RDN, a dietitian/nutritionist and director of clinical services at Strata Integrated Wellness and Spa in Colorado Springs, Colorado. </p>
<p> The Mayo Clinic says gastritis symptoms and risk factors also can vary. For example, some people have no symptoms whatsoever, while others experience nausea, vomiting or burning aches or pains in the abdomen. What's most important is that you get a proper diagnosis so that you can get the right treatment. This can vary from antibiotics to kill ​H. pylori​ to medications that neutralize excess acid in your digestive system. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> How Food Can Work for You </p>
<p> Although gastritis refers to medical conditions that impact the lining of the stomach, food itself is rarely a cause, according to the NIDDK. The dietary factors that can play a role include food allergies, celiac disease, excess alcohol consumption and iron supplements — all have been linked to cases of gastritis. </p>
<p> Of note is that certain cases of gastritis can lead to nutrient deficiencies that may require special diets or supplements to remedy the situation. Working closely with your doctor and a dietitian can ensure that you get the nutrients you need. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> On the other hand, once you have gastritis, the foods you eat can play a role in lessening the severity of your gastritis symptoms, Gragg says. She recommends the following foods for help in managing gastritis, fighting inflammation and easing the discomfort along with what to avoid, which can be just as important as what you eat: </p>
<p> ​Low-fat foods.​ Keep fat intake at a healthy level by choosing lean proteins and fat-free dairy. Skip the fatty cuts of meat and foods high in saturated fat. </p>
<p> ​High-fiber foods.​ Vegetables, whole grains like barley, beans, and fruits, notably berries and apples with their skins, promote overall digestive health. </p>
<p> ​Fermented foods.​ "Fermented foods are generally recognized as crucial for contributing to healthy gut microbiota," says Gragg. Good choices include kombucha, yogurt, kimchi, miso and sauerkraut. </p>
<p> ​Non-caffeinated, non-carbonated beverages.​ Coffee, teas and soda can be irritating for people with sensitive stomachs. Remember, when all else fails, water is always an excellent choice for hydration. </p>
<p> The Mayo Clinic cautions against eating dishes that are spicy, fried or highly acidic as well as fatty as these can all aggravate your stomach. The size and frequency of your meals count, too. </p>
<p> "First of all, don't overeat," says Zachary T. Weik, MHS, PA-C, a physician assistant and assistant professor of medical science at Arcadia University in Glenside, Pennsylvania. "A fully expanded stomach will have difficulty breaking down the food in a timely manner and moving it along into the bowels." </p>
<p> "Smaller, more frequent meals would be recommended," Weik says. "Also, avoid lying down for at least 30 minutes after eating to allow gravity to work in your body's favor and avoid reflux." </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599748" filename="3-6.htm" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.biblehub.com/genesis/3-6.htm">
<p> New International Version When the woman saw that the fruit of the tree was good for food and pleasing to the eye, and also desirable for gaining wisdom, she took some and ate it. She also gave some to her husband, who was with her, and he ate it. </p>

<p> to the eyes. </p>

<p> Hosea 6:7 But they like men have transgressed the covenant: there have they dealt treacherously against me. </p>
<p> Romans 5:12-19 Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned: … </p>
<p> (6) And when the woman saw . . . she took.--Heb., And the woman saw . . . and she took, &c. In this, the original form of the narrative, we see the progress of the temptation detailed in a far more lively manner than in our version. With awakened desire the woman gazes upon the tree. The fruit appears inviting to the eye, and possibly was really good for food. The whole aspect of the tree was beautiful; and, besides, there was the promise held out to her that it possessed the mysterious faculty of developing her intellectual powers. To this combined influence of her senses without and her ambition within she was unable to offer that resistance which would have been possible only by a living faith in the spoken word of God. She eats, therefore, and gives to her husband--so called here for the first time--and he eats with her. The demeanour of Adam throughout is extraordinary. It is the woman who is tempted--not as though Adam was not present, as Milton supposes, for she has not to seek him--but he shares with her at once the gathered fruit. Rather, she is pictured to us as more quick and observant, more open to impressions, more curious and full of longings than the man, whose passive behaviour is as striking as the woman's eagerness and excitability. </p>
<p> Verse 6. - And (when) the woman saw. "An impure look, infected with the poison of concupiscence" (Calvin); cf. Joshua 7:21. That the tree was good for food. "The fruit of this tree may have been neither poisonous nor beautiful, or it may have been both; but sin has the strange power of investing the object of desire for the time being, whatever its true character, with a wonderful attraction" (Inglis). And that it (was) pleasant Literally, a desire (Psalm 10:17), a lust (Numbers 11:4). To the eyes. Ἀριστὸν τοῖς ὀφθαλμοῖς (LXX.); pulchrum oculis (Vulgate); lustye unto the eyes (Coverdale); i.e. stimulating desire through the eyes (cf. 1 John 2:16). And a tree to be desired to make (one) wise. לְהַשְׂכִּיל (from שָׂכַל - </p>
<p> When the woman הָֽאִשָּׁ֡ה (hā·’iš·šāh) Article | Noun - feminine singular Strong's 802: Woman, wife, female </p>
