<p> ^ Batten, Alicia. "Fishing Economy in the Sea of Galilee". Bible Odyssey. Retrieved 10 Jan 2016. Fishing was a fundamental part of the embedded agrarian economy of first-century Galilee. This region was ruled by Herod Antipas; a client king of the Romans. An “embedded” economy was one in which questions of production, processing, trade, and their regulation could not be separated from politics, religion, and family or village life. There was no free market that functioned independently from other dimensions of society, and little if any upward mobility. Most peasant fishing families were poor and lived at subsistence level, while a small minority of elites held the bulk of wealth and power. </p>

<doc id="file21599749" filename="animal-crossing-new-horizons-eating-fruit-guide" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/animal-crossing-new-horizons-eating-fruit-guide/">
<p> A guide to eating fruit in Animal Crossing: New Horizons </p>
<p> Animal Crossing: New Horizons has slightly changed the way we use the fruit on our islands. Originally, the ability to eat fruit was a strange, wasteful feature that didn’t do anything helpful for the player. Rather, eating fruit was just a way to throw out resources and money-makers. However, New Horizons has given eating fruit a new life and ability. </p>
<p> Eating fruit adds gameplay to an already-expanded and ever-growing game. But initially, it’s not entirely clear what eating fruit can really do, which can lead to some problems later on. Here is everything you need to know about eating fruit. </p>
<p> What does eating fruit do? </p>
<p> There are two abilities fruit grants you: Picking up trees and breaking rocks. It doesn’t matter what type of fruit you eat, and you can store the power of 10 fruits at a time. You can see how much fruit is in your system in the upper left-hand corner. A number out of 10 will appear after you’ve eaten some fruit, and each time you use one of the abilities, the number will go down. </p>
<p> With an apple, orange, peach, pear, cherry, or coconut in your virtual stomach, you can take a shovel to a tree and pick it right up. Your villager will pocket the tree and you can plant it, without the need of a shovel, in a new spot. </p>
<p> Also using your shovel, you can hit a rock. Rather than doling out money or resources like clay, stone, or iron nuggets, it’ll break. You won’t get all of the material you normally would when hitting a rock, up to eight, though. A broken rock leaves just one resource in its place. </p>
<p> Why should I eat fruit? </p>
<p> The ability to pick up trees allows you to move a tree in an awkward spot without losing it. This is especially useful when crafting your ideal island layout. I moved the most trees when I first began laying down paths. I didn’t want to lose the island greenery, especially if it was growing valuable foreign fruit. Moving it even just one space over is an easy fix. </p>
<p> You can also visit the island of a friend that has a different native fruit. Pick up the tree and leave one behind with your native fruit. Pocketing fruit trees rather than shaking them and planting the fruit in the ground means skirting the three-day waiting period before anything grows. This is also useful when gathering coconut trees from mystery islands or if you land on one of the rare spots bearing foreign fruit. </p>
<p> Breaking rocks can solve the same issue when you find they get in the way. Breaking a rock forces the rock to respawn in a different place. This is a technique a lot of players who want to create rock gardens use to move their rocks from one place to another. If you find a rock in an inconvenient spot, mine those resources or Bell bags and break it. </p>
<p> Still, it’s imperative to remember that your island will respawn only one rock each day. So, if you have more than one rock that needs to be relocated, it’s most beneficial to break only one of them per day. The new geodes will show up in a random place, so you might still have some work to do until you can achieve your preferred design. Nevertheless, as with most things in Animal Crossing, it requires some time before you can begin to see a profit. </p>
<p> How do I remove the fruit buff? </p>
<p> Maybe you accidentally ate too much fruit; it happens. Instead of forgetting and unintentionally demolishing your precious rocks, get that fruit out. The simplest thing you can do is pick up a tree and replant it. We promise you that it won’t hurt or alter the tree, whether it bears fruit or not. </p>
<p> For a more practical method, we suggest popping a squat on a toilet. Animal Crossing has always featured toilets as furniture pieces. New Horizons made them valuable. Resting on one eliminates the fruit buff and immediately flushes as you remove yourself from the porcelain throne. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599838" filename="animals-eat-fruit-79c3fe863f2be589" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.reference.com/science/animals-eat-fruit-79c3fe863f2be589">
<p> What Animals Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> By Staff WriterLast Updated March 29, 2020 </p>
<p> Follow Us: </p>
<p> Many animals feed on fruit, such as birds, fruit bats, mice, civets, deer and chimpanzees. Some animals subsist entirely on fruit while others, such as foxes, feed on a variety of foods including fruit. </p>
<p> Fruit bats live entirely on fruits, such as mangoes, bananas and avocados. They are important pollinators. As the bats sip nectar from flowers, pollen gets caught in their fur and carried to other flowers. The seeds from the fruit are distributed through the bats' excrement. Fruit bats are distinct from their insect-eating cousins. They have small ears, long noses and resemble foxes. </p>
<p> Orangutans are another mammal with a fruit-filled diet. Ninety percent of their food is fruit, coming from at least 400 different types of plants and trees. Their favorite food is a durian, a spine-covered fruit with a strong aroma. Orangutans play an important role in the life cycle of fruit by dispersing the seeds throughout their rain forest home. Many of those seeds must pass through the orangutans; digestive tracts in order to grow. </p>
<p> Many species of birds, including the American robin, blue jay, scarlet tanager, bluebird, purple finch and house wren eat fruit when available, particularly berries, such as cherries, raspberries, blueberries and elderberries. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599578" filename="ar-BB1ed6bq" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.msn.com/en-us/health/nutrition/the-one-food-to-eat-after-getting-the-covid-19-vaccine-says-science/ar-BB1ed6bq">
<p> You are using an older browser version. Please use a supported version for the best MSN experience. </p>
<p> The One Food to Eat After Getting the COVID-19 Vaccine, Says Science </p>
<p> Feeling under the weather after getting the COVID-19 vaccine? When we're not feeling 100%, it's common to turn to the foods that always comfort us and make us feel better—like a mug of steaming tea or a bowl of chicken soup. If this is something you're craving, take this as your sign to reach for those things. Why? Because chicken soup is the best food to eat after getting the vaccine. </p>
<p> Here's why chicken soup truly is for the soul, and for even more healthy eating tips, be sure to check out our list of The 7 Healthiest Foods to Eat Right Now. </p>
<p> Your body will be in a state of inflammation post-vaccine. </p>
<p> According to the CDC, you may experience some adverse side effects of taking the COVID-19 vaccine. While this doesn't happen for everyone, some vaccine patients have mentioned experiencing side effects for a few hours after taking the vaccine, including fevers, chills, tiredness, and a headache. </p>
<p> In a Q&A with Cleveland Clinic, Thaddeus Stappenbeck, MD, PhD, says that these side effects are coming from inflammation that is happening within your body. Your body is reacting to the spike protein and is working to fight off the simulated infection. Sore arms, fevers, muscle aches are all common when your immune system is fighting something. </p>
<p> This is why eating immune-boosting foods is important for your recovery, particularly foods with a high-water content. The CDC also states that drinking plenty of fluids is important for recovery after getting the COVID-19 vaccine. This means any anti-inflammatory foods that can also hydrate your body will help immensely with your recovery—especially these 8 Best Foods To Eat Before and After Getting the COVID Vaccine. </p>
<p> Video: What Should You Eat Before and After the COVID Vaccine? Here’s What a Nutritionist Says (Health.com) </p>
<p> What Should You Eat Before and After the COVID Vaccine? Here’s What a Nutritionist Says </p>
<p> Soup is a great anti-inflammatory food to turn to. </p>
<p> In particular, broth-based soup—like chicken noodle, minestrone, or a simple bone broth—is a great food to slurp on if you're feeling under the weather. Plus, if your soup is full of good immune-boosting foods (like kale, beans, lentils, potato, broccoli) you're giving your immune system even more of a boost with that meal. </p>
<p> This brings us back to the trusty ol' chicken soup. If you have to pick any soup to have after getting the COVID-19 vaccine, chicken soup would be your best bet. According to CHEST Journal, chicken soup actually does have "beneficial medicinal activity" when consumed and has a "mild anti-inflammatory effect" on the body. While it's unclear which particular element of the soup is helpful, The UCLA Center for East-West Medicine says that including all of those classic elements (chicken, onions, carrots, celery, parsley, salt, and pepper) have been proven to help fight inflammatory infection. </p>
<p> If you don't necessarily feel like eating anything, sipping on a cup of bone broth can also be a great substitute. According to Healthline, bone broth contains an amino acid called glycine and arginine, which have strong anti-inflammatory effects. </p>
<p> So whether it be a steaming cup of bone broth or a hearty bowl of chicken noodle soup, be sure to treat yourself to this best food to eat after getting the vaccine. Especially if you're making our Cozy Crock-Pot Chicken Noodle Soup Recipe. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599767" filename="are-humans-designed-to-eat-meat" parent_folder="web2" url="https://plantbasednews.org/opinion/are-humans-designed-to-eat-meat/">
<p> Be the first to know! </p>
<p> Receive all the best news updates, giveaways, and much, much more. </p>
<p> Join us </p>
<p> By clicking submit, you agree to share your email address with the Plant Based News to receive marketing and updates. Use the unsubscribe link in those e-mails to opt-out at any time. </p>
<p> Success! You're on the list. </p>
<p> Whoops! There was an error and we couldn't process your subscription. Please reload the page and try again. </p>
<p> Thank you, your sign up request was successful! Please check your e-mail inbox to confirm. </p>
<p> Thank you, your sign up request was successful! Please check your e-mail inbox to confirm. </p>
<p> Are Humans ‘Designed’ To Eat Meat? </p>
<p> We have short, soft fingernails, not claws and our canine teeth are small and blunt and have no chance of penetrating a hide </p>
<p> Share: </p>
<p> Print </p>
<p> Reading Time: 4 minutes </p>
<p> Do you think that our little canine teeth show that we are natural meat-eaters? If so, you are not alone, but you are wrong. </p>
<p> Consider how carnivores eat, you might not (literally) have the stomach for it; could you snatch up a rabbit and tear into the flesh with your bare teeth like a lion does? </p>
<p> Their canines reach up to seven centimeters in length and can rip just about anything apart, yours can’t. </p>
<p> Comparing carnivores and herbivores </p>
<p> Carnivores have sharp teeth and claws that help them to rip their prey apart, tearing off chunks of raw meat and ‘wolfing’ them down without the aid of a knife and fork. Their acidic stomachs help to digest flesh quickly and their short intestines allow the rapid expulsion of rotting meat remains. </p>
<p> The diet of wolves, for example, consists mainly of meat from large prey such as elks, with nutrient-dense organs eaten first followed by muscle tissue. When carnivores eat saturated fat from meat it does them no harm, we, on the other hand, respond very differently – saturated fat clogs up our arteries increasing our risk of heart disease and stroke. </p>
<p> Herbivores, such as rabbits, horses and sheep, chew from side-to-side and have longer intestines to absorb nutrients. Their saliva (and ours) contains amylase, an enzyme that helps digest starchy carbohydrates found in bread, rice and other whole grains. </p>
<p> Carnivores don’t spend as much time chewing nor do they consume many carbohydrates, so there is no need for amylase in their saliva. Their strong jaws can only open and shut and are incapable of moving from side to side as ours do. </p>
<p> Human beings have characteristics of herbivores </p>
<p> We have short, soft fingernails, not claws and our canine teeth are small and blunt and have no chance of penetrating a hide. When asked if humans are herbivores, carnivores or omnivores, Dr William C. Roberts, Editor-in-Chief, of The American Journal of Cardiology said: “Although most of us conduct our lives as omnivores in that we eat flesh as well as vegetables and fruits, human beings have characteristics of herbivores, not carnivores.” </p>
<p> The Palaeolithic, or hunter-gatherer, diet as a model for modern human nutrition was first proposed in the 1980s by US anthropologists Boyd Eaton and Melvin Konner. It assumed our ancestors ate mostly lean meat and fish, with some fruit and vegetables, but no dairy, grains or pulses – a diet high in protein and low in carbs. Paleo promoters reckon the mismatch between this diet and contemporary Western diets is responsible for the current high levels of obesity, diabetes and heart disease. </p>
<p> The evidence </p>
<p> The evidence shows something different. Charred fragments found in 170,000-year-old ashes in a cave in southern Africa suggest the real Paleo diet included lots of roasted vegetables rich in carbohydrates, similar to modern potatoes. </p>
<p> At a Stone Age site in Israel, more than 9,000 remains of edible plants provided more compelling evidence that our ancient ancestors enjoyed a varied, plant-based diet, including root vegetables, leafy veg, celery, figs, nuts, seeds and chenopodium seeds (similar to quinoa). </p>
<p> Writing about our ancient ancestors in Horizon, the EU Research and Innovation magazine, Dr Amanda Henry, Associate Professor at the Faculty of Archaeology at Leiden University in the Netherlands, said: “Plants were the staples. They were the foods that formed the basis of our calories in most environments.” </p>
<p> The trend continues throughout our history, with geochemical analysis of grains and pulses from Neolithic sites confirming that early farmers also relied much more heavily on plant protein than previously thought. So, only in recent times, it seems, did we switch to relying so heavily on animal protein. </p>
<p> A flawed notion </p>
<p> The notion that we are designed to eat meat has many other flaws. The average life expectancy of our ancient ancestors was around 30 years, so even if they did live on a diet of meat and more meat (they didn’t), they simply wouldn’t have lived long enough to develop heart disease. </p>
<p> Paleo pundits assume that our biology has not changed from the Palaeolithic era that began over three million years ago but genetic evidence doesn’t agree and shows that our bodies have adapted over time to suit a plant-based diet – and that includes producing more amylase in our saliva. Domesticated dogs produce much more amylase than wolves from whom they evolved – not in their saliva but from their pancreases – allowing them, too, to thrive on starch-rich diets. </p>
<p> Adapted to plant foods </p>
<p> Another adaptation that points to a plant-based diet is our ability to build long-chain fatty acids, important for brain development and cognitive function. </p>
<p> Neolithic farmers probably ate less of these than their predecessors and evidence shows how we developed enzymes to build these long-chain fats from the short ones found widely in nuts, seeds and their oils. </p>
<p> Plant foods fuelled our evolution </p>
<p> Despite the evidence that plant foods fuelled our evolution and that we are more suited to a plant-based diet, the meaty myths persist, including the notion that meat made us smart. </p>
<p> The ‘expensive-tissue hypothesis’, proposed in the 1990’s by British scientists Leslie Aiello and Peter Wheeler, states that the high energy requirement of our relatively large brains is offset by a corresponding reduction in our gut size. The theory is that eating meat enabled us to reduce the size of our gut, freeing up energy for the brain. </p>
<p> But it’s not as simple as that. Researchers say that the discovery of fire and cooking improved the quality of our diet by making food easier to digest. We also saved energy by walking upright, by growing more slowly and reproducing later and it was these factors that fuelled the growth in our brain size. </p>
<p> Meat and illness </p>
<p> Far from tearing animals apart with our teeth, we aren’t even suited to eating raw meat or cooked meat, even at moderate levels, as it is linked to a wide range of health problems, including obesity, heart disease, diabetes and cancer – in fact, all the big killer diseases. </p>
<p> The typical Western diet, packed with meat, dairy and processed food, is linked to a wide range of illnesses and diseases but a Paleo diet is not the answer. All major health bodies recommend reducing meat consumption, not only for your own health but for the planet too, because animal agriculture is having a devastating effect on the environment. </p>
<p> A varied vegan diet can meet all your nutritional needs and is the best diet for animals and the planet – and we are designed for it. </p>
<p> You can find out more about vegan diets on Viva!’s website here </p>
<p> Dr. Justine Butler of Viva! </p>
<p> Dr. Butler graduated from Bristol University with a PhD in molecular biology and a BSc First Class (hons) in Biochemistry from UWE before joining Viva! in 2005. She currently researches, writes and campaigns for Viva!Health. More by Dr. Justine Butler of Viva! </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599775" filename="are-humans-designed-to-eat-meat" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.veganfoodandliving.com/features/are-humans-designed-to-eat-meat/">
<p> SIGN UP TO OUR NEWSLETTER FOR EXCLUSIVE FEATURES, RECIPES AND COMPETITIONS </p>
<p> JOIN OUR COMMUNITY Join Vegan Food & Living and you will receive the magazine direct to your door every month as well as an amazing bundle of benefits </p>
<p> Are humans designed to eat meat? </p>
<p> Our evolutionary history and ancient ancestors reveal all, explains Dr Justine Butler, Senior Researcher for Viva! Health... </p>
<p> Herbivores, such as rabbits, horses and sheep, chew from side-to-side and have longer intestines to absorb nutrients. </p>
<p> Their saliva (and ours) contains amylase, an enzyme that helps digest starchy carbohydrates found in bread, rice and other wholegrains. Carnivores don’t spend as much time chewing, nor do they consume many carbohydrates, so there is no need for amylase in their saliva. </p>
<p> Their jaws can only open and shut and are incapable of moving from side to side as ours do. </p>
<p> We have short, soft fingernails, not claws, and our canine teeth are small and blunt and have no chance of penetrating a hide. </p>
<p> Asked if humans are herbivores, carnivores or omnivores, Dr William C. Roberts, Editor-in-Chief, of The American Journal of Cardiology said: “Although most of us conduct our lives as omnivores in that we eat flesh as well as vegetables and fruits, human beings have characteristics of herbivores, not carnivores”. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Do you think that our little canine teeth show that we are natural meat-eaters? You’re not alone, but you are wrong. </p>
<p> Think how carnivores eat – you might not (literally) have the stomach for it. Could you snatch up a rabbit and tear into its flesh with your bare teeth like a lion does? </p>
<p> Their canines reach up to 7cm (3in) in length and can rip just about anything apart, yours can’t! </p>
<p> Carnivores have sharp teeth and claws that help them to rip their prey apart, tearing off chunks of raw meat and ‘wolfing’ them down without the aid of a knife and fork! </p>
<p> Their acidic stomachs help to digest flesh quickly, and their short intestines allow the rapid expulsion of rotting meat remains. </p>
<p> The diet of wolves, for example, consists mainly of meat from large prey such as elks, with nutrient-dense organs eaten first, followed by muscle tissue. </p>
<p> When carnivores eat saturated fat from meat it does them no harm, we on the other hand respond very differently – saturated fat clogs up our arteries, increasing our risk of heart disease and stroke. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> CONTINUE </p>
<p> Paleo misconceptions </p>
<p> The palaeolithic, or hunter-gatherer, diet as a model for modern human nutrition was first proposed in the 1980s by US anthropologists Boyd Eaton and Melvin Konner. </p>
<p> It assumed our ancestors ate mostly lean meat and fish, with some fruit and vegetables, but no dairy, grains or pulses – a diet high in protein and low in carbs. </p>
<p> Paleo promoters think the mismatch between this diet and modern Western diets is responsible for the current high levels of obesity, diabetes and heart disease. </p>
<p> The evidence shows something different. Charred fragments found in 170,000-year-old ashes in a cave in southern Africa suggest the real paleo diet included lots of roasted vegetables rich in carbohydrates, similar to modern potatoes. </p>
<p> At a stone age site in Israel, more than 9,000 remains of edible plants provided more compelling evidence that our ancient ancestors enjoyed a varied plant-based diet, including root vegetables, leafy veg, celery, figs, nuts, seeds and chenopodium seeds (similar to quinoa). </p>
<p> Writing about our ancient ancestors in Horizon, the EU Research and Innovation magazine, Dr Amanda Henry, Associate Professor at the Faculty of Archaeology at Leiden University in the Netherlands, said: “Plants were the staples. They were the foods that formed the basis of our calories in most environments”. </p>
<p> The trend continues throughout our history, with geochemical analysis of grains and pulses from neolithic sites confirming that early farmers relied much more heavily on plant protein than previously thought. So, only in recent times, it seems, did we switch to relying so heavily on animal protein. </p>
<p> It’s a dogs life </p>
<p> The notion that we are designed to eat meat has many flaws. The average life expectancy of our ancient ancestors was about 30 years, so even if they did live on a diet of meat and more meat (they didn’t), they wouldn’t have lived long enough to develop heart disease. </p>
<p> Paleo pundits assume that our biology hasn’t changed from the palaeolithic era that began over three million years ago, but genetic evidence doesn’t agree and shows that our bodies have adapted over time to suit a plant-based diet – and that includes producing more amylase in our saliva. </p>
<p> Domesticated dogs produce much more amylase than wolves from whom they evolved – not in their saliva, but from their pancreas – allowing them, too, to thrive on starch-rich diets. </p>
<p> Another adaptation that points to a plant-based diet is our ability to build long-chain fatty acids, important for brain development and cognitive function. </p>
<p> Neolithic farmers probably ate less of these than their predecessors and evidence shows how we developed enzymes to build these long-chain fats from the short ones found widely in nuts, seeds and their oils. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Brain size </p>
<p> Despite the evidence that plants fuelled our evolution and that we are more suited to a plant-based diet, the meaty myths persist, including the notion that meat made us smart. </p>
<p> The ‘expensive-tissue hypothesis’, proposed in the 1990s by Leslie Aiello and Peter Wheeler, states that the high energy requirement of our relatively large brains is offset by a corresponding reduction in our gut size. </p>
<p> The theory is that eating meat enabled us to reduce our gut size, freeing up energy for the brain. But it’s not that simple. Researchers say that the discovery of fire and cooking improved the quality of our diet by making food health easier to digest. </p>
<p> We also saved energy by walking upright, by growing more reducing slowly and reproducing later and it was these factors that fuelled the growth in our brain size. </p>
<p> Far from tearing animals apart with our teeth, we aren’t even suited to eating raw or cooked meat, even at moderate levels, as it is linked to a wide range of health problems, including obesity, heart disease, diabetes and cancer – all the big killer diseases. </p>
<p> The typical Western diet, packed with meat, dairy and processed food, is linked to many illnesses and diseases, but a paleo diet isn’t the answer. </p>
<p> All major health bodies recommend reducing meat consumption, not only for your own health, but for the planet too, because animal agriculture is having a devastating effect on the environment. </p>
<p> A varied vegan diet can meet all your nutritional needs and is the best diet for animals and the planet – and we are designed for it! </p>
<p> Viva! Health is a part of the charity Viva!, Europe’s largest vegan campaign group. They monitor scientific research linking diet to health and provide accurate information on which you can make informed choices about the food you eat. www.vivahealth.org.uk </p>

</doc>
<doc id="file21599791" filename="article533702" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/health-and-fitness/ask-a-health-expert/i-cant-eat-fish---is-there-a-way-to-still-get-its-nutritional-benefits/article533702/">
<p> I can't eat fish - is there a way to still get its nutritional benefits? </p>
<p> This article was published more than 9 years ago. Some information in it may no longer be current. </p>
<p> I know that eating fish a few times a week is really healthy/nourishing for one's diet, however, I cannot eat fish as I'm allergic to all types. A) What nourishment is contained in fish? B) What can one eat in their diet to get the same nourishment? </p>
<p> The answer </p>
<p> Story continues below advertisement </p>
<p> You're right, fish is very nutritious. It's an excellent source of protein that's low in saturated fat. It also contains nutrients that may benefit the brain such as iron, vitamin E, selenium. But most of the positive attention that's been given to fish has to do with its omega-3 fat content. </p>
<p> Cold water fish like salmon, trout, sardines, mackerel and herring contain two omega-3 fatty acids called DHA (docosahexaenoic acid) and EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid). People with higher blood levels of these omega-3 fatty acids have a lower risk of heart disease, heart attack, coronary death and Alzheimer's disease. </p>
<p> With respect to heart health, omega-3 fats in oily fish make the blood less likely to form clots, lower blood triglyceride levels and protect against irregular heartbeats that can cause sudden cardiac death. </p>
<p> Since you are allergic to the protein in fish you can't get these two omega-3 fatty by eating fish or taking a fish oil supplement. Although fish oil supplements do not contain protein – only fish oil – most people who are allergic to fish don't take a chance by supplementing with fish oil. The same is true for foods like milk, eggs and yogurt that are fortified with DHA from fish oil. </p>
<p> There are other options for you to get omega-3 fats. DHA supplements made from plants – not fish – are available. These contain DHA derived from algae. These supplements are marketed to vegetarians but there are also suitable for people allergic to fish. I suggest asking for this product at a good quality natural food store or supplement store. </p>
<p> You'll also find an omega-3 fatty acid called alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) in certain plant foods. Good sources of ALA include flax oil, ground flaxseed, chia seeds, walnuts, canola oil and soybeans. </p>
<p> Research suggests that a regular intake of ALA helps protect from heart disease, but the data is much less compelling than the evidence for DHA and EPA. Still, since you don't eat fish, getting ALA from your diet could lower the odds of developing heart disease. </p>
<p> Story continues below advertisement </p>
<p> ALA does not have any known function in the brain however. Only a very small amount of the ALA we consume is converted to DHA in the body, an omega-3 fat that does benefit the brain. What's more, this conversion becomes even less efficient as we age. </p>
<p> ALA is considered an essential fat, meaning our bodies can't make it and it must be obtained from the diet. Adult women need 1.1 grams per day (1,100 milligrams) and men require 1.6 grams (1,600 milligrams). It's not hard to get your ALA. One teaspoon of flax oil provides 2.4 grams, a teaspoon of canola oil offers 0.4 grams, and ½ cup of soybeans delivers 0.5 grams of ALA. </p>
<p> Send dietitian Leslie Beck your questions at dietitian@globeandmail.com. She will answer select questions, which could appear in The Globe and Mail and/or on the Globe website. Your name will not be published if your question is chosen. </p>

<doc id="file21599600" filename="ate-vs-eat-which-is-correct-in-terms-of-grammar" parent_folder="web2" url="https://ell.stackexchange.com/questions/102770/ate-vs-eat-which-is-correct-in-terms-of-grammar">
<p> Stack Exchange Network </p>
<p> Stack Exchange network consists of 177 Q&A communities including Stack Overflow, the largest, most trusted online community for developers to learn, share their knowledge, and build their careers. </p>
<p> your communities </p>
<p> English Language Learners Stack Exchange is a question and answer site for speakers of other languages learning English. It only takes a minute to sign up. </p>
<p> Connect and share knowledge within a single location that is structured and easy to search. </p>
<p> I always have a problem with this word usage. When I want to ask someone if they ate or they didn't. </p>
<p> It is called "do-support"; we use the auxiliary "do" to from questions. You may like to search "do-support" on the internet. – Cardinal Sep 6 '16 at 8:24 </p>
<p> A simple rule to remember: you don't have to conjugate to eat, because you already conjugated to do. After do, you just use the bare infinitive. – stangdon Sep 6 '16 at 14:55 </p>
<p> 3 Answers 3 </p>
<p> You would never say "Did you ate?". In this specific context you would use "Did you eat?" or "Have you eaten?" </p>
<p> You can use "Ate" as a verb to simplify other sentences, for example: "I ate today" rather than "I have eaten today". </p>
<p> Ate is the preterite conjugation of eat and is used when conjugating without the verbs "do" or "have" (therefore, you do not use "ate" when asking a question, only when stating a fact). </p>
<p> Examples: </p>
<p> "I ate that." </p>
<p> "We ate your food, Blake." </p>
<p> Eat is the infinitive form and is used when conjugating alongside the verb "do", such as when giving a command or asking a question about whether an action took place. </p>
<p> Examples: </p>
<p> "Do not eat that or I'll take away your phone." </p>
<p> "Did you eat my empanadas?" </p>
<p> Eaten is the past participle and is used when conjugating alongside the verb "have", such as when asking about the current state of the subject of the sentence or stating something that is not necessarily a fact. </p>
<p> "Have you eaten today?" </p>
<p> "Have you ever eaten ravioli?" </p>
<p> "I might have eaten your leftovers." </p>
<p> As mentioned by Avery Ross, these categories can often overlap depending on the tone that you want to convey. "I ate today" and "I have eaten today" are equivalent in meaning. </p>
<p> As an aside, you may use ate when asking questions, but only when it is not preceded by the verb "to do" (example: "You ate last night?"). However, this is usually confusing unless said in response to something that suggests that the subject did eat last night, such as an empty takeout container in the living room. When asking if the subject ate after talking about something unrelated, you should use eat (example: "Did you eat last night?"). </p>
<p> Remember this rule of thumb and would never be confused in the future: " is never followed by a word in the past tense". So "Did you ate?" is wrong because "ate" is in the past tense. </p>
<p> By clicking “Accept all cookies”, you agree Stack Exchange can store cookies on your device and disclose information in accordance with our Cookie Policy. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599726" filename="axolotls-eat-fish" parent_folder="web2" url="https://axolotlnerd.com/axolotls-eat-fish/">
<p> Do Axolotls Eat Fish? </p>
<p> When you buy through my referral links, I may earn a commission. As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases. </p>
<p> Do you want to own axolotls, but you already have some fish in your tank? Or you want to add some fish next to your axolotl, and you don’t know what will happen. Will axolotl eat your fish? </p>
<p> The answer is yes, axolotls can consume fish, especially the smaller fish. In fact, many axolotl owners feed their amphibians smaller fish as a part of the diet, which goes to show that they will happily consume the fish. With larger fish species, this doesn’t usually occur, and especially if the fish has the ability to defend itself. But for smaller fish, it can happen. </p>
<p> That’s why you have to be wary if you want to keep axolotls with fish in the tank. It’s better to know which fish species will be better for axolotls and will not get eaten. That’s what we’re here for; we’ll talk about which fish species are more prone for being eaten by axolotls, and what you can do to reduce the chance. </p>
<p> Should You Feed Live Fish to Axolotls? </p>
<p> As we have already mentioned, many axolotl owners decide to feed the axolotls live fish, which the axolotls will gladly eat. In fact, axolotls are known for eating just about anything that comes in their way. So yes, they’ll eat the live fish, and you can have the fish as a part of their diet. </p>
<p> But, feeding the live fish to axolotls should be done with caution. First of all, live fish can have some parasites or diseases that can rub off on the axolotl, and can make your axolotl sick if you are not careful. That’s why the fish that you feed to axolotls should be thoroughly vetted, or you should avoid it altogether. </p>
<p> Live fish can be an important part of the axolotl’s diet. They provide several beneficial nutrients, such as proteins and fish fats that will keep the axolotl healthy. But they should be checked before you feed them. </p>
<p> For example, goldfish can carry several parasites that can threaten the life of an axolotl. The best way to feed them live fish is to breed the fish at home. If you can afford to, you should get a separate tank where you will breed the smaller fish. </p>
<p> What Fish Can Axolotls Eat? </p>
<p> Axolotls should only be fed the fish that will feed in their mouths. This includes the smaller fish that will not be too fast for the axolotls to be caught. Additionally, you can feed them the smaller fish with tweezers so that they won’t get away from the axolotls. </p>
<p> Some of the smaller fish species that can be fed to axolotls include: </p>
<p> Guppies or other subspecies of guppies, </p>
<p> Mollies, </p>
<p> Goldfish (they should be vetted so they are without parasites) </p>
<p> Other smaller and slow-moving fish. </p>
<p> We should also take a look at which fish are probably not the best for axolotls. As we know, these animals are not too fast when it comes to swimming and moving around, so it’s probably not the best idea to feed them fast-moving fish. </p>
<p> If you do so, you should consider feeding them with tweezers, or you should not feed them such fish altogether. Some of these fish species that you shouldn’t feed to axolotls include: </p>
<p> Tetras </p>
<p> Danios </p>
<p> Other schooling or fast-swimming fish. </p>
<p> Even if these fish are small enough for the axolotl to consume, they won’t be able to catch them, so they are not the best way to feed your axolotls. If you do consider live fish as a form of food, take a look at the fish above. </p>
<p> Can Axolotls Eat Fish Food? </p>
<p> Axolotls can eat fish food, especially the meat-based fish foods. These can include fish pellets or other types of food. Though, you would want to avoid feeding your axolotls plant-based foods as they are strictly carnivorous. </p>
<p> Another thing to keep in mind is that the fish food should in no way be the only source of food for your axolotls. You should try to keep as much variety as you can when it comes to the diet, and this includes various live foods, frozen foods that you can combine with the fish food. </p>
<p> As for the best type of food, you should avoid the pellets that can expand and can cause impaction for axolotls. Instead, opt for more compact fish foods that won’t expand as much when you put them in the water. </p>
<p> In order to keep a varied diet, you should try to incorporate live foods such as earth worms, trout, or salmon. Sure, these foods can cost quite a bit, but they should be added from time to time. They carry essential nutrients and minerals that are just not found in regular fish foods. Other foods that can keep a variety are crickets, grasshoppers, and bloodworms </p>
<p> Can Axolotls Eat Snails? </p>
<p> Snails can also be considered as a type of food for axolotls. Though, you will also want to be moderate with snails. If the axolotl eats too many snails, it can clog their intestines, which can lead to congestion, and even impaction. </p>
<p> Another thing to keep in mind is that you shouldn’t feed them snails with particularly hard shells. Instead, you can get smaller snail species and make sure that the shells are not too hard, or remove them first before you feed them to your axolotl. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> Keeping a variety in the axolotl’s diet is essential for keeping them healthier for a long time, and ensuring longevity. Axolotls will eat live fish or frozen fish, but they should in no way be the only or primary source of food. </p>
<p> In addition, many fish species can be bad for axolotls, because they carry parasites and diseases that can spread onto the axolotls, causing them to suffer from these illnesses. Before you feed them the fish, make sure they are vetted properly. The best way is probably to breed the fish at home and feed them to your axolotls. </p>
<p> Questions & Answers </p>
<p> My axolotls love the two tiger gouramis I have. Granted it’s a 55 gallon but nonetheless. My gouramis are always hanging around and next to my axolotls. Never once has my axolotl attacked my fish. That’s just my experience though. Good luck </p>
<p> Hey! Thanks for sharing your experience with us! I’m sure there are other special cases where axolotls will do ok with fish, but these are rare. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599704" filename="axolotls-eat-fish-food" parent_folder="web2" url="https://axolotlnerd.com/axolotls-eat-fish-food/">
<p> Can Axolotls Eat Fish Food? </p>
<p> When you buy through my referral links, I may earn a commission. As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases. </p>
<p> For many new axolotl owners comes the question of diet – what will the axolotl eat, and can I feed the fish food. This question arises due to these owners already having a fish tank with other fish. Therefore, buying the same foods for axolotls and your fish can save you money and the time for picking the food. But can axolotls eat fish food? </p>
<p> Yes, axolotls can eat fish food, but only the food you will feed to your carnivorous fish. Axolotls are purely carnivorous animals as well, so they won’t like any plant-based foods or flakes. They will eat meat-based fish pellets or just about anything you feed to your carnivorous fish – live foods, frozen foods, or pellets. </p>
<p> There are some things that you should avoid, though, and we’ll go more into detail in this article. </p>
<p> Food the Axolotls Can Eat </p>
<p> Let’s take a look at what axolotls will eat. </p>
<p> Live Insects </p>
<p> Axolotls will love to eat live insects, especially the ones that are easily available in your local pet store, or you can come up with your own solutions with live insects. Perhaps you can collect the live insects from nature, or you can start to harvest your own little pool of live insects that you’ll feed to axolotls. </p>
<p> Crickets, worms, daphnia, and anything that’s not too big for their mouths and that doesn’t have too strong of a shell. Be careful, though, if you’re collecting these live insects on your own you might want to make sure that they are not toxic or anything. </p>
<p> Frozen Foods </p>
<p> Frozen foods are perhaps one of the most popular ways of feeding axolotls; it can be a very tasty treat for them, or you can have the frozen foods as the staple of their diets. When it comes to frozen foods, there’s usually plenty of choice, and it can be bought in your local pet store as well. </p>
<p> Here, bloodworms are a very popular choice for axolotls. Most likely, these will be available in your vicinity, but you can always order them from Amazon. Bloodworms are packed with proteins and beneficial ingredients that help improve the health of an axolotl, and will enable the young axolotls to grow. </p>
<p> Another good choice is tubifex, or sludge worms, which also come readily available in many pet shops around the world. The best thing about it is that you can feed it to both your axolotl and your fish. </p>
<p> Brine Shrimp </p>
<p> Your axolotl will love brine shrimp. It’s one of the tastiest foods for fish and axolotls, and they are full of beneficial fatty acids and lipids, as well as protein. Just like other foods, these should probably be readily available near you, or you can order it online. </p>
<p> A good idea is also to hatch the brine shrimp at home and culture them on your own; it would take some time to establish an effective system, but it can save you a lot of resources on the long-term. They are also a favorite food of some of the fish. </p>
<p> Earthworms </p>
<p> Earthworms are also a popular choice among axolotl owners, however, there is some debate when it comes to this type of food. Some people swear by frozen earthworms, arguing that this type of food is the most beneficial for baby axolotls, as they contain a better array of nutrients and is easier to feed. </p>
<p> Other people argue that frozen earthworms are not the best for axolotls as they get cold and mushy, and the axolotl might not like that. However, it comes down to your personal preference and you should certainly try feeding both frozen earthworms as well as the live ones. </p>
<p> In any case, earthworms present one of the best choices for feeding axolotls because they taste great and contain essential nutrients such as protein nutrients, as well as some beneficial fats. </p>
<p> What to Feed Axolotls when Out of Food? </p>
<p> At one point in time, you might experience a food crisis, a time when you’ll have no foods to feed your axolotls. Or, you haven’t been to the pet store in a while and the foods are running out, and the store is closed for the next couple of days. What to do then? </p>
<p> Well, it turns out that there are still plenty of options, ones that might require some more effort from your part. You can buy these foods in most grocery stores or supermarkets, so there is no excuse for feeding them these foods. These are the best foods to feed to your axolotls when you run out of other foods: </p>
<p> Raw or cooked chicken meat. </p>
<p> Raw salmon. </p>
<p> Beef heart. </p>
<p> Raw or cooked beef. </p>
<p> As you can see, it’s better to buy quality foods that might cost a bit more, but it will have tremendous effects on your axolotl’s health. Note that you can feed them these foods always as a treat or a side dish. </p>
<p> What to Avoid Feeding to Axolotls? </p>
<p> There are some things to avoid from feeding to your axolotls: </p>
<p> Processed meats. These include foods such as salami, and this should be self-explanatory. These meats and foods go through a long process where they get loaded with preservatives and other chemicals that can harm your axolotls. </p>
<p> Feeder fish. Plenty axolotl owners still swear by this method, but we can tell you to avoid it, because the feeder fish can actually hurt your axolotl. That’s because feeder fish can contain diseases or parasites that can easily be transferred to your axolotl. </p>
<p> Bugs with hard exoskeleton. This one is also pretty obvious, and it’s clear that hard shells can cause axolotls digestive problems. Some axolotls will likely not even eat these. </p>
<p> Algae wafers. Not the best food for axolotls considering they are carnivorous animals. </p>
<p> Axolotls will likely not eat bread, and it can also cause digestive problems. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> To conclude, axolotls can eat fish foods, but only certain types of fish food. Herbivorous types such as flakes should be avoided, and axolotls will prefer meat-based foods instead. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599742" filename="backyard-birds-that-eat-fruit" parent_folder="web2" url="https://learnbirdwatching.com/backyard-birds-that-eat-fruit/">
<p> 21 Backyard Birds That Eat Fruit: A Comprehensive Guide </p>
<p> If you have fruit trees in your backyard, then you know that these are a great food source for birds. Fruit is rich in nutrients and energy, so it’s no wonder that many species of birds enjoy eating them. In this article, we take a look at 21 backyard birds that eat fruit, as well as their favorites. </p>
<p> American Crow </p>
<p> Crows are intelligent creatures that have been observed to communicate with one another. Scientists believe that they may also be capable of communicating the location of food sources, such as fruit trees. Crows can often be seen gathering around fruit trees in the early morning hours and late evening hours when other foods are scarce. </p>
<p> Bluebird </p>
<p> Bluebirds are very common birds in North America. They mostly feed on insects and spiders, but when the season changes from summer to fall they will start eating berries and other types of fruit. Bluebirds enjoy eating the sweet nectar from ripe fruit, as well as small insects that have been caught on the sticky surface of a flower. </p>
<p> Blue Jay </p>
<p> Select have you ever wondered if Jays eat fruit? In a recent study, scientists discovered that Blue Jay’s will consume over 30 different types of fruits. From figs to blackberries, Jays have been found to enjoy them all. However, they only consumed the ripe fruit which means that their diet is restricted in variety and high in sugar content. </p>
<p> Indigo Bunting </p>
<p> Buntings are a small bird that live in North America. They are often found in open fields, on power lines, and at feeders. Fruit is a good source of vitamins and nutrients for birds like the Indigo Bunting because it contains natural sugars which help with energy levels as well as antioxidants that keep their feathers looking nice. </p>
<p> Gray Catbird </p>
<p> Catbirds eat fruit and insects to survive. They also feed on leaves, berries, flowers, seeds and occasionally small vertebrates such as lizards or frogs. The catbird is an omnivore that consumes both animal-based food sources and plant-based food sources depending on its mood. </p>
<p> Northern Cardinal </p>
<p> The Northern Cardinal is a common sight in gardens and yards. It’s the state bird of seven states, including Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, North Carolina, Ohio, and Virginia. The Northern Cardinal is a bird that has the most variety of fruits in its diet. The range of fruit this bird eats ranges from apples to grapes and berries, and more. </p>
<p> House Finch </p>
<p> House finches are small, bright red birds that eat fruit. They can be found in North America and parts of South America. House finches eat fruit to get the nutrients they need for energy. Their diet is made up mostly of seeds, berries, fruits, and insects like ants or caterpillars. </p>
<p> Grosbeaks </p>
<p> Grosbeaks are large birds that eat mostly seeds, but they sometimes eat fruit. Grosbeaks are large birds that eat mostly seeds, but they sometimes eat fruit. They like to live in places with a lot of trees and bushes because this is where the food is for them. These types of places also provide protection from their natural predators like hawks and owls. </p>
<p> Northern Mockingbird </p>
<p> Northern Mockingbirds are an abundant species of bird that is found throughout North America. They live in a variety of habitats and feed on insects, fruit, seeds, and sometimes even small vertebrates. The Northern Mockingbird eats many different types of fruits including grapes, strawberries, blueberries, blackberries, and cherries to name a few. </p>
<p> Orioles </p>
<p> The Baltimore Oriole is a species of songbird in the Icteridae family. Baltimore Orioles are migratory birds and can be found throughout North America, Central America, South America, and into parts of Canada. They primarily eat fruit from trees or plants. They usually live in habitats such as parks, fields with scattered trees or hedges, woodland edges close to open areas like farmlands or wetlands. </p>
<p> American Robin </p>
<p> American robins are native to North America and can be found in both the eastern and western regions of the continent. They eat a variety of food, including worms, berries, grasshoppers, bugs, and caterpillars. The robin will also occasionally eat fruits like apples or cherries when they find them on the ground. </p>
<p> Sapsuckers </p>
<p> The sapsucker is a woodpecker found throughout North America. This bird has been known to enjoy the taste of fruit, and may have even become partially dependent on this food source. They enjoy many types of fruit including apples, grapes, blueberries and strawberries. They will also eat oranges and bananas if they are available. </p>
<p> Sparrows </p>
<p> House sparrows are small birds that inhabit most areas of the world. They live in all types of habitats including gardens, forests, and urban settings. In their natural habitat, they eat insects, seeds, and grains; however when given access to fruit trees house sparrows will flock there for a meal. </p>
<p> Tanagers </p>
<p> Tanagers are found in the Americas and parts of Europe. Tanagers eat fruit, insects, seeds, nuts and berries to survive. They have a diet that includes lots of berries during the summer months, but as winter approaches they switch to eating insects. </p>
<p> Thrashers </p>
<p> Do Thrasher’s eat fruit? Thrashers are small, brightly colored songbirds that live in the Americas. These birds often travel in flocks and feed on insects, seeds, and berries. They will also occasionally eat some types of fruit such as blueberries or apples. </p>
<p> Raisins </p>
<p> Towhees </p>
<p> Towhees are a small songbird that is found in North America. The range of towhees includes Canada, the United States, Mexico, and Central America. Towhees are omnivores and their diet varies by season. They may be opportunistic feeders in the winter when fruits are scarce and so may be attracted to fruiting trees during this time of year as a source of food. </p>
<p> Waxwings </p>
<p> These birds usually feed on berries and other fruit during their breeding season, but they also eat insects in winter. Waxwings can be seen at many parks and gardens in the United States during the summer months because they come to North America for food as well as to breed. </p>
<p> Vireos </p>
<p> Vireos are small birds that are found in the Americas. The most common Vireo is the Red-eyed Vireo, which can be found throughout North America and Central America. They have a wide variety of food sources including fruit, such as cherries and apples. However, they do enjoy eating insects and berries too! </p>
<p> Woodpeckers </p>
<p> Woodpeckers are birds that love to eat fruit. Woodpeckers have a strong beak, which is why they can eat so many different types of fruits. Woodpeckers live in North America and the Western Hemisphere. In their habitat, there are lots of trees with delicious fruits on them, so woodpeckers don’t need to fly very far to find food! </p>
<p> Titmice </p>
<p> Titmice are small birds that typically eat seeds, insects and fruit. In the winter time, they will often search for sunflower seeds, or insects, but in the summer, it is much easier for them to find plenty of fruit. If you have a lot of fruit trees in your yard, then they will be happy! </p>
<p> Starlings </p>
<p> Starlings are a type of bird that is native to the United States. These birds are typically found in open fields, as well as areas with some water nearby. The birds are known for their distinctive calls and beautiful patterns on their feathers. Starlings are fruit-eating birds and make up a significant part of their diet. In fact, there are many types of fruits that starlings enjoy eating! </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599551" filename="benefits-eating-fruits-before-meals-8275.html" parent_folder="web2" url="https://healthyeating.sfgate.com/benefits-eating-fruits-before-meals-8275.html">
<p> Related Articles </p>
<p> Sweet foods often appear at the end of a meal as dessert, but when the sweet treat is fresh fruit, you may decide to start with it instead. High in fiber and loaded with important micronutrients, fruit makes an excellent first course for any meal of the day. It's also a good way to fit in part of your daily recommended 1.5 to 2 cups of fruit. </p>
<p> Nutrition </p>
<p> Many fruits are filled with essential micronutrients, making them a high-value carbohydrate choice. Citrus fruits are famously high in vitamin C. Bananas contain vitamin B6 and potassium. Many orange and reddish fruits, including mango, apricot, cantaloupe and guava, are rich in vitamin A. Because different fruits have an array of nutritional benefits, look for variety in the fruits with which you start your meals. Begin breakfast with pink grapefruit packed with vitamins C and A, try a banana before lunch or dried blueberries with your starter salad at dinner. </p>
<p> Fiber </p>
<p> Most fruits contain fiber, a special kind of carbohydrate that aids in digestion and contributes to good cardiovascular health. Fiber comes in two forms, soluble and insoluble, and both forms are indigestible; this is why fiber has no net calories as part of your diet. By beginning your meal with fruit, you increase your likelihood of getting the recommended 25 to 30 grams of fiber your body needs daily. Many main dishes lack fiber, so adding it in the form of a fruit course is important. </p>
<p> Benefits for Satiety </p>
<p> Snacking on fruit before a meal might help you feel fuller after you eat. That's because you'll boost your intake of fiber, a special type of carb that doesn't supply calories but does help fill your stomach. Fiber also slows the release of sugar into your bloodstream after a meal, which means you'll have more stable sugar levels -- and avoid the hunger caused by blood sugar crashes. Many fruits, including apples, berries and pears, contain 3 to 5 grams of fiber per serving, so starting every meal with fruit can supply you with enough fiber to make a potential difference in satiety. </p>
<p> Antioxidants </p>
<p> The many vibrant colors of fruits are more than just appealing to the eye; they indicate the presence of antioxidants, naturally occurring compounds that provide protection from harmful free radicals. Chemically reactive free radicals cause damage at the cellular level, but antioxidants help shield cells from this damage, potentially reducing your risk of cancer and heart disease. Beta-carotene, lycopene and lutein are antioxidants commonly found in fruit. To get more antioxidants in your diet, choose colorful fruits such as raspberries, blackberries and plums. </p>
<p> Lauren Whitney covers science, health, fitness, fashion, food and weight loss. She has been writing professionally since 2009 and teaches hatha yoga in a home studio. Whitney holds bachelor's degrees in English and biology from the University of New Orleans. </p>
</doc>
