<p> Can Geckos Eat Fruit? [Important Considerations For Owners] </p>
<p> Fruit is a readily available food and you may consider offering your gecko some as a treat, but it’s important to ask if it’s safe for them to eat. One of the most common inquiries from gecko owners is regarding their diet. So I have decided to conduct some thorough research into the topic in which I will be sharing with you here today. </p>
<p> So, can geckos eat fruit? Some species of gecko do eat fruits as well as insects. These are known as Frugivorous species; and enjoy fruits such as grapes, apples and apricots. The most common species kept as pets include crested and day geckos. Other species, like leopard and African fat-tailed are exclusively insectivorous. If you want to feed fruit to your gecko, you must make sure that your pet is one of the species that can feed safely on it. </p>
<p> Geckos, like most lizards, are predators and enjoy a varied diet of insects. While they make excellent pets, you must know how to feed a gecko before bringing one home. </p>
<p> Let us now take a closer look at the topic so that you can get a better understanding as to how to best look after your lizard. </p>
<p> Do Geckos Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> The particular species, age, and activity level of your gecko will determine the type of diet that you should feed. </p>
<p> Most gecko species prefer a diet of juicy live insects and would never care to eat fruit; whereas other are known as frugivorous species whom love and do well when consuming fruit. </p>
<p> Below, we will take a look at some of the most common species of gecko that can and do consume fruit. </p>
<p> What Species of Gecko Can Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> The crested and day geckos are the most popular fruit consuming species, among a few others. </p>
<p> Crested geckos can eat fruit several times during the week in addition to their staple diet of insects. They like mashed fruit like bananas, peaches, and nectarines. </p>
<p> Day geckos mostly eat insects but occasionally eat tropical fruits like mango, papaya, and even fruit baby food. </p>
<p> Both species also benefit from supplemental multivitamins, vitamin D3, and calcium powder. This ensures that their diet is nutritionally complete. </p>
<p> What Species of Gecko Cannot Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> Many other commonly kept species, such as leopard geckos and African fat-tailed geckos are mostly if not entirely insectivorous. </p>
<p> This means that they eat a diet entirely of insects. If you are to own one of these species, you should not look to feed fruit to them. There is no benefit in doing so, and in some cases, can prove problematic. </p>
<p> What Fruits Can Geckos Eat? </p>
<p> Before feeding fruits to your pet gecko, make sure that you carefully prepare the fruit by mashing it up or putting it in a blender. You can also chop up fruits into small pieces. </p>
<p> Be sure to only provide a small serving at a time. This is because geckos lack the dentition and strength in their jaws to bite into solid food. </p>
<p> You’ll also want to consider the fruits that you are offering. Certain fruits have poor nutritional content and can even be imbalanced for the needs of your gecko; making them ill. So, not all fruits are safe and you should choose fruit wisely. </p>
<p> One of the main considerations as a gecko owner is the calcium to phosphorous ratio. </p>
<p> Your gecko’s food must have twice as much calcium as it does phosphorus. The calcium to phosphorus ratio is something every pet owner must be aware of as it can affect your gecko’s health. </p>
<p> Fruits like banana, nectarine, and peach have inadequate calcium to phosphorus ratio and should only be given in moderation. </p>
<p> Make sure that you wash all fruit thoroughly before offering it. You must make sure that you remove as much pesticide residue and bacteria as possible. If possible, always opt for fresh organic fruits. </p>
<p> Separate parts of the fruit that are toxic and inedible such as the pits and seeds – this includes fruits like apples, cherries, peaches, pears, and apricots. </p>
<p> For smaller geckos, consider grating fruit and cutting it into pieces no bigger than space in between your gecko’s eyes. </p>
<p> Here are some example of the best and most suitable fruit to offer your gecko. They are more balanced in terms of calcium/phosphorous and are generally easier for them to consume: </p>
<p> Berries – these include raspberries, blueberries, and blackberries. </p>
<p> Pitted fruits – these include apples, pears, and cherries. </p>
<p> Tropical fruits – these include figs, pineapples, and papayas. </p>
<p> Other fruits – these include melons, persimmons, and grapes. </p>
<p> As previously mentioned, just ensure all pits and seeds are removed and fruit is mashed up or broken down into easily consumed sized chunks. </p>
<p> What Kind Of Food Do Geckos Eat? </p>
<p> All geckos, whether they eat fruit or not, like to eat live insects. </p>
<p> Geckos don’t thrive eating prepared foods, so you must purchase or breed live insects for your gecko. </p>
<p> You must feed your gecko a wide variety of different insects, and do not rely on one type of insect as your gecko will lack all of the nutrition that they need. </p>
<p> Suitable insects to feed your gecko include: </p>
<p> Crickets – crickets are usually at the core of most pet gecko diets. They are not necessarily the healthiest, but they are some of the easiest to breed and purchase. </p>
<p> Mealworms – mealworms are often too large for many pet geckos; however, they are the staple diet for leopard geckos. </p>
<p> Flies – flies are ideal for small geckos, and fruit flies are often the easiest to locate for purchase. </p>
<p> Waxworms and Superworms – these insects are very rich and calorie dense. They should only be offered no more than once a week as a special treat. </p>
<p> Most gecko owners will find purchasing live insects troublesome, as it often requires frequent trips to the pet store. </p>
<p> Thankfully, you can get various different types of live insects on Amazon for great prices that are ideal for geckos. Here are the best ones available: </p>
<p> When and How Much Food to Feed Your Gecko </p>
<p> Because most geckos are nocturnal, it is best to feed them at night to guarantee they will be awake during meal times. </p>
<p> Young geckos must eat every day, whereas adult geckos only need to eat every other day. Geckos need to have continuous access to clean water. </p>
<p> The amount of food to offer your gecko depends on their age and activity level. </p>
<p> You must avoid putting too many insects into your gecko’s cage as they can escape, die, and will eventually rot; leading to the growth of bacteria and germs. </p>
<p> Introduce bugs one or two at a time. Feed your pet as much as they are willing to eat; they should eat with enthusiasm within the first few minutes. </p>
<p> As your gecko’s enthusiasm for food begins to dwindle, reduce the amount you give them, looking for the moment when they want to stop eating entirely. </p>
<p> Some geckos will eat from long tweezers, so this could be an option for controlling the number of insects you feed your gecko. </p>
<p> Make sure to clear away all uneaten insects and fruit after your gecko has eaten. Both insects and fruit rot, which can create an unsanitary environment for your pet. </p>
<p> Finally </p>
<p> Some frugivorous species of gecko eat fruit. The best fruits to offer include berries, stone fruits (without the pits/seeds) and some tropical fruits. However, you should be sure to offer small amounts at a time and offer them broken up for your gecko to safely and easily eat. </p>
<p> Whether a gecko is frugivorous or not, all species eat insects and need variety in their diet. </p>
<p> Sometimes geckos can stop eating, which is a worry for any owner; but thankfully there are adjustments that you can make before rushing your gecko to the vet. Usually, a gecko refusing to eat is an indicator that something else is wrong. </p>
<p> If a gecko is too cold, they might stop eating. It could be a simple matter of the heat bulb being burned out or the heat pad not working – these are issues are an easy fix through simple replacing. </p>
<p> Secondly, if a gecko’s metabolic rate drops below 70 degrees Fahrenheit, they will automatically stop eating. Geckos need their environment to be at around 80 degrees Fahrenheit to eat well and be healthy. </p>
<p> If you suspect your gecko has an illness, then you must take your gecko to the vet at the earliest opportunity. Aside from this, be sure to clean out and optimize their enclosure. </p>
<p> Many diseases can prevent your lizard from eating, and in some circumstances getting immediate medical attention is the only way to rectify this issue. </p>
<p> Nonetheless, purchase plenty of live and nutritious insects, and some of the recommended fruits (if you own a frugivorous species) and you’ll gecko should live a long and happy life in your care. </p>
<p> Related Questions </p>
<p> Can geckos eat bananas? While frugivorous spies of gecko can safely eat banana, it has a very poor calcium-to-phosphorus ratio so you should feed this fruit rarely, if at all. If you decide to do so, be sure to blend and mash it up so that you gecko can easily consume it. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599770" filename="can-giant-pandas-eat-meat" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.bestofpanda.com/can-giant-pandas-eat-meat/">
<p> Can Giant Pandas Eat Meat or Small Animals? </p>
<p> 7 </p>
<p> Shares </p>
<p> We know of pandas today because they are cute animals that eat bamboo shoots all day long. But that’s not the entire truth. Though we can see and symbolize bamboos as the primary diet source of pandas, in actuality, they have a digestive system similar to that of a wolf or wild boar. </p>
<p> But did you know if they eat anything else besides bamboo? And can giant pandas really eat meat? </p>
<p> Table of Contents </p>
<p> Do Pandas Eat Meat? </p>
<p> Yes, they do! Hopefully, you have now gotten used to the fact that our cuddly and on the verge of extinction bears are not always bamboo and leaf-eating. </p>
<p> BBC reported something very out of the ordinary earlier this decade in 2011. They had reported seeing a wild panda gnaw on the remains of a dead animal. </p>
<p> This animal was gnu, which is a type of wild cow. The scientists from the Wanglong Nature Preserve observed this behavior and recorded these wild pandas found in China’s Sichuan Province. </p>
<p> More or less, 1 percent of the panda population eats meat. The digestive system of pandas is such that they can easily digest meat. </p>
<p> They resemble the digestive system of those known to eat meat, such as wolves and other carnivores. Yet Pandas possess such a unique digestive track that effectively digest grass and other leafy green substances. </p>
<p> Looking at Pandas and their biology theoretically, pandas should only be able to eat meat. Because even after thousands and millions of years of evolution from carnivores to herbivores, their inner system fundamentally digests meat and proteins. </p>
<p> In some recent studies, researchers found that pandas were all meat-eating about 2.4 million years ago. Then they had shifted to consuming 24-86 pounds of bamboo a day. </p>
<p> I know, right! That’s a lot! But because these GIANT bears only rely on bamboos to live, it’s completely understandable. </p>
<p> What Kind of Meat Do Pandas Eat? </p>
<p> Pandas ate what any other carnivore ate – that is cows, goats, and other animals. Even now, 1 percent of the pandas’ diet allows them to eat small animals in emergency and need times. </p>
<p> Scientists have found that until 5000 years ago, pandas have a very varied diet. They ate meat yet also had a diverse vegetative diet. </p>
<p> Pandas, in short, can eat any meat they want, but that’s it. They do not want to eat meat. </p>
<p> Why Did Pandas Stop Eating Meat? </p>
<p> In 2010, a party of scientists from the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Department from the University of Michigan made some discoveries. </p>
<p> This discovery let us know about the reason behind this shift from meat to bamboo shoots. </p>
<p> While trying to stay away from technical terms, the scientists said that mutation occurred in the pandas’ T1R1 gene into a pseudogene. </p>
<p> This mutation leads to a difference in flavor pickup of pandas. Those bears cannot taste the distinct umami taste of meat and therefore did not prefer to eat them anymore and lost all interest in it. </p>
<p> Why Are Pandas Considered Carnivores? </p>
<p> In simple terms, the giant panda’s digestive system more closely resembles a carnivore. They could eat small animals as part of their calorie intake – it’s just that they prefer not to. </p>
<p> And though pandas are very similar to carnivorous animals like lions, they have a unique bacterium in their stomach called Clostridium. </p>
<p> This bacterium has digestive enzymes that break the sugars into simpler sugars. </p>
<p> What usually happens is that when a carnivorous animal eats plants, it cannot digest them properly. That’s why you’ll never see a lion eating leaves or grass. </p>
<p> On the other hand, Plants have cellulose, which gets broken down into energy by the body. This way, plants are digested by Pandas. </p>
<p> When Do pandas Eat Meat? </p>
<p> Rarely, today. But there can be times when you can see pandas getting their hands dirty and munching on some animals. </p>
<p> You will see wild pandas more prone to doing this, but you won’t see those cuddle bears holding their stomachs in pain later, either. </p>
<p> Being herbivores with a carnivorous digestive system, Pandas still require proteins. Bamboo shoots are a form of protein for Pandas. </p>
<p> But since bamboo shoots provide very little nutrition, pandas eat about 12-38 kg every day. They must do this to get a fulfilling, nutritious meal. </p>
<p> How Many Types of Pandas Are There, and How Many Eat Meat? </p>
<p> As far as humans are aware, we have three types of Pandas. </p>
<p> The Red Panda </p>
<p> The Giant Panda </p>
<p> The Regular White and Black Panda </p>
<p> Do Red Pandas Eat Meat? </p>
<p> Yes, but the latest ones are vegetarians with different diet patterns. </p>
<p> The Red Panda (Ailurus fulgens) is a species closely related to raccoons. These bears spend a lot of their time on trees and can be found by people mainly in China, Nepal, and Bhutan. </p>
<p> Red Pandas live in the eastern Himalayas. Though red Pandas mainly eat small insects and vegetation, they also have the same ancestors as other animals eating Pandas. </p>
<p> The Giant Panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) is unfortunately on the verge of extinction and is rarely seen by people anywhere. </p>
<p> They are present in the temperate forests of the high mountains of southwest China. These Giant Pandas are similar to the red pandas and can also eat meat along with bamboos and leaves. These Pandas are the most famous and rare ones. </p>
<p> The often found red and white pandas (Ailuropoda melanoleuca qinlingensis) are the most commonly found species of Pandas. They are mainly found in the secluded mountainous regions of central China and the provinces Sichuan, Shaanxi, and Gansu Provinces. </p>
<p> These Pandas, like the other two, are also meat-eating species yet vegetarians. </p>
<p> Therefore, we can see that all these subspecies had the same ancestors. These ancestors, before the mutation, ate meat and lived on it. After millions of years, now though they can eat meat, they are vegetarians with a varied diet. </p>
<p> Do baby Pandas eat meat? </p>
<p> No, they don’t. The baby pandas mostly rely on their mother’s milk for food and protection for as long as a period of six months. </p>
<p> Their mothers feed them and take care of them like a normal baby. However, they start eating bamboo, leaves, stems, and shoots to fulfill their fiber requirements. </p>
<p> They do not begin to feed on the meat as long as they are approximately one year old. </p>
<p> How Often Are Pandas Eating Meat? </p>
<p> Not very often. Pandas are somewhat like humans in this regard. Like how vegetarians chose not to eat meat, they intake those proteins from other sources such as tuna, beans, and some particular greens. </p>
<p> Pandas are consummate vegetarians and belong to the Carnivora group of mammals. </p>
<p> They are Carnivora because, like other dogs, cats, weasels, hyenas, mongooses, and other similar animals, Pandas also can eat meat. But since their diet mostly consists of bamboo shoots, roots, and leaves, they are called vegetarians. Or so it seems outwardly to us. </p>
<p> Do Pandas Eat Small Animals? </p>
<p> Yes, they do! We are aware our cute and adorable Pandas can and do eat meat. </p>
<p> We did not know that these Carnivora also eat fish along with small animals such as lizards and insects, etc. Fish also have much nutritional value in them, such as proteins and antioxidants. </p>
<p> Do Pandas Eat or Attack Humans? </p>
<p> No, they don’t. Pandas, any species of them, are not violent by nature. They are calm and friendly creatures that keep to themselves mostly. </p>
<p> They prefer most of their time in solitude and in mountainous areas where there are many trees. Pandas often spend all their days eating, lazing around, and sleeping. They are not very active and aggressive. </p>
<p> But despite their preference for solitude and lazing, they are the subject of adoration and study of many people and scientists, respectively. </p>
<p> Because of this, Pandas are always in the eyes of humans. The Panda bears are significantly less in number. </p>
<p> There are only somewhat 2000 or more pandas left in the world. We know that we mainly find them in China, but China has an ever-growing population and industrial sector due to which land is continuously being developed by the Chinese government. </p>
<p> This process is causing significant damage to the habitat of Pandas. They are forced to evacuate and are lessening in number over the years. </p>
<p> Pandas usually are not aggressive or a danger to humans. That is until you provoke them. You can make a Panda attack you if you irritate them enough. </p>
<p> If they are not provoked or made angry, Pandas won’t do anything out of the ordinary. </p>
<p> So, it would be best if you didn’t irritate a Panda when you see one. Chances are, it’ll attack you. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> Natures, all animals are exceptional and unique in their ways. But Pandas are very special due to their extreme cuteness, adorable behavior, and general appearance. </p>
<p> Pandas are endangered and can go extinct very soon if they keep reducing at the current rate. Pandas’ eating habits are distinguishable from most animals as they have a carnivorous digestive system but digest all cellulose and depend heavily on bamboo. </p>
<p> They had ancestors who ate meat, and evolution made them into vegetarians. </p>
<p> Did you find this article helpful? Share it on your social media! </p>
<p> Below is a Pinterest friendly-photo… so you can pin it to your “Panda” Board! </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599721" filename="can-leopard-geckos-eat-fruit" parent_folder="web2" url="https://uniquepetswiki.com/can-leopard-geckos-eat-fruit/">
<p> Can Leopard Geckos Eat Fruit?: What not to feed them </p>
<p> Leopard geckos are adorable and one of the best reptiles that you can keep. It is a perfect pet for beginners, and you will not go wrong once you keep them in the right environment with nutritious food. Can leopard geckos eat fruit? Let’s find out! </p>
<p> Leopard geckos are insectivorous animals and will eat any insect that moves in front of them. However, you should avoid overfeeding or giving them the wrong type of food to avoid serious health consequences. </p>
<p> You may be wondering if leopard geckos can eat any other food source apart from common bugs. In this article, you will learn more about whether leopard geckos can eat fruit and what type of food is suitable. </p>
<p> To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video </p>
<p> Can Leopard Geckos Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> To address your concern on fruit feeding for your leopard gecko, we firstly need to know: can leopard geckos eat fruit? </p>
<p> Leopard geckos are known as insectivores and they cannot eat fruits or vegetables. Some people show that leopard geckos can eat some fruit. But as long time reptile owners, nobody recommends you feed leopard geckos fruits. </p>
<p> The main reason why many believed that leopard geckos can’t eat fruit is that their bodies are not designed to digest the fruit. Leopard geckos do not have a functioning caecum, which helps digest cellulose, the nutrient found in fruit and vegetables. </p>
<p> They also have a shorter and alkaline digestive tract. In comparison, herbivore animals have a longer and acidic digestive tract. </p>
<p> Many believed they don’t eat fruit because their skull and jaw have evolved (small and less robust) to eat meat. It is unlikely that fruit will do your gecko any good, and if you find your gecko eating fruit, it is because the food is available for them. </p>
<p> It is best if you stick to an insect diet for your leopard geckos to digest them naturally. </p>
<p> Can All Leopard Geckos Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> Although leopard geckos can eat fruits if readily available, it will not be beneficial to their body. In captivity, you can feed your leopard geckos with a varied diet of commercially available insects like crickets, roaches, mealworms, etc. </p>
<p> You can then gut-load the insect feeder with fruits and vegetables at least 24 hours before you feed your gecko. If you plan on giving your geckos with fruit, ensure that you carefully prepare the fruit by mashing it or blending it. You can also chop the fruit into small pieces before you give your gecko. </p>
<p> Ensure you wash the fruit thoroughly before you offer your gecko. You will also need to separate parts of the fruit that are inedible or toxic like pits and seeds. </p>
<p> This will help to remove pesticide residue and bacteria that can be on the fruit. Furthermore, ensure that you provide them with small serving at a time. This is mainly because they lack dentition and do not have the jaw strength to bite into solid food. </p>
<p> What Fruits Can Geckos Eat? </p>
<p> Before feeding your geckos with fruit, you will need to consider the nutritional content of the fruit. Some fruits can make the needs of your gecko imbalanced and will make them ill. This is why you need to consider the calcium to phosphorus ratio of the fruit before you give your geckos. </p>
<p> Your geckos need twice as much calcium than phosphorus. You will need to give them fruits with twice as much calcium as phosphorus. </p>
<p> Fruits That Leopard Can Geckos Eat </p>
<p> Although leopard geckos will not eat any fruit or vegetable, it can try out some types of fruit. Here are some examples of the best fruits that you can offer your gecko. </p>
<p> Pitted fruits: pears, apples, and cherries, and so on. </p>
<p> Grapes, </p>
<p> Melons, etc. </p>
<p> Note: the best fruit for your gecko must have balanced calcium to phosphorus ratio. </p>
<p> Fruits That Leopard Geckos Cannot Eat </p>
<p> You should avoid feeding your leopard gecko with fruits that contain dangerous compounds that can be toxic to them. You should avoid feeding them with rhubarb, starfruit, and avocado. </p>
<p> You can also avoid fruits like nectarine, banana, or peach or give them in moderation. This is because they have inadequate calcium to phosphorus ratio. </p>
<p> How Often Can You Feed Leopard Geckos With Fruits? </p>
<p> It is best to feed your leopard geckos only as a treat, whether they are hatchling or adult. This is because fruits do not have nutritional benefits to your gecko. </p>
<p> However, you can gut load insect feeders with fruit 24 hours before you feed your gecko. You just have to ensure that the insect is not bigger than the space between your gecko eyes. Furthermore, you can feed hatchling leopard geckos every day while juveniles and adults can eat every other day. </p>
<p> Leopard geckos are crepuscular, and the best time to feed them is around dawn or dusks. The amount of food to feed your gecko should be the ones it can eagerly eat within a few minutes. </p>
<p> This means you don’t need to put too many insects in their cage as they can escape, die, or even make your gecko overeat. </p>
<p> Once your gecko is done eating, ensure you clear out the uneaten insects. This is because leftover insects can rot or even nimble your gecko and cause stress. </p>
<p> Offering Fruit </p>
<p> When offering fruit to geckos, ensure you wash the fruit before you give your pet. This helps to remove bacteria and pesticide residues on the fruit. Separate the inedible or toxic parts like pits and seeds from the fruits. </p>
<p> Always ensure that the fruit is prepared in a way that your pet can easily eat it. You can use a food processor to make the fruit. And if you do not have one, you can simply cut the food into tiny parts with a knife or shred with a grater. </p>
<p> Note: Ensure that the fruit you offer them is soft, and their dimension should not be longer than the dimension between your geckos’ eyes. </p>
<p> Wrapping Up </p>
<p> Although leopard geckos do not eat fruit, some geckos can eat fruits. However, you should avoid feeding your leopard gecko with fruit because fruits comprise high sugar and acid. </p>
<p> You should know that leopard geckos do not like fruit taste and will only take it when starving or needs more moisture. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599690" filename="can-spiders-eat-fruit" parent_folder="web2" url="https://woodypet.com/can-spiders-eat-fruit/">
<p> Can Spiders Eat Fruit? </p>
<p> Can Spiders Eat Fruit? Probably they can </p>
<p> In the world, there are so many species of animals that we can call fructivores, or those that can enjoy the flavor of a fruit juice or the entire fruit itself as their main food to sustain their lives’ requirements of nutrients and energy. </p>
<p> Fruits are the way from some angiosperms (or plants with flowers that produce seeds) to multiply and reproduce, but they also can be part of some animals’ diet. The edible ones could also give many nutrients and could be great for hydration because of their high content of water in them. </p>
<p> So, you may be asking: But can spiders eat fruit? After all, they are also animals that are omnivores (the ones that can eat almost anything) Let’s see with some question and if they are, in fact, able to eat fruit like some other species of animals, or if they are only strictly hunter that eat meat. </p>
<p> Do spiders eat veggies? </p>
<p> It was a known fact that most (if not all) species of our arachnid friends only just eat meat (or at least the juices inside the said prey), but it was discovered fairly recently that some species of spiders do eat veggies. </p>
<p> A study from some universities from the UK, Switzerland and the United States discovered that some species of spiders do eat veggies, and the species mostly found eating greens are the jumping spiders. </p>
<p> The biggest group that likes a veggie meal once in a while is Salticidae, a family of jumping spiders with over 5,000 species spread across the entire world, characterized by the pair of big, shiny eyes at the front of their heads. Salticidae accounted for 60 percent of the documented plant-eating incidents. </p>
<p> One of the investigators said in an interview that “The ability of spiders to derive nutrients from plants is broadening the food base of these animals; this might be a survival mechanism helping spiders to stay alive during periods when insects are scarce”. Additionally, “diversifying their diet with plant is advantageous from a nutritional point of view, since diet mixing is optimizing nutrient intake.” </p>
<p> However, when it comes to what the plants can offer to the nature, like leaves, flowers and fruits, could be a little be different in if spiders can eat fruits, or leaves, or whatever. </p>
<p> Although, there is one type of spiders from Mexico and other countries of Central America which feeding is based mostly (if not only) of an herbivorous diet. This is a species of jumping spider and it is know to be the only one to have this kind of diet. </p>
<p> Do spiders eat leaves? </p>
<p> Mostly in what the above investigation says, some species of spiders do eat leaves from time to time. </p>
<p> Although this is a behavior in some species of spiders, that alone does not say that spiders actually chew and nibble the leaves as toothed animals or herbivores would do. </p>
<p> What spiders can do with leaves, pollen and other parts of the plant is to extract the juice from them or, in the case of some of those particles getting caught in their webs, the possibility of being eaten while the spider starts to eat their own webs. </p>
<p> That last behavior alone can actually provide with some good nutrients like calories from the pollen getting stuck in the web. And because the spiders are actually good recycler creatures, they can eat their own webs to get some energy and nutrients back. </p>
<p> Do spiders eat fruit? </p>
<p> When someone asks: Can spiders eat fruit? The answer would be around the: “No, they can’t. They are carnivores” and while the answer is mostly right, it can be more complex than a simple no. So, do spiders eat fruit? </p>
<p> In short answer: No. They do not eat fruit. In a more elaborate way: No, because it is not like they can chew the fruit like most animals would do, but they probably can suck the internal juice from a fruit, just like some species of spiders would do while extracting nectar from some flowers or the sap from a particular tree… Or even the liquids from an insect, toads, birds or fish, as they commonly do. </p>
<p> So, basically, the spiders can’t chew the pulp of a fruit and digest it normally like others animals would do, though they could get the juice from inside those fruits to get hydrated or to get more nutrients and energy. </p>
<p> In the world exists a well-known species of spiders that mostly (if not entirely) have a diet that is based of just vegetarian food. It is the Bagheera kiplingi, a species of spiders which diet is basically vegetarian only, being the only one in the entire world that is know to have a marked herbivorous diet. </p>
<p> For the Bagheera kiplingi spiders, the Beltian bodies are a delight. They would try to avoid fights to ants guarding said Beltian bodies, that are rich in lipids, sugars and proteins. The spiders mostly feed from these parts of the acacia’s trees and, from time to time, also consume nectar and occasionally steal ant larvae from passing worker ants for food, meaning that they are not totally herbivores but also carnivores. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> When talking about if spiders can eat fruit, the answer is a simple no. But that does not mean the spiders can’t get some nutrients from these or other parts of a plant, without actually nibbing or chewing said parts. </p>
<p> Spiders are mostly known to be carnivorous meaning they would mostly eat meat from animals like insects, toads, birds and fish (the last three are almost incredible to believe, but some species can actually catch fish!) but there is an exception of this rule. </p>
<p> The Bagheera kiplingi is a species of spider that is mostly found in Central America, in countries like Mexico and Guatemala, where those little spiders can have a diet mostly herbivorous. They eat from the Beltian bodies from the leaves of the acacia trees, while trying to avoid confrontation and disturbance of the ants that make some type of symbiosis with those parts of the tree. </p>
<p> Woody Pet provide information and tutorials for your pet which include horse, guinea pig, rabbit and spider. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599727" filename="can-you-eat-fish-eyes" parent_folder="web2" url="https://catchandfillet.com/can-you-eat-fish-eyes/">
<p> Can You Eat Fish Eyes? (Shocking Truth!) </p>
<p> Yes, you can cook fish eyes. Many different cultures around the world use fish eyes as a regular ingredient in their meals. Cooking fish eyes isn’t much different than cooking the whole fish. You can cook fish eyes on their own or keep them as part of the fish head. When you scoop out fish eyes to eat, make sure to get the muscles underneath the eye for added texture and flavor. </p>
<p> Eating Fish Eyes </p>
<p> There are many different parts of animals and see lights that a human being should not eat. But it may surprise you when we tell you that fishes are not one of them. Many cultures around the world eat fishes and serve them as their dish. As long as the eyes are appropriately prepared and cooked thoroughly, no one should experience any gastrointestinal issues. The main reason many people don’t eat fish eyes originates from their own squeamishness or because they are allergic to fish. </p>
<p> The most common cultures that consume fish eyes as a regular part of their cuisine is most of southeast Asia and the ocean and beach regions of Central America and South America. Many Slavic cultures that border an ocean or have lakes also use fish eyes in many dishes. </p>
<p> How to Prepare Fish Eyes for Eating </p>
<p> However, if you are used to American Cuisine, then you will not find many recipes for fish eyes. You will have to go to other countries and other culture’s recipes to find ways to cook fish eyes and make them more delicious. </p>
<p> There are two main ways you can cook fish eyes. You can cook fish eyes by leaving them within the fish and cooking it, or you can remove the eyes and cook them on their own. Either way is acceptable, but each method has its own steps. </p>
<p> Cooking Fish Eyes </p>
<p> You can use the same methods you usually perform to cook fish in order to cook fish eyes. If you use a sauce, be sure to place a generous amount of sauce over and underneath the eyes. The methods you can use while cooking an entire fish are </p>
<p> Sauteing </p>
<p> Frying </p>
<p> Boiling </p>
<p> Eating Fish Eyes </p>
<p> If you’re not one for grilling or deep frying, then adding fish eyes to a traditionally thick French sauce might be the way for you to get used to them. A few articles online state that fish eyes have a gelling agent inside them. When they are cooked with creamy sauces and spices, the liquid begins to turn thick. This may be a great way to experiment with a new ingredient in a traditional sauce you are familiar with. You can also add in pasta. We recommend that you start with a cream-based sauce, so the fish eyes will be more acceptable to your palette. </p>
<p> Benefits of Eating Fish Eyes </p>
<p> Reduce Waste </p>
<p> You may not think that throwing away fish eyes is a waste, but actually, they’re edible. If food is edible, that means that not eating it is technically wasting it. It is not like the guts or bones of a fish. Fish eyes can be adapted to any recipe. </p>
<p> Culture </p>
<p> Very few Western cultures eat fish eyes. It is often seen as low class or third world to eat parts of a fish or other animals that are unsavory. But this is only due to the culture of the West. Hispanic and Latino cultures, Asian cultures, and Slavic cultures use fish eyes as an ingredient in one or more of their dishes. </p>
<p> Delicious </p>
<p> When we think of food as delicious and savory, people usually dream up images of salmon sprinkle with lemon herbs or shrimp cocktails, pounds and pounds of Ceviche, guacamole, and chips. Very few people think officious in a stewed broth as delicious. If you cook fish eyes in a spiced broth, the eyes will easily absorb the flavor or salt around it. Plus, the muscle behind the eye also captures the flavor and adds different textures. I know it may be difficult to get used to the idea of fish eyes as a part of your food, but try out this part of the fish in a broth or sauce, and you’ll realize what you have been missing. </p>
<p> What Else to Know About When Eating Fish Eyes </p>
<p> Since human beings started fishing and catching fish to supplement their meals, there have been countless myths about eating different parts of the fish. Many of these myths include the eyes. Although we have dispelled many of them, there is one that always gets around even to this day. It is the myth that eating fish eyes will improve the quality and vision of your own eyes. This is not true or found in any scientific study. If there was any truth to it, it would be because fish eyes have minerals and vitamins that help maintain your vision. It does not mean that eating fish eyes add extra “eye compounds” to your ocular region. It is the same type of myth that involved carrots in World War II. </p>
<p> Don’t Eat Just the Eye </p>
<p> When you may think of consuming fish eyes, you’ll probably only consider the eyeball as the only part of the eye. However, there is an entire ocular system filled with nerves and muscles that are parts of the eyeball as well. When you prepare your first fish eyeball recipe, you should not leave out these extra outside parts. Many people state that if you only scoop out the eyeball and nothing else, your recipe will be quite bland and unappetizing. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> If you are looking to eat the more unsavory parts of an animal, fish eyes might be the mildest introduction to your journey. You can consume the eyes in a sauce or leave them inside the fish head while you broil, grill, or fry it in a pan. And don’t forget to eat the muscle underneath! </p>
<p> Disclaimer: Some recommended products may use affiliate links. CatchandFillet.com is a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for sites to earn advertising fees by advertising and linking to Amazon.com. Amazon and the Amazon logo are trademarks of Amazon.com, Inc or its affiliates. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599728" filename="can-you-eat-fish-scales" parent_folder="web2" url="https://catchandfillet.com/can-you-eat-fish-scales/">
<p> Can You Eat Fish Scales? </p>
<p> Learning about fishing can be very interesting and a lot of fun. It’s an exciting feeling to catch your own food. There’s quite a bit of work involved after catching a fish to get it ready for your dinner plate. </p>
<p> If you’re looking to cut back on that work, you may be wondering “can you eat fish scales”? The short answer to the question is yes, you can. You can safely eat the fish scales without causing any harm to yourself. That doesn’t mean you would want to though. The fish scales do have some minerals and healthy fats in them. </p>
<p> Don’t let his bit of healthy knowledge encourage you to leave those scales on. If you eat the fish with the scales removed your body will still get a healthy dosage of these minerals and fats. </p>
<p> What is Eating Fish Scales Like? </p>
<p> If you’re thinking about skipping a step of cleaning that fish up for dinner and leaving the scales on, then you are not about to have a treat. Think about what it’s like eating popcorn when a piece of kernel gets stuck in your teeth. Pretty annoying, right? </p>
<p> Just imagine every bite of popcorn you took has around 7 or 8 kernels in it. That is what eating fish scales is like. Getting one popcorn kernel stuck between your teeth is irritating enough. Can you imagine sitting through a meal where something hard was getting stuck in your teeth with every bite? </p>
<p> If you are ever preparing fish for a date night then you can understand why it’s important to remove all of those scales. </p>
<p> Types of Fish Scales </p>
<p> Interestingly enough, there are 4 different types of fish scales. Each type of fish scale is different in its chemical composition as well as it’s size. Some fish scales are a little bit healthier than others. Let’s take a look at the 4 different types of fish scales. </p>
<p> Placoid </p>
<p> Placoid scales are usually flattened rectangular shapes. They can be found on sharks and rays. These scales don’t change in size as the fish grows. New scales grow in to fill up the empty space. </p>
<p> Cosmoid </p>
<p> Cosmoid scales are very similar to placoid scales in shape and size. They are usually found on fossil fish as well as lungfish. These strong scales consist of two layers of bone, a layer of dentine, and a final layer of vitrodentine. This is not a scale that would be fun to bite down on. </p>
<p> Ganoid </p>
<p> Ganoid scales take on the shape of a rhomboid and articulating peg and socket joints in between them. These can be found on a wide variety of fish such as sturgeons, bowfin, and paddlefish just to name a few. </p>
<p> Cycloid ; Ctenoid </p>
<p> The cycloid and ctenoid scales are the most common type of scales found on bony fish. These scales have greater flexibility than the other ones because the anterior part of the scales is overlapped by the posterior part of the scale in the front. </p>
<p> Nutritional Properties of Fish Scales </p>
<p> As unappetizing as it sounds, there are still some great nutritional properties of fish scales. If you really want to eat them then you may as well learn about what makes them good for you. </p>
<p> Collagen </p>
<p> Fish scales have a healthy dosage of collagen in them. Collagen is great for helping to improve ligaments, and bones, as well as supporting joints. Adding more sources of collagen to your diet can help you achieve softer skin and stronger hair and nails. So, maybe fish scales can help make you prettier. </p>
<p> Extra Omega-3 and Other Healthy Fats </p>
<p> One of the most common reasons people add fish to their diets is because fish is loaded with healthy fats, especially omega-3 fatty acids. Eating fish with the scales still on is just a way to get even more of these healthy fats into your body. Omega-3 fatty acids are a great way to help build healthy brain cells, keep your heart healthy, and prevent a stroke from happening. </p>
<p> Okay, so maybe there are some great nutritional properties to fish scales. They also seem like they could help fix a lot of beauty issues naturally. So, is there a more appetizing way to eat fish scales? </p>
<p> Fish Scale Jelly </p>
<p> We couldn’t talk about all the wonderful things fish sales can do for your body without introducing a more appetizing way of eating them. If you would like an easy way to add more collagen to your diet then consider putting this healthy jelly on your crackers. </p>
<p> Simmer for a few hours until the scales have dissolved </p>
<p> Once dissolved, filter the fish scales </p>
<p> Add dried longan </p>
<p> Cook for an additional 30 mins </p>
<p> Pour into a jelly mold and allow it to cool in the fridge for 4 or more hours. </p>
<p> If you don’t plan to consume the whole batch of jelly within 7 days, then make sure you freeze what you don’t eat to avoid waste. Don’t worry, the process of making this jelly (and the results) don’t have a stink fish smell to it. That is why this jelly is a much more pleasant way to get your collagen fix from fish scales. </p>
<p> Final Verdict: Can You Eat Fish Scales? </p>
<p> Yes, fish scales are edible. That doesn’t mean you’re going to want to eat them though. Imagine trying to have a nice conversation at dinnertime with fish scales finding room in your teeth upon every bite? That doesn’t sound like a very appetizing dinner. </p>
<p> Fish scales do have a lot of nutritional benefits to them. If you are looking for a way to naturally add more collagen and healthy fats to your diet then consider trying the fish scale jelly recipe as a much tastier alternative to eating scales left on the fish. </p>
<p> Disclaimer: Some recommended products may use affiliate links. CatchandFillet.com is a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for sites to earn advertising fees by advertising and linking to Amazon.com. Amazon and the Amazon logo are trademarks of Amazon.com, Inc or its affiliates. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599777" filename="can-you-eat-fish-scales-what-you-need-to-know" parent_folder="web2" url="https://dinnercaptain.com/can-you-eat-fish-scales-what-you-need-to-know/">
<p> Can You Eat Fish Scales? What You Need to Know </p>
<p> Can You Eat Fish Scales? The brief answer is yes, you can. Although, I do not recommend it. Fish scales are safe to eat as long as you are eating fish scales right away without injuring your mouth or throat. They must be cooked very well before eating. And they are not tasty and do not provide much nutritional value. </p>
<p> There are five types of fish scales – Cosmoid, Placoi, Cycloid, Ganoid, and Ctenoid. Cycloid and Ctenoid types of scales can be found on the majority of our regular types of fish with bones that we eat. Sharks and sturgeons, in contrast, have placoid types. </p>
<p> I was surprised to find out that the fish scales have healthy fats and certain minerals that are beneficial to our body. However, just because of this fact, do not leave all fish scales on when cooking or eating fish. </p>
<p> Fish without scales is excellent too with a good sufficient dose of fats and minerals. Plus, fish scales are very small, and the amount of good stuff in them just does not necessarily justify eating them. </p>
<p> Can you eat fish scales? </p>
<p> Yes, you can eat fish scales as they are generally edible and nutritious on their small scale. However, eating them right and the right size and right amount is equally essential. </p>
<p> Fish scales are embedded with some nutrients. If you really wish to add in healthy fats and more collagen by eating them, then try making tasty fish scale included recipes. I would not. </p>
<p> If you are thinking you should eat the fish scales this time for dinner then, it is not a treat. It would be somewhat like eating popcorn with stuck kernels in your teeth. It could be very annoying. Eating fish scales feels like eating the softened outer shell of sunflower seeds. </p>
<p> Some of the fish scales that are left after some good descaling can still serve the purpose since the fish by itself has good nutrients. When you can eat the remaining scales without hurting your mouth then yes, you can eat fish scales as they will eventually digest. </p>
<p> Just do not indulge yourself with large amounts of fish scales in your food for fear of hurting your digestive tract. Remember – you are NOT a cat! </p>
<p> Some nutritional advantages of fish scales: </p>
<p> Though quote unappetizing, fish scales offer some nutritional benefits. Eating them will give you the benefit of eating them. </p>
<p> Provides collagen – Fish scales have a small dose of collagen which is ideal for improving bones, ligaments, and joints. Adding your meal with collagen sources will assist in getting stronger hair, nails, and soft skin. Therefore, fish scales make you more pretty. But, man, you would have to eat a lot of them, which is not good for you. </p>
<p> Omega-3 and healthy fats – Several individuals add fish to their lunch or dinner to load healthy fats into their diet. This is particularly true for omega-3 fatty acids. To eat fish scales means consuming a little bit more omega-3 and other healthy fats to assist in the building of health to heart, brain cells and avoiding an occurrence of a stroke. </p>
<p> Beauty – they provide a little bit more elasticity and suppleness to your skin. Your skin becomes beautiful naturally. But again, I would rather stick with fish meat for that. </p>
<p> Can you eat fish scales on salmon? </p>
<p> Yes, it is safe to eat fish scales on salmon and its skin. In fact, you can eat salmon fish scales more nicely than scales from some other types of fish. Salmon fish scales are loaded with all the good staff present in salmon fish. </p>
<p> Eating skin and scales each time to get benefits is recommended by some. While others might not like eating the scales from a view of fine dining. It is not fine dining – when you eat fish scales – it is very exotic food. </p>
<p> By the way, I am not necessarily talking about fish skin here. </p>
<p> Let us distinguish between fish skin and fish scales. Fish scales sit on top of fish skin. Eating wild salmon with skin is quite healthy and I love it sometimes. You will not be able to notice the scale when salmon skin is well baked. In fact, well-baked salmon skin is crispy and tasty. The other varieties of salmon with scales you can easily eat are pink, sockeye, Atlantic, chinook, and coho. </p>
<p> Since the scales are not so pleasant to eat, they are often descaled prior to cooking. Owing to its tough texture, people often discard it. They are however safe to eat. Just like salmon meat itself, its skin with scales is very nutritious with omega-3 fatty acids. </p>
<p> Can you eat cooked fish scales? </p>
<p> Yes, it is fine to eat cooked fish scales, however, they are not pleasant or tasty to eat. You can prepare some tasty dishes by cooking fish with scales or fish scales into other dishes. So, you can eat cooked fish scales depending on how you cook them. </p>
<p> Note, that the more you cook fish scales, the more easily you can eat them. Longer cooking makes them softer. Long cooking, especially boiling or simmering, can totally disintegrate fish scales with water to make a liquid or jelly. </p>
<p> You can grill the fish by kiting or butterflying by splitting them but not slicing them into 2 different halves or pieces. They are called so, due to their appearance after splitting. This way you eliminate fish bones while there is no need to remove fish scales. </p>
<p> You can grill this fish either on the open flame or using aluminum foil. People often prefer the latter for cleaner food. This way the tougher scales burn while tender ones are not. They remain on the skin. This way even the fish flesh is protected. </p>
<p> You can scrape off the burnt scales off leaving the rest on the skin. </p>
<p> Add a little seasoning with little olive oil to enjoy the natural flavor of the fish. </p>
<p> This is one good way of enjoying the fish scales and taking in the benefit as well without any harm done to the throat or mouth. </p>
<p> Can you eat fish skin with scales on it? </p>
<p> Yes, as I mentioned, you can eat fish skin with scales as long as it is properly cleaned. Fish scales can be edible and so is the fish skin. Salmon is the best, in my opinion. Just note that cooking fish with its skin on takes longer no matter which method you use – grilling, baking, frying, or steaming. </p>
<p> Note: If you want to cook fish skin with scales on it, make sure you do it thoroughly, as long cooking disintegrates the scales. For example, grilling on low fire instead of high, but for a long time. </p>
<p> Baking or simmering on medium or low for hours may make scales very soft, to the point that they essentially melt with skin. Then you can eat fish skin with scales on it more safely. </p>
<p> Few tips on how to cook fish skin with scales </p>
<p> As mentioned in the previous section, grilling is one of the good ways of eating fish with scales after cooked. Baking too. </p>
<p> You can add in garlic, herbs, cilantro, parsley, onions, and other aromatics to season the grilled fish. </p>
<p> Add in a coat of barbeque sauce over the fish before grilling. </p>
<p> Cook the fish and then add in different sauces by cutting smaller pieces of the grilled fish. </p>
<p> One other way of cooking fish with scales is by popping the fish scales by pushing them with your thumb. Essentially, this is deep frying in oil on a pan. </p>
<p> Heat the oil to 350-400 deg F and then place the fish into the oil. </p>
<p> The fish scales puff up and crackle. You can check the fish being cooked using a cake tester. Use snapper or a sea bream to make these crispy fish scales. </p>
<p> Another way recommended is to bake the fish with its scales on and bake it well. </p>
<p> All the above processes protect fish flesh from high heat. </p>
<p> Tip: tiny fish scales are usually more eatable than large fish scales. Some fish, like Atlantic char, has tiny and eatable fish scales. </p>
<p> What happens if you eat fish scales? </p>
<p> Nothing, if you cooked skin well and if you are careful and eat just a little bit of them. You can eat fish scales provided you are supposed to eat them without hurting yourself. However, eating fish scales can be unpleasant. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> Eating fish scales is one’s personal choice. However, eating fish scales is safe and fish scales have only a little bit of nutrients and healthy fats in them. Cooking them appropriately and eating the tender ones is one good way to enjoy them. </p>
<p> On the other hand, I personally do not eat fish scales as it is not quite on our regular human menu. Cats, for example, do a much better job digesting fish scales. </p>
<p> Still, if you want to shock your friends with the super-exotic meal, then fish scales will do it. Just cook them very well, or you may lose your friendship. Just saying. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599631" filename="causes-of-tired-after-eating" parent_folder="web2" url="https://drhealthbenefits.com/disease-disorder/common-symptoms/causes-of-tired-after-eating">
<p> 8 Causes of Tired After Eating (No.6-8 Deadly) </p>
<p> √ Scientific Checked Pass quality checked by advisor, read our quality control guidelance for more info </p>
<p> Post author Scientific review: Dr Heben's Team </p>
<p> Have you ever felt so drowsy and tired after eating? Most people had this experience and sometimes this phenomenon makes people become little bit concerns about their health conditions. People tend to afraid that they are suffering from specific diseases and they ended up asking questions like “Why am I tired after eating?”. </p>
<p> For many people, feeling tired after eating, especially after they get their lunch, could be very disturbing since it will affect your productivity throughout the day. The most common thing on why people tend to feel tired after eating is related to food that you consume. The tiredness after eating is a form of reaction from your body to types of food you are consuming. Some experts say the tiredness after eating is a normal condition. But, when you can’t keep your eyes open and just want to sleep so bad no matter what you eat, you should be more concerns about your health since it could be a signal for health problems. In this article, you will find the causes on why you feel so tired after eating. </p>
<p> Tired after Eating is a Normal Condition </p>
<p> In most cases, the tiredness that you feel after eating a food is a normal situation. Everybody will experience this thing. Here are some explanations on why feeling tired after having a meal is a normal condition. </p>
<p> Body Reactions Against Food That You Eat </p>
<p> This is the most ideal explanation on why you always feel tired after having a meal. You just feel tired because of your body reacts to the food that you already just ate. After you consume sweet or bakery products, that’s pretty normal if you feel tired afterwards. Food that has a great amount of sugar causes your brain to release high amounts of neurotransmitter and serotonin hormone, which will make people tend to fall asleep. </p>
<p> Besides, eating bakery products that contain flour will also make the blood sugar rise higher than normal. This thing will stimulate your pancreas to release great amounts of insulin, which will transports protein blocks called tryptophan from the bloodstream to your brain, then it will convert into serotonin that will make you feel tired and sleepy. </p>
<p> Digestive System Take Over Your Body’s Energy </p>
<p> This is one of the possibilities on why you feel tired after eating. Digestive organs like small intestine and large intestine requires high amounts of energy so they can work properly. After you have some meals, your body needs to digest lots amount of calories from your food. To digest this high amount of calories, your brain will shifts your body’s energy to focus on digestive systems. This will releases the red blood cells over to break down the food and transport its nutrients into your body. </p>
<p> Because your body’s attention is fully focused on digestion, the rest of your body tends to relax. This is why you feel tired and drowsy after having a meal. You might also feel tired after eating spicy foods. Your body needs to spend huge amounts of energy to digest spicy food. Also, spicy food will metabolize a chemical called capsaicin, which will make you feel tired. </p>
<p> Side Effects of High Amounts of Carbohydrate That You Just Consume </p>
<p> After you consume food with high amount of carbohydrate such as rice, potatoes, or bread, you might feel drowsy afterwards. Consuming foods with high-glycemic index carbohydrates will release high amounts of insulin, which will help to store the sugar you just consumed as glycogen. This would have advance effects on dropping your sugar level, which without a doubt will make you feel tired, drowsy, and sluggish. So, if you want to suppress the possibility of tiredness after eating, you should consider low-carbohydrate food to decrease the amount of carbohydrate in the body. </p>
<p> Effects on Over-Stressed </p>
<p> This is one of the possibilities on normal condition why you always feel tired after eating food. It is simply just because you are mentally tired and stressed. The tiredness because over-stressed can cause an “energy draining”, which will make you become more tired than before. Unlike the other three reasons as mentioned above, this possibility doesn’t relate to the digestive system, so all you can do is just relax and rest a little while. </p>
<p> You’re Not Exercise Enough </p>
<p> If you think that stay inactive or just sit throughout the day will help you to maintain your energy, well you’re wrong. On the contrary, staying active throughout the day will help you to reduce the possibilities of feeling tired after having a meal. In fact staying active all the day would help you to get a better sleep in the night and stay alert during the day. </p>
<p> Tired After Eating Could be a Sign of Health Problems </p>
<p> While most of the common reason on why you feel tired after eating is because your body reaction to food that you just ate, there are also some concerns regarding your health when you are always feeling tired after having a meal, no matter what food you are consuming. </p>
<p> These are the signs that could happen to you associated with tiredness after meal. If these signs occur, you might have some problems related to your health problems. </p>
<p> Nutrient Deficiencies </p>
<p> Everyone of you who evidence undigested food in your feces might have nutrient deficiencies problems. Nutrient deficiency is a condition where your body is unable to process the nutrients from the food you just ate. As the results, you wouldn’t gain any energy from your food after having a meal, which will make you feel tired and sleepy. </p>
<p> Diabetes </p>
<p> Diabetes is a kind of condition when your body couldn’t produce insulin properly. As diabetics, your body is unable to produce insulin which is really important to regulate your blood sugar level, either to stored it as glycogen, or transform it into glucose which will boost your energy. When your blood sugar doesn’t store as glycogen or transformed as glucose, of course your blood sugar level will increase suddenly, which will lead to headache, dizziness, and fatigue. </p>
<p> Food Allergies and Food Intolerance </p>
<p> For everyone of you who feel so tired after having some meals, and then follows up by many symptoms like diarrhea, constipation, or any allergic reactions, you should avoid the same food next time you have some meals as you could be allergic and have intolerance to certain ingredients in that food. </p>
<p> How to Prevents the Tiredness after Eating </p>
<p> After you know the reason on why you always feel tired after eating, we recommend you to consider these tips so you avoided from tiredness after eating. </p>
<p> You Need to Ask Yourself About Your Eating Habits </p>
<p> First of all you need to evaluate your eating habits, either you frequently like to eat food on a higher portion or in a lower portion. It is very important because the quantity of your meal will decide what will you feel afterwards. If you eat large portions of unhealthy food, you will be more likely to feel tired afterwards. However, if you forced to consume unhealthy foods, just try to reduce the size of your portion. </p>
<p> Eat Less </p>
<p> This is the follow up from the point 1. It is better to eat at a small portion, but more frequently rather than huge portions at once. A large portion of meals means that your body needs more energy to digest it. You could balance the small portion of your meals with “mid-snacks”, so you will get calories that you need throughout the day. Take a notice that you must take meals every 3 hours. </p>
<p> Eat Healthy Snacks </p>
<p> As already mentioned above, you should take mid-snacks in between your main meals schedule. But you are not recommended to consume snacks with high amount of sugar or carbs. Snack like fruit is best choice to maintain the energy level of your body and get rid of the feeling of tiredness after eating. </p>
<p> Eat a high complex-carbohydrate and high protein </p>
<p> Instead of eating junk food, you should consider your food carefully. Make sure that the food that you would like to eat contains complex carbohydrate and also high protein. Here is the example of foods you should choose because of its nutrients. </p>
<p> Any kind of vegetables, including tomatoes, cabbage, sprouts, celery, broccoli, cauliflower, cucumbers, onions, etc. </p>
<p> Any kind of fruits </p>
<p> Green beans </p>
<p> Mushrooms </p>
<p> Whole wheat bread, whole wheat pasta, whole wheat crackers, brown rice </p>
<p> Choose mineral water rather than coffee or alcohol </p>
<p> Sometimes, make a glass of beer or coffee is more tempting, rather than consuming mineral water, but don’t do that if you don’t want to feel tired after eating. Although coffee is widely known to make you stay alert, coffee can make you become addicted to caffeine, and it is not a good thing. Meanwhile, consuming alcohol is also not a good thing because alcohol is sedative, so after you consume a glass of beer, it would not be a surprise if you become more tired than before. Consuming mineral water is the best choice since this beverage will keep you hydrated troughout the day. </p>
<p> Stay Active After You Eating </p>
<p> After eating, you should keep yourself active during the day, don’t just sit down in the same place for hours. It is always a good idea to have some exercises, even the most simple one like walking on your way home, use stairs instead of elevators, or do some stretches in your office. Just make sure that you keep yourself moving since it will help you to get proper blood flowing and get rid of tired feeling. </p>
<p> In summary, feeling sleepy and tired after eating is a common condition, and it should be because it is your brain that convert your body’s energy to digest all of calories from food that you just ate. Meanwhile, you can prevent and reduce the feeling of tiredness and sleepiness by consuming healthy food with smaller portions, alongside apply the tips that we already provided above. Stay healthy! </p>
</doc>

<p> What to Eat When You Have Clostridium Difficile (C. Diff) </p>
<p> Dietary Recommendations for Better Management </p>
<p> Sherry Christiansen is a medical writer with a healthcare background. She has worked in the hospital setting and collaborated on Alzheimer's research. </p>
<p> Lindsey Waldman, MD, RD, is a board-certified pediatrician and pediatric endocrinologist. </p>
<p> The infectious bacteria Clostridium difficile (C. diff) produces an inflammation of the colon and severe diarrhea. This highly-contagious organism primarily impacts people over age 65, particularly those who are taking antibiotics and are in the hospital or living in a facility such as a senior care center. </p>
<p> In some instances, C. diff symptoms are mild, but it still may be passed to others easily. The primary goal of the C diff diet is to eat foods and take supplements that help alleviate the primary symptom, which is diarrhea. </p>
<p> Benefits </p>
<p> Although there is limited research on the effectiveness of diet for alleviating symptoms of C. diff, researchers know quite a bit about foods that worsen and those that alleviate diarrhea. When it comes to those at high risk of getting C. diff due to antibiotic use, foods and supplements that have probiotics have been found to be effective. </p>
<p> In fact, in a 2018 study of adults and children who were taking antibiotics and co-administered a probiotic supplement, there was a lower risk of Clostridium difficile infections.﻿﻿ The study authors concluded that “Moderate-quality evidence suggests that probiotics are associated with a lower risk of C. difficile infection.” </p>
<p> C. diff bacteria multiply when the normal (good) bacteria in the gut is suppressed—such as when antibiotics are taken. Probiotics may reduce the risk of developing C. diff.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Administration of probiotics is a logical treatment modality, but the studies show mixed evidence that specific probiotics, such as Saccharomyces and Lactobacillus species, speed up recovery of C. diff. ﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Another benefit of the C. diff diet is that it offers easy to digest foods, as well as those that have soluble fiber. There are basically two types of fiber, soluble and insoluble. Insoluble fiber may worsen symptoms of diarrhea. Soluble fiber is thought to help flush the C. diff bacteria out of the body. </p>
<p> Soluble fiber is contained in foods such as oats and barley (foods that absorb water and become sticky when wet). Insoluble fiber comes from foods such as celery and apple peels; when these foods are placed in water, they do not absorb the water and do not change form. </p>
<p> People with C. diff should consult with their healthcare provider, nutritionist, or another medical professional before taking any type of supplements, including probiotics or fiber supplements. Some digestive problems worsen with fiber supplements. </p>
<p> How It Works </p>
<p> Antibiotics are known to destroy the good "friendly" bacteria in the gut. Friendly bacteria are instrumental in fighting off infections in the colon, such as C diff. Foods that replace the good bacteria in the gut—such as fermented foods and those with probiotics and probiotic supplements—are thought to help alleviate symptoms of C. diff (such as diarrhea). </p>
<p> A soft diet (with foods that are easy to chew and swallow) that includes soluble fiber while avoiding foods high insoluble fiber (such as nuts and seeds) may help promote digestion. But there is a lack of definitive evidence from medical research studies to prove the best type of diet.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Duration </p>
<p> The C. diff diet should be implemented until your healthcare provider gives the all clear that the condition has resolved. The diet may be continued after a bout of C. diff as a prevention measure to keep the bacteria from re-growing and the condition from recurring. </p>
<p> Once your registered dietitian or another healthcare provider gives the order to discontinue the diet, it may be important to gradually start adding back the foods you were once accustomed to, rather than drastically changing the diet all at once. This gives your digestive system adequate time to adjust to foods that are relatively new. </p>
<p> It is not uncommon for those who contract C. diff to get the disease more than once, therefore, it’s important to take steps to prevent the disease once a person heals from C. diff. </p>
<p> According to the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, “The most important thing to introduce into your diet are “friendly bacteria”, often called probiotics, that will help repopulate your gut and crowd out the potential for regrowth of the C. diff bacteria.” </p>
<p> What to Eat </p>
<p> The C. diff diet is comprised of foods that help to alleviate or lessen diarrhea. Initially, your healthcare provider may recommend a diet of clear fluids, but this diet can only be implemented safely for a few days. It may take up to two weeks for a bout of C. diff to respond to treatment and for diarrhea to clear up. </p>
<p> In the interim, while waiting for treatment to be effective, many people with C. diff eat a diet of foods that won’t exacerbate (worsen) symptoms, but that may help lessen the severity of diarrhea. Your healthcare provider and a registered dietitian will recommend the exact eating plan. </p>
<p> Compliant Foods </p>
<p> Fermented foods such as yogurt, sauerkraut, tempeh (fermented soybeans), miso (fermented soybean paste) </p>
<p> Foods high in soluble fiber </p>
<p> Vegetables (non-cruciferous) cooked into soups or mixed into smoothies (such as green beans, zucchinis, and cucumbers) </p>
<p> Lean protein sources (such as turkey, chicken, and eggs) </p>
<p> Oats, oat bran, oatmeal, rice bran </p>
<p> Barley </p>
<p> Bananas </p>
<p> Natural applesauce (no added sugar) </p>
<p> Fruits such as citrus fruits, melons, peaches, cherries, strawberries, and watermelon </p>
<p> Lentils, beans </p>
<p> Low fiber cereal (such as Rice Krispies) </p>
<p> Finely ground flaxseeds (not whole) </p>
<p> Starchy, easy to digest foods, like potatoes, noodles, crackers and white rice </p>
<p> Lots of water and liquids to replenish water loss from diarrhea (such as soup and soup broth) </p>
<p> Non-Compliant Foods </p>
<p> Foods high in insoluble fiber </p>
<p> Cruciferous vegetables (such as cabbage, cauliflower, Brussels sprouts and broccoli), turnips, beets, carrots, cabbage </p>
<p> Unnatural oils (such as margarine, Olean, or Olestra) </p>
<p> Nuts and seeds (including nut butter) </p>
<p> Unpeeled apples, blackberries, blueberries, and raspberries </p>
<p> Prunes, prune juice, dates </p>
<p> Sugar substitutes like sorbitol and xylitol </p>
<p> Large amounts of sweet foods, such as cakes and cookies (the sugar and fat may worsen diarrhea) </p>
<p> Peas (have both soluble and insoluble fiber, but may be best to avoid due to insoluble fiber content) </p>
<p> Caffeine </p>
<p> Friendly (Good) Bacteria </p>
<p> It’s important to eat foods that contain probiotics to replenish the gut with good bacteria for those with C.diff, particularly if antibiotics have been taken long-term. A 2018 review study found that using probiotics helped to reduce diarrhea in those with C. diff, without any side effects. </p>
<p> Probiotics can be found in certain foods, such as those that are fermented, including yogurt, kefir and more. It’s important to ensure that the fermented food products do, in fact, contain live cultures. Probiotic-rich foods such as yogurt and kefir should not contain sugar—because sugar promotes the growth of bad bacteria in the gut. </p>
<p> An over-the-counter or prescription probiotic supplement may be beneficial. But be sure to consult with your healthcare provider before taking any type of supplements. </p>
<p> A combination of Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus casei, Saccharomyces boulardii, Lactobacillus rhamnosus, and other species in a dosage of more than 10 billion colony forming units, taken each day, may be effective. </p>
<p> Soluble/Fermentable Fiber </p>
<p> Studies have shown that eating a diet high in soluble fiber may help to eliminate C. diff. (and other types of bacterial infections in the bowel) sooner than a diet high in insoluble fiber. Foods that contain soluble fiber include oats, oat bran, oatmeal, beans, strawberries, apple pulp, and citrus fruit. </p>
<p> Some experts recommend taking banana flakes (available in a supplemental form) to prevent diarrhea. Bananas have pectin (a soluble fiber), which may help to slow the emptying of the gut and decrease the urgency/frequency of diarrhea. </p>
<p> Banana flakes can be purchased at a local pharmacy, but it’s important to consult with your healthcare provider before taking banana flakes, or any other type of natural supplements, particularly for those with C. diff. </p>
<p> Avoiding Insoluble Fiber </p>
<p> Foods that contain insoluble fiber include nuts, seeds, apple skin, wheat, wheat bran, barley, beets, carrots, cabbage, and cruciferous vegetables. These should be avoided. </p>
<p> Recommended Timing </p>
<p> Eating small amounts of foods and fluids frequently throughout the day is recommended for those on the C. diff diet. Large meals or snacks may increase diarrhea stools. </p>
<p> Cooking Tips </p>
<p> Very hot and very cold liquids and foods increase the frequency of diarrhea; drinking fluids at room temperature may help to control diarrhea. But everyone’s body is different, so experimenting with the temperature of foods and fluids may be needed to find out what works best. </p>
<p> Cooking vegetables until they are soft may lower the fiber content. Steaming or boiling, for example, can destroy much of the fiber content, as will deep-frying many foods. </p>
<p> Pureeing foods and processing them in a blender to make smoothies is not known to significantly lower the fiber content. However, using a juice extractor (which removes the pulp) will dramatically lower the fiber content in most foods. </p>
<p> Removing the peel from foods (such as apples) will reduce the fiber level, making foods high in insoluble fiber easier to digest and more suitable for the C. diff diet. </p>
<p> When cooking, it’s important to try to avoid using cooking oil whenever possible. </p>
<p> Modifications </p>
<p> An excessive amount of fluid may be lost when a person has chronic diarrhea. Along with the water, some nutrients and electrolytes are lost. Examples of modifications that may need to be made on the C. diff diet include: </p>
<p> Drink plenty of fluids (at least eight to 10 glasses of water per day). </p>
<p> Avoid caffeinated beverages (which can increase dehydration). </p>
<p> Replace lost potassium. Eat foods high in potassium such as bananas, boiled potatoes, and more. </p>
<p> Replace lost sodium. Drink bouillon soup, broths, tomato juice, and orange juice. Eat salty foods such as pretzels and cheese. </p>
<p> Replace lost calcium. Drink and eat plenty of dairy products if tolerated. If lactose intolerant, include almond milk, soy milk, and other milk replacements. </p>
<p> It’s important to drink small amounts (such as a half of a cup) of fluids frequently throughout the day instead of gulping large amounts of water). Drink fluids throughout the day; do not wait to feel thirsty. </p>
<p> Tips for getting extra fluids include eating/drinking plenty of: </p>
<p> Avoid taking salt pills and always consult with your healthcare provider to inquire about the need for potassium supplements. </p>
<p> Considerations </p>
<p> A long-term C. diff diet is not recommended because the foods may not supply enough of the nutrients needed on a long-term basis. Also, malabsorption of nutrients is a common side effect of C. diff. It’s important to receive close medical intervention to ensure levels of sodium, calcium, magnesium, and potassium are normal. </p>
<p> Look for foods high in these nutrients and follow your healthcare provider’s instructions closely on when to start back on a normal diet to ensure adequate nutritional intake. </p>
<p> Dietary Restrictions </p>
<p> Whole milk and whole milk products are known to cause stomach upset; a person who has C. diff is more likely to have trouble digesting lactose. Using a milk substitute (such as oat milk) may be recommended. Other tips for substituting milk products on the C. diff diet include: </p>
<p> Eat/drink smaller amounts of milk products at a time. </p>
<p> Eat low lactose dairy such as yogurts that contain live active cultures are low in lactose. </p>
<p> Select cheeses such as mozzarella, swiss, feta, and parmesan cheese. </p>
<p> Try enzymes that help with digestion of lactose (after consulting with your healthcare provider). </p>
<p> A Word From Verywell </p>
<p> Having a condition such as C. diff can be very challenging. Consulting with a professional registered dietitian nutritionist (RD or RDN) may be helpful. To find a registered dietitian near you, a nationwide search can be done online at the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics’ online referral service. </p>
<p> Was this page helpful? </p>
<p> Thanks for your feedback! </p>
<p> Sign up for our Health Tip of the Day newsletter, and receive daily tips that will help you live your healthiest life. </p>
<p> Verywell Health uses only high-quality sources, including peer-reviewed studies, to support the facts within our articles. Read our editorial process to learn more about how we fact-check and keep our content accurate, reliable, and trustworthy. </p>
<p> Oncology Nutrition. Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. Diet and C.difficile. Updated March 2019. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599682" filename="celebrities-who-only-eat-fish" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.thethings.com/celebrities-who-only-eat-fish/">
<p> www.thethings.com </p>
<p> Follow TheThings.com </p>
<p> Something New </p>
<p> 10 Celebrities Who Only Eat Fish </p>
<p> These celebrities chose to go meatless but became pescatarians to add protein and healthy fats into their diets. </p>
<p> Many celebrities choose a vegan or vegetarian diet because of their stance against eating meat or because they believe a plant-based diet is better for their health. While many stars forgo meat for good, some include fish in their vegetarian diets for added health benefits. </p>
<p> Pescatarians don't eat meat, but they do eat fish. These celebrities chose to go meatless but became pescatarians to add protein and healthy fats into their diets. They eat salmon, tuna, and even sardines, which are all high in omega-3s and very good for your heart, brain, and circulation. Cutting out red meat and becoming a pescatarian worked out great for the stars listed below. </p>
<p> 10 Cam Newton </p>
<p> New England Patriots quarterback Cam Newton is just one of many athletes that went pescatarian, avoiding red meat and eating shrimp, and other fish. He has been a pescatarian for quite some time, but this year, he's gone fully vegan, crediting his newly plant-based diet for a boost in his health. </p>
<p> According to the football star, the shift to becoming a vegan has helped him recover after a shoulder injury in 2018. "I've seen a remarkable change in the way my body responds to the food I eat." He also shared in a video blog, "When you look at gorillas, when you look at elephants, they find their course of protein in plants and I do the same thing. I'm loving how I'm feeling." </p>
<p> 9 Olivia Wilde </p>
<p> Actress Olivia Wilde ditched her vegan diet to become a pescatarian, stating in a 2014 interview that it changed the way she looked at dieting. "Fear of carbs, of gluten, of everything - we've distanced ourselves from the beauty of food, the art of it," Wilde shared with Allure magazine. "It makes me sad when people say, 'Oh, I don't eat gluten. I don't eat cheese. I don't eat this. So I eat cardboard." </p>
<p> Even though the star no longer keeps up with the celeb trend of becoming a vegan, she still maintains a healthy outlook at eating by eating fish, which is an excellent source of B-complex vitamins, vitamin A and vitamin D. </p>
<p> 8 A$AP Rocky </p>
<p> In 2012, A$AP Rocky told Complex that he decided to become a pescatarian after learning about the brutal ways animals are slaughtered for their meat.
