"I don't eat meat, so people don't like to celebrate Thanksgiving with me. They can't enjoy it. Most people in my family, they mix meat in everything that they cook. So it's just pretty annoying," the rapper shared. </p>
<p> A$AP Rocky was so upset about the torture process of animals, especially the poultry industry that he eventually became a vegetarian and seems fully committed to never eating meat. </p>
<p> 7 Common </p>
<p> Common hasn't eaten meat since the '90s and told JustJared back in 2009 that he has been feeling much healthier with a pescatarian diet. "I just decided to be more aware of my health and well-being," the "Glory" singer shared, adding, "I felt that beef and pork wasn't good." </p>
<p> 6 Raven Goodwin </p>
<p> Raven Goodwin is best known for starring in the drama series Being Mary Jane and has shared that she is a fan of the pescatarian diet and that it has helped her become vegan. However, she confessed that if being a vegan doesn't work out for her, she'll gladly go back to eating fish. </p>
<p> This year, the actress showed off a slimmer figure on her Instagram and shared with her followers that she started a new health and fitness journey, which has clearly been working very well for the star. </p>
<p> 5 Steve Job </p>
<p> Steve Jobs was told by doctors and his family to consume more protein when he was diagnosed with a rare form of pancreatic cancer in 2003. According to Owaves, Jobs developed a love for eating sushi including fatty tuna, salmon, and yellowtail, and also ate eggs some that he can consume more protein. </p>
<p> Before his diagnosis, Jobs considered himself a fruitarian, a subset of veganism, and would only eat foods like apples and carrots for weeks at a time. </p>
<p> 4 Ben Stiller </p>
<p> During an interview with Conan O'Brien, actor Ben Stiller spilled the details about his diet and how he was improving his lifestyle. The Meet the Fockers star shared that not only had he decided to let go of coffee, he became vegan, too. However, he mentioned that he'd eat fish here and there, which technically makes the actor a pescatarian. </p>
<p> While Stiller expressed that sticking to not eating meat can be hard, his wife, Christine Taylor explained that letting go of meat has improved her life. "It really changed our energy level. Sometimes you don't realize it until someone says it to you, like, 'your skin looks amazing," she shared. </p>
<p> 3 Victoria Beckham </p>
<p> Victoria Beckham always looks her best and that's because she follows a Five Hands Diet, according to The Daily Mail. The diet consists of just five handfuls of food a day, and Beckham reportedly snacks on small portions of smoked salmon, prawns with chili, yellow-fin tuna, and scrambled eggs. </p>
<p> The former Spice Girl went on a specific diet to lose the baby weight she gained when she was pregnant with her daughter, Harper. "Five days after birth, she started eating five high-protein meals a day accompanied by green vegetables, drinking gallons of water, and only snacking on goji berries and nuts," a source told Grazia magazine. </p>
<p> 2 Howard Stern </p>
<p> In 2012, while speaking with Grub Street, radio personality Howard Stern revealed that he and his wife gave up meat and became pescatarian. "We recently became pescatarians, which means the only protein we're getting is from seafood these days... we just learned the word pescatarian," he shared, adding that it "it felt really funny eating turkey and chicken... we stopped that completely." Stern also shared that he loves snacking on cashews and his favorite restaurant is Nobu, which serves mainly fish and seafood dishes. </p>
<p> 1 Kaley Cuoco </p>
<p> The Big Bang actress Kaley Cuoco follows a pescatarian diet, telling Women's Health magazine in 2016 that she was "done" with eating meat, though she does eat fish. In her interview, she broke down what she eats in a day, sharing that for breakfast, she'll have peanut butter on toast, for lunch, she'll chow down on half a sandwich, and for dinner, the star will usually eat fish and vegetables. </p>
<p> Marika Kazimierska is a New York City raised, Detroit based freelance journalist specializing in the areas of celebrity news, lifestyle, reality television, and entertainment. She holds a Bachelor's Degree in Communication with a concentration in Journalism from Adelphi University in Long Island, NY. She enjoys vanilla chia lattes, hiking with her German Shepherd, and reading murder mysteries. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599535" filename="chris-packham-what-i-eat-food-diary" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/jan/27/chris-packham-what-i-eat-food-diary">
<p> Chris Packham: what I eat </p>
<p> Breakfast </p>
<p> I have Asperger’s and I like routine, so I eat the same thing if I possibly can. Granola or muesli with soya milk – and that’s it. I gave up tea 10 years ago and haven’t drunk coffee since 1990. I was on the ceiling and didn’t like it. I just have water. </p>
<p> Lunch </p>
<p> If I’m at home with my partner, Charlotte, we’ll have cheese and biscuits. I like gruyère. If I’m on my own, I’ll skip lunch. </p>
<p> Dinner </p>
<p> I don’t eat meat. I make one of three things for dinner. I will have a pasta with tomato, peppers and Quorn, a stirfry or some grilled fish – seabass or salmon – with a peppery salad. </p>
<p> Snacks </p>
<p> At home I don’t snack, but I’ve just been away for work and I snacked to hell. I like my weight to be between 75 and 76kg but I’m well over where I want to be. I like sweet things. I frequently wake in the night with a sugar craving. My favourite is dried mango. Chocolate is my treat. I subscribe to Cocoa Runners, who send you four bars of fine chocolate from around the world once a month. There’s a fabulous one from Peru; I have some here from Madagascar, Indonesia and Newcastle. </p>
<p> There are things I won’t touch. I haven’t had a soft drink for 15 years. Crisps are another no-no. And I don’t eat fruit – I don’t like eating it manually. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599459" filename="conures-toxic-food" parent_folder="web2" url="https://vivopets.com/conures-toxic-food/">
<p> This page might contain affiliate links, which will earn us a commission. As an Amazon Associate we earn from qualifying purchases. </p>
<p> What Should Conures Not Eat? 10 Foods to Avoid </p>
<p> Conures are one of the most wholesome pet companions you can have. They’re intelligent, bubbly, often comical and most importantly, come in a range of eye-catching colors. </p>
<p> They also have quite a long lifespan – up to 20 years or more; which means you get to enjoy their spunky awesomeness for a little bit more. </p>
<p> Unfortunately, many of the wild species of conure have nearly gone extinct mostly because of environmental changes and to some extent, human activities. </p>
<p> Bad diets, in particular, are a major cause of death to these precious birds and if you have a pet conure, or looking to get one in future, you need to feed it with the right foods to avoid illness and other complications. </p>
<p> So, through this article, I will take you through all the foods you should and shouldn’t feed your conures as well as what steps to take if your bird pet accidentally comes into contact with toxic foods. Sounds good? Ok… </p>
<p> Toxic Food For Conures </p>
<p> Harmful foods that you should never feed your pets include: </p>
<p> – Chocolate </p>
<p> Chocolate is a sweet, and relatively beneficial treat for humans but resist the temptation to share a bar with your conure. The reason being that while our digestive systems can fully process the main compounds in chocolate (that is, theobromine and caffeine), birds have difficulties doing so. </p>
<p> Matter of fact, chocolates can induce tremors, hyperactivity and increase heart rate in conures and higher levels may even cause death. If you really want to give your birdie a sugary treat, consider more healthier options, like a ripe banana, or maybe a grape. </p>
<p> – Avocado </p>
<p> Avocado fruits are high in the “good” fatty compounds, which is why it’s such a popular food within the wellness community. However, one component of the avocado plant, called persin, has been seen to have adverse effects on birds, ranging from heart failure to respiratory problems and even death. </p>
<p> Notably, the inner pulp contains lower concentrations of persin compared to the leaves, which explains why it’s considered safe for humans and even some bird types. </p>
<p> However, you may not know how much persin a given avocado contains and how it may affect your conure hence it’s safer to just keep them away from your bird. </p>
<p> – Candy </p>
<p> Sugary foods like candy are not recommended for humans and it also follows that you should also not give them to your conure. </p>
<p> For one, candies are very high in sugar, fats and sodium, all of which contribute to obesity and can also cause diarrhea and heart problems. </p>
<p> – Fruit Seeds </p>
<p> Fruits are generally safe and healthy for conures – except the ones mentioned here of course – but even so, don’t let your bird eat the seeds. </p>
<p> This is especially important when it comes to fruits like apples, pears, plums, cherries and apricots, as their seeds and pits contain very high levels of cardio-toxic cyanide, which causes death in birds. </p>
<p> If you really want to give some fruity treats, consider grapes, tomatoes, melons, pomegranates and squash, which are much safer options. </p>
<p> – Meat </p>
<p> While meat is not as harmful to conures and parrots as the other foods in this list are (wild birds eat lots of insects) it is still not advisable to feed it to your bird as you’re likely to overdo it. </p>
<p> Feeding your bird too much meat can promote buildup of fat deposits, leading to obesity, which is in itself a big health risk for parrots. </p>
<p> – Cheese </p>
<p> Cheese, and other similarly fatty foods like butter and nuts, cause health problems in humans, so imagine what they can do to the much smaller conures. </p>
<p> Even the tiniest bites of cheese can clog the birds’ arteries, making them susceptible to heart failure and stroke. And the smaller the bird, the higher the risk. </p>
<p> – Peanuts </p>
<p> Peanuts are typically very rich in fats, yet almost deficient in other minerals like calcium and vitamin A. Giving them to your bird promotes fat buildup while not adding any nutritional value to them, which basically leads to malnutrition. </p>
<p> Peanuts, and other seeds in general, are pretty useless when offered as standalone meals, and are better included in more balanced diets. </p>
<p> – Coffee Beans </p>
<p> Coffee beans are rich in caffeine which is considerably more effective (read harmful) to conures than in humans, for obvious reasons. </p>
<p> A few sips of coffee beans may not sound bad to you but the caffeine in it may significantly increase your bird’s heart rate, lead to hyperactivity, and potentially trigger cardiac arrest. </p>
<p> Remember that caffeine is not limited to coffee but is also present in tea, soda and many other beverages, so you may want to stick to only giving clean water. </p>
<p> – Onion and Garlic </p>
<p> They may sound cute and healthy, but onions and garlic are one of the most dangerous foods you can ever feed your bird (or any pet, for that matter). </p>
<p> Onions, in particular, contain lots of sulfur, which is a very potent toxin that can cause anemia and in a worse case scenario, rupture of red blood cells. </p>
<p> Hell, the sulfur composition remains the same whether the onions are cooked, raw or dehydrated so avoid feeding your conure with cooked food containing onions. </p>
<p> Garlic, on the other hand, contains a compound called allicin, which is also toxic to birds like conures. Intake of allicin can also cause anemia or even death in birds. </p>
<p> Admittedly, this chemical is not present in all garlic variants but since you probably won’t be able to tell which ones have it, it is advisable to keep away all garlic from your birdie’s reach. </p>
<p> – Mushroom </p>
<p> A lot of mushroom varieties are neither safe for human nor bird consumption and are generally best avoided. Some mushrooms may also be variably toxic – in that they’re toxic at different heat levels, or in different areas, and safe in others. </p>
<p> So, unless you are willing to conduct thorough scientific analysis on every bit of shroom you give to your bird, you may want to just avoid them all. </p>
<p> What Conure Birds Should Eat? </p>
<p> Avian nutritionists recommend feeding your pet conure a diet similar to the one they would take if they were in the wild. In essence, 50-70 percent of the diet should contain pellets, while the remaining 30-50 percent should consist of fresh foods. </p>
<p> You can find a lot of fortified and nutritious pellets at an avian pet shop so you don’t need to worry about that. For the fresh feeds, consider organic veggies (raw or steamed), small amounts of fruite, cooked whole grains like rice, oats, barley and legumes. </p>
<p> For more balanced meals, use the Chop Approach, which involves cooking a bunch of grains, legumes and chopped vegetables then mixing them in a large container, which then goes into the fridge. </p>
<p> Every day, take a serving of the food, warm it, then feed it to your birdie. The whole thing saves you time and ensures that every day, your pet will get the required mix of nutrients and vitamins. </p>
<p> What to Do If Your Conure Accidentally Eats Toxic Food? </p>
<p> If your conure somehow gets in contact with any of the toxic foods mentioned above, you need to swing into action as fast as you can to save its life. </p>
<p> The first course of action, naturally, should be to assess the situation (is the bird still breathing? Any seizures? Is there evidence of hemorrhage? etc), then depending on the circumstances, stabilize the bird and throw away any toxic substances in the vicinity. </p>
<p> Stabilization procedures here may include performing CPR, giving water, controlling seizures, taking the bird outside for fresh air, and so forth. </p>
<p> The next logical step is visit a vet for the necessary tests and evaluation and to get more informed advice on the next steps. </p>
<p> Remember, you should still visit the vet even when your bird shows recovery after your stabilization procedures, as there may still be other unsolved internal problems that you didn’t notice, and which may cause problems later. </p>
<p> A full medical evaluation gives you a more clear picture and helps make timely, and potentially lifesaving interventions. </p>
<p> Wrapping Up </p>
<p> Taking care of your feathered friend goes beyond providing shelter, companionship and food. </p>
<p> Providing the right types of food is extremely essential to enhancing the bird’s health and lifespan, and subsequently increasing your mutual bond. </p>
<p> I’m Noah, chief editor at VIVO Pets and the proud owner of a playful, energetic husky (Max). I’ve been a volunteer at Rex Animal Rescue for over 2 years. I love learning and writing about different animals that can be kept as pets. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599620" filename="cough-after-eating" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.healthline.com/health/cough-after-eating">
<p> 6 Reasons You Cough After Eating </p>
<p> Many people have a mysterious cough after eating. It might happen after every meal or only occasionally. There are several possible causes of this, including acid reflux, asthma, food allergies, and dysphagia, which refers to difficulty swallowing. </p>
<p> Coughing is your body’s way of keeping irritants out of your respiratory system, so work with your doctor to figure out what’s causing the irritation. Most causes are treatable by changing your diet and eating habits or taking medication. </p>
<p> Acid reflux happens when stomach acid moves back up to your esophagus. There’s a band of muscle around the bottom of your esophagus called the lower esophageal sphincter. When you eat or drink, it relaxes, allowing food and liquid to move into your stomach. Sometimes it doesn’t completely close after you eat or drink, allowing acid from your stomach to move up into your esophagus. This irritates your esophagus, which may cause you to cough. </p>
<p> Other symptoms of acid reflux include: </p>
<p> sore throat </p>
<p> bitter taste in the back of your throat </p>
<p> sour taste in your mouth </p>
<p> burning sensation in your chest, known as heartburn </p>
<p> Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) </p>
<p> GERD is an ongoing, more severe form of acid reflux. A chronic cough, especially after eating, is a common symptom. </p>
<p> nausea or vomiting </p>
<p> trouble swallowing </p>
<p> Laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) </p>
<p> LPR, sometimes called silent reflux because it doesn’t have traditional reflux symptoms, is a type of GERD that involves stomach acid passing through your esophagus and into your larynx or even your nose. You can have LPR with or without GERD. LPR can make you cough during and after meals. You might also cough when waking up, talking, or laughing. </p>
<p> Symptoms of LPR include: </p>
<p> hoarseness </p>
<p> constantly needing to clear your throat </p>
<p> sensation of something dripping down the back of your throat from the nose, called postnasal drip </p>
<p> Talk to your doctor if you have any LPR symptoms. Untreated LPR may eventually lead to voice disorders or throat ulcers, so early treatment is key. </p>
<p> There isn’t a cure for acid reflux, GERD, or LPR, but certain medications and home treatments can help you manage the symptoms. </p>
<p> Many coughs are caused by upper respiratory infections, but these coughs usually clear up within two to three weeks. Any cough lasting 8 weeks or longer is considered chronic. A chronic cough after eating could be caused by an infection that never healed properly. </p>
<p> A cough caused by an infection sounds like a harsh, dry, persistent hack. This cough causes inflammation to the airway, which can lead to more coughing. </p>
<p> Coughs caused by infections are difficult to treat because the cycle of inflammation and coughing prevents healing. If the cough doesn’t go away, your doctor may prescribe anti-inflammatories, such as inhaled or oral steroids. </p>
<p> Asthma is a chronic disease that affects the lungs. It can cause wheezing, chest tightness, and coughing. Asthma usually starts in childhood, but it can also appear when you’re older. Coughing caused by asthma is usually worse late at night or early in the morning. </p>
<p> The symptoms of asthma worsen during an attack. Many things that can trigger an asthma attack, including sulphites, which are in beer and wine as well as dried fruits and vegetables, pickled onions, and soft drinks. If you tend to cough after eating or drinking any of these, asthma could be the cause. </p>
<p> You can often easily manage asthma using medications and avoiding common asthma triggers. </p>
<p> Food allergies usually develop when you’re a child, but they can strike at any age. It’s even possible to develop an allergy to a food that you’ve been eating for years. Food allergies typically cause an allergic response within two hours of eating. </p>
<p> Allergic reaction symptoms vary from person to person, and they sometimes affect the respiratory system, causing you to cough. Other respiratory symptoms of a food allergy include wheezing and shortness of breath. </p>
<p> In rare cases, food allergies can lead to anaphylaxis, a life-threatening condition that affects your breathing. Make sure you know how to recognize it so you can get immediate treatment. </p>
<p> Dysphagia refers to having difficulty swallowing. If you have dysphagia, your body takes more time and effort to move food and liquid into your stomach, making swallowing painful or almost impossible. This can lead to coughing or gagging while swallowing. Dysphagia can also make it feel like you have food stuck in your throat, causing you to cough. </p>
<p> Many conditions can cause dysphagia, including acid reflux and GERD. Work with you doctor to figure out what’s causing your dysphagia. Sometimes simple exercises are enough to fix the problem. In more serious cases, you may need an endoscopic procedure or surgery. </p>
<p> Sometimes small pieces of food or drops of liquid are inhaled into your lungs, where they can introduce bacteria. This usually happens when you swallow something and it “goes down the wrong hole.” Healthy lungs typically clear themselves out, but if they don’t, these bacteria can cause a serious condition called aspiration pneumonia. Having acid reflux or dysphagia increases your risk of developing aspiration pneumonia. </p>
<p> A wet-sounding cough after eating is a symptom of aspiration pneumonia. You may also cough up mucus that looks green or bloody. Other symptoms include: </p>
<p> fever that starts within an hour of eating </p>
<p> shortness of breath or fatigue while eating or drinking </p>
<p> Left untreated, aspiration pneumonia can cause serious problems, such as a lung abscess or respiratory failure. Talk to your doctor as soon as possible if you think you might have aspiration pneumonia. </p>
<p> Regardless of what’s causing you to cough after eating, some simple steps may help you cough less and avoid complications such as aspiration pneumonia: </p>
<p> Eat slowly. </p>
<p> Keep a food diary and mark any foods that make you cough. </p>
<p> Don’t eat during a coughing attack — this could lead to choking. </p>
<p> Take all your medications, especially those for acid reflux or asthma, as prescribed. </p>
<p> Keep a glass of water nearby when you’re eating and take lots of sips. </p>
<p> Several things can make you cough after eating, and most of them are easy to treat or manage. Keep track of any additional symptoms you have and work with your doctor to figure out the underlying cause. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599611" filename="cough-eat-9fecd5945ac24cef" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.reference.com/science/cough-eat-9fecd5945ac24cef">
<p> Why Do I Cough When I Eat? </p>
<p> By Staff WriterLast Updated March 29, 2020 </p>
<p> Follow Us: </p>
<p> Coughing during and after eating may be a result of a serious condition called dysphagia, which causes a person to have trouble properly swallowing and digesting food. Dysphagia can result in numerous symptoms, coughing while eating being just one. This is a complex condition that tends to occur in older people who struggle with dry mouth, notes About.com. </p>
<p> MedlinePlus identifies symptoms of dysphagia as choking, struggling to chew, food sticking in the throat, chest pain, heartburn, sour taste and nausea. A person may not experience all of these symptoms; however, it is important to see a doctor about this condition if coughing is persistent. </p>
<p> Elderly people displaying these symptoms are especially vulnerable. According to an article by Maura Keller on Today's Geriatric Medicine, older people are at risk of experiencing aspiration. This happens when food or liquid leaks into the lungs. Swallowing difficulties can also lead to malnutrition. </p>
<p> Multiple sclerosis is another serious disorder that has a direct link to dysphagia symptoms. Swallowing involves coordination between the nerves, muscles and brain. All of these areas are negatively impacted by MS. Symptoms related to dysphagia can come and go, according to Dr. Julie Stachowiak. If dysphagia is not the problem, the coughing may be caused by asthma, postnasal drip or gastrointestinal problems. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599719" filename="couple-who-only-eat-fruit-diet" parent_folder="web2" url="https://teddyfeed.com/trending/couple-who-only-eat-fruit-diet/">
<p> Meet The Couple Who Only Eat Fruit And Never Brush Their Teeth </p>
<p> By Jessica Miller, Published on Apr 29, 2019 </p>
<p> The life of a fruitarian </p>
<p> Because we all choose to live our own lives, we all know what we like and want to eat, and what we don’t. For some, this means eating what they want, when they want. They will eat meat, they will eat dairy, and they’ll eat anything that lands on the dish in front of them. </p>
<p> However, there are others who don’t follow this doctrine. Many people have adopted vegetarian and vegan lifestyles over the years, and the trend has become increasingly popular. Yet, have you ever heard of a fruitarian? </p>
<p> The couple in question </p>
<p> Well, two people who live by a fruitarian lifestyle are Tina Stoklosa (39) and Simon Beun (26). The couple are currently gearing up to tie the knot and solidify their love, and they are getting ready to do so at their home on the beautiful Indonesian island of Bali. </p>
<p> Over the past few years, the couple has become famous on social media for their way of life. They have shared pictures and videos of their fruitarian lifestyle on Instagram and on their YouTube channel, and it’s fair to say that people have a lot to say about their choices. </p>
<p> A normal day </p>
<p> Perhaps the biggest question Tina and Simon are faced with is: What do you eat? A fruitarian is someone who only eats fruits and avoids all other foods within their diet. Because of this, the couple have to cater their daily dishes to suit this lifestyle. </p>
<p> For breakfast, they will drink four glasses of freshly squeezed orange juice. For lunch, they will drink a banana smoothie made from seven fresh bananas, as well as half an avocado on the side. As a snack, they will munch on two dates. Then, for dinner, they will have two glasses of orange juice and a whole avocado! </p>
<p> A whole load of benefits </p>
<p> To most of us, that seems like a very small and insignificant food experience. After all, they seem more like snacks rather than actual meals. However, this daily diet provides them with just over 2,000 calories, and they swear by the health benefits. </p>
<p> Over the course of their fruitarian lifestyle change, the couple have noted that they have become more energetic, they feel healthier than they ever have before, they look younger, and that they never been ill. In their eyes, it’s a miracle diet that they will never stray from ever again. </p>
<p> Not always been that way </p>
<p> While Tina and Simon have now thoroughly embraced their fruitarian existence, it hasn’t always been that way. In fact, they have only been a couple for a few years, and Bali hasn’t always been their home. Both Tina and Simon come from two completely different walks of life and from two completely different countries. </p>
<p> Just a few years ago they were just like every other Average Joe who would eat animal products and go about their typical 9-5. Yet, they gave this all up to change their lifestyle for what they believe is the better. </p>
<p> The life of Tina </p>
<p> Before she moved to Bali and met Simon, Tina was living in her home country of Poland. She had set up residence in Warsaw and worked as a successful interior design architect. Although she had a great job and a wonderful set of friends, Tina didn’t feel as though she was very happy in her life. </p>
<p> She knew that she should be grateful for what she had around her, but there was always something that pulled her back down to earth. No matter how successful she became, Tina never felt comfortable in her own body. </p>
<p> A binge eater </p>
<p> During an interview with the Daily Mail, Tina noted that she had been overweight for much of her life before adopting a fruitarian diet. She felt uncomfortable with her weight, and she tried every diet in the book. </p>
<p> However, nothing worked for her, and she soon turned to binge eating to help curb her emotions and make her feel better about herself and her appearance – if only for an hour or two. Yet, this was a vicious cycle for Tina, as she believed her increasing weight was the reason she was still single, and the reason that she didn’t feel as though she was beautiful. </p>
<p> Making a few changes </p>
<p> By the time 2013 came around, Tina was becoming increasingly upset. She knew that she wanted to lose weight, but she just couldn’t seem to do it. As Christmas loomed ever closer, she aimed to feel at least a little bit more comfortable in herself and her body. </p>
<p> So, she decided to look for a new diet that would hopefully allow her to stop binge-eating and lose the pounds that she had built up. It was this decision that ultimately changed her life and put her on the path of fruitarianism. </p>
<p> Stumbling across it </p>
<p> As Tina began to research healthy smoothies that would allow her to increase the amount of fruit and vegetables into her diet, she stumbled across a woman who only ate fruit. She was intrigued and decided to do a bit more digging into this strange lifestyle. </p>
<p> As Tina did this, she realized that this woman wasn’t just a singular person who had decided to try out a rather different approach to eating. She saw that there were thousands of fruitarians across the globe who had decided to set up their own online community and help each other through the motions. </p>
<p> Couldn’t believe it </p>
<p> At first, Tina was skeptical. She couldn’t believe that people who only had fruit in their diet could be living a healthy and happy lifestyle, and she wanted to know more. It was during these investigations that she realized the people who had adopted this diet looked better than the people she walked past in the street. </p>
<p> They were slim but not too skinny, they didn’t look wrinkly or old, and they looked incredibly happy and healthy. The more she read about it, the more she was intrigued. </p>
<p> Endurance athletes </p>
<p> The fruitarians that Tina found on the internet weren’t just people who worked office jobs or sat in their bedrooms playing video games. A large portion of them were endurance athletes who needed to be fit, healthy, and energetic to take part in races and competitions. </p>
<p> Because Tina was concerned that a fruit-only diet would leave her feeling weak and hungry, she was amazed to see that these people were so spritely and full of life. Thanks to this research, Tina decided to give fruitarianism a go for a week. </p>
<p> The positive effects </p>
<p> Although she was worried that the transition would be difficult, Tina noticed that she felt a difference in her mental and physical health almost instantly. After just a few days her whole perspective on life had changed, and she felt like a completely different person. </p>
<p> She felt light and optimistic, and she felt as though she was “in love with everything.” Tina also felt as though she had more energy and that she could take on anything she put her mind to. In her eyes, the fruit was worth it even just for the mental changes. </p>
<p> A permanent change </p>
<p> After the week came to a close, Tina realized that she didn’t want to go back to “normal” food. She had grown to love the sweet taste of the fruit that she ate on a daily basis, but it wasn’t all that easy. </p>
<p> Because her body was so accustomed to eating meat, dairy, nuts, legumes, and more, it began to crave these things. On a few occasions, Tina decided to give in to these cravings, but she never felt the buzz from this food that she felt when she ate her fruitarian diet. </p>
<p> Becoming more strict </p>
<p> Because of this, Tina decided to become more strict with herself over the next few years. She wanted to become a fruitarian full-time, and she didn’t want to feel herself slipping. As she did this, she realized that her physical body was also changing. </p>
<p> After years of struggling to shed her excess weight, Tina found the weight just fell off her as the adopted the fruitarian lifestyle. She became happier in herself and her outward appearance, and she felt so much lighter. It was what she had always dreamed of. </p>
<p> Losing the weight </p>
<p> Within just a few months of ditching normal cooked food for a raw fruitarian diet, Tina lost a huge amount of weight. She went from weighing 183 pounds to 113 pounds, and she dropped four dress sizes. </p>
<p> Although many years have passed since that initial weight loss, Tina has found that she has not regained any of that weight since. She has noted that she can eat as much fruit as she wants, and even eat as much as her fiancé, but she knows that there is little chance of her ever gaining this weight back. </p>
<p> Finding something new </p>
<p> After two years of living a strict fruitarian diet, Tina was more confident than ever that it was the lifestyle for her. Not only did she enjoy the fruit that she was eating, but she felt better than she had ever felt in her life – and that was all down to her food intake. </p>
<p> However, she found that her fruit options were limited in her home country of Poland. She was getting bored of the same fruit every single day, and she wanted to try something more exotic. So, she decided to quit her job, pack her bags, and book a one-way flight to Bali. </p>
<p> Documenting her life </p>
<p> Moving to Bali was a big step for the interior design architect, but she wanted to dedicate her life to her fruitarian existence without the interruption of the Western world – and Bali was the place to do that. Yet, she didn’t want to cut herself off completely. </p>
<p> To keep in touch with other fruitarians across the globe, Tina decided to set up social media accounts for herself. She created a YouTube channel where others could follow her new life, and she even started an Instagram page to document her everyday actions. </p>
<p> On his own journey </p>
<p> It was through these social media channels that she first laid eyes on her now-fiancé, Simon. Like her, he was on his own journey into the realm of fruitarianism, and he was intrigued by her life. However, Simon was not from Poland or Bali. </p>
<p> He was born in Izegem in Belgium, and his upbringing had been very different. Unlike Tina, he had not struggled with his weight or struggled with his eating habits over the years. He instead wanted to transform his body so that he would be in peak condition, but he just didn’t know how. </p>
<p> A keen athlete </p>
<p> As a keen athlete, Simon had always been active in terms of his physical health. He was the kind of person who wanted to push his athletic ability to the limit and wanted to see just how far he could go. </p>
<p> Because he wanted his body to be as healthy as can be, Simon decided to adopt a vegan lifestyle during his late teens and early 20s. He removed all traces of animal product from his diet and tried to eat as organically as possible. This seemed to work for him, so he decided to maintain this lifestyle. </p>
<p> Looking for inspiration </p>
<p> When Simon was in his final year of college, he signed himself up for a local marathon race. He was determined to push his body and achieve his personal best, so tried to find inspiration online. </p>
<p> The athlete often found solace in others who were going through the same journey as him, but he also loved to watch those who had already reached their goals. He had athletic idols, and he looked to them for guidance and advice within his own journey. It was during this investigation that he came across a specific athlete. </p>
<p> A truck full of fruit </p>
<p> As Simon continued to watch videos online, he stumbled upon a marathon runner by the name of Michael Arnstein. Although Michael is known for being an impressive runner who loves to showcase his talent, he’s also known for being a fruitarian. </p>
<p> Simon only realized this when he saw the athlete stock up on watermelon and bananas for one of his races. Arnstein placed the fruit on a truck and had it follow him during an ultra-marathon. Simon was intrigued and decided to investigate further. </p>
<p> Open to making changes </p>
<p> The Belgian native was amazed to see that Michael was so successful even after removing the likes of protein from his diet, and could see that the athlete wasn’t struggling. He looked in peak health, and he looked as though he had all the energy in the world to complete his ultra-marathon. </p>
<p> Because Simon himself was open to making changes to his diet for the sake of his health and fitness, he decided to give fruitarianism a go. In that instant, he decided that fruitarianism was the way forward. </p>
<p> Changing it overnight </p>
<p> Simon changed his diet overnight and made the decision to never go back to normal food. He was ready and willing to make the sacrifice for his health, and he was ready to make these drastic changes for the sake of his athleticism. </p>
<p> Because he loved to see what other people were doing in their lives, he soon found the large community of fruitarians online and tried to find help and guidance from them. It was during this round-up on social media platforms that he stumbled across Tina’s profile. </p>
<p> Messaging her </p>
<p> Simon was impressed with Tina’s dedication to fruitarianism, and he also couldn’t deny the fact that he was attracted to her. He decided to reach out to her on Instagram and sent her a message, asking about her life and her dietary habits. </p>
<p> Tina replied to him, and they soon began sending messages back and forth for many months. After six months of talking online, Simon realized that he wanted to take things to the next level with Tina, and she wanted to actually meet her in person. So, he flew to Bali. </p>
<p> Falling in love </p>
<p> Both Tina and Simon were excited to meet each other in person, and they immediately that they had a connection. Not only did they have a romantic connection, but they also had similar views when it came to their thoughts and beliefs on the world. </p>
<p> They were both interested in fruitarianism, and they both wanted to explore some of the most delicious fruits in the world while also living as happily and healthily as possible. Before too long, they fell in love and decided to build their life together in Bali. </p>
<p> An impressive connection </p>
<p> After falling in love and realizing that they didn’t want to part ways, Simon decided to join Tina in Bali. They have since made it their mission to travel around the island and try out some of the most delicious and exotic fruits that are on offer, and they are documenting the whole thing on social media. </p>
<p> They call themselves @fit_shortie_eats on Instagram, and they have nearly 50,000 followers! As if that wasn’t enough, the couple also films regular videos for their YouTube channel of the same name, which has over 54,000 subscribers. </p>
<p> A cure for wellness </p>
<p> Simon and Tina now spend their days advocating the fruitarian lifestyle, and one of the biggest reasons for this is because they believe it is the healthiest diet on offer. In fact, they believe that a fruitarian diet can actually cure diseases and medical conditions. </p>
<p> During an interview with the Daily Mail, Tina noted that eating a fruit-only diet can help to cure depression as well as many other mental illnesses, such as anxiety. As if that wasn’t enough, they also believe that it can cure digestive issues and even cancer. </p>
<p> No scientific evidence </p>
<p> Of course, many scientists and nutritionists have criticized the couple for their way of life, and have noted that nothing can cure cancer or other similar diseases. These experts have noted that there is no scientific evidence to support their claims, but Tina and Simon don’t need evidence for their lifestyle. </p>
<p> They believe that they are living proof that fruitarianism is good for you, and that this lifestyle change can be beneficial to your health. They have also noted that they have known fruitarians who have cured their cancer through their fruit-only diet. </p>
<p> Connected to nature </p>
<p> More than anything, the couple believes that their fruitarian lifestyle brings them closer to nature. They feel as though they are connected to Mother Earth, and believe that it is their mission to taste all of Her fruits. In their eyes, the more exotic, the better! </p>
<p> Because of this, they spend most of their days foraging around the rainforest near to their home. They create videos of what they search for, how they forage for them, and what these fruits look like when they are cut open. It’s safe to say that these videos garner a lot of attention. </p>
<p> Sharing their stories </p>
<p> As well as sharing their own experiences of living as fruitarians, Tina and Simon also share other stories on their social media profiles. They like to share the experiences of other fruitarians, and state how changing up their diets have changed their lives for the better. </p>
<p> They hope that this will persuade others to do their research and make a few changes to their own food habits because they aren’t the only ones who have experienced physical and mental benefits. Alongside this, they also love to congratulate their fellow fruit-lovers. </p>
<p> Monetary benefits </p>
<p> In Tina and Simon’s eyes, the benefits of a fruitarian lifestyle have impacted their lives in more ways than they can count. They feel happier, they feel healthier, and they feel on top of the world. However, this isn’t the only way the fruitarian diet has changed their lives. </p>
<p> Eating only fruit also has monetary benefits for the couple, as they do not require a kitchen or any appliances to cook their food. As if that wasn’t enough, they also rarely have to shell out money on food because they forage for it. Because of this, they live a very minimalist lifestyle. </p>
<p> Saving money </p>
<p> The couple doesn’t just save money on food, though. They also save money on buying toothbrushes and toothpaste, because they don’t brush their teeth! It may sound strange to many of us, but the couple have avoided brushing their teeth since moving to Bali because they don’t feel the need to. </p>
<p> In their opinion, their teeth and gums are as healthy as can be, and they don’t need any outside fluoride or brushing to do what Mother Nature can do on Her own. So, does that mean they have dirty teeth? </p>
<p> High sugar content </p>
<p> Because the couple relies on fruits that are high in natural sugars, you might think that Tina and Simon would have rotten teeth that would be in desperate need of a trip to the dentist. However, that isn’t the case. The couple are of the opinion that the high levels of fiber in their diet cleans their teeth for them. </p>
<p> They believe that these fruits rid their teeth and gums of any dirt or decay, and leave them looking and feeling sparkling clean. To make sure that this was the case, Tina even went to the dentist a few years after her fruitarian transformation. </p>
<p> Going for a check-up </p>
<p> After a few years of only eating fruit, Tina made her way to the dentist for him to check out what was going on with her gums. He was amazed to see the health and the quality of her teeth, and couldn’t believe that she had achieved such a result without brushing her teeth at all. </p>
<p> In fact, Tina told the Daily Mail that the dentist had to call in his colleagues to take a look inside her mouth. They just couldn’t get their heads around the fact that her teeth were so perfect. </p>
<p> Not the same </p>
<p> Although Tina would love to inspire any fruitarian to ditch the toothbrush and to ditch brushing twice a day, she does have a few words of warning. Not brushing your teeth only works if you are going to eat raw and fresh fruit all day. </p>
<p> It’s not the same if you eat dried fruit, because this dry food can stick to your gums and rot while in your teeth. Because of this, you need to make sure that you are eating as fresh as possible – just as she is. </p>
<p> Trying something new </p>
<p> Despite the fact that Tina and Simon are extremely content with their fruitarian lifestyle in Bali, they are constantly on the lookout for something more exciting. They travel around the country and the rest of the world in search of new fruits that will tickle their taste buds and become a staple in their lives. </p>
<p> They have made it their mission to find the most exotic fruit in the world, and they also make sure that they try the best quality. They base their diet on what’s in season, and what fruit will be as high quality as possible. </p>
<p> A new addition </p>
<p> For many years, Tina and Simon have only had to think about themselves. They have only had to provide for themselves, and they have only had to forage for themselves. However, this all changed in 2018 when the couple discovered that they were expecting a baby. </p>
<p> They were over the moon with the news, and it’s fair to say that their followers were also excited for the new addition. Tina maintained her fruitarian diet throughout her pregnancy and even created special pregnancy-related videos for their popular YouTube channel. </p>
<p> Raising him the same </p>
<p> Tina and Simon welcomed baby Leo into the world on March 30th, 2019. The couple instantly fell in love with their little one, but they were also inundated with comments from people across the globe. </p>
<p> These people wanted to know if the couple were planning on raising their child on their fruitarian lifestyle, and it didn’t take them long to answer. The couple have no doubt about the fact that they will raise their child solely on a fruit diet, as they believe it’s the healthiest diet for him. </p>
<p> Ignoring the haters </p>
<p> Of course, this decision has not come without controversy. Since making the transition into fruitarianism – and especially since welcoming Leo into the world – they have been overwhelmed with negative comments. </p>
<p> Many believe that it’s wrong of the couple to force such a lifestyle on their baby, and there are even some who have called their decision child abuse. For the most part, Tina and Simon ignore the haters and brush the comments off. They let them slide off them like water off a duck’s back. </p>
<p> A different perspective </p>
<p> Shannon Cooper from Brisbane, Australia, decided to raise her kid on a zero-carb and zero-sugar diet, and the results were unreal. The Paleo diet is known officially as the Paleolithic diet and follows the rules of the caveman. The general premise is simple: If a caveman couldn’t hunt or gather it themselves, then you shouldn’t be putting it in your body. This diet consists of fresh fruit and vegetables, as well as meat and fish, and aims to completely cut out processed foods. </p>
<p> What the experts say </p>
<p> It’s safe to say that the medical world is divided when it comes to the Paleo diet. Many experts suggest that eating natural food is healthier than the processed food we eat in today’s day and age because it is rich in the minerals and vitamins we need to thrive. This diet also cuts out the likes of fat and sodium, which can both have adverse effects on our body. It was perfect for the cavemen, but is it healthy for a newborn baby? </p>
<p> A few negatives </p>
<p> Although many experts suggest the Paleo diet is healthy, there are others who have their doubts. While our cavemen ancestors were strong and fairly healthy, they were also incredibly vulnerable to diseases and parasites from the meat and plants that they ate. Alongside this, it’s also been confirmed that these cavemen also had hardened arteries, which can cause major blockages later in life. This can then lead to more serious health conditions, such as heart disease, heart attacks, blood clots, and strokes. </p>
<p> Approaching with caution </p>
<p> Of course, Shannon knew that she shouldn’t just go full steam ahead with Grace’s diet plan. She approached the idea with caution and even asked a doctor for their opinion on the matter. Was it healthy to raise a child on this diet? Because there is very little research into raising babies on the Paleo diet, the doctor could not give Shannon a proper answer. She would need to make that decision herself. She decided to go ahead with the plan, with just one exception. </p>
<p> Making just one exception </p>
<p> If Shannon were to follow the Paleo diet properly, Grace would not be allowed any breast milk. However, Shannon knew that she had to make an exception on this matter. She wanted to breastfeed her daughter for the first few months of her life, and she knew that it was the best option. After all, babies can’t eat meat and handfuls of vegetables. She would have to disregard this rule for a while, at least until she could find an alternative for baby Grace. </p>
<p> Finding an alternative </p>
<p> Because more and more people are adopting the Paleo diet, you can now find recipes for Paleo baby formula that you can make at home. Although many parents are choosing to use this, experts are warning new moms and dads against this route. In fact, one health expert has noted that certain DIY formulas can “cause permanent damage” or even be fatal to the child. That’s because these formulas include nutrients that are too complicated for babies to digest or break down. </p>
<p> Making it herself </p>
<p> After successfully breastfeeding her daughter, Shannon made the decision to gradually move her daughter onto her own homemade baby food. She did not want to buy any processed jars, because she could never know what was truly going into her baby’s body. So, she bypassed the baby food aisle in her grocery store, and instead opted to blend up fruits and vegetables into a paste that would be much more nutritious for the growth and the development of her child. </p>
<p> Making a smooth transition </p>
<p> Shannon made an incredibly smooth transition into solids. Instead of breastfeeding one day and giving her homemade food the next day, Shannon tried to incorporate solid food onto Grace’s plate one small step at a time. She would gradually up the quantities of food, and decrease the amount of times that Grace would breastfeed. This was the only way for Shannon to really know what her daughter was eating. Little did she know this diet would have a drastic effect on her daughter. </p>
<p> A special bond </p>
<p> As Grace finally made her way onto full plates of solid food, Shannon made the decision to document the food that they would eat together. She would create colorful plates of vegetables, fruit, and meat, and she would get Grace to help her prepare these meals. This was not only a great way for them to bond, but it was also a great way to get Grace involved in the healthy lifestyle she was adopting. However, those who saw the photographs were a little concerned about this. </p>
<p> Keeping them at bay </p>
<p> In fact, by the time Grace was just 13 months old, she was eating healthy meals that many adults have still not tried to this day. She would go about her day with a stomach full of chia pudding, quinoa porridge, and sauerkraut, and she was apparently loving every second of it. Yet, Grace’s Paleo diet was not just about what she was putting in her body. She was not allowed to eat carbs or sugary treats, which most children eat as youngsters. </p>
<p> No sign of illness </p>
<p> Shannon has kept a close eye on Grace throughout the Paleo diet, and it’s safe to say that she has been delighted with the results. The mom notes that her daughter is always full of life and energy, and is rarely ever ill. In fact, she has confessed that her daughter has only had one small cold over the course of her life! She believes that her heightened immune system is all thanks to her Paleo diet, and she can’t believe how much healthier she is. </p>
<p> Making a name for herself </p>
<p> Many critics have fired back at Shannon and her decision to raise Grace on a Paleo diet, but Shannon stands by her choice. She has seen the results for herself, and she has seen her daughter in comparison to other children. She believes that Grace is much healthier, and she believes that she is also much happier. Because she feels so strongly about this diet, Shannon has since made a name for herself as an author, and she has released numerous Paleo cookbooks. </p>
<p> Taking from everything </p>
<p> Shannon also rejects the notion that she is raising Grace on a specific Paleo diet. Instead, she likes to suggest that she is simply raising her daughter on a healthy diet. She takes certain elements that she likes from various different diets and ways of life, and hopes to incorporate these onto Grace’s plate. While Shannon is convinced that her daughter will stick to this diet as she grows older, there are skeptics who believe otherwise and believe that she may get jealous when she sees other kids. </p>
<p> Not stopping her </p>
<p> Shannon has been incredibly clear about how she feels on this matter. Although she is now trying to raise her daughter on a very specific diet, she knows it may not last. She doesn’t want this to happen, either. The last thing she wants is to feel as though her daughter resents her because she can’t have a slice of cake at her friends’ birthday party, and she knows that Grace will eventually experiment. Shannon will not stop her from doing this. </p>
<p> Educating her daughter </p>
<p> For the most part, Shannon wants to know that she is educating her daughter on healthy foods and a healthy lifestyle. When she gets older, Shannon is more than willing to let her daughter move away from the Paleo diet if that’s what she wants. However, she also hopes that when Grace tries these sugary foods and carbs, she will know enough to understand that these foods are not beneficial to a healthy diet. She wants her daughter to make the right decisions in her life. </p>
<p> A bout of criticism </p>
<p> Although Shannon stands by her decision to raise Grace on a Paleo diet, there are other people who aren’t so convinced. She has received huge bouts of criticism over the years from those who do not agree with her strict diet regime. Many suggest that Grace should be able to live like any other kid and try out the foods that might not necessarily be the healthiest for her, and others believe that Shannon is forcing something onto Grace that she might not want to follow. </p>
<p> Confused at the response </p>
<p> While the mom accepts that everyone has their own opinions, she does not get the logic behind these haters. She is often confused as to why parents are so shocked by the fact that she feeds her daughter healthy fruits and vegetables, while they themselves let their children eat takeout and fast food. In her eyes, her way of raising her child is much more healthy and beneficial, but she had no idea that this was just the start of the media storm that was coming. </p>
<p> Something to say </p>
<p> It seemed as though the whole world has had something to say on Shannon’s decision, and she has received messages and comments from people across the globe. As if that wasn’t enough, Shannon has also had nutritional experts reach out to her and criticize her choice. One particular expert told her that it was not healthy to give a young child such a regimented diet and that there was no scientific proof to say that the Paleo diet was beneficial in any way. </p>
<p> It’s completely normal </p>
<p> Although Shannon has listened to what everyone has to say, she has also stood by her decision. She has seen with her own eyes just how healthy, and happy Grace has grown up to be, and she doesn’t see anything wrong with her diet. She has noted that Grace does not eat anything a regular adult wouldn’t eat, so why should it be an issue? To finish up her argument for the Paleo diet, Shannon has one last piece of information to win over those who don’t agree. </p>
<p> Feeling good </p>
<p> The main thing that Shannon has discovered about her daughter is that she is healthy and happy, and there is nothing that matters more to her than that. She puts this down to the good food that is going into her gut and the fact that she enjoys what is put on her plate. She does not grumble but actually loves to eat the food that her mother makes her. At the end of the day, Shannon wants her daughter to “eat what makes her feel good.” </p>
<p> My Food Religion </p>
<p> Because she has seen the effects of healthy living for herself, Shannon now dedicates her life to helping others make changes to their health and wellbeing. As well as working as a health and wellness coach, she also has her own portion of the internet that she calls “myfoodreligion.” This is where she showcases her cooking skills, her tips and tricks, and even a few exercises to help others make the most of their bodies. But what does Grace think about all this? </p>
<p> Getting older </p>
<p> In August 2018, Shannon shared a photograph of her daughter on her Instagram page, and caught them up to date with the fact that Grace was off to her first day of kindergarten! She couldn’t believe that her baby had grown so quickly, and she noted that she was over the moon to have raised such a healthy and happy little girl. Fans were quick to congratulate the mother and daughter duo, but there were still concerns about the longevity of this Paleo lifestyle. </p>
<p> Taking a little breather </p>
<p> From the get-go, Shannon Cooper has always stood by the fact that she will never force her daughter to do something she doesn’t want to do – and that includes her Paleo diet. However, it seems as though Grace sticks to her healthy lifestyle even when she doesn’t have to. When Shannon and Grace made their way to Mykonos in Greece for their summer vacation, Grace was happy to fill her stomach with strawberries and other healthy treats. She’s been able to make healthy fun. </p>
<p> Room for more </p>
<p> Although the Paleo diet largely consists of fruit, vegetables, and meat, Shannon knows that those foods can often get pretty boring. In fact, she knows there is always room for more – especially when she has a craving for sweetness. She often shares her sweet recipes for her fans on Instagram, and it’s fair to say that her “Nut-Free No-Bake Fig & Quinoa Bars” always go down a treat. In Shannon’s eyes, there’s always room for something to round off a meal on the Paleo diet. </p>
<p> Not just food </p>
<p> However, the Paleo diet isn’t all about what you are and aren’t putting into your body. To follow Paleo accurately you need to adapt to the whole lifestyle, and Shannon often writes about this on her website and through her social media channels. She will often meditate, and she will even use natural remedies to help with her sleeping patterns and her beauty regime. She hopes that her daughter will continue to follow in her footsteps as she gets older, and continue to live this way. </p>
<p> Sharing the experience </p>
<p> One of the main reasons why Shannon feels so positively about Grace’s Paleo diet is because they are sharing the experience together. They are able to bond over something extraordinary, and Shannon is being as open and honest about the lifestyle as possible. She informs Grace of everything she is cooking or baking because she wants Grace to make her own decisions as she gets older. Of course, Shannon hopes that Grace will choose to stick with the Paleo diet, but she will not force her. </p>
<p> Tried and tested brands </p>
<p> Now that Shannon has been living the Paleo lifestyle for almost a decade, she feels as though she has tried and tested numerous companies that all promote a healthy way of life. She has been able to whittle down those that don’t quite hit the mark, and she has been able to determine which ones would be beneficial to her and her daughter’s lifestyle. These include beauty brands, fitness brands, and even a brand of organic coffee that Shannon just can’t get enough of. </p>
<p> Writing everything down </p>
<p> Because Shannon is passionate about living a healthy life, she has decided to make it easier for others to follow her tips and tricks. She has written everything she knows down and has made them into three ebooks that can be bought by those wishing to change their health and wellbeing for the better. Within these books, she writes all of her yummy recipes that all follow the Paleo diet, and she tries to make it easier for people to get rid of “poisonous” food. </p>
<p> Traveling the country </p>
<p> Yet, Shannon’s helping hands don’t stop there. As well as releasing her own books, updating her website, and inspiring others on social media, Shannon has also decided to meet fans in person. Today, she travels around the country and sets up workshops and demonstrations for those who want to get into the Paleo lifestyle. She shows them how they can make these changes in their lives, and she gives them firsthand knowledge of her own experiences on the diet. </p>
<p> The perfect pairing </p>
<p> Although many believe that Shannon focuses too much on the Paleo diet in her family, that just isn’t the case. Shannon makes sure that she always has mother-daughter time to truly enjoy their lives together. Shannon and Grace love nothing more than getting into their matching unicorn pajamas and chilling out on the couch. It’s during these moments that she gets to really learn and grow with her daughter, outside of the kitchen. It’s also during these moments that she makes sure her daughter is happy. </p>
<p> Positive feedback </p>
<p> There are many critics who still believe that Shannon should not be getting her young daughter to live a Paleo lifestyle, but it’s fair to say that her knowledge has also not gone unnoticed. Her website, myfoodreligion, is constantly inundated with positive feedback from those who have used her information to transform their own lives. Thanks to this, Shannon feels even more inspired to continue sharing her Paleo journey with the rest of the world – and this includes Grace’s journey. </p>
<p> Striving to be healthy </p>
<p> As a new mother, Shannon had a new priority in her life. Grace was her pride and joy, and she would do anything to keep her out of harm’s way. Because of this, she knew that she would have to make some sacrifices in terms of her eating habits. She didn’t want her daughter to be around anything that was going to stunt her growth or development, and decided to devise a special diet for her newborn. Shannon was determined to stick to it. </p>
<p> Good for gut health </p>
<p> Of course, Grace wasn’t put on a diet because she was overweight. Shannon decided to put her daughter on the Paleo diet because she had followed the same diet throughout much of her life. When Shannon first heard about the Paleo diet, she was impressed with the fact that it was so good for the health of your gut, and she wanted to provide her daughter with food that was completely natural. She wasn’t going to let processed baby food affect Grace’s health. </p>
<p> Not for everyone </p>
<p> The main thing that Tina and Simon know is that fruitarianism isn’t for everyone. For them, it’s the perfect way of life for them. They have been able to feel the mental and physical health benefits, and they don’t even have to clean their teeth any longer! </p>
<p> While the couple would love it if more people adopt this lifestyle and see it for themselves, they know that it’s not going to happen. So, they are going to embrace their own quirks, and let everyone else embrace theirs. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599689" filename="couple-who-only-eat-fruit-diet-fb" parent_folder="web2" url="https://teddyfeed.com/trending/couple-who-only-eat-fruit-diet-fb/">
<p> Couple Only Eat Fruit And Never Brush Their Teeth For Years </p>
<p> By Jessica Miller, Published on Apr 29, 2019 </p>
<p> One couple truly are living by the rule that they are their own people and that they should be able to live their lives as they please. They have uprooted their home, they have transformed their diet, and they have since made new and impressive changes to their existence. So, who are they? Well, this couple only eats fruit and never brush their teeth, and it’s safe to say that their way of life has raised a few eyebrows. After all, most of us couldn’t imagine removing the likes of meat, potatoes, dairy, or even nuts and legumes from our diets. How can someone survive solely on fruit? This couple has made it work, and they have noted that their lives have become 100% times better because of this new lifestyle change. </p>
<p> Of course, their wild lifestyle changes don’t end there. Thanks to their weird and wacky diet, this man and woman haven’t brushed their teeth in years. This has led many to question their oral health, their aesthetic appearance, and even the smell of their breath. How are they doing it? Why are they doing it? Should we all follow in their footsteps? This is their story… </p>
<p> The life of a fruitarian </p>
<p> Because we all choose to live our own lives, we all know what we like and want to eat, and what we don’t. For some, this means eating what they want, when they want. They will eat meat, they will eat dairy, and they’ll eat anything that lands on the dish in front of them. </p>
<p> However, there are others who don’t follow this doctrine. Many people have adopted vegetarian and vegan lifestyles over the years, and the trend has become increasingly popular. Yet, have you ever heard of a fruitarian? </p>
<p> The couple in question </p>
<p> Well, two people who live by a fruitarian lifestyle are Tina Stoklosa (39) and Simon Beun (26). The couple are currently gearing up to tie the knot and solidify their love, and they are getting ready to do so at their home on the beautiful Indonesian island of Bali. </p>
<p> Over the past few years, the couple has become famous on social media for their way of life. They have shared pictures and videos of their fruitarian lifestyle on Instagram and on their YouTube channel, and it’s fair to say that people have a lot to say about their choices. </p>
<p> A normal day </p>
<p> Perhaps the biggest question Tina and Simon are faced with is: What do you eat? A fruitarian is someone who only eats fruits and avoids all other foods within their diet. Because of this, the couple have to cater their daily dishes to suit this lifestyle. </p>
<p> For breakfast, they will drink four glasses of freshly squeezed orange juice. For lunch, they will drink a banana smoothie made from seven fresh bananas, as well as half an avocado on the side. As a snack, they will munch on two dates. Then, for dinner, they will have two glasses of orange juice and a whole avocado! </p>
<p> A whole load of benefits </p>
<p> To most of us, that seems like a very small and insignificant food experience. After all, they seem more like snacks rather than actual meals. However, this daily diet provides them with just over 2,000 calories, and they swear by the health benefits. </p>
<p> Over the course of their fruitarian lifestyle change, the couple have noted that they have become more energetic, they feel healthier than they ever have before, they look younger, and that they never been ill. In their eyes, it’s a miracle diet that they will never stray from ever again. </p>
<p> Not always been that way </p>
<p> While Tina and Simon have now thoroughly embraced their fruitarian existence, it hasn’t always been that way. In fact, they have only been a couple for a few years, and Bali hasn’t always been their home. Both Tina and Simon come from two completely different walks of life and from two completely different countries. </p>
<p> Just a few years ago they were just like every other Average Joe who would eat animal products and go about their typical 9-5. Yet, they gave this all up to change their lifestyle for what they believe is the better. </p>
<p> The life of Tina </p>
<p> Before she moved to Bali and met Simon, Tina was living in her home country of Poland. She had set up residence in Warsaw and worked as a successful interior design architect. Although she had a great job and a wonderful set of friends, Tina didn’t feel as though she was very happy in her life. </p>
<p> She knew that she should be grateful for what she had around her, but there was always something that pulled her back down to earth. No matter how successful she became, Tina never felt comfortable in her own body. </p>
<p> A binge eater </p>
<p> During an interview with the Daily Mail, Tina noted that she had been overweight for much of her life before adopting a fruitarian diet. She felt uncomfortable with her weight, and she tried every diet in the book. </p>
<p> However, nothing worked for her, and she soon turned to binge eating to help curb her emotions and make her feel better about herself and her appearance – if only for an hour or two. Yet, this was a vicious cycle for Tina, as she believed her increasing weight was the reason she was still single, and the reason that she didn’t feel as though she was beautiful. </p>
<p> Making a few changes </p>
<p> By the time 2013 came around, Tina was becoming increasingly upset. She knew that she wanted to lose weight, but she just couldn’t seem to do it. As Christmas loomed ever closer, she aimed to feel at least a little bit more comfortable in herself and her body. </p>
<p> So, she decided to look for a new diet that would hopefully allow her to stop binge-eating and lose the pounds that she had built up. It was this decision that ultimately changed her life and put her on the path of fruitarianism. </p>
<p> Stumbling across it </p>
<p> As Tina began to research healthy smoothies that would allow her to increase the amount of fruit and vegetables into her diet, she stumbled across a woman who only ate fruit. She was intrigued and decided to do a bit more digging into this strange lifestyle. </p>
<p> As Tina did this, she realized that this woman wasn’t just a singular person who had decided to try out a rather different approach to eating. She saw that there were thousands of fruitarians across the globe who had decided to set up their own online community and help each other through the motions. </p>
<p> Couldn’t believe it </p>
<p> At first, Tina was skeptical. She couldn’t believe that people who only had fruit in their diet could be living a healthy and happy lifestyle, and she wanted to know more. It was during these investigations that she realized the people who had adopted this diet looked better than the people she walked past in the street. </p>
<p> They were slim but not too skinny, they didn’t look wrinkly or old, and they looked incredibly happy and healthy. The more she read about it, the more she was intrigued. </p>
<p> Endurance athletes </p>
<p> The fruitarians that Tina found on the internet weren’t just people who worked office jobs or sat in their bedrooms playing video games. A large portion of them were endurance athletes who needed to be fit, healthy, and energetic to take part in races and competitions. </p>
<p> Because Tina was concerned that a fruit-only diet would leave her feeling weak and hungry, she was amazed to see that these people were so spritely and full of life. Thanks to this research, Tina decided to give fruitarianism a go for a week. </p>
<p> The positive effects </p>
<p> Although she was worried that the transition would be difficult, Tina noticed that she felt a difference in her mental and physical health almost instantly. After just a few days her whole perspective on life had changed, and she felt like a completely different person. </p>
<p> She felt light and optimistic, and she felt as though she was “in love with everything.” Tina also felt as though she had more energy and that she could take on anything she put her mind to. In her eyes, the fruit was worth it even just for the mental changes. </p>
<p> A permanent change </p>
<p> After the week came to a close, Tina realized that she didn’t want to go back to “normal” food. She had grown to love the sweet taste of the fruit that she ate on a daily basis, but it wasn’t all that easy. </p>
<p> Because her body was so accustomed to eating meat, dairy, nuts, legumes, and more, it began to crave these things. On a few occasions, Tina decided to give in to these cravings, but she never felt the buzz from this food that she felt when she ate her fruitarian diet. </p>
<p> Becoming more strict </p>
<p> Because of this, Tina decided to become more strict with herself over the next few years. She wanted to become a fruitarian full-time, and she didn’t want to feel herself slipping. As she did this, she realized that her physical body was also changing. </p>
<p> After years of struggling to shed her excess weight, Tina found the weight just fell off her as the adopted the fruitarian lifestyle. She became happier in herself and her outward appearance, and she felt so much lighter. It was what she had always dreamed of. </p>
<p> Losing the weight </p>
<p> Within just a few months of ditching normal cooked food for a raw fruitarian diet, Tina lost a huge amount of weight. She went from weighing 183 pounds to 113 pounds, and she dropped four dress sizes. </p>
<p> Although many years have passed since that initial weight loss, Tina has found that she has not regained any of that weight since. She has noted that she can eat as much fruit as she wants, and even eat as much as her fiancé, but she knows that there is little chance of her ever gaining this weight back. </p>
<p> Finding something new </p>
<p> After two years of living a strict fruitarian diet, Tina was more confident than ever that it was the lifestyle for her. Not only did she enjoy the fruit that she was eating, but she felt better than she had ever felt in her life – and that was all down to her food intake. </p>
<p> However, she found that her fruit options were limited in her home country of Poland. She was getting bored of the same fruit every single day, and she wanted to try something more exotic. So, she decided to quit her job, pack her bags, and book a one-way flight to Bali. </p>
<p> Documenting her life </p>
<p> Moving to Bali was a big step for the interior design architect, but she wanted to dedicate her life to her fruitarian existence without the interruption of the Western world – and Bali was the place to do that. Yet, she didn’t want to cut herself off completely. </p>
<p> To keep in touch with other fruitarians across the globe, Tina decided to set up social media accounts for herself. She created a YouTube channel where others could follow her new life, and she even started an Instagram page to document her everyday actions. </p>
<p> On his own journey </p>
<p> It was through these social media channels that she first laid eyes on her now-fiancé, Simon. Like her, he was on his own journey into the realm of fruitarianism, and he was intrigued by her life. However, Simon was not from Poland or Bali. </p>
<p> He was born in Izegem in Belgium, and his upbringing had been very different. Unlike Tina, he had not struggled with his weight or struggled with his eating habits over the years. He instead wanted to transform his body so that he would be in peak condition, but he just didn’t know how. </p>
<p> A keen athlete </p>
<p> As a keen athlete, Simon had always been active in terms of his physical health. He was the kind of person who wanted to push his athletic ability to the limit and wanted to see just how far he could go. </p>
<p> Because he wanted his body to be as healthy as can be, Simon decided to adopt a vegan lifestyle during his late teens and early 20s. He removed all traces of animal product from his diet and tried to eat as organically as possible. This seemed to work for him, so he decided to maintain this lifestyle. </p>
<p> Looking for inspiration </p>
<p> When Simon was in his final year of college, he signed himself up for a local marathon race. He was determined to push his body and achieve his personal best, so tried to find inspiration online. </p>
<p> The athlete often found solace in others who were going through the same journey as him, but he also loved to watch those who had already reached their goals. He had athletic idols, and he looked to them for guidance and advice within his own journey. It was during this investigation that he came across a specific athlete. </p>
<p> A truck full of fruit </p>
<p> As Simon continued to watch videos online, he stumbled upon a marathon runner by the name of Michael Arnstein. Although Michael is known for being an impressive runner who loves to showcase his talent, he’s also known for being a fruitarian. </p>
<p> Simon only realized this when he saw the athlete stock up on watermelon and bananas for one of his races. Arnstein placed the fruit on a truck and had it follow him during an ultra-marathon. Simon was intrigued and decided to investigate further. </p>
<p> Open to making changes </p>
<p> The Belgian native was amazed to see that Michael was so successful even after removing the likes of protein from his diet, and could see that the athlete wasn’t struggling. He looked in peak health, and he looked as though he had all the energy in the world to complete his ultra-marathon. </p>
<p> Because Simon himself was open to making changes to his diet for the sake of his health and fitness, he decided to give fruitarianism a go. In that instant, he decided that fruitarianism was the way forward. </p>
<p> Changing it overnight </p>
<p> Simon changed his diet overnight and made the decision to never go back to normal food. He was ready and willing to make the sacrifice for his health, and he was ready to make these drastic changes for the sake of his athleticism. </p>
<p> Because he loved to see what other people were doing in their lives, he soon found the large community of fruitarians online and tried to find help and guidance from them. It was during this round-up on social media platforms that he stumbled across Tina’s profile. </p>
<p> Messaging her </p>
<p> Simon was impressed with Tina’s dedication to fruitarianism, and he also couldn’t deny the fact that he was attracted to her. He decided to reach out to her on Instagram and sent her a message, asking about her life and her dietary habits. </p>
<p> Tina replied to him, and they soon began sending messages back and forth for many months. After six months of talking online, Simon realized that he wanted to take things to the next level with Tina, and she wanted to actually meet her in person. So, he flew to Bali. </p>
<p> Falling in love </p>
<p> Both Tina and Simon were excited to meet each other in person, and they immediately that they had a connection. Not only did they have a romantic connection, but they also had similar views when it came to their thoughts and beliefs on the world. </p>
<p> They were both interested in fruitarianism, and they both wanted to explore some of the most delicious fruits in the world while also living as happily and healthily as possible. Before too long, they fell in love and decided to build their life together in Bali. </p>
<p> An impressive connection </p>
<p> After falling in love and realizing that they didn’t want to part ways, Simon decided to join Tina in Bali. They have since made it their mission to travel around the island and try out some of the most delicious and exotic fruits that are on offer, and they are documenting the whole thing on social media. </p>
<p> They call themselves @fit_shortie_eats on Instagram, and they have nearly 50,000 followers! As if that wasn’t enough, the couple also films regular videos for their YouTube channel of the same name, which has over 54,000 subscribers. </p>
<p> A cure for wellness </p>
<p> Simon and Tina now spend their days advocating the fruitarian lifestyle, and one of the biggest reasons for this is because they believe it is the healthiest diet on offer. In fact, they believe that a fruitarian diet can actually cure diseases and medical conditions. </p>
