<doc id="file21599780" filename="do-vegans-eat-fish" parent_folder="web2" url="https://tofubud.com/blogs/tips/do-vegans-eat-fish">
<p> This section doesn’t currently include any content. Add content to this section using the sidebar. </p>
<p> Do Vegans Eat Fish: The Low-Down On Alternative Diets </p>
<p> Vegan, vegetarian, pescatarian, flexitarian - many people are making the switch to these and other diet alternatives for many reasons ranging from health to ethics. What do they mean? Can vegans eat fish? We're here to clear up the confusion. </p>
<p> There are many confusing terms thrown around these days to describe almost every diet choice under the sun. For the diets mentioned above, let's break them down a little further. </p>
<p> There are several types of vegetarian diet, including lacto, ovo, and lacto-ovo vegetarians; some vegans choose to consume honey, and some choose not to eat white sugar and other products that are processed by animal products. The dietary options are seemingly endless, which can be confusing. </p>
<p> Can a vegetarian or vegan eat seafood? Is fish meat? Read below for more on what defines each alternative diet and what types of foods are considered part of a vegan diet. </p>
<p> Can you eat fish on a vegan diet? </p>
<p> Do vegans eat seafood? No, vegans don’t eat fish. Veganism is defined as a diet that is entirely free of any animal by-products. At its core, veganism was created in 1944 and is a lifestyle that is void of any animal products to limit animal exploitation. </p>
<p> Nowadays, people follow vegan diets but may not always subscribe to "veganism" and may enjoy the health benefits of eating a plant-based diet. </p>
<p> Vegans don't eat fish, being an animal product, but many make exceptions to build a diet that works for them. At that point, they don't follow traditional veganism but can still enjoy many of the benefits of a "vegan plus fish" diet of their own definition. </p>
<p> Is fish vegan? No. If you eat a plant-based diet but you also eat fish, your diet falls under the umbrella of "pescatarian." </p>
<p> Alternative Fish Products for Vegans </p>
<p> If you’re a vegan, have no fear. There are plenty of fish alternatives for you to enjoy: </p>
<p> #1. Algae and mushrooms </p>
<p> You can use these two ingredients to make a plant-based alternative to fish stock. Algae has a salty and savory flavor of the sea and makes for an excellent fish substitute. You can also use soya sauce and miso paste as a fish alternative. </p>
<p> Algae can also be used to make vegan caviar. </p>
<p> #2. Tofu-based alternatives </p>
<p> Tofu is a vegan’s best friend. It’s made from soaked and compacted soya beans that have been mixed with a coagulant. It has a very bland and neutral taste, that absorbs all the flavors of the food or sauce that it’s cooked with. Cook it with vegan fish broth, ground algae and crispy bread. It makes a delicious alternative to fish fingers. </p>
<p> #3. Seitan and jackfruit </p>
<p> Seitan is gluten-based and is neutral like tofu. It can be seasoned and marinated in delicious ways. It’s great for plant-based fish fillets and burgers. </p>
<p> Similarly, jackfruit absorbs the flavor of the food it’s cooked with, and makes fantastic fish alternatives. </p>
<p> #4. Marinated carrots </p>
<p> The way you prepare the carrots is key here. Cut them into thin strips and soak them for a few hours in a mixture of oil, vinegar, algae and liquid smoke. The carrot strips absorb all of this and taste like salmon! </p>
<p> #5. Tomatoes </p>
<p> Skin, pitted, filleted and marinated in the right spices and you can get tomatoes to taste just like tuna! </p>
<p> #6. Vegan sushi </p>
<p> You can use cucumber, avo and bell pepper to make vegan sushi. </p>
<p> Other Alternative Protein: Vegan Food Products </p>
<p> If you want to follow a diet that omits all animal by-products, some incredible meat alternatives are available to up your protein intake in any vegan meal. </p>
<p> Tofu is the #1 most popular plant-based protein enjoyed by those that eat vegan diets. It's incredibly versatile, high in protein, and contains essential minerals. You can stir-fry, bake, steam, or grill tofu - it's even delicious deep-fried, like in this tasty tofu tempura. </p>
<p> Other beans and legumes like lentils, black beans, and chickpeas are fantastic sources of protein and fiber that can be eaten fresh on salads or baked into meatless burgers. </p>
<p> Nuts and seeds like walnuts, peanuts, almonds, and sunflower seeds, are high in protein and brain-protecting fats; enjoy them raw, or blend soaked cashews to make a mean vegan cheese sauce. </p>
<p> Fermented, gut-healthy tempeh is an excellent substitute for bacon with its salty flavor and chewy texture, while wheat-based seitan has an uncanny resemblance to meat in both texture and flavor. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat fish? </p>
<p> Vegetarians abstain from eating the flesh of animals and fish but generally continue to enjoy products from animals, like dairy, eggs, honey, and more. </p>
<p> A vegetarian that eats fish also falls under the definition of "pescatarian." </p>
<p> Pescatarian vs. Vegetarian Diet </p>
<p> Pescetarians follow a mostly no meat diet but also choose to eat fish.So they will eat animal by-products like eggs, dairy, gelatine, and honey. They won’t eat red meat or chicken. If you’re interested in finding out more about the health benefits of vegetarianism and pescetarianism, read this article. </p>
<p> Pescatarian vs. Veganism </p>
<p> People who are vegan but eat fish are pescatarians. A vegan that eats fish might think of themselves as vegan, but any vegan diet with fish is best classified as pescatarian. </p>
<p> Why follow a pescatarian diet? </p>
<p> Vegetarian and vegan diets can feel quite restrictive, and sometimes finding food to eat outside of your own cooking can be challenging. Although vegan food availability seems to be improving, restaurants often don't have a ton of vegan options, if any at all. </p>
<p> Fish has some incredible health benefits, as they're incredibly rich in nutrients. Seafood is exceptionally high in protein and many essential vitamins and minerals, including vitamin B12, which is commonly far too low in many vegans. </p>
<p> Why? B12 is in many plant-based foods, but our bodies don't absorb B12 from plants as readily as animal by-products. </p>
<p> Fish also provides vegans and vegetarians with high doses of other essential nutrients. Omega-3 eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid (EPA & DHA), for example, are almost non-existent in plant-based foods. These two fatty acids are crucial for optimal brain health, heart health, and proper fetal development. </p>
<p> Vegetarians can get omega-3 alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) and convert it in the body to EPA and DHA. Still, the process is complicated, leaving many vegetarians low in these two crucial fatty acids. </p>
<p> Ostrovegan diet </p>
<p> There are many people who follow a plant-based diet, who also eat oysters and mussels. This is because they feature many of the same characteristics as plants. What are these characteristics? </p>
<p> They are stationary; they can’t move around by themselves </p>
<p> They don’t have central nervous systems, and therefore can’t experience pain </p>
<p> They are not sentient beings; they have no senses </p>
<p> They can be farmed responsibly </p>
<p> Which diet should I choose? </p>
<p> Choosing to follow a specific diet is complicated; keep all of your most essential considerations in mind to find one that aligns with your values. </p>
<p> Here are a few things to consider when choosing a diet: </p>
<p> Health risks and potential improvements </p>
<p> Environmental implications </p>
<p> Following any of these diets is a choice, not a self-imposed restriction. Choose based on what you want to do for yourself and not from outside pressures. Don't worry about breaking the rules because you choose your own to live by and decide when it's okay for you to break them. </p>
<p> The term "flexitarian" defines the ever-growing complexity of dietary choices - it encompasses people that are mostly vegetarian or vegan but sometimes choose to consume animal products. </p>
<p> Final notes: Veganism with fish </p>
<p> Can a vegan eat fish? We've learned that no, a vegan who eats fish isn't a vegan, but a pescatarian. </p>
<p> A pescatarian diet can allow flexibility for those that mostly follow a vegan or vegetarian diet and who want to include fish and seafood. And even further along that spectrum, a flexitarian eats other animal by-products on occasion while mostly avoiding them in their diet. </p>
<p> There are many health benefits to pescetarianism, flexitarianism, as well as vegetarianism, and veganism. Weigh your values and determine what works best for you - there is no shame in doing what feels right for you, no matter the choice. It all comes down to personal preference. </p>
<p> Related Blog Posts </p>
<p> Many companies are updating ingredients to make vegan-friendly treats. Read our top 19 vegan candy list to find your favorites! </p>
<p> Tofu is a superfood for veggies and vegans. Read on to learn about tofu nutrition, what it is, and how good it is for you. </p>
<p> Plant-based dieters don’t need to ditch ketchup! Learn more about vegan condiments and stock your pantry with all of your favorite staples. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599788" filename="do-vegetarians-eat-fish" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/do-vegetarians-eat-fish">
<p> Do Vegetarians Eat Fish or Seafood? </p>
<p> Vegetarian eating has become increasingly popular in recent years, and people may choose to eat this way because of ethical, environmental, religious, or health reasons. </p>
<p> A vegetarian diet emphasizes plant foods and includes some animal foods, so you may wonder if vegetarians eat fish or seafood. </p>
<p> This article provides an overview of whether you can eat fish on a vegetarian diet. </p>
<p> Vegetarians do not eat the flesh of animals. Thus, by this definition, fish and seafood are not vegetarian (1). </p>
<p> Some vegetarians, known as lacto-ovo-vegetarians, eat certain animal products, such as eggs, milk, and cheese. Still, they do not eat fish. </p>
<p> If vegetarians include fish and seafood in their diets but still avoid the flesh of other animals, they’re considered pescatarians. </p>
<p> However, whether pescatarians are labeled as such may be up to interpretation. Some people may still consider those who mostly eat a fully plant-based diet — with rare consumption of fish and seafood — vegetarians. </p>
<p> Those who follow other forms of predominantly plant-based eating patterns, such as the flexitarian or Mediterranean diet, may also eat fish and seafood (1). </p>
<p> Summary </p>
<p> Since fish and seafood are considered animal flesh, they’re not technically vegetarian. If someone eats these foods while otherwise following a vegetarian diet, they’re typically referred to as a pescatarian. </p>
<p> Eating fish or seafood can add more variety to a diet and allow more options for protein sources at meals. </p>
<p> Fish and seafood are rich in protein and provide numerous vitamins and minerals, including zinc and vitamin B12, which are vital for your immune and nervous systems. It can be difficult to get enough of these nutrients on a strict vegetarian diet (2, 3, 4). </p>
<p> For example, a single oyster provides 85% of the Daily Value (DV) for zinc and 78% of the DV for vitamin B12 (5). </p>
<p> Fish, especially salmon, herring, and sardines, is also the best dietary source of the omega-3 fatty acids eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). On the other hand, very few plant foods contain EPA and DHA (6). </p>
<p> These essential nutrients are important for proper fetal development and optimal brain and heart health throughout your life (7). </p>
<p> Certain plant foods provide the omega-3 alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), which your body can convert into EPA and DHA, but it’s not easily converted. Thus, some vegetarian diets may lack omega-3 fatty acids (8). </p>
<p> The variety of vital nutrients that fish and seafood provide may be one of the main reasons that pescatarians choose to incorporate them into their otherwise plant-based eating patterns. </p>
<p> Summary </p>
<p> Pescatarians may choose to add fish to their vegetarian diets for more variety, as well as the protein, micronutrients, and omega-3 fatty acids that fish and seafood contain. </p>
<p> However, a pescatarian diet is a primarily plant-based diet that incorporates fish and seafood. </p>
<p> People may choose to follow a pescatarian eating pattern instead of a strictly vegetarian one for more variety, as well as the nutritional benefits of fish. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599768" filename="do-vegetarians-get-sick-if-they-eat-meat-9-ways-to-reintroduce-meat" parent_folder="web2" url="https://sarasveggiekitchen.com/do-vegetarians-get-sick-if-they-eat-meat-9-ways-to-reintroduce-meat/">
<p> Do Vegetarians Get Sick If They Eat Meat? 9 Ways To Reintroduce Meat </p>
<p> As a vegetarian, we have all experienced that moment when we realize there is chicken broth in the soup we just ate or bits of meat in the casserole. We also may just wonder can I binge on one burger without any negative effects. Do vegetarians get sick if they eat meat? </p>
<p> Vegetarians may experience temporary digestive symptoms when reintroducing meat back into their diets. Your “gut flora” and meat disgesting enzymes need time to readjust to the digestion of meat again. Gradually reintroduce meat products starting with broth and then small pieces of fish or poultry moving on to heavier and fattier meats last. </p>
<p> What Happens When A Vegetarian Eats Meat? </p>
<p> A vegetarian can experiance eating meat in one of two ways. </p>
<p> They’ve accidentally consumed meat in a meal. </p>
<p> The person has intentionally reintroduced meat. </p>
<p> Regardless of the way the vegetarian has eaten meat they may experience phycological and physical effects after consuming meat. </p>
<p> In this article, I will share the most common symptoms of consuming meat after being a vegetarian and how to best reintroduce meat if you choose to do so. </p>
<p> The Psychological Reaction Of Eating Meat As A Vegetarian? </p>
<p> Many vegetarians have chosen to abstain from eating meat due to their compassion for animals. If a vegetarian has eaten meat accidentally or intentionally they may start to feel physicological effects. </p>
<p> A person may feel guilt or shame </p>
<p> One may feel regretful </p>
<p> Having these feelings may cause a person to feel physical effects. Depending on how upset the person becomes they may feel nausea, lightheadedness, uneasiness, stomach pain, and headache. </p>
<p> The Amount Of Meat You Eat Matters </p>
<p> The amount of meat you eat after being a vegetarian will affect how your body responds. </p>
<p> It’s better to reintroduce meat slowly. Your body will respond much better to consuming small amounts of meat compared to a large steak, hotdogs, and burgers. </p>
<p> If the meat consumption was accidental it’s likely that the amount was small and you should not experience any negative symptoms. </p>
<p> The Quality Of The Meat You Eat Matters </p>
<p> It makes a difference if you are eating a lean piece of chicken or fish compared to a bacon double cheeseburger. The quality of the meat being consumed matters. </p>
<p> If you are going to eat meat again after abstaining for some time it’s best to reintroduce small amounts of lean meats like fish, chicken, turkey, and pork. These meats are much easier to digest and are less likely to cause any negative side effects. </p>
<p> Your Digestive System Does Not Like Change </p>
<p> Everyone’s digestive system has built its own custom bacteria “gut flora”. This “gut flora” is based on the diet that one consumes and adjusts over time to suit that person’s diet. </p>
<p> If a person stops consuming meat products the enzymes needed to properly digest meat may decrease as they are not needed. </p>
<p> The reduction of meat digesting enzymes is not permanent. Your gut is amazing and will adjust to the needs of the foods being consumed. If your diet is drastically changed like eliminating meat or adding a lot of fiber-rich vegetables you may experience symptoms while your gut adjusts to its new needs. </p>
<p> Anytime you eat something different it can upset the balance of your “gut flora” and your gut will need time to adjust. </p>
<p> Drastic changes to your diet will affect your “gut flora” and can cause a temporary upset to your body. It’s best to make gradual dietary changes to lessen any symptoms you may experience. </p>
<p> You May Be Experiencing Food Poisioning </p>
<p> It’s possible that when someone has accidentally or intentionally eaten meat after being a vegetarian that they have gotten food poisoning. </p>
<p> The symptoms of food poisoning can be severe. The most common symptoms are. </p>
<p> Stomach Cramps </p>
<p> Food poisioning can last from several hours to days. </p>
<p> Some People Have Food Sensitivity To Meat </p>
<p> A meat sensitivity may cause digestive discomfort for some people like bloating, stomach issues, nausea, and headaches. If you’ve reintroduced meat for some time and you are still experiencing discomfort start keeping a log of your symptoms. </p>
<p> You can be tested for food sensitivities to know if you should be avoiding meat permanently. </p>
<p> Some Vegetarians May Have A Meat Allergy </p>
<p> Less than 1% of the population has a meat allergy. Those that have a meat allergy will have symptoms that are similar to other allergies like runny nose, eyes, congested air passages. These symptoms are much different and can be life-threatening compared to the typical discomfort of a diet change. </p>
<p> It’s unlikely that a person would develop this allergy while being a vegetarian. Most likely a person would’ve always had an allergy to meat. </p>
<p> What Symptoms Have Vegetarians Experienced When They’ve Eaten Meat? </p>
<p> Do vegetarians get sick if they eat meat? The side effects of eating meat after following a vegetarian diet will vary from person to person. Some people may not experience any symptoms while others may experience many. </p>
<p> The most common side effects are. </p>
<p> STOMACH PAIN </p>
<p> Some people have complained of stomach pains after reintroducing meat into their diets. </p>
<p> BLOATING </p>
<p> As your digestive system tries to adjust to the consumption of meat it is common to experience some abdominal bloating. </p>
<p> NAUSEA </p>
<p> The smell or consumption of meat has been known to cause nausea in vegetarians that have abstained from meat for a while. </p>
<p> SKIN PROBLEMS </p>
<p> Some vegetarians have experienced acne outbreaks after reintroducing meat to their diets. On the other hand, many people have experienced their acne problems disappearing and clearing up. </p>
<p> HORMONAL PROBLEMS </p>
<p> Women may experiance an increase in severity of menstrual symptoms. </p>
<p> TIREDNESS </p>
<p> Some people feel tired after eating meat. It may be due to the amount of energy needed to digest meat compared to plant products. </p>
<p> ACHINESS </p>
<p> People have complained of body aches after consuming meat. </p>
<p> GUILT </p>
<p> Most vegetarians are animal lovers and suffered from guilt after consuming meat. </p>
<p> How To Reintroduce Meat After Being A Vegetarian </p>
<p> You want to reintroduce meat back into your diet but, you’ve been a vegetarian for some time. These are my tips on how to best make this transition. </p>
<p> Re-introduce Meat Slowly </p>
<p> After being a vegetarian for some time the worst thing you can do is to binge eat meat. It’s best to gradually reintroduce meat products one at a time and in small portion sizes. Start with fish, poultry and then add red meat. </p>
<p> 2. Have Vegetables Remain The Staring Role </p>
<p> Your body has been used to consuming vegetables. Keep those vegetables in the staring role of your meals. Pasta with vegetables and small chunks of chicken. A baked sweet potato, roasted broccoli with a side of salmon. Your body will adjust better when your diet remains similar to what it has been. </p>
<p> 3. Support Your Gut Bacteria </p>
<p> Eat fermented foods and take a probiotic supplement for at least two weeks before reintroducing meat. </p>
<p> 4. Start With Bone Broth </p>
<p> If your digestive system has been sensitive to meat in the past start with bone broth before moving on to solid meat. </p>
<p> 5. Use Marinades With Acids </p>
<p> Marinate your meat in acids like vinegar and pineapple juice to help tenderize the meat before consumption. </p>
<p> 6. Consider Taking Digestive Enzymes </p>
<p> If you experience a heavy feeling after consuming a meal and have a difficult time digesting food talk to your doctor about reintroducing meat and taking digestive enzymes. </p>
<p> 7. Purchase High Quality Meats </p>
<p> Look for the highest quality meat you can purchase organic, grass-fed, and grass-finished meats. </p>
<p> 8. Consider The Source Of Your Meats </p>
<p> There is a good chance you became a vegetarian due to the unethical treatment of animals. Make sure if you transition back to consuming meat that it is sourced from places and ways that align with your personal ethics. </p>
<p> 9. Give Yourself Time </p>
<p> It doesn’t need to be a race. Slowly take your time with the reintroduction of meat and do what feels best for you. Most likely you transitioned slowly to a vegetarian diet. Take the same approach when exploring adding meat back into your diet. </p>
<p> CONCLUSION </p>
<p> Do vegetarians get sick if they eat meat? </p>
<p> After not consuming meat for some time a vegetarian may experience some digestive symptoms when reintroducing meat. </p>
<p> Gradually reintroduce meat products starting with broths then small pieces of fish and poultry. Avoid eating a steak or fattier meats like burgers, sausage, and hot dogs until you are well adjusted to consuming meat again. </p>
<p> Give your gut the time it needs to adjust. The enzymes in your gut are not used to digesting meats. Over time your gut will build up the required enzymes needed to fully digest meat. </p>
<p> You should not experience any severe discomfort. If you do you may be experiencing food poisoning, food sensitivity, or a food allergy. Talk with your doctor about any symptoms you experience. </p>
<p> Whatever your reasons were for becoming vegetarian or adding meat back into your diet, it’s best to listen to your body and fuel it with what it needs to thrive. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599491" filename="E2_80_8Bwhen-and-what-to-eat-after-dental-cleaning-procedures" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.stgeorgesmiles.com/blog/2017/12/07/%E2%80%8Bwhen-and-what-to-eat-after-dental-cleaning-procedures/">
<p> ​When (and what) To Eat After Dental Cleaning Procedures </p>
<p> A funny phenomenon we’ve seen in our dental office is as soon as a patient has had their bi-annual dental cleaning, they immediately ask us how long they need to wait to eat. </p>
<p> It is an understandable concern. No one wants to undo the dental cleaning work but many people come into the office without eating for hours prior to the appointment. </p>
<p> There are a few factors which may influence when you should eat after your appointment. Check and see which of these apply to your particular case. </p>
<p> Carefully Eat Right After Dental Cleaning </p>
<p> You don’t have to wait for hours to eat after your dental cleaning. In fact, you don’t have to wait at all! That’s right, you can eat right after a dental cleaning. You just might not want to eat anything. </p>
<p> Dental cleaning can cause your teeth and gums to be sensitive. Very cold or very hot foods may be too intense for freshly cleaned teeth. </p>
<p> Fluoride Treatment Means You Should Wait </p>
<p> Okay, in most cases you can eat right after a dental cleaning. Except if you receive a fluoride treatment with your dental cleaning. </p>
<p> A fluoride treatment can help strengthen your teeth against decay, repairing the enamel on your teeth. To receive the most out of this treatment, you will need to wait 30 minutes after your dental cleaning to eat or drink. By waiting 30 minutes, the fluoride treatment has enough time to seal around your teeth. </p>
<p> What To Eat After A Dental Cleaning </p>
<p> While you can eat whatever you want after a dental cleaning, there may be some things you want to avoid. Some foods to avoid for a while after a cleaning are foods which are: </p>
<p> Citruses </p>
<p> Spicy </p>
<p> Crunchy </p>
<p> Now, that may seem like you now have no food options. But the sensitivity of your teeth will calm down in a few hours and you can feel free to eat whatever you would like. Directly post-dental cleaning, some of the foods you should eat are: </p>
<p> Also, be sure you stay hydrated. You should avoid sugary drinks, as it can be harsh on your newly cleaned teeth. Water is the best choice, as it will not stain your teeth and hydrates you the best out of any liquids you could be drinking. </p>
<p> Here at Riverside Dental Care, we take pride in caring for our patients’ oral health. So whether you are coming in for your bi-annual cleaning or some cosmetic dentistry, you can be assured that you are in good hands. </p>
<p> Meet Riverside Dental Care </p>
<p> Let us be your St. George Dentist! As the premier St. George dental office, we work hard to make sure you enjoy your trip to the dentist by providing the most advanced dental care. To schedule an appointment, please call our office at 435-673-3363 or click on the link above and fill out the Appointment Request Form. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599672" filename="easter-traditions-reason-people-eat-5256165" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.essexlive.news/news/essex-news/easter-traditions-reason-people-eat-5256165">
<p> Easter traditions: The reason why people eat fish on Good Friday </p>
<p> Sign up to our newsletter for daily updates and breaking news </p>
<p> Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign up here! </p>
<p> We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time.More info </p>
<p> It’s no secret that many of us like to gorge on fish and chips on Fridays, but are you aware that fish is traditionally what you’re ‘meant’ to eat on Good Friday? </p>
<p> Eating fish on the Friday before Easter Sunday is a ritual lots of people, religious or not, choose to follow every year. </p>
<p> It’s a tradition that is as essential to Easter, as lovely chocolate eggs, except it goes back much further - and most folks don’t even know why. </p>
<p> The custom started with the Catholics, who gave eating warm-blooded animals the swerve on Fridays, to acknowledge and do penance for the death of Jesus. </p>
<p> Good Friday marks the day Jesus Christ was crucified and, according to Christianity, Jesus sacrificed his flesh on Good Friday, when he was executed and died for our sins. </p>
<p> Sign up to the EssexLive newsletter </p>
<p> If you're looking for a way to stay up-to-date with the latest breaking news from around Essex, the EssexLive newsletter is a good place to start. </p>
<p> The twice-daily update will deliver the top news and features to your inbox every morning and evening. </p>
<p> We choose the most important stories of the day to include in the newsletter, including crime, court news, long reads, traffic and travel, food and drink articles and more. </p>
<p> Signing up to the newsletter is simple. All you have to do is to click here and type in your email address. </p>
<p> It's one of the many ways that you can read the news that matters to you from EssexLive. </p>
<p> This is why the Church advises Christians to ‘abstain from meaty flesh’ on the anniversary of the Messiah’s death, as a reminder. </p>
<p> And it’s not only Good Friday you do this (if you’re a conservative follower), as Catholic law claims that Catholics aged 14 and older should avoid eating meat on every Friday during Lent. </p>
<p> In ancient times, meat was seen as a delicacy and therefore a worthy sacrifice and only slaughtered when there was something to celebrate. </p>
<p> It was seen as something eaten during feasts whereas fish was an ‘everyday thing’, especially as most people were fishermen. </p>
<p> But our eating habits have changed considerably over the years with many fish widely viewed as the classier of the two. </p>
<p> Why is the Friday before Easter called Good Friday? </p>
<p> It's down to the actual meaning of the word ‘good’, according to the Oxford Dictionary. </p>
<p> The word ‘good’ traditionally “designates a day on (or sometimes a season in) which religious observance is held”. </p>
<p> Some people also say that ‘good’ means holy and others suggest it’s actually a corruption of ‘God’s Friday.’ </p>
<p> Is anything else prohibited on Good Friday? </p>
<p> Gambling was banned in Britain on Good Friday until just over a decade ago. </p>
<p> Betting shops have only been given permission to open up on the holiday since 2008, and racing was forbidden on the day until 2014. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599517" filename="Eat-After-a-Tooth-Extraction" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.wikihow.com/Eat-After-a-Tooth-Extraction">
<p> Log in </p>
<p> Social login does not work in incognito and private browsers. Please log in with your username or email to continue. </p>
<p> This article was co-authored by Alina Lane, DDS. Dr. Alina Lane is a Dentist who runs All Smiles Dentistry, a general practice dental office based in New York City. After completing a DDS at the University of Maryland, Dr. Lane completed a year-long clerkship in Implantology at the University of Maryland, where she focused on the advanced restoration of dental implants. She continued her advanced education by completing a General Practice Residency at Woodhull Medical Center, an affiliate of the NYU School of Medicine. She received the Woodhull Medical Center Resident of the Year 2012-2013. </p>
<p> There are 26 references cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page. </p>
<p> This article has been viewed 13,429 times. </p>
<p> Getting a tooth extraction means you’ll have a tender wound in your mouth for at least a week. It may seem daunting to think of foods that won’t hurt to eat or irritate the wound, but it’s easier than you might think. The idea is to get the nutrients you need with as little chewing as possible. Knowing what kinds of foods to avoid is also key to ensure your gums heal quickly and without complications. </p>
<p> Wait at least 1 hour after your surgery to remove the gauze and eat. It’s normal for the area to bleed for the first 24 hours after your surgery. Your dentist will have placed gauze on top of the extraction site after your surgery and may have given you some to take home. If the site starts to bleed again while you’re eating (or at any time), gently bite down on a fresh piece of gauze or a damp tea bag until the bleeding stops.[1] X Research source </p>
<p> If you plan to take pain medication, you’ll need to eat something to help coat your stomach and prevent nausea. </p>
<p> You may not feel like eating anything after your surgery, and that’s okay because the wound will need at least an hour to form a blood clot so it can stop bleeding. </p>
<p> If your dentist didn’t give you gauze to take home and you don’t have any tea, you can buy dental gauze from most drugstores. </p>
<p> Take in liquids or mushy items only for the first 2 days of your recovery.[2] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. From the swelling to the jaw pain, eating might be a little rough the first couple of days. You’ll need to stick to a liquid or near-liquid diet to get as many nutrients as you can with the least amount of chewing (and pain).[3] X Research source </p>
<p> A few days before your surgery, stock up on fruits and veggies for smoothies or buy as many pre-made shakes you need to get through the first 48 hours. </p>
<p> Incorporate small, soft solid foods 3 to 4 days after your surgery. For the first 1 to 3 days, you’ll need to follow a liquid or mushy diet. Once the swelling has gone down and you can talk or move your jaw without so much pain, you can try to eat small bits of solid foods like fish or well-cooked vegetables.[4] X Research source </p>
<p> Just be sure to chop or process solids like meats and veggies into small bits the first day you transition away from liquid or mushy foods. </p>
<p> Take small bites to avoid overwhelming your jaw. Your mouth and jaw will likely be swollen and sore for a few days after your surgery. Smaller bites will be less taxing than trying to deal with large quantities of food in your mouth.[5] X Research source </p>
<p> Let the food rest on your tongue for a bit so your saliva can soften it up. </p>
<p> Don't chew food on the same side of your mouth as the extraction. Use the other side of your mouth to gently chew your food until you’re fully recovered.[6] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. This will minimize the chance that any food bits will irritate your gums or get stuck in the site of the extraction.[7] X Research source </p>
<p> If you accidentally get food lodged in the extraction site, gently swish it out with warm saltwater.[8] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. Don’t pick at it or try to get it out with your finger, a toothbrush, or a toothpick. </p>
<p> If the food doesn’t come out after swishing and exacerbates any pain or swelling, call your dentist or oral surgeon right away. </p>
<p> Avoid sucking anything through a straw. Straws create pressure in your mouth, which can dislodge the blood clot. Not only will this reopen the wound and cause bleeding, but it will slow down the healing process.[9] X Research source </p>
<p> Using wide-mouthed straws or 2 straws isn’t a better option so try to avoid straws altogether. </p>
<p> Drink healthy smoothies or meal-replacement drinks. Add lots of water or milk so the smoothie is thin and easy to drink. You won't be able to use a straw, so make sure it's loose enough to drink normally out of a cup. If you don’t want to make your own smoothie or don’t have access to a blender, buy pre-made meal replacement shakes instead.[10] X Research source </p>
<p> Try adding cocoa powder, banana, or frozen berries to sweeten up your smoothie. </p>
<p> Don't add any small seeds like flax or chia because they could scrape your gums or get lodged in the site of the extraction. </p>
<p> Avoid making smoothies with fruits like blackberries and strawberries because the seeds may not fully break down in the blender. </p>
<p> Sip on smooth, brothy soups free of chunks or chewy bits. For pre-made soups, use a strainer to take out any noodles, vegetables, or protein chunks. You can also whip up your own brothy soup from scratch by putting well-cooked vegetables into a blender with water, cream, or broth.[11] X Research source </p>
<p> If you like, grind up the vegetables, noodles, and chicken and put them back into the soup for a serving of protein. </p>
<p> Make sure the soup or broth isn't too hot because excessive heat can irritate the wound. </p>
<p> Get whole grains and fiber with warm, runny oatmeal. Use regular oats or instant oats and avoid steel-cut varieties because they're too tough and the small bits may get lodged in the wound. Make sure the oats aren’t steaming hot when you eat them because exposing the wound to heat may increase blood flow to the area and cause the wound to start bleeding again.[12] X Research source </p>
<p> Oats contain a type of fiber that boosts your immune system, speeding up your recovery process. </p>
<p> Try making overnight oats by combining equal amounts of old-fashioned (rolled) oats and your choice of milk in a bowl or jar. Stir or shake the mixture before sealing and refrigerating it for at least 6 hours. </p>
<p> Start the day with soft scrambled eggs 1 to 3 days after surgery. Set your stove to medium heat and stir the whisked eggs as they're cooking. Once they've barely firmed, remove them from the stove, let them cool a bit, and dig in. [13] X Research source </p>
<p> You can also make soft poached, boiled, or sunny-side-up eggs. </p>
<p> Add thin slices of avocado on top for a healthy serving of omega 3 fatty acids. </p>
<p> Get your protein from soft white fish, refried beans, and pureed legumes. Beans are an excellent source of protein and fiber that will fill you up with less chewing. Buy pre-made refried beans or cook your own and mash them up in a food processor. If you eat fish, soft white varieties like sole, cod, and trout are good options.[14] X Research source </p>
<p> Feel free to add spices and herbs like paprika, cilantro, cumin, onion powder, garlic powder, and thyme for a burst of flavor. </p>
<p> Snack on soft cheeses or add them to meals. Cottage cheese, cream cheese, and soft cheeses like brie and feta are ways to get probiotics, protein, and healthy fats while the wound is healing. Avoid eating large or thick slices of hard cheeses like smoked gouda, parmesan, cheddar, and manchego because you'll have to do extra chewing. [15] X Research source </p>
<p> If you want to have harder cheeses, use a fine grater to shred them first and don't eat the tough skins. </p>
<p> Mash skinned potatoes any way you like. Skin, chop, and boil whatever variety of potato you like—sweet potato, russet, red, white, or new potatoes are all nutritious options. Just be sure to peel the potatoes first because the fibrous skins can get stuck in the gap where your tooth used to be.[16] X Research source </p>
<p> You can add solid proteins and vegetables to your potatoes after day 3—just be sure to cook and dice them well so you don't have to chew as much. </p>
<p> Add water or milk to the potatoes before you mash them to make them thinner. </p>
<p> Treat yourself with pudding, jello, frozen yogurt, or ice cream. Lucky for you, these soft, sweet treats can glide down your throat with little to no chewing! Stock your fridge or freezer with any variety of pudding, jello, frozen yogurt or ice cream—just make sure to choose varieties that are free of hard chunks and toppings.[17] X Research source </p>
<p> For instance, avoid getting a flavor of ice cream that has waffle cone pieces or chewy cookie bits in it. </p>
<p> You should also avoid yogurt that has blackberries or strawberries blended at the bottom. The seeds can get stuck in the wound. </p>
<p> Cut out all varieties of bread for at least 4 days. Bread requires lots of chewing, so you'll have to wait until your gums are strong enough and the excavation site has mostly healed. Crunchy toast can also scratch your sensitive gums so it’s best to skip bread altogether until at least 5 days to 1 week after your surgery.[18] X Research source </p>
<p> This includes all types of tortillas, flatbreads, and pizzas. </p>
<p> You may be able to enjoy extremely soft varieties of bread like sweet Hawaiian rolls after 1 week. </p>
<p> Don’t eat rice or foods with small, granular pieces.[19] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. All varieties of rice are off-limits because the small, granular grains can get stuck in the extraction site. Bulgar, quinoa, farro, barley, and couscous will also have to wait for at least 7 days or until you’re able to eat normally again.[20] X Research source </p>
<p> This includes soups with rice or grains in them. If you only have pre-made soup with these grains, use a fine mesh strainer to remove them. </p>
<p> Forego hard, crunchy snack foods.[21] X Expert Source Alina Lane, DDS Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 21 April 2020. Crackers, popcorn, pretzels, chips, seeds, and nuts are too sharp and crunchy to eat with exposed, tender gum tissue in your mouth. Snack on soft foods like yogurt, applesauce, and soft cheese for the first week or until the wound has completely healed.[22] X Research source </p>
<p> Hard, crunchy foods should be the last thing you reintroduce into your diet once you're healed up. </p>
<p> Stay away from spicy foods and condiments for 1 week. Hot sauce, spicy peppers, and spices like cayenne can irritate the wound and prolong the healing process. Instead, use salt, pepper, and mild, non-fibrous herbs to flavor your food.[23] X Research source </p>
<p> For example, pieces of dried rosemary leaves can scratch or get stuck in the extraction site, so choose ground rosemary powder instead. </p>
<p> Avoid chewy and al dente varieties of pasta. Unfortunately, most varieties of pasta are going to be extremely difficult to chew. They may even stick to the site of the excavated tooth. Penne, spaghetti, orzo, and bowties and other varieties are off-limits for at least 5 days or until the wound has healed.[24] X Research source </p>
<p> If you can't go without pasta, macaroni and cheese is a soft, easy-to-eat option. Be sure to use lots of milk or water so it’s soft and creamy. </p>
<p> Cooked polenta is also a great way to satisfy a craving for pasta while your gums are recovering. </p>
<p> Dr. Alina Lane is a Dentist who runs All Smiles Dentistry, a general practice dental office based in New York City. After completing a DDS at the University of Maryland, Dr. Lane completed a year-long clerkship in Implantology at the University of Maryland, where she focused on the advanced restoration of dental implants. She continued her advanced education by completing a General Practice Residency at Woodhull Medical Center, an affiliate of the NYU School of Medicine. She received the Woodhull Medical Center Resident of the Year 2012-2013. </p>
<p> Stay clear of hard or crunchy foods since they can be really difficult to chew after your surgery. </p>
<p> Dr. Alina Lane is a Dentist who runs All Smiles Dentistry, a general practice dental office based in New York City. After completing a DDS at the University of Maryland, Dr. Lane completed a year-long clerkship in Implantology at the University of Maryland, where she focused on the advanced restoration of dental implants. She continued her advanced education by completing a General Practice Residency at Woodhull Medical Center, an affiliate of the NYU School of Medicine. She received the Woodhull Medical Center Resident of the Year 2012-2013. </p>
<p> Soup is great choice since it's soft and doesn't require a lot of chewing. You could also try eating soft pasta. </p>
<p> Tips </p>
<p> Ask your dentist for a list of foods you should eat and avoid. Since extractions are quite common, they’re likely to have one on hand. </p>
<p> Warnings </p>
<p> Call your dentist if the wound is still bleeding, extremely swollen, or more painful the day after the extraction.[25] X Research source </p>
<p> If you experience extreme swelling that hinders your ability to breathe or if you develop a fever of over 101°F (38°C) that lasts for over 72 hours, seek medical care as soon as you can.[26] X Research source </p>
<p> About This Article </p>
<p> This article was co-authored by Alina Lane, DDS. Dr. Alina Lane is a Dentist who runs All Smiles Dentistry, a general practice dental office based in New York City. After completing a DDS at the University of Maryland, Dr. Lane completed a year-long clerkship in Implantology at the University of Maryland, where she focused on the advanced restoration of dental implants. She continued her advanced education by completing a General Practice Residency at Woodhull Medical Center, an affiliate of the NYU School of Medicine. She received the Woodhull Medical Center Resident of the Year 2012-2013. This article has been viewed 13,429 times. </p>

<doc id="file21599661" filename="eat-before-or-after-a-workout" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.powerofpositivity.com/eat-before-or-after-a-workout/">
<p> Science Explains If It’s Better to Eat Before or After a Workout </p>
<p> Science Explains If It’s Better to Eat Before or After a Workout </p>
<p> Exercises </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Power of Positivity September 19, 2020 16:03Last modified September 19, 2020 20:56 </p>
<p> To eat or not to eat, that is the question on many fitness enthusiasts’ minds. Are you still baffled as to whether you should eat before or after working out? Many experts say that there’s no easy answer because it depends on the person. </p>
<p> Do you exercise as soon as you get up, or do you wait until the evening? That’s a factor to consider for your food choices during the day. How your body will respond is based on whether you eat before or after your workout. </p>
<p> Some people prefer to wait until after exercising to refuel their bodies, called a fasted workout. If you have a bite to eat before you hit the gym, it’s known as a fed workout. Before you make your decision, here are some points to consider about each option. </p>
<p> Eating Afterwards: Fasted Workout Pros </p>
<p> Here are the benefits of a “fasted workout.” </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Fasted Workouts Allow Your Body to Burn Fat for Fuel </p>
<p> Think of your body as an automobile. Instead of gasoline, your body is fueled by carbohydrates and body fat. When you eat, your body breaks the food down and converts the fat to triglycerides and the carbohydrates like sugar and glycogen. The triglycerides are stored in your fatty deposits, and the glycogen is stored in your muscles and liver. </p>
<p> If you eat a meal before you work out, your body will use the carbs from that food for immediate fuel. Your blood glucose and levels will also be higher after you eat. Fasting workouts make your body use its fat reserves for energy, meaning you will burn more fat. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Fasted Workouts May Help You Avoid Indigestion </p>
<p> Maybe you’re one of those people who feel queasy while trying to exercise after eating. If you do a fasted exercise session, you may not get the usual nausea and indigestion. Meals heavy in carbs can also give you that groggy feeling similar to where you stuff yourself at the Thanksgiving table. </p>
<p> Fasted Workouts May Stop Exercise Procrastination </p>
<p> How many times have you been determined to get up a half-hour earlier in the morning for your exercise routine? Maybe you’ve been intent on doing a workout right after work, instead. Deciding when to eat and when to exercise can make a big difference in following your goal. </p>
<p> Before you plan your time slot for exercising, think about your usual mornings at home and your days at work. You wrestle the kiddos out of bed, make sure they are ready for school, feed them breakfast, and rush them out the door to catch the bus. Then, you grab a health shake and hope you make it to work on time. </p>
<p> While running back and forth at the office, you may be tempted to grab something not-so-healthy from the vending machine. Maybe you eat lunch while trying to finish emails or make important phone calls. No wonder you procrastinate working out after work. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Instead, you might consider a fasted workout in the morning, even if you need to set your alarm clock to get you up earlier than usual. Did you know that exercise can make your body produce hormones that boost your moods and performance? Not only can you burn some extra body fat, but you’ll have a jump start on your day. </p>
<p> Cons of Fasted Workouts </p>
<p> Here are a few reasons a fasted workout might not work for you. </p>
<p> Less Energy During a Session </p>
<p> Knowing when to eat is a vital tool for working out. You may do your best when you eat before exercising. It may boost your energy and help you have a more productive session. </p>
<p> However, exercise regimens must be tailored to the individual. Are you one of the many people who notice a less intense workout if you don’t eat beforehand? Many individuals experience this energy droop. </p>
<p> For an optimal training session, your body needs glucose for its fuel mix. If you don’t have some available in your bloodstream at the time, your body must tap into your reserves that are stored as glycogen in your muscles. </p>
<p> What if you don’t have enough glycogen in your reserves? Then, your body will turn to its fat reserves for energy. Unfortunately, fat isn’t oxidized as quickly as carbs (glycogen) in your body, so your exercising performance may be lackluster. </p>
<p> Your workout intensity will also help you decide when to eat. The average person doing a 30-minute session a day may not have an issue with fasted workouts. However, you may not reach peak performance for high-intensity training without a pre-workout meal. </p>
<p> Low Blood Sugar </p>
<p> If you are following an exercise routine, you are also probably maintaining a healthy diet. Are you trying one of the many diets that encourage a low-carb and high-protein intake? You’ll have less glycogen stored in your muscles, so your body won’t have the extra fuel it needs for a workout. </p>
<p> In this case, fasted workouts can cause a sudden drop in your blood glucose levels, and you may feel groggy and nauseous. You may even be tempted to binge-eat. If this is your experience, a fasted workout may not be the best option for you. </p>
<p> Eating Before: Fed Workout Pros </p>
<p> Here are some great reasons to opt for a fed workout. </p>
<p> You’ll See Fewer Drops in Blood Sugar </p>
<p> Do your blood glucose levels drop significantly before eating? A fed workout may minimize this condition. Knowing when to eat when you have an insulin sensitivity is essential for your health and your workout success. </p>
<p> You Will Have More Energy for Workouts </p>
<p> It stands to reason that if you want energy and strength for an optimal workout, you need fuel. Having a small meal before your exercise session will provide your body with protein and carbs to burn. You’ll notice that you can exercise harder and longer. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> Deciding when to eat for the best workout can make a difference in how many calories you burn. A pre-workout meal may help you sustain longer sessions and lift heavier weights. These benefits can result in burning more fat and sculpting a leaner body. </p>
<p> Preserves Your Muscles </p>
<p> Muscle preservation is an essential component of strengthening and toning your body. Did you know that some people lose more nitrogen during a fasted workout than a fed one? Nitrogen is critical for processing protein that builds and maintains healthy muscles. </p>
<p> Helps Burn More Calories After Your Workout </p>
<p> Did you know that your body continues to burn calories after you finish an exercise session? You are breathing harder and inhaling more oxygen, which burns more calories for a bit. This process is called excess post-exercise oxygen consumption (EPOC), which isn’t inhibited after a fed workout. </p>
<p> Fed Workout Cons </p>
<p> Here are some reasons that you might to skip the “fed workout.” </p>
<p> Name * </p>
<p> Email * </p>
<p> Submit </p>
<p> Need to Give More Thought to Your Snack </p>
<p> If you opt for a fed workout, pay close attention to what you consume. Skip milk, high-fiber, or high-fat foods, as you could get a stomachache if you work out after eating these. The Mayo Clinic suggests a smoothie, a piece of fruit, an organic energy bar, or a half of a peanut butter sandwich as great options. </p>
<p> You Might Feel Sluggish </p>
<p> Many fitness enthusiasts report feeling sluggish after eating, losing the motivation to work out after a meal. </p>
<p> Additional Tips on When to Eat in Relation to Your Exercise Sessions </p>
<p> Knowing what to eat for an optimal workout is just as important as knowing when to eat. Not all foods are created equal. If you decide that a fed workout is best for you, consider these points: </p>
<p> • Stay Hydrated </p>
<p> You lose a lot of water during a heavy exercise routine, so you should consider drinking some before you start. Keep plenty of water handy for during and after the workout. Some trainers also recommend sports drinks to replace essential electrolytes. </p>
<p> • Eat Some Carbs </p>
<p> Your body must have a certain amount of carbohydrates for energy and survival. Complex carbs are best for your pre-workout snack or light meal. Try steel-cut oatmeal, a slice of whole-wheat toast, a piece of fruit, or a low-sugar/low-fat energy bar. </p>
<p> ADVERTISEMENT </p>
<p> • Try a Protein Shake </p>
<p> For a healthy boost of protein, you can’t beat a tasty protein shake or a fruit and protein smoothie. Protein shakes are quick and easy to make. You may also enjoy a small handful of nuts, low-fat Greek yogurt, a boiled egg, or a lean slice of turkey. </p>
<p> What Should You Eat After a Workout </p>
<p> Do you do well with a fasted workout? It would help if you had some nourishment as soon as your session is complete. Rehydrate your body and replenish your electrolytes with water or a sports drink. Then, have a light meal or snack that’s high in complex carbs and protein. </p>
<p> If you choose, you can enjoy another health shake afterward. For the best post-workout food combination, try things like fish, brown rice, quinoa, beans, or a little tofu. </p>
<p> Final Thoughts on When to Eat–Before or After a Workout? </p>
<p> Have you ever finished an intense workout and felt like you could eat everything in the refrigerator? The feeling is incredibly potent if you’ve completed a fasted exercise session. Be careful not to give in to cravings. </p>
<p> If it helps, pre-portion your workout meals and snacks. You’ll have them on-hand before or after and won’t be grabbing the first thing that comes to mind. Fruit, health shakes, and low-fat protein bars are quick snacks when you are on the go from the gym. </p>
<p> Enjoy a balanced meal with protein, complex carbs, and essential fats. Eat the correct portions and keep your calories under control. Overeating and indulging in empty calories will only defeat your workout efforts. </p>
<p> Deciding when to eat for an optimal workout is a personal choice. Both fasted workouts and fed activities have their benefits and shortcomings. Before you make a choice or start any new exercise regimen, discuss it with your primary healthcare provider, a certified trainer, or a registered dietician. </p>

<doc id="file21599471" filename="eat-during-juice-cleanse" parent_folder="web2" url="https://detoxisgood.com/eat-during-juice-cleanse/">
<p> Getting into shape can seem like an uphill battle. Everything seems to tie into each other, and complex juicing recommendations can only make things worse. It can be hard to determine what can be eaten during a juice cleanse. </p>
<p> Can you eat anything during a juice cleanse? Consuming solid food is not only permitted but also encouraged to help your body get rid of toxins. During and after your cleanse, it is important to only eat vegetables, either raw or steamed. Fruits and nuts are also acceptable to snack on during a cleanse. </p>
<p> Juicing doesn’t have to be as complicated as it seems. Below, we’ll go over what foods are the best to eat during a cleanse, as well as foods to avoid and cover the topic of juice cleansing more in-depth. </p>
<p> Foods You Can Eat and When? </p>
<p> The foods you will be allowed to eat are determined by how far into your cleanse you are. Expect to stick to fruit and vegetables for the first few days to get your body used to its new diet. </p>
<p> For the first time cleansers, you may need a higher caloric intake than dieters who have cleansed longer than you have. </p>
<p> With juicing comes three separate phases that have different food options to keep your diet on track. Each phase has a varying timeline of how long it should last. The three phases are known as </p>
<p> Pre-Cleanse (2-7 days depending on your lifestyle and diet) </p>
<p> During (3-10 days) </p>
<p> Post-Cleanse(Min. 5 days & up to 2 weeks) </p>
<p> Your body is going to need time to adapt to its new diet, so if you’re used to eating pizza, you may need to get your body used to juicing before committing to it completely for 3-10 days. </p>
<p> #1. Pre-Cleanse: It’s fine to add some proteins </p>
<p> Start off with a lighter but still healthy diet at least three days before you start your cleanse. This will help make sure that your body is able to fight off future cravings better, and you’ll be more likely to stick to the plan. </p>
<p> These are other acceptable things to eat other than fruits and vegetables or high-calorie foods during your first few days before the cleanse. The list below even features healthy proteins: </p>
<p> Whole Grains: Foods such as Rice and Quinoa are perfectly acceptable, but veer away from starch. </p>
<p> Eggs: Stick with organic eggs to play it safe and try to keep away from frying them because of the oils </p>
<p> Your main intake is going to be from blended up vegetables and fruits, so packing in some healthy protein can ensure that you stay full longer, and gives you a broader palette of options to choose from in the beginning. </p>
<p> By that we mean you have more foods to choose from and aren’t stuck with picking the same options repeatedly. </p>
<p> #2. During the Cleanse: Eat as little solid food as possible, but it’s fine to include some </p>
<p> During this time, your body is going to be going through the process of detoxifying. Which means the harmful toxins in your body are being flushed out. </p>
<p> Hunger pangs are common at this phase for those that are not experienced, and it is advised to eat small healthy snacks in between juicing. This phase can last anywhere from 3-7 days. </p>
<p> Many nutritionists stress having 100% of your daily nutritional intake comes directly from juicing. Why? Because eating solid foods run the risk of slowing down the juicing progress altogether. </p>
<p> That doesn’t mean that solid foods are prohibited at this pointed. If you do choose other alternatives, then follow the list below to help give you an idea of what would be best to eat without hurting the cleansing process. </p>
<p> Extra Virgin Olive Oil ( it contains heart-healthy fat and polyphenols, which act as antioxidants. Add 1-2 tbsp of olive oil to your salad is perfectly fine.) </p>
<p> Soaked Nuts and Seeds (These are great for getting nutrients such as the B vitamins. Chia seeds have great nutritional value at 4.6 grams ) </p>
<p> The two foods above make sure you don’t branch out too far from your diet plan. </p>
<p> #3. Post-Cleanse: time to slowly re-introduce solid foods </p>
<p> This phase can take up to two weeks, and its recommended to slowly escalate to more solid foods over time. This is a very key stage! Your stomach is very detoxed at this point. So, to correctly re-introduce solid food, it will prevent you from having post-cleanse diarrhea. </p>
<p> Here is the point where you will be able to slowly start reintroducing the foods you were practically banned from eating. </p>
<p> You may feel excited to start eating meals that you originally had before the plan, but that is not recommended. </p>
<p> Follow a diet that was similar to the juice cleanse at first. This will make sure that your body has completely gone through with the cleansing process before you put in any more potentially harming food back into your system. </p>
<p> Your first day after finishing the juice cleanse should still see foods that you ate during it as your main nutritional source. On the second day, these options begin to become more viable: </p>
<p> Brown Rice (You can also eat other rice such as couscous) </p>
<p> Eggs </p>
<p> Vegan Yogurt (foods like coconut or almond yogurt can be added) </p>
<p> Notice how protein and dairy are coming back in its healthiest forms? The list grows to cover protein sources like chicken and fish only five to six days after you finished your cleanse. </p>
<p> Don’t be afraid to add in a small amount of starch like the Brown Rice above, but make sure to limit the number of carbs you gain from them. </p>
<p> You can eat carbs to keep you full for a longer amount of time, but make sure not every food you eat is packed with them. </p>
<p> Remember that throughout this entire process, it is very important to stick with purely organic food. </p>
<p> With all these being said, below is a summary of things you are suggested to eat during a juice cleanse. </p>
<p> Please note that it’s better to choose less than 5 munchable food and stick to them during your juice cleanse day. </p>
<p> Studies show that limited food options can help you reducing craving needs, also it leaves your body enough energy for the cleansing process. </p>
<p> SUMMARY </p>
<p> STAGES </p>
<p> TYPES OF FOOD </p>
<p> EXAMPLES </p>
<p> Min. 60% fruit & vegetables Max. 40% healthy solid food </p>
<p> Brown rice Eggs, Vegan Yogurts </p>
<p> Foods to Avoid During A Juice Cleanse </p>
<p> If you are interested in juicing, then you will have to follow a rigorous diet. </p>
<p> There are some food out there that would be great for juicing if they didn’t have low water content. Foods like Bananas and Avocados are terrible for juicing but make for decent smoothies or just eat directly. </p>
<p> Besides, you are better off not only using foods that have very high water-content during juicing as it will be hard to properly blend them up. But it needs up to you to do the mix regarding the taste and texture. </p>
<p> Apricots and peaches </p>
<p> Overripe tropical fruits (Pineapple, Kiwis.etc) </p>
<p> However, below are the things that you should avoid these at all cost: </p>
<p> Alcohol: Drinks like a beer can be very high in calories and carbs </p>
<p> Caffeine: Slows or stops the process of the diet </p>
<p> Processed Foods: Often high in carbs and saturated fat </p>
<p> Meat: Has great protein, but the saturated fat can pose a problem for your body </p>
<p> Dairy: During a cleanse, dairy products can prevent unwanted weight gain and promote diseases. </p>
<p> The food mentioned in the list above can certainly bring their fair share of benefits, but consuming any of these during your cleanse can seriously set the progress back. </p>
<p> Many people flock to these foods because they are unable to properly control their cravings during the cleanse. </p>
<p> How to Deal With Cravings That Come With Cleansing </p>
<p> Hunger pangs and cravings are common for those just starting off the diet. It is also why so many people stop because they aren’t very well prepared. </p>
<p> This can mean the person didn’t pre-diet properly or didn’t know the options available to fight off these problems. </p>
<p> If these problems are becoming persistent throughout your diet, then you will be relieved to know that there are outside remedies that can tide you over. These are the best foods to keep cravings and stomach aches at bay </p>
<p> Vegetable Broth: Even Bone-broth is fine for you to eat. Salt should be added in moderation, and spices like fresh turmeric can add flavor </p>
<p> Carrots </p>
<p> Salads: Avoid Caesar salads as sometimes the chicken is processed. Chia seeds are great to add in along with olive oil and vinegar. Keep your condiments completely natural </p>
<p> Celery </p>
<p> Carrots and Celery aren’t the only vegetables you can eat. Any other vegetables are fine, but seeing how some are high in water-content, it may be best to not juice them. </p>
<p> image: courtesy of KamranAydinov / Freepik </p>
<p> It is also important to remember that scheduling your juicing sessions closer together can help you with this as well. </p>
<p> Don’t push them too far apart, or else you may see yourself growing more and more tempted to quit the cleanse altogether. Don’t drink too much whenever you juice, but make sure they are scheduled closely together </p>
<p> What Does A Juice Cleanse do to Your Body? </p>
<p> The main goal of a juice cleanse to detoxify the body and help it lose weight. It can provide the body with extra vitamins and nutrients since all of your body’s energy is going to come mainly from fruits and vegetables. </p>
<p> Juices also contain a fair amount of anti-inflammatory compounds that can help with your immune system. Broccoli is an ingredient that is advised to put in for its Vitamin K that helps with the compounds. </p>
<p> The anti-inflammatory compounds work hand in hand by supporting enzymes that help with a healthier digestive system. </p>
<p> Your body may see serious withdrawals since it will no longer be gaining energy from meat and poultry. </p>
<p> This is why we added the list above to help you fight off future cravings. Symptoms of withdrawal include </p>
<p> Low Blood Sugar </p>
<p> Dehydration </p>
<p> Dizziness </p>
<p> Constipation </p>
<p> Negative Side-Effects from Juicing </p>
<p> Juicing has its advantages, but it isn’t for everyone. There are a few risks that come with juicing. Drinking large amounts of the juice too often can result in diarrhea, kidney damage, as well as getting your body used to a drastically lower calorie intake than what it was used to. </p>
<p> The symptoms of this can encompass things such as shortness of breath and nausea, and many sufferers report bouts of fatigue </p>
<p> The nutrients you take in have a risk of not staying in your system since the juice also acts as a laxative, another issue that would not pair well with kidney damage. This means you may not retain everything you put in your body throughout the day. </p>
<p> Add in the fact that lower blood sugars are a common risk, and you’ll see that cheating on your diet doesn’t sound as dangerous as before. </p>
<p> By that we mean it’s not as harmful to have prohibited foods to keep your body’s nutrients balanced. </p>
<p> These factors are some of the reasons why you need to be hesitant about starting a juice cleanse. Yes, the diet does have its benefits, but you still need to steer clear of juicing companies that claim their products can cure diseases or act as a permanent solution to weight loss. Many of those claims don’t have the proper medical backing. </p>
<p> Can You Drink Coffee While Juicing? </p>
<p> Coffee can be very appealing for those that have had to ditch it and focus on their diet. Some dieters may also believe that a single cup couldn’t hurt. </p>
<p> Although you can, you run the risk of hindering the process of getting the toxins out of your body. </p>
<p> If you are having problems with caffeine withdrawals than organic coffee with no creamer or sugars can work for you. However, it is considered better for you to wean yourself off of caffeine a few days before your fast begins. </p>
<p> Coffee isn’t completely off the table for the diet; you just need to make sure that everything you put into your body throughout the cleanse is organic. </p>
<p> Water is your best friend for helping the juice gets rid of the toxins, so try and drink the recommended eight glasses of water every day along with your juice. </p>
<p> Caffeine isn’t just found in coffee, and it’s advised that you also stay away from other possible temptations such as </p>
<p> Green Tea </p>
<p> Black Tea </p>
<p> Chocolate </p>
<p> Because de-cafe doesn’t have any caffeine in it, you will still be able to enjoy it as you would outside of the juice cleanse. </p>
<p> The Verdict </p>
<p> Eating foods isn’t prohibited during a juice cleanse, and it is oftentimes recommended for those that aren’t used to juicing themselves. </p>
<p> Each phase is different in both time and what foods you are allowed to eat to not disturb the process your body is undergoing. </p>
<p> No matter what phase you are going through, there is always an option for you when you get hungry. </p>
