<p> Sensitivity to Food by: shruti Hello, I am an advanced practitioner of yoga and prayanyam for last 5 years. I have noticed a great sensitivity to food as I am advancing in yoga. I am a pure vegeterain and have noticed my gradual disinterest in spicy foods. But I do occasionally eat at restaurants and indulge in spicy food at times. Whenever I do this, I see bad side effects... like a gastro reflux resulting almost imediately in a sore throat hoarse voice etc. Is this common? </p>
<p> I am unable to eat out completely now due to these side effects and have become very sensitive to spicy foods and sometimes when I have no choice I have to eat out BUT just CANNOT. I would think yoga is making my digestion better and I should be able to digest fried heavy foods but infact I feel my digestion is getting weaker. Is this a why a SATTVIC diet is so strongly recommended? Does anyone else also see such digestion sensitivity? </p>
<p> Thank you! Shruti </p>
<p> Editors Note Thanks Shruti for sharing your experience. As you advance in yoga the tendency to eat sattvik food is strengthened. Also, yoga practice and eating sattvik food clears the toxins from the body. Afterwards, as and when we eat junk or fast food, it is not easily accepted by the body. </p>
<p> In case, you have to eat out, you can be more selective while ordering your food. Rely more on food items which are freshly prepared without much of spices. For example rice, idli (rice pancakes), curd, salads, fruits, fresh fruit juices etc. </p>
<p> Your digestive system is not getting weaker, it is getting more efficient and is indicating to you what foods to avoid. </p>
<p> Hope this helps. Daljit </p>

<p> Editors Note Though it is preferable to be off meat if you want to adopt yogic lifestyle, you can eat meat if have difficulty giving up eating meat. </p>
<p> I will suggest start yoga and do not worry much about your eating habits, keep eating what you eat now. Eating meat is not good for advanced yoga practice/ meditation, but keep away from processed food, fast food, soft drinks, sodas and other junk food. Gradually shift to more healthy choices. <p> Weakness After Yoga by: Anonymous I am a steel plant worker and my job is sometimes hard. Everyday I do yoga for half an hour in morning but when I go to my workplace I feel weak and I am not able to get enough sleep can anybody tell me this weakness is due to lack of sleep or yoga or lack of nutrition in body. </p>
<p> Editors Note By practicing yoga you should feel more energetic. If possible, meet a yoga teacher and discuss your yoga sequence and life style. However, lack of strength can be due to any of these factors or combination of these: - </p>
<p> Lack of Sleep You must take 7-8 hours of sleep. </p>
<p> Poor Quality of Sleep Do some rhythmic breathing/ deep breathing before sleeping. Also eat a light and early dinner. </p>
<p> Poor Nutrition Eat healthy, easily digestible and nutritious food. </p>
<p> High Stress Levels Try to reduce stress levels. Let go of things and do not think too much. Start doing meditation or try yoga nidra. Lack of proper rest and relaxation can result in poor health. </p>

<p> Changes Due to YOGA by: paru I started doing yoga at 6-7 AM in the morning since last 21 days, 5 times a week. Before that for last 1.5 years I was doing aerobics(3 times/week). But I have noticed that now I feel hungry more. I feel my food digests very fast. I am worried I may gain weight due to eating more. Kindly suggest me what to do. </p>
<p> Editors Note It is great to know that you are getting hungry and able to digest your food. Yoga practice tones up the metabolism. Do not worry if you do yoga and eat in moderation, you will not gain weight. Follow the yogic principles of eating, eat a balanced healthy diet and do yoga for one hour. </p>
<p> Eat plenty of low calorie foods mainly fruits and vegetables, practice moderation in eating, avoid binging. </p>
<p> However, if your lifestyle is sedentary, remember that weight gain depends on your calorie intake and calories burnt. So take more of low calorie foods and go for a walk or a run. Adopt an active lifestyle. </p>

<p> Eating After Yoga by: Anonymous After yoga,do not eat after 30 minutes. Why do we have to wait for 30 minutes before you be able to eat? </p>
<p> Editors Note Yoga practice massages and revitalises our body organs. Also yoga increases our vital energy i.e prana. It is better to allow the body to normalise after yoga practice and this vital energy will rejuvenate our body. We may not want to load our digestive system just after a rejuvenaing yoga session. </p>
<p> We generally do not fee much hungry after yoga and can wait for at least 30 minutes before eating anything. You can drink warm milk or any light breakfast. </p>
<p> For example if you do yoga in the evening, you must ensure that you are not feeling hungry before starting yoga. Or you can take some health drink an hour before yoga so that you do not feel hungry before doing yoga. </p>
<p> Just listen to your body. If you feel famished after yoga practice, drink a cup of tea or warm milk after 15 minutes of yoga practice. </p>
<p> Hope this helps. </p>
<p> Namaste Daljit </p>

<p> Feeling Hungry While Doing Yoga by: Karishma Usually I have dinner around 7 PM, and doing my pranayams and meditation starting around 6-7 AM in the morning. Thank You.. </p>
<p> Editors Note If you can control your hunger while doing yoga it is better. You can take preferably warm milk or tea 30 minutes after doing yoga. Eat light breakfast or fruits 45 to 60 minutes after doing yoga. </p>
<p> If you cannot control your hunger it is better to take some energy drink after getting up in the morning and do yoga around 30 to 45 minutes later. Best option is to take one glass of lime juice with one or two teaspoon of honey. Other option is to drink a cup of coffee or cup of warm low fat milk (or dilute the milk). </p>

<p> Rating </p>
<p> relation of diet and yoga by: Anonymous Dear Sir </p>
<p> My question is, why yoga can not be practiced after meal? If possible please give me scientific answer. </p>
<p> Editors Note It is advised that yoga should not be done upto three hours after eating a meal. Here are my views on the subject. </p>
<p> 1. I will not be able to give you any scientific proof. However, you can know the difference yourself by experience. I suggest one day eat very light and easy to digest sattvik food and then do yoga after 3 hours. Next day you fill your stomach with spicy or processed rajasik/ tamasik food which is difficult to digest and do yoga after 3 hours. By using your body awareness you can realise the difference. </p>
<p> 2. After heavy meals you cannot do the asanas which puts pressure on abdomen. Also, you will not be able to breathe fully when stomach is full with food. </p>
<p> 3. Yoga is to be done with least effort and distraction for relaxation of body and mind. Therefore, your body should not be busy attending to digesting the food when all your energy is required for doing the asanas and focusing your mind. Can we do yoga when stomach is growling or burping? </p>
<p> 4. At the same time, you should not do yoga if you are feeling hungry. If you feel hungry before doing yoga, take some fruit juice or preferably half a glass of warm milk with honey or some fruit about 30 to 45 minutes before doing yoga. </p>
<p> 5. Dring enough water during the day to keep you hydrated for the yoga practice. </p>
<p> Hope this helps Daljit </p>
<p> Rating </p>
<p> Please help me, hungry after night shift.. by: Anonymous I am doing night shift job. I am coming to my room by 5AM. But I am very much hungry and I am eating in the morning itself. Can you please suggest how to do yoga? Is it ok to do yoga in the afternoon in between 2PM and 4PM? </p>
<p> Editors Note </p>
<p> Yes you can do yoga provided your stomach is empty and you have taken adequate sleep after doing night duty. You can do your breakfast after coming back from night shift, sleep for 7-8 hours and then do yoga. Exact timings for your yoga practice will depend on time available to you and following the time limits for not eating before and after yoga. </p>
<p> Surya Namasakra by: Bhavya Sir, I do yoga in the morning for one hour and even I would like to do Yoga in the evening. Is it wrong if I will do in the evening. I do Pranayama everyday,for pranayama I have to maintain any specific food habits if so what are the food habits I have to maintain. Bowels are very difficult to before yoga so what I do for this. </p>
<p> And my main focus is to reduce my abdominal fat and I will be working for more than 12 hours and entire day I will be sitting in front of the PC to reduce the stress which yoga pose is useful for me. Kindly do the needful. </p>
<p> Thanks and Regards, </p>
<p> Editors note 1. If you have spare time, there is nothing wrong in doing yoga in the evening. Only requirement is that you should not be too tired and stomach should be empty. </p>
<p> 2. For correct eating habits, avoid junk, processed food and eat only the food which provides nutrition. Raw salads, boiled vegetables, whole grains, milk and nuts are some of the best sources of nutrition for a yoga practitioner. </p>
<p> 3. For reducing stress, relax in shavasana and practice yoga nidra. Practice pranayama so that your breathing becomes better. </p>
<p> 4. While in office, maintain erect posture in front of the computer screen. Take frequent breaks and if possible do rhythmic breathing for a while say five minutes. </p>

<doc id="file21599470" filename="foods-to-eat-while-taking-antibiotics" parent_folder="web2" url="https://burtsrx.com/foods-to-eat-while-taking-antibiotics/">
<p> 6 Foods to Eat While Taking Antibiotics (and 4 to Avoid) </p>
<p> Antibiotics are a common way to fight infections, but many don’t realize there are certain foods to eat while taking antibiotics. </p>
<p> Antibiotic therapy is the first line of treatment for the majority of bacterial infections. Unfortunately, these drugs aren’t without side effects. </p>
<p> Rarely, they can cause a variety of unpleasant symptoms like </p>
<p> Bloating </p>
<p> Diarrhea </p>
<p> Nausea </p>
<p> Abdominal pain </p>
<p> Although these side effects are usually mild, transient, and harmless, they can become severe and signal the need for a change in medication. </p>
<p> Sometimes, patients find they can control these side effects, or even eliminate them completely, with just a few basic diet changes. </p>
<p> In other cases, it’s the food causing the problem and removing it from their diet is enough. </p>
<p> In this post, we’ll tell you about six of the best foods to eat while taking antibiotics – and the four you should always avoid, too. </p>
<p> Why Do Antibiotics Cause GI Side Effects? </p>
<p> During times of good health, your body maintains a balance of good and bad bacteria in your intestines. </p>
<p> The natural ratio of good bacteria to bad is set at just the right rate for both to coexist without causing you any harm. </p>
<p> When you take antibiotics, the very drugs you take to fight off an infection also target the good bacteria in your G.I. tract, too. </p>
<p> The result? </p>
<p> Your intestines lose the delicate balance maintained between both sides, leading to gastrointestinal upset and other unpleasant symptoms. </p>
<p> The Best Foods to Eat While Taking Antibiotics </p>
<p> Good news: certain foods support good bacteria levels in your body. </p>
<p> These are the best foods to eat while taking antibiotics. By eating them, you reduce or eliminate the side effects common to antibiotic treatment. </p>
<p> Most of these contain either probiotics or prebiotics. </p>
<p> A few of the most common foods to eat while taking antibiotics include: </p>
<p> Prebiotics — Prebiotics are the building blocks for healthy gut bacteria. When you ingest them, they help to make your gut a friendly place for more healthy bacteria to grow. Find them in kefir, yogurt, and even fortified cereals. </p>
<p> Yogurt and Fermented Milk — Both yogurt and fermented milk (kefir) increase the presence of Lactobacilli (a critical element of digestion) in the intestines. They also significantly curb overflow of bad bacteria at the same time. </p>
<p> Kimchi and Fermented Soy Products — Kimchi and fermented soy products are loaded with probiotics and prebiotics. They’re also rich in another digestion-critical bacteria called Bifidobacteria. </p>
<p> Foods High in Vitamin K — Antibiotic treatment can rarely lead to Vitamin K deficiency which may contribute to bacteria imbalances. Get more K by ingesting leafy green vegetables, cauliflower, liver, and eggs. </p>
<p> Coconut Oil — This medium-chain triglyceride contains fatty acids, which may help to reduce your risk of developing an antibiotic-related yeast infection. If you’re female, this will be especially helpful to you! </p>
<p> What Foods to NOT Eat While Taking Antibiotics </p>
<p> There are some foods you should avoid while on antibiotics, either because they interfere with absorption or because the combination can make you feel sick. </p>
<p> In most cases, these foods simply interact poorly and make the antibiotics less effective. </p>
<p> Foods to avoid include: </p>
<p> Grapefruit — You should avoid both the fruit and the juice of this sour citrus product. It contains compounds that can keep the body from properly absorbing your antibiotics – as well as other medications, too! </p>
<p> Excess Calcium — Some studies show that excess calcium interferes with absorption. For best results, stick to fermented dairy products until you are finished with your antibiotics. </p>
<p> Alcohol — Mixing alcohol and antibiotics can lead to a host of unpleasant side effects. The most common of these are </p>
<p> Increased nausea </p>
<p> Abdominal pain </p>
<p> Dizziness </p>
<p> Heart rate issues. You should avoid alcohol throughout the duration of treatment and for 48 to 72 hours after treatment ends. </p>
<p> Sugars and Yeast — For some patients (especially women) antibiotic usage may lead to candida (yeast) infections. Avoid foods high in sugar and yeast to avoid feeding the candida organism. This is especially important if you find you nearly always end up with a yeast infection after a course of antibiotics. </p>
<p> Taking Antibiotics Properly </p>
<p> Along with knowing the best foods to eat while taking antibiotics, they must also be taken as directed. </p>
<p> Improper use can render them ineffective or even cause antibiotic resistance over time. Heed these tips to stay on the right track. </p>
<p> 1. Antibiotics begin their work as soon as they enter your bloodstream. However, that doesn’t necessarily mean you’ll feel well right away. It may take a day or two before you really begin to feel better. In the meantime, discuss what you can do to control your symptoms with your doctor. Don’t end treatment early unless directed by your physician, even if you think it isn’t working. </p>
<p> 2. Always finish your antibiotic treatment as prescribed. A lot of people stop taking their antibiotics when they feel better in order to avoid further side effects. This may lead to the infection not properly clearing, resulting in recurrence and the need for another round of medication. </p>
<p> 3. Never double up on antibiotic doses, especially if you miss a dose, unless specifically directed. Taking more won’t make you feel better faster. In the case of a missed dose, simply resume at your next scheduled time and continue taking your medication until you run out. </p>
<p> 4. Women should be especially cautious when taking antibiotics. Yeast infection development is the biggest concern, but can be prevented if you stay on top of taking probiotics or eating yogurt. </p>
<p> 5. Antibiotics also reduce the effectiveness of birth control. Women taking these drugs should abstain or use a backup method until they finish treatment. </p>
<p> Conclusion </p>
<p> Doctors and researchers are now working hard to reduce the risk of antibiotic resistance each year. </p>
<p> We now know that antibiotics should really only be used when absolutely necessary. </p>
<p> Rest assured: your doctor won’t prescribe them unless they really feel you need them. </p>
<p> Taking them properly and supporting your body through the process will speed up your recovery and reduce the need for a change in medication or a second course. </p>
<p> Have additional questions? Talk to your doctor or pharmacist. Otherwise, do your best to keep your diet in check and you should be able to keep the side effects under control! </p>
<p> 28 comments on “6 Foods to Eat While Taking Antibiotics (and 4 to Avoid)” </p>

<doc id="file21599573" filename="food-stuck-in-throat" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.healthline.com/health/food-stuck-in-throat">
<p> What to Do If You Get Food Stuck in Your Throat </p>
<p> We include products we think are useful for our readers. If you buy through links on this page, we may earn a small commission. Here’s our process. </p>
<p> Overview </p>
<p> Swallowing is a complex process. When you eat, around 50 pairs of muscles and many nerves work together to move food from your mouth to your stomach. It’s not uncommon for something to go wrong during this process, making it feel like you have food stuck in your throat. </p>
<p> When you take a bite of solid food, a three-step process begins: </p>
<p> You prepare the food to be swallowed by chewing it. This process allows the food to mix with saliva, and transforms it into a moistened puree. </p>
<p> Your swallowing reflex is triggered as your tongue pushes the food to the back of your throat. During this phase, your windpipe closes tightly and your breathing stops. This prevents food from going down the wrong pipe. </p>
<p> The food enters your esophagus and travels down into your stomach. </p>
<p> When it feels like something didn’t go all the way down, it’s usually because it’s stuck in your esophagus. Your breathing isn’t affected when this happens because the food has already cleared your windpipe. However, you may cough or gag. </p>
<p> Symptoms of food stuck in your esophagus develop immediately after it happens. It’s not uncommon to have severe chest pain. You may also experience excessive drooling. But there are often ways to resolve the issue at home. </p>
<p> Thousands of people die from choking every year. It’s particularly common among young children and adults over the age of 74. Choking happens when food or a foreign object gets stuck in your throat or windpipe, blocking the flow of air. </p>
<p> make squeaky sounds when trying to breathe </p>
<p> Choking is a life-threatening emergency. If you or a loved one experiences these symptoms, call your local emergency services and perform rescue techniques such as the Heimlich maneuver or chest compressions immediately. </p>
<p> The following techniques may assist you in removing food that’s become lodged in your esophagus. </p>
<p> The ‘Coca-Cola’ trick </p>
<p> Research suggests that drinking a can of Coke, or another carbonated beverage, can help dislodge food stuck in the esophagus. Doctors and emergency workers often utilize this simple technique to break up food. </p>
<p> Although they don’t know exactly how it works, doctors believe that the carbon dioxide gas in soda helps disintegrate the food. It’s also thought that some of the soda gets into the stomach, which then releases gas. The pressure of the gas can dislodge the stuck food. </p>
<p> Try a few cans of diet soda or seltzer water at home immediately after noticing the stuck food. </p>
<p> Simethicone </p>
<p> Over-the-counter medications designed to treat gas pain may help dislodge food stuck in the esophagus. In the same way as carbonated sodas, medications containing simethicone (Gas-X) make it easier for your stomach to produce gas. This gas increases the pressure in your esophagus and can push the food loose. </p>
<p> Follow the standard dosing recommendation on the package. </p>
<p> Water </p>
<p> A few big sips of water may help you wash down the food stuck in your esophagus. Normally, your saliva provides enough lubrication to help food slide easily down the esophagus. If your food wasn’t chewed properly, it may be too dry. Repeated sips of water may moisten the stuck food, making it go down more easily. </p>
<p> A moist piece of food </p>
<p> It may feel uncomfortable to swallow something else, but sometimes one food can help push another down. Try dipping a piece of bread in some water or milk to soften it, and take a few small bites. </p>
<p> Another effective option may be to take a bite of banana, a naturally soft food. </p>
<p> Alka-Seltzer or baking soda </p>
<p> An effervescent drug like Alka-Seltzer may help break down food that’s stuck in the throat. Effervescent drugs dissolve when mixed with a liquid. Similar to soda, the bubbles they produce when dissolving may help disintegrate the food and produce pressure that can dislodge it. </p>
<p> If you don’t have Alka-Seltzer, you can try mixing some baking soda, or sodium bicarbonate, with water. This may help dislodge food in the same way. </p>
<p> Butter </p>
<p> Sometimes the esophagus needs an extra bit of lubrication. As unpleasant as it may sound, it may help to eat a tablespoon of butter. This can sometimes help moisten the lining of the esophagus and make it easier for the stuck food to move down into your stomach. </p>
<p> Wait it out </p>
<p> Food that gets stuck in the throat usually passes on its own, given some time. Give your body a chance to do its thing. </p>
<p> If you’re unable to swallow your saliva and are experiencing distress, go to your local emergency room as soon as possible. If you’re not in distress but the food is still stuck, you can have an endoscopic procedure to remove the food within 24 hours. After that, there’s risk of damage to the lining of your esophagus. Some doctors recommend coming in after 6 to 12 hours to reduce the likelihood of damage and make the extraction easier. </p>
<p> During an endoscopic procedure, your doctor can identify any possible underlying causes. If you frequently get food stuck in your throat, you should consult a doctor. One of the most common problems is a narrowing of the esophagus caused by the buildup of scar tissue, or esophageal stricture. A specialist can treat esophageal stricture by placing a stent or performing a dilation procedure. </p>
<p> Getting food stuck in your throat can be frustrating and painful. If this occurs frequently, talk to your doctor about possible underlying causes. Otherwise, you may be able to avoid a trip to the emergency room by treating yourself at home with carbonated beverages or other remedies. </p>
<p> In the future, be particularly careful when eating meat, as it’s the most common culprit. Avoid eating too quickly, take small bites, and avoid eating while intoxicated. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599473" filename="foods-you-can-eat-after-sell-by-date" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/body/a47128/foods-you-can-eat-after-sell-by-date/">
<p> We earn a commission for products purchased through some links in this article. </p>
<p> 12 foods you can eat after their 'best before' date </p>
<p> Chocolate and booze should never be binned. </p>
<p> Jan 26, 2021 </p>
<p> Getty Images </p>
<p> PSA to those of you who throw your food away as soon as it hits the Best Before date: you really, really don't need to. In fact, most of the dates on your food labels are for shops, and not for shoppers (hence 'sell by), and yet, we're still throwing away as much as £346 worth of quality, edible food from each household a year. </p>
<p> New research from Too Good To Go found that 45% of adults are confused about the meaning of Best Before labels. So, to be clear: Use Bys are important, because they refer to actual food safety, where as Best Before rules a little more flexible. </p>
<p> "The truth is that the dates given on Best Before labels are often extremely conservative and that food can have a much longer life than is specified, with no significant drop in quality," Jamie Crummie, Co-Founder of Too Good To Go, said. "The best way to tell if a food is good to eat is to look at it, smell it, taste it and to trust your own judgment.” </p>
<p> You won't ever catch a Best Before on meat or fish because this could be unsafe to eat – these will have a Use By date instead. But the food that you can be a little more flexible with? </p>
<p> Foods you can eat after their Sell By / Best Before date </p>
<p> Yoghurt </p>
<p> Bet you're surprised by that one, huh? While the texture and taste of yoghurt may change over time, the acidic nature of the product means bad bacteria are kept at bay almost indefinitely - particularly if the yoghurt is unopened, and has been stored correctly. So if your yoghurt looks, smells and tastes okay, it should be perfectly safe to eat for several weeks past the Best Before date. </p>
<p> Chocolate </p>
<p> You know that kind of white, grainy look chocolate gets when it's been hanging around for a while? It's called bloom, and is caused by the crystallisation of the fat and sugar in the bars. Honestly, it doesn't look great, and it does affect the quality a bit, but it's pretty much safe to eat - it just depends how desperate you are for that bar of Dairy Milk from last Christmas that you just found at the back of the cupboard... </p>
<p> Getty Images </p>
<p> Eggs </p>
<p> There's a really simple way to tell if your eggs are still okay once the Best Before date has passed - put them into a jug of cold water. If they sink, they're still fresh, if they sit on the bottom but point upwards, they're on the turn but should be alright, and if they float? Get rid of them, asap - the older an egg is, the longer air has been entering the shell and making it buoyant. Oh, and btw, even if the test totally fails you and you end up cracking a bad egg, you'll know about it - they absolutely stink. </p>
<p> Crisps </p>
<p> Crisps can totally go soft or stale, depending on whether you're a Kettle Crisp or Monster Munch kinda person, but they're also really high in salt, which helps to preserve them well after their Best Before dates. If you've got a half-open packet in the cupboard, seal them up with a plastic clip, and don't sweat it if you finish them a few days after the numbers tell you to. </p>
<p> Getty Images </p>
<p> Biscuits </p>
<p> Similarly, biscuits and crackers that have been left open will lose their crunch, but won't go off for a while - they'll just develop a kind of stale taste. The only risk factor is if some of the oils in the recipe go off, so be sure to give them a good sniff before you dunk them in your tea, and chuck them if they taste even remotely funky. </p>
<p> Tinned food </p>
<p> Got a stash of beans and tinned tomatoes you bought with the intention of cooking up some healthy stews and soups? Yeah, us too, and they've sat there ever since. Apparently, the dates on canned foods are around three years after they hit the shelves, but they're usually alright to use a little while afterwards. As long as they've been kept in a cool, dark area as instructed, you should be safe to use them the next time you're a little skint and/or hungry. </p>
<p> Getty Images </p>
<p> Bread </p>
<p> The Best Before on bread is just a guideline - they might not be at their best after this point, but loaves that've gone a bit hard can be eaten without any problems. For stale bread, try sprinkling with water or warming it through in the oven to soften it up - or to extend the life of fresh bread, keep it in a cool, dark place (NOT the fridge, as often recommended; this actually makes it go stale quicker). </p>
<p> Fruit and veg </p>
<p> The freshness of produce should always be on your radar, but if it looks and smells fine (and isn't unreasonably past the Best Before) you should be okay to eat it. If it's on the turn - not mouldy, but just looking a bit sad - you can still whizz it into smoothies or soups or make it into chutney. Taking precautions, but still sick of finding gone-off berries in their punnet? Try these genius hacks to keep your healthy food fresh for longer. </p>
<p> Faiz Naquiddin Abd Lataf / EyeEmGetty Images </p>
<p> Dry pasta </p>
<p> The main rule with pasta is to make sure whatever you're storing it in is airtight - if that's the case, it should last for absolutely yonks because there's no moisture to cause it to expire. So if your penne is a few days 'pasta' its sell by (sorry), there's nothing to stop you boiling it up. </p>
<p> Hard cheese </p>
<p> OK so you obviously shouldn't eat cheese - or any dairy, for that matter - that's super out of date and covered in mould, but sturdy cheeses like Cheddar and Parmesan have surprisingly long shelf lives. On the flip side, it's worth noting that you don't want to apply the same policy to soft cheese like Brie and Camembert (or the end of a tub of Philadelphia..), as the more moist a cheese is, the more likely it is to go off when your back is turned. </p>
<p> Getty Images </p>
<p> Honey and jam </p>
<p> Just like crisps are kept relatively fresh by their high levels of salt, preserves are, er… preserved by their high levels of sugar. They won't keep indefinitely, but can definitely be eaten after the Best Before, particularly if they've not even been opened yet. When stored properly, they tend to last for around 6 months - just use your common sense, and don't go eating anything that's furry round the top of the jar. </p>
<p> Alcohol </p>
<p> Mmhmm, the one we've all been waiting for. Alcohol does go off, but it often takes years, and some booze, like wine, actually gets better with age (not when opened, though). When times become desperate at a house party, you should still go careful with anything cream-based or that's been sat in direct sunlight for too long, but with hard spirits like vodka and whiskey, you won't get sick from a few past Best Before shots. Hooray! </p>
<p> Issues of Cosmopolitan UK are out now and you can SUBSCRIBE HERE. </p>
<p> This content is created and maintained by a third party, and imported onto this page to help users provide their email addresses. You may be able to find more information about this and similar content at piano.io </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599486" filename="foods-you-can-ignore-expiration-dates-2018-11" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.insider.com/foods-you-can-ignore-expiration-dates-2018-11">
<p> 15 foods you can eat past their expiration dates </p>
<p> Oftentimes expiration dates are a guideline and not a strict rule, usually referencing the quality rather than the actual safety of the food. </p>
<p> Although it is still important to check the packaging, there are quite a few foods where the date has no significance. </p>
<p> Dry, boxed pasta can last for quite some time if it's unopened. </p>
<p> Oftentimes "expired" bread is fine to eat if you don't see any mold. </p>
<p> It's a common misconception that the date printed on packaged food is a firm deadline for when you should toss it. </p>
<p> In reality, one of the only items in the US with a federally-regulated expiration date is infant formula ― which is why "sell by" dates and "best if used by (or before)" dates are more of a guideline than a rule. </p>
<p> As Paul VanLandingham, a senior faculty member at the Center for Food and Beverage Management of Johnson & Wales University explained in an interview with WebMD, these numbers refer to food quality rather than food safety. </p>
<p> Although the former dictates how long a store should display a product to ensure its highest level of quality, the latter refers to long consumers should keep a product before it loses flavor or declines in quality. </p>
<p> When it comes to these 15 food items, you can oftentimes disregard the date on the package. </p>
<p> You can keep dry, boxed pasta for one to two years past its printed date. </p>
<p> According to FoodSafety.gov, a food resource from the US Department of Health & Human Services, dry pasta can be kept for one to two years past its printed expiry date </p>
<p> Fresh (uncooked) pasta ― the kind you'll often find in the refrigerated section of the supermarket next to Italian cheese ― is only good for four to five days beyond the date printed on the packaging. When frozen, it will typically keep for six to eight months. </p>
<p> Generally, cooked pasta, whether dry or fresh, can be kept for seven days in the fridge. In the freezer, it will typically stay fresh for six to eight months. </p>
<p> When it's unopened, breakfast cereal lasts six to eight months past the date on the box. </p>
<p> In contrast, cooked cereals such as oatmeal will only keep for four to five days in the fridge once prepared. </p>
<p> "Cereals don't really go bad. There is not that much of a quality issue. If you leave your cereal box open, it can get stale, but you are still not going to get sick from it," Emily Broad Leib, the director of Harvard Food Law & Policy Clinic, told TIME magazine. </p>
<p> No matter what date is on the carton, you can use eggs within three to five weeks of purchasing them. </p>
<p> There are many ways to check if an egg has gone bad (like doing the float test or sniffing it to see if it has a sulfur smell), but generally the fresher the egg the better it tastes. </p>
<p> "In terms of freshness, a company can put a sell-by date or best used-by date on the carton. There is no regulation on that. The date is a good indicator of freshness," Kevin Murphy, food safety and sanitation expert and professor and chair of hospitality services at the University of Central Florida's Rosen College of Hospitality Management, previously told Insider. </p>
<p> "The closer you get to the date, the less fresh the eggs are going to be. But, just because you've hit that date or gone beyond it doesn't mean that the eggs are necessarily bad," he added. </p>
<p> Raw meat and poultry keep long past their sell-by date if you freeze them. </p>
<p> Although raw meat and poultry will only keep for a few days in the fridge, these items can be kept past their sell-by date if you freeze them. </p>
<p> "Food poisoning bacteria does not grow in the freezer, so no matter how long a food is frozen, it is safe to eat. Foods that have been in the freezer for months may be dry, or may not taste as good, but they will be safe to eat," according to the US Department of Agriculture report on the agency's blog. </p>
<p> Raw fish also lasts much longer in the freezer. </p>
<p> Smoked fish can last for three to six months in the freezer, and commercially frozen fish will keep for 10 to 12 months if it doesn't thaw. </p>
<p> Additionally, unopened canned fish (such as tuna) can keep for between two and five years past its printed date. </p>
<p> As with many food items, appearance and odor will tell you more about if cheese is safe to eat than the number on the package. </p>
<p> Even if cheese (whole, cut, or sliced) grows mold, it can often be salvaged by cutting around the decay. </p>
<p> In fact, white mold is normal on so-called "bloomy rind" or soft-ripened cheeses like Camembert and Brie, according to the Gourmet Cheese Detective. Most colored molds, such as the orange, blue, and green varieties, however, are not edible. </p>
<p> Of course, the brighter mold is okay when it comes to blue cheeses ― but only if it's spread evenly in a vein-like pattern and not concentrated in one spot. </p>
<p> Leafy greens, including bagged salads, can be revived with ice water if they begin to wilt. </p>
<p> For example, you can resuscitate semi-wilted greens by submerging them in ice water for five to 10 minutes. </p>
<p> You can keep dairy milk five days or more past its printed date. </p>
<p> How long milk keeps depends on its fat content. Although non-fat milk can last between seven and 10 days, you can keep whole milk five to seven days past the date on the carton. </p>
<p> If milk does spoil, it will look discolored with a lumpy texture and dispel a sour odor. </p>
<p> Canned foods have a long shelf life. </p>
<p> With the exception of highly acidic items like tomatoes and pineapple, canned vegetables, and some canned soups are okay to eat a year or two after they "expire." </p>
<p> Unopened packages of frozen fruit and frozen vegetables are good for eight to 10 months beyond their printed date. </p>
<p> Eat By Date advises that unopened packages of frozen fruit and frozen vegetables can both keep for eight to 10 months past their printed date. </p>
<p> When unopened and refrigerated, yogurt will last two to three weeks past the date on the container. </p>
<p> In the fridge, unopened yogurt can still be tasty for one to two weeks past its best by date. When frozen, yogurt will keep up to two months, according to StillTasty. </p>
<p> Bread is usually fine to eat if you don't see any mold. </p>
<p> According to StillTasty, packaged bread (such as white bread) will keep for five to seven days at room temperature if it's stored properly. Once refrigerated, it will retain its freshness for three to four days before becoming stale. </p>
<p> If you want to extend its shelf life, packaged bread will stay fresh for at least three months in the freezer. </p>
<p> Unopened jars of peanut butter can keep for up to a year past their printed date. </p>
<p> Natural peanut butter has a shorter shelf life, lasting three to six months past its date if it's stored in the fridge. </p>
<p> In contrast, a sealed jar of another popular, nutty spread ― Nutella — will keep just one to two months past its printed date. </p>
<p> Some condiments, such as ketchup and mustard, are good for a year or two beyond their printed dates if the bottles are unopened. </p>
<p> Honey only really spoils if it's introduced to moisture. </p>
<p> Honey is known for its seemingly indefinite shelf life, a characteristic that can be attributed to the sticky stuff's chemical make-up. </p>
<p> As a sugar, honey is a hygroscopic substance ― one that doesn't contain much water but can absorb moisture from the air. </p>
<p> "Honey in its natural form is very low-moisture," Amina Harris, executive director of the Honey and Pollination Center at the Robert Mondavi Institute at the University of California, Davis, told Smithsonian Magazine. "Very few bacteria or microorganisms can survive in an environment like that, they just die. They're smothered by it, essentially." </p>
<p> That being said, honey can spoil if it's introduced to moisture. Still, contrary to popular belief, just because a jar of honey crystallizes doesn't mean it's gone bad. The grainy texture is caused by glucose molecules as they separate from water. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599532" filename="foods-you-can-leave-out-overnight-2018-12" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.insider.com/foods-you-can-leave-out-overnight-2018-12">
<p> 7 foods that you can leave out overnight </p>
<p> The USDA says food that has been left out of the fridge for more than two hours should be thrown away. </p>
<p> At room temperature, bacteria grows incredibly fast and can make you sick. </p>
<p> Reheating something that has been sitting at room temperature for longer than two hours won't be safe from bacteria. </p>
<p> There are some types of foods that don't necessarily need to be stored in the fridge and some things like bread, that shouldn't be kept in the fridge at all, so if you leave them out overnight, they're still safe to eat. </p>
<p> You've probably accidentally left food out on your kitchen counter overnight at least once or twice, but is it still safe to eat? </p>
<p> According to the USDA, food that has been left out of the fridge for more than two hours should be thrown away. That's because between 40° F and 140° F (what the USDA calls the "Danger Zone"), bacteria grows incredibly fast and can make you sick. </p>
<p> However, there are types of foods that don't necessarily need to be stored in the refrigerator or won't be as harmful to you if you leave them out for a while. Some foods, like bread, shouldn't even be stored in the fridge in the first place. </p>
<p> Read on to find out what foods are still safe to eat after they've been left out overnight and be sure to throw out anything else that's been left out for longer than two hours, or one hour if it's a hot day. </p>
<p> Bread shouldn't be put in the refrigerator at all. </p>
<p> Though some people believe putting bread in the fridge makes it last longer, it actually does the opposite. Bread kept in the fridge goes stale, according to StillTasty.com, because the cooler temperatures dry it out. </p>
<p> On the counter, bread generally lasts for about a week, but freezing your bread is a safe way to help it last longer. </p>
<p> Certain kinds of pies are safe to leave out for a couple of days before refrigerating them. </p>
<p> Fruit pies are safe to leave at room temperature for two days before refrigerating them as long as they're covered. After that, they can be put in the fridge for another two days before going bad, according to kitchn. </p>
<p> However, pies that have custard or cream fillings should be kept refrigerated at all times and pies made with eggs (such as pumpkin pie or pecan pie) can be warmed up to be served, but should be stored in the fridge. </p>
<p> Pasteurized, salted butter can be left at room temperature for a couple of days. </p>
<p> Though other dairy products have to be stored at or below 40° F to avoid going bad, pasteurized, salted butter is the exception because of its high-fat content, according to an FDA report. </p>
<p> Even though it is unnecessary, refrigeration does help the butter last longer, according to State Food Safety, which also said butter can be left out from a couple of days up to 10 days. </p>
<p> However, homemade or unpasteurized butter should always be kept refrigerated. </p>
<p> Certain condiments don't need to be refrigerated all the time, even after they've been opened. </p>
<p> Condiments like soy sauce, vinegar-based hot sauces and honey shouldn't be refrigerated at all, according to MSN. Meanwhile, ketchup and mustard can be kept in the fridge, but won't be harmful if they're left out overnight, even if they've been opened. </p>
<p> Dijon and horseradish-based mustards should stay in the fridge, but because yellow mustard doesn't have ingredients that spoil, it can stay out, though it may lose flavor, according to the outlet. </p>
<p> Opened containers of mayonnaise, tartar sauce and horseradish should be kept in the fridge. If they are kept at a temperature of 50 °F or more for longer than eight hours, they should be thrown away, according to FoodSafety.gov. </p>
<p> Cheeses can stay out for up to six hours and hard cheeses can stay out even longer. </p>
<p> According to research done in Wisconsin, cheese can stay out for up to six hours at 70°F or cooler without growing life-threatening amounts of bacteria. Hard cheeses like parmesan can even be out for 24 hours safely, Marianne Smukowski from the Wisconsin Center for Dairy Research told Bon Appetit. </p>
<p> However, cheeses may also start to dry out and not look as appealing if they are left out for more than a couple of hours. </p>
<p> There are many raw, uncut fruits that don't have to be stored in the fridge at all. </p>
<p> Bananas, grapefruit, lemons, limes, mangoes, oranges, papaya, pineapple, pomegranates, watermelon, and apples can all be kept out of the fridge, according to Spoon University. However, after seven days, you should move your apples to the fridge to keep them fresh. </p>
<p> Other fruits that should start on your counter, but be moved to your fridge include avocados, peaches, plums, nectarines, and kiwi. </p>
<p> If you cut or cook any of these fruits, though, they should be immediately stored in the fridge to avoid bacterial growth. </p>
<p> Some raw, uncut vegetables can be stored on your counter instead of the fridge. </p>
<p> Peppers, cucumbers, eggplant, garlic, and ginger don't have to be stored in your fridge and onions, tomatoes and potatoes should not be stored in the fridge at all, according to Spoon University. </p>
<p> Onions and tomatoes can start to grow mold if they're kept in the fridge and the cooler temperatures break down the starch in potatoes and make them get grainy. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599541" filename="foods-you-cant-eat-if-you-have-high-uric-acid" parent_folder="web2" url="https://steptohealth.com/foods-you-cant-eat-if-you-have-high-uric-acid/">
<p> Foods You Can't Eat if You Have High Uric Acid </p>
<p> 5 minutes </p>
<p> If you have high uric acid, it's important to take care and watch your diet, weight, and some habits. Thanks to a balanced diet you can keep uricemia under control. </p>
<p> Last update: 12 June, 2020 </p>
<p> High uric acid or hyperuricemia has traditionally been related to people who love excesses, both in eating and drinking. Although we know that it depends on a variety of factors, diet change is important if you have high uric acid. </p>
<p> Hyperuricemia or high uric acid </p>
<p> Uric acid is a compound made up of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and hydrogen that’s created when your body breaks down purines. Purines form naturally in the body, and they’re also found in some foods. </p>
<p> Uric acid doesn’t cause health problems when you have normal levels, since it’s excreted by the kidney. However, sometimes, for various reasons, your uric acid levels can increase beyond acceptable levels. </p>
<p> When you have high uric acid, one of the most feared symptoms is gout. However, the negative consequences of hyperuricemia can be even more serious. It’s related to a higher risk of kidney and cardiovascular problems, and chronic arthritic damage. </p>
<p> Foods that have high uric acid </p>
<p> You should correct an excess of uric acid to avoid long term health problems and loss of quality of life. Changing a few dietary habits can be very beneficial. </p>
<p> If you suffer from this health problem, you should avoid some foods. Although you should keep in mind that we’re not talking about prohibited foods, just foods you should limit. </p>
<p> Purine rich foods </p>
<p> Purines are components that naturally form in the body. When they break down they turn into uric acid. Therefore, controlling your intake of high purine foods can help reduce the amount of uric acid in your blood. Especially during gout outbreaks. </p>
<p> The following are high purine foods: </p>
<p> Liver, kidney, sweetbread, and other organs. </p>
<p> Red meat from cows, sheep, and pigs. </p>
<p> Fatty fish and seafood like sardines, anchovies, tuna, prawns, shrimp, and crab. You shouldn’t get rid of all of them, because then you’d be missing out on their benefits. But you should be eating moderate portions. </p>
<p> Sausages. </p>
<p> Very fermented cheeses. </p>
<p> Some vegetables like asparagus, peas, spinach, and tomato are high in purines. A sensible option is to moderate your consumption of this type of vegetables to once or twice a week. </p>
<p> Fatty foods </p>
<p> It’s harder to eliminate urates when you eat a lot of fat. For this reason, you should control the fat in your diet if you have high uric acid. </p>
<p> The best option, as is almost always the case, is to use extra virgin olive oil. You can use it raw to dress your dishes, and also for cooking. It’s better to completely eliminate processed foods that can have trans or hydrogenated fats, and reduce your saturated fat intake. </p>
<p> Fructose and sugary drinks </p>
<p> Fructose is the only carbohydrate that has been shown to have a direct relation to metabolizing uric acid. In this case, we’re talking about sodas, fruit juice, and other sweetened drinks. The risk of gout is double in people that drink two or more sugary drinks a day, when compared to those who drink less than one per month. </p>
<p> However, we don’t know the exact reason for this increase in uric acid. It could be due to other ingredients in the drinks besides fructose, or because of other unhealthy habits. </p>
<p> Alcohol </p>
<p> In the case of alcoholic drinks, there’s no doubt. The risk of developing gout is more than double among men who drink 50 grams or more of alcohol per day, compared with those who don’t drink alcohol. </p>
<p> Both in men and women, alcohol consumption is related to higher rates of uricemia and gout. In fact, the risk is higher in women. </p>
<p> This is because consuming a lot of alcohol in a short time increases lactic acid concentration. This makes it hard for the kidney to eliminate uric acid. On the other hand, if you chronically drink alcohol, the problem comes from high levels of purines. </p>
<p> Dietary steps to keep in mind </p>
<p> When we talk about hyperuricemia, we’re not just talking about foods you can’t eat. There are other dietary steps and related aspects you can change to improve your situation: </p>
<p> It doesn’t help to have a weight higher than what is considered healthy. If you’re overweight, you should take measures for gradual weight loss. </p>
<p> You shouldn’t fast or extremely restrict your calories, since this can also increase your levels. </p>
<p> Stay hydrated. You should drink about 2 liters (8 cups) of water per day. </p>
<p> All of these steps should accompany your specific medical treatment laid out by a medical professional. </p>
<p> In summary </p>
<p> You should limit your consumption of red meat, fatty fish, sugary drinks, and alcohol, if you suffer from hyperuricemia. Eating in moderation, drinking a lot of water, and eating a diet full of fresh fruits and vegetables, whole grains, skim milk, and yogurt, will be a big help to combat this health problem. </p>
<p> Álvarez Larido B, Alonso Valdivielso JL. [Hyperuricemia and gout; the role of diet]. Nutrición Hospitalaria. Abril 2014. 1;29(4):760-70. </p>
<p> Jamnik J, et al. Fructose intake and risk of gout and hyperuricemia: a systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies. BMJ Open. Octubre 2016. 3;6 (10). </p>
<p> Rongrong L. et al. Dietary factors and risk of gout and hyperuricemia: a meta-analysis and systematic review. Asia Pacific Journal of clinical Nutrition . 2018;27(6). 1344-1356. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599536" filename="foods-you-should-and-shouldnt-eat-after-breaking-a-water-fast" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.thelist.com/198470/foods-you-should-and-shouldnt-eat-after-breaking-a-water-fast/">
<p> Foods You Should And Shouldn't Eat After Breaking A Water Fast </p>
<p> So you've had exclusively water for quite some time and now it's breakfast — or break fast if it's not the morning. But what should you eat now? It's important not to reload your body with the wrong things, and it's also important not to reload the wrong way. Perhaps most importantly, though, you need to be aware that while there are some health benefits associated with water fasting, the risks and dangers can be quite high, including dehydration, worsening of medical symptoms, muscle loss, and other health concerns (via Healthline). </p>
<p> After a brief water fast, some ideal foods to eat for your first meal are: vitamin-rich juices, raw fruits and veggies, broths, fermented foods like unsweetened yogurt and kefir, leafy greens, starchy veggies like potatoes, and healthy fats like avocados, eggs, and coconut oil. These foods are easy to digest and packed with all sorts of nutrients your body needs after going without food. For your second meal you'd be wise to eat things like beans, whole grains, nuts and seeds, as well as meat and poultry (via VitaCost). </p>
<p> The dos and don'ts of breaking a fast </p>
<p> Shutterstock </p>
<p> When coming out of a longer fast, it is recommended that you gradually add food back into the diet day-by-day. Livestrong suggests that on day one after a water fast, a blend of water and sugar-free juice high that's in vitamins can be consumed in the morning, and broth soups can be added the second part of the day. On day two, continue with liquids and add in some yogurts and dairy in the evening. On day three, eat fresh produce, soup, and dairy, then add in meats and eggs in the evening. On the last day, eat whatever you want, though you'll probably want to avoid junk food and the like, for obvious reasons. </p>
<p> There are some definite don'ts when beginning to eat again after a water fast. This is especially important if you are coming out of a long period of fasting (five or more days). There can be some serious health consequences for incorrect refeeding. It is recommended that before and after partaking in a long fast you check in with a doctor, as one of the most serious problems that can occur is an illness called refeeding syndrome, which can cause severe and dangerous effects to your heart, kidneys, nervous system and more (via Medical News Today). </p>
<p> What not to eat after a fast </p>
<p> Shutterstock </p>
<p> Fasting plans don't focus too much on what not to eat after the whole thing is over, but it's certainly not an excuse to binge on junk. Eating unhealthy, highly processed food, and foods high in sugar and fat will undo whatever health benefits you obtained from the process, plus could cause bloating and discomfort. It's always best to eat nutrient-dense, soothing foods in small portions as you ease back into a regular diet (via Healthline). </p>
<p> Furthermore, when you've been fasting for a longer period, your intestinal tract loses some of it's protective layers, leaving it more sensitive. It's important that fruit is not the first thing you eat. The sugar in fruit is difficult for your body to process and can irritate your gut, causing uncomfortable side effects. Protein shakes and dairy are also out as a first meal, because they too can irritate your vulnerable intestines. And lastly, cruciferous veggies are not a great option for the very first snack after a fast, because they basically encourage gas in your gut (via Hylete). </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599508" filename="Food___Water" parent_folder="web2" url="https://subnautica.fandom.com/wiki/Food_%26_Water">
<p> Food & Water </p>
<p> This article is about Food & Water in Subnautica. To see this subject's article on the Below Zero Wiki, click here. </p>
<p> Food & Water are categories of consumable items crafted from materials and creatures using the Fabricator. They are only available in Survival and Hardcore mode. Consuming Food & Water is required to maintain the player's Food & Water levels or else the player risks dying from thirst or malnutrition. </p>
<p> While some Food can be eaten raw, this action dehydrates the player and yields significantly less Food than when it is cooked. The player can also choose to cure fish instead of cooking them, so as to make them immune to decay. Cured fish has the same Food values as cooked fish, but dehydrates the player by -2 H2O. </p>
<p> To consume Food & Water items the player can left-click on the item in the PDA. </p>
<p> The two gauges are marked out of 100 but work slightly differently: the Water gauge never exceeds 100 under any circumstances, but the Food gauge will "overflow" above 100 if a consumed item's Food value would take it beyond 100, and it is not already 100 or higher. The maximum value for Food is therefore 174 (eating a Nutrient Block at 99 Food). </p>
<p> Contents </p>
<p> Starvation and Dehydration </p>
<p> A player will starve fully in about 50 minutes (1 unit of food every 30 seconds ) and so it is important to watch out, as not being cautious can mean death. </p>
<p> With dehydration, on the other hand, a player will die in about 33 minutes. (1 unit of thirst every 20 seconds) </p>
<p> In both cases, a player will be warned that they are close to starvation and/or dehydration when only 20 units of either food or water remain. Another warning will be heard when 10 units remain. </p>
<p> Rot and Decay </p>
<p> Cooked Food may raise the player's H2O levels, but it's also prone to rotting and decomposing. Curing fish instead of cooking them solves this problem but decreases hydration. Still, this is a preferable alternative for dealing with hunger when far from base or when local fish are sparse, as cured fish are the only kind of Food with any sort of long-term storage. Nutrient blocks, snacks, and gel sack also don’t rot, however, they can be rare and/or do not give ideal food levels. </p>
<p> Cooked Food slowly starts to lose its Food & Water value leading to Decomposition. The level will go as low as -25 H2O and -25 Food. During decomposition the Food amount lowers slowly; but when it reaches a certain level the Food becomes Ripe; Ripe Food eventually becomes rotten when it reaches -1 Food. It is recommended to eat the Food while you can during the early stages of decomposition as you will still gain some hunger. </p>
<p> Starts after: ~2-3 min. </p>
<p> Decomposing: ~2-3 min. </p>
<p> Ripe: ~13-18 min. </p>
<p> It is possible to store live fish in storage containers that will not rot until the player is ready to cook them. However, stored cooked fish will still rot regardless. </p>
<p> Note that decomposition also applies to plant Foods as well, and it is not possible to cook or cure them. While this means they cannot be carried around as a portable food supply, they can still be used for planting, or in the case of Creepvine, fabrication. Gel Sacks will never decay so they can be stored indefinitely while giving positive food and water. </p>
<p> Food And Water Items </p>
<p> Water </p>
<p> Cooked Food </p>
<p> Cooking Food requires: </p>
<p> 1x Raw Food Item </p>
<p> Cooked Food can be obtained using a Fabricator or by killing the creature with a Thermoblade. </p>
<p> Salting has given the flesh a mousse-like consistency. Dehydrating, but keeps well. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599638" filename="freezer-burn-food" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.eatthis.com/freezer-burn-food/">
<p> Is It Safe to Eat Food That Has Freezer Burn? </p>
<p> It's time to settle the debate on whether you should scrape off the affected area or just toss the food out. </p>
<p> You can spot freezer burn the minute you see it—it's that mound of ice crystals that have seemingly fused onto your frozen blueberries and strawberries in the Ziploc bag, or on the top layer of your beloved, unfinished pint of ice cream, or to the corner of that piece of steak you've been saving. This blemish may cause you to draw the conclusion that the affected food is no longer edible, right? We turned to Natalie Rizzo, MS, RD, and author of The No-Brainer Nutrition Guide For Every Runner to set the record straight, once and for all. But before we dive into whether food with freezer burn is actually safe to eat or not, it may be helpful to identify what freezer burn is and why it appears, so let's start there. </p>
<p> What is freezer burn? </p>
<p> Freezer burn can either change the color of a particular food—most likely meat—or it can appear as a clump of ice crystals. You may have pulled out a raw chicken breast from the freezer before and noticed that a grayish-brown patch had formed on it. As Claudia Sidoti, head chef of Hello Fresh, told us in an article about storing chicken in the freezer, this discoloration occurs when the chicken is exposed to air, and as a result, becomes dehydrated. </p>
<p> Is it safe to eat food with freezer burn? </p>
<p> "According to the USDA, freezer burn just makes food dry because of air coming in contact with food," says Rizzo. "You can cut off spots with freezer burn, or you may want to discard the entire item if it's covered in freezer burn because it won't taste very good." </p>
<p> It all comes down to taste because it's completely safe to eat food that has freezer burn. However, cooking up a dried-out piece of steak will not taste nearly as satisfying as one that's fresh and tender. And do you really want to munch on that cluster of ice crystals just to get to the sweet ice cream that lies beneath it? Thankfully, there are preventative measures you can take to stop freezer burn in its tracks to begin with. </p>
<p> What causes freezer burn, and how do you prevent it? </p>
<p> "Freezer burn can happen to any food, but it's more likely [to occur] on foods that are left in the freezer for months. Also, if a food isn't properly stored, it's more likely to get freezer burn," explains Rizzo. "To properly store it, make sure it's wrapped tightly enough so that air can't get in. If you are putting it in a freezer bag, wrap it in plastic wrap first and then squeeze the air out of the bag, or store it in an airtight, freezer-safe container." </p>
<p> Rizzo also recommends letting hot food cool in the fridge for a few hours before packing it into the freezer. An expedited way to chill food would be placing the food into a small heat-resistant bowl and then putting that bowl inside of a larger glass one with half water and half ice. It's important to chill food before it goes into the freezer. Otherwise, this warm food could bring down the temperature in the freezer, causing nearby foods to partially thaw and then refreeze. This, in part, may cause the food's texture and even flavor to alter. </p>
<p> Also, be sure to keep your freezer tightly packed—not overflowing—to conserve energy and to ultimately help keep all of the foods in the freezer frozen. </p>
<p> Now, are you inspired to do a quick check of your freezer? Luckily, you can still eat those foods with freezer burn on them—and you've also learned how to avoid it in the first place! </p>
<p> Cheyenne Buckingham </p>
<p> Cheyenne Buckingham is the news editor of Read more </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599702" filename="freshwater-puffer-fish-food-does-it-eat-everything" parent_folder="web2" url="https://uniquepetswiki.com/freshwater-puffer-fish-food-does-it-eat-everything/">
<p> Freshwater puffer fish food – Does it eat everything? </p>
<p> What is freshwater puffer fish food? Pufferfish are omnivorous animals, and they will eat a fairly varied diet. Puffers have four front teeth that converge and look like a beak. You need to put it into consideration when you care for a puffer fish. </p>
<p> The teeth form a sharp chopping machine, and they feed regularly. For their upkeep, you will need to feed them on hard shells of food to file them down and not allow it to stop growing. Puffers have an exciting personality, and they will learn to beg for food from their owners. </p>
<p> Puffers also have specialized requirements for their food. Some of the things that I found out about feeding of pufferfish after extensive research are listed below. </p>
<p> To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video </p>
<p> Puffer fish diet </p>
<p> Pufferfish diets comprise of algae and invertebrates, and large specimens can also crack and eat clams, shellfish, and mussels with their hard beaks. They are also able to synthesize their deadly toxin from the bacteria in the animals that they eat. </p>
<p> Behavior of pufferfish </p>
<p> In the wild, pufferfish are ferocious predators, and different species have different hunting techniques. Some of the open water hunters like the golden puffer and South American puffer who swims over rocky and sandy substrate searching for prey. </p>
<p> South American Puffer </p>
<p> Pufferfish like crested pufferfish and dwarf puffers are stealth predators. You will find then in overgrown riverbanks and places with various hiding spots where they can hide and attack their prey from the shadows. </p>
<p> Species like Congo puffers belongs to the group of ambush predators. This group will dig themselves in the sand while they wait for fish to come by so they can lunge upward and kill it. </p>
<p> Pufferfish are also aggressive to each other and other fish species. They are also fin-nippers as they will nip the fins of the fish that are kept with them. A unique behavior found in numerous pufferfish species is their ability to blow or spit water over the substrate to uncover prey. They will also spit water at you from the surface when they are hungry or for more food. </p>
<p> Puffer fish eats everything? </p>
<p> You will need to feed your puffers based on its size. If you are keeping small species, you will feed them daily. Mid-sized species can be fed every other day while the large species can be fed twice or three times a week. </p>
<p> Note: Avoid overfeeding them; they are also good at doing things that will impress you to earn more food. </p>
<p> Feeding Your Puffers </p>
<p> You do not have an excuse to feed your puffers with a poor diet. Many puffers have a diet which comprises of just crustaceans, shellfish, and hard-shelled foods like snails. The foods listed are a basic requirement when it comes to feeding puffers so that their teeth are constantly worn down to prevent its overgrowth. It means if you feed them with shell foods, you will not need to file their teeth yourself. </p>
<p> Note: some puffers rely more on the hard foods to wear down their teeth than other species. The hunter category of puffers seems to benefit more from eating this diet than the ambush category. However, there is usually some exception to this at times. </p>
<p> Types of freshwater pufferfish food </p>
<p> Freshwater puffer fish food are very from the frozen food to Freeze-dried food, or live food such as small shrimp. </p>
<p> Frozen food </p>
<p> You can offer varieties of food to your fish. The most common food to feed them is frozen food, and this is because you can easily store them. All you need is to keep the food frozen, and you will then thaw the food before you give it to your fish. Some of the frozen foods that you can feed them are krill, mussel, crabs, cockle, prawn, black worms, king prawn, bloodworm, etc. </p>
<p> Thawing of frozen food </p>
<p> There are different ways that you can thaw the food before you feed your puffers. Some people leave the frozen food to defrost overnight in the fridge while some defrost them with a cup of tank water. You can boil water and allow it to cool off before you pour it in a bowl that contains frozen food. Another way to thaw it is by enabling the feed to thaw with vitamin water. </p>
<p> After defrosting, it is best if you strain the water off before you feed your fish. If you have pre-packed frozen cubes like bloodworm, it is good advice to defrost, rinse, and strain them through a fine net. This method will make sure that you add only the food into the tank and nothing else that can cause an increase in the bio load in your tank. </p>
<p> Freeze-dried food </p>
<p> Freeze-dried food is another form of food for your pufferfish. You will need to soak freeze-dried food before you offer it to your fish. A great way is by using vitamin water for soaking them so that your puffer can get a healthy meal. Some of the freeze-dried foods for your puffers are plankton and krill. </p>
<p> Live food </p>
<p> You can also feed your puffers with live food, and you will find numerous live food to feed them. However, it would be best if you avoided feeder fish because they can cause problems for your puffer. It would be best if you kept in mind that not all puffers are piscivorous. By introducing feeder fish to them, they can contract diseases, and the diet is not going to be beneficial to them. Prolong feeding your puffer with fish can lead to issues like fatty liver and ultimately, death. </p>
<p> If you want to feed them with live foods, it is great if you can gut load them before you offer them. For instance, if you are offering a ghost shrimp, you can feed the shrimp on vegetation which the puffers can receive when they feed on them. </p>
<p> If you are going to harvest the live food yourself, you should take into consideration the area where you source for them. That is, you should source for your live food from the area that is free of fertilizers, pesticides, weed killers, and so on. </p>
<p> Feeding your fish with live food </p>
<p> You should ensure that you feed your freshwater puffers with live foods that are quarantined. It would be best if you tried to segregate the life feeder foods as they may make your puffers sick, and they also feed on prey animals like snails. Some of the live food that you can feed your puffers are crayfish, snails, shrimps, crabs, crickets, earthworms, blackworms, bloodworms, etc. </p>
<p> Note: When feeding your puffers, it is best to keep watch as much as possible. This will give you the chance to see if they are feeding well, and you can also remove the remaining food from the tank to prevent the deterioration of the water. It will also benefit your puffers if you can feed them with a varied diet. </p>
<p> What household food can pufferfish eat? </p>
<p> Crustaceans </p>
<p> You can feed your puffers with hard and crunchy food such as unshelled shrimp for their teeth. You can also feed them with crabs and shrimp, but they have a chemical known as thiaminase. Thiaminase interferes with the absorption of vitamin B1. You can quickly get around this by soaking the thawed crab and shrimp in B1 supplements. It is also best to feed them with these sparingly. </p>
<p> Bivalves </p>
<p> Your puffers will love cockles, clams, and mussels. One of the best foods that you can give your puffers is the mussels because they have thinner shells that puffers can crunch with their beaks. You can feed them whole to large puffers or dice them for smaller puffers. Mussels also comprise of thiaminase, but you can quickly soak them in supplements. </p>
<p> Frozen Fish </p>
<p> Pufferfish will appreciate frozen and fresh fish. If you want to feed them with frozen fish, you can shave off chunks with a cheese grater. You should avoid feeding them with oily species such as tuna and herring. Salmon is excellent for puffers as it is rich in carotenoids, which helps in maintaining the color of aquarium fish. It would help if you kept in mind that puffers need crunchy foods in their diet and should avoid feeding them with fish alone. </p>
<p> Squid </p>
<p> Squid is also a perfect pufferfish food that you can quickly get. You will need to chop the squids to size, and you can use a cheese grater to shave off chunks for frozen squid. Since squid has no crunchy parts, you will also need to feed your puffers crunchy foods. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599686" filename="Fruitarianism" parent_folder="web2" url="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fruitarianism">
<p> Fruitarianism </p>
<p> Fruitarianism (/fruːˈtɛəriənɪzəm/) is a subset of dietary veganism, consisting of primarily fruits, and possibly nuts and seeds, but without animal products. Fruitarian diets are subject to numerous criticisms and health concerns. </p>
<p> Some fruitarians will eat only what falls (or would fall) naturally from a plant: that is, plant foods that can be harvested without killing or harming the plant.[2][3][4] These foods consist primarily of culinary fruits, nuts, and seeds.[5] According to author Adam Gollner, some fruitarians eat only fallen fruit.[6] Some do not eat grains, believing it is unnatural to do so,[citation needed] and some fruitarians feel that it is improper for humans to eat seeds as they contain future plants,[6] or nuts and seeds,[7] or any food besides juicy fruit.[8] Others believe they should eat only plants that spread seeds when the plant is eaten.[9] Others eat seeds and some cooked foods.[10] Some fruitarians use the botanical definitions of fruits and consume pulses, such as beans, peas, or other legumes. Other fruitarians' diets include raw fruits, dried fruits, nuts, honey and olive oil,[11] nuts, beans or chocolate.[12] </p>
<p> Some fruitarians wish, like Jains, to avoid killing anything, including plants,[10] and refer to ahimsa fruitarianism.[13] For some fruitarians, the motivation comes from a fixation on a utopian past, their hope being to return to a past that pre-dates an agrarian society to when humans were simply gatherers.[14] Another common motivation is the desire to eliminate perceived toxicity from within the body. For others, the appeal of a fruitarian diet comes from the challenge that the restrictive nature of this diet provides.[14] </p>
<p> According to nutritionists, adults must be careful not to follow a fruit-only diet for too long.[15] A fruitarian diet is wholly unsuitable for children (including teens), nursing mothers and their babies. Death can result from malnutrition.[16][15] </p>
<p> Fruitarianism is even more restrictive than veganism or raw veganism.[17] Maintaining this diet over a long period can result in dangerous deficiencies, a risk that many fruitarians try to ward off through nutritional testing and vitamin injections.[14] The Health Promotion Program at Columbia University reports that a fruitarian diet can cause deficiencies in calcium, protein, iron, zinc, vitamin D, most B vitamins (especially B12), and essential fatty acids.[16] </p>
<p> Although fruit provides a source of carbohydrates, they have very little protein, and because protein cannot be stored in the body as fat and carbohydrates can, fruitarians need to be careful that they consume enough protein each day.[18] When the body does not take in enough protein, it misses out on amino acids, which are essential to making body proteins which support the growth and maintenance of body tissues.[18] Consuming high levels of fruit also poses a risk to those who are diabetic or pre-diabetic, due to the negative effect that the large amounts of sugar in fruits has on blood sugar levels.[19] These high levels of sugar mean that fruitarians are at high risk for tooth decay.[19] Another concern that fruitarianism presents is that because fruit is easily digested, the body burns through meals quickly, and is hungry again soon after eating.[14] A side effect of the digestibility is that the body will defecate more frequently.[14] Additionally, the Health Promotion Program at Columbia reports that food restrictions in general may lead to hunger, cravings, food obsessions, social disruptions, and social isolation.[16] The severe dietary restrictions inherent in a fruitarian regime also carries the serious risk of triggering orthorexia nervosa.[14] </p>
<p> Harriet Hall has written that a fruitarian diet "leads to nutritional deficiencies, especially in children. Fruitarians can develop protein energy malnutrition, anemia, and low levels of iron, calcium, essential fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals."[20] </p>
<p> Vitamin B12, a bacterial product, cannot be obtained from fruits. According to the U.S. National Institutes of Health "natural food sources of vitamin B12 are limited to foods that come from animals."[21] Like raw vegans who do not consume B12-fortified foods (for example, certain plant milks and some breakfast cereals), fruitarians may need to include a B12 supplement in their diet or risk vitamin B12 deficiency.[21] </p>
<p> In children, growth and development may be at risk. Some nutritionists state that children should not follow a fruitarian diet. Nutritional problems include severe protein–energy malnutrition, anemia and deficiencies including protein, iron, calcium, essential fatty acids, raw fibre and a wide range of vitamins and minerals.[22] </p>
<p> Some notable advocates of fruitarianism, or of diets which may be considered fruitarian, or of lifestyles including such a diet, are: </p>
<p> Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, better known as Indian political and spiritual leader Mahatma Gandhi, sustained a fruitarian diet for 5 years.[29] He apparently discontinued the diet and went back to vegetarianism due to pleurisy, a pre-existing condition, after pressure from Dr. Jivraj Mehta.[30][31] </p>
<p> Author Morris Krok, who earlier in his life lived "only on fruits",[33] allegedly advised against a diet of "only fruit",[34] although it was subsequently reported that Krok's diet consisted of "just fruit",[35] with dietary practices of fruitarians as varied as definitions of the term "fruitarianism". </p>
<p> Actor Ashton Kutcher was hospitalized and said that his "pancreas levels were completely out of whack" after following a fruitarian diet in preparation for his role playing Apple Inc. CEO and onetime fruitarian Steve Jobs, in the film Jobs. Jobs died of pancreatic cancer.[36] </p>
<p> The Order of the Golden Age published the journal Herald of the Golden Age (1896-1918), which promoted a "fruitarian system of living".[24] </p>
<p> The minor character Keziah in the 1999 film Notting Hill, (played by Emma Bernard) tells William "Will" Thacker (Hugh Grant) that she is a fruitarian.[40] She says she believes that "fruits and vegetables have feeling," meaning she opposes cooking them, only eating things that have "actually fallen off a tree or bush" and that are dead already, leading to what some describe as a negative depiction.[41] </p>
