<p> Will dams spoil one of Europe’s last wild rivers? </p>
<p> Albania’s Vjosa River also faces other development threats, including an airport. Designating the river a national park could save it. </p>

<p> Traditionally religious, pilgrim routes may offer travelers from all walks of life a chance to find inner peace and reconnect with the world. </p>

<p> They’re more like us than we realized, scientists say. But why sharks socialize is still an open question. </p>

<doc id="file21599604" filename="stomachache-after-eating" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.healthline.com/health/stomachache-after-eating">
<p> What’s Causing This Stomachache After I Eat? </p>
<p> We include products we think are useful for our readers. If you buy through links on this page, we may earn a small commission. Here’s our process. </p>
<p> Overview </p>
<p> Are your eyes bigger than your stomach? Nearly everyone has overindulged at one time or another, leading to indigestion, fullness, and nausea. But if you’re experiencing stomach pain when eating normal amounts of food, it could be a sign of a problem. </p>
<p> Most causes of stomachache and indigestion aren’t serious and don’t require medical attention. Mild stomach upset can usually be treated at home with over-the-counter (OTC) medications. </p>
<p> But if your pain is moderate or severe, you should talk to your doctor. Your symptoms could be a sign of a serious underlying condition. </p>
<p> There are many reasons why your stomach might hurt after eating. Read on to learn more. </p>
<p> There are many different types of stomach pain and upset. You’ve probably experienced many of them before. </p>
<p> If you or someone you know is having severe stabbing pain, it could be a medical emergency. You should consult with a doctor right away. </p>
<p> Dehydration is also a medical emergency. If you’re unable to consume liquids without vomiting or are having severe and persistent diarrhea, you may need to go to the emergency room for intravenous (IV) fluids. </p>
<p> There are several potential causes for stomach pain after you eat. These include: </p>
<p> Food allergies </p>
<p> Food allergies occur when your body mistakes a certain food for a harmful foreign invader and your immune system releases antibodies to fight it. This immune response can cause an array of symptoms, including stomach pain. Common food allergies include: </p>
<p> Many people experience lactose intolerance, which means that milk and other dairy products give them symptoms of stomach upset. </p>
<p> Celiac disease </p>
<p> Celiac disease is when your body has an immune response to gluten — a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. With repeated exposure, it causes damage to the lining of the small intestine. This causes symptoms of stomach upset and can lead to other serious complications. </p>
<p> GERD </p>
<p> Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a chronic (long-lasting) digestive condition in which stomach acid comes back up into your esophagus. This acid reflux irritates the lining of your esophagus and can cause damage. </p>
<p> Crohn’s disease </p>
<p> Crohn’s disease is a serious, chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It causes inflammation in different parts of the digestive tract, which can lead to severe pain, diarrhea, and bloody stools, along with other symptoms. It’s a serious condition with potentially life-threatening complications. </p>
<p> Peptic ulcers </p>
<p> Peptic ulcers are sores that develop on the inside lining of your stomach and the upper part of your small intestine (duodenum). The most common symptom of an ulcer is a burning stomach pain. This pain can be aggravated by spicy foods. </p>
<p> Sugar alcohols </p>
<p> Sugar alcohols, which oddly contain neither sugar nor alcohol, are artificial sweeteners used in many sugar-free gums and candies. Sugar alcohols, like sorbitol, are food additives regulated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Some people find that they cause digestive distress. The FDA warns that excessive consumption of sorbitol can have a “laxative effect.” </p>
<p> Constipation </p>
<p> Constipation happens when stool moves too slowly through the digestive tract and cannot be eliminated normally. Chronic constipation — several weeks with three or fewer bowel movements — can cause stomach pain and bloating. After you eat, when your body is trying to digest new food, your symptoms may get worse. </p>
<p> Your doctor might be able to diagnose the cause of your stomach pain just by listening to you describe your symptoms. Sometimes, however, more invasive tests may be necessary. This could include: </p>
<p> If you suspect that you have a food intolerance, then trial and error is often the best way to identify it. You may want to keep a food diary to keep track of your symptoms. Your doctor might also recommend an elimination diet. </p>
<p> If you’re experiencing stomach pain after eating, you may already have tried a few at-home treatments. If you haven’t found anything that works, it could be because you haven’t pinpointed the right underlying cause. </p>
<p> Ultimately, treatment for stomach pain will depend on what’s causing it. If you think you may have a food allergy, you should be evaluated by an allergist for correct diagnosis. If you have a food intolerance, you should try to avoid that food as much as possible. </p>
<p> A lactose-free diet may sound unappealing at first, but there are ways to make it work. You might want to consider seeing a nutritionist or picking up a cookbook with lactose-free recipes. If you think you may have an issue with gluten, you shouldn’t go gluten-free until you’ve been evaluated by a gastroenterologist and celiac disease has been ruled out. Testing for celiac disease should be done while on a diet which contains gluten. </p>
<p> Many of the uncomfortable symptoms of post-meal stomach pain can be managed with OTC medications. As always, talk to your doctor before starting any new medication, even if it doesn’t require a prescription. </p>
<p> Here are a few treatment options that you can find at your local pharmacy: </p>
<p> Simethicone (Gas-X) helps relieve uncomfortable bloating. </p>
<p> Antacids (Alka-Seltzer, Rolaids, Tums) neutralize stomach acid to reduce burning feelings. </p>
<p> Acid-reducers (Pepcid) reduce the production of stomach acid for up to 12 hours. </p>
<p> Beano helps prevent gas. </p>
<p> Antidiarrheals (Imodium) stop diarrhea and its associated symptoms. </p>
<p> Lansoprazole and omeprazole (Prevacid, Prilosec) block acid production and help heal the esophagus when taken daily. </p>
<p> Pepto-Bismol coats the lining of the esophagus to reduce burning and treat nausea and diarrhea. </p>
<p> Diphenhydramine (Benadryl) fights symptoms associated with an allergic immune response and helps treat nausea and vomiting. </p>
<p> Acetaminophen (Tylenol) relieves pain without irritating the stomach like aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen can. </p>
<p> Probiotics aid in overall digestive health by introducing more good bacteria into your system. </p>
<p> Fiber supplements (Metamucil, Benefiber) help produce normal bowel movements and prevent constipation, though they can cause gas and bloating. </p>
<p> Possible complications will depend on what’s causing your stomach pain. Food allergies can lead to a severe allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis, which can cause you to stop breathing. Anaphylaxis is a medical emergency. </p>
<p> GERD can result in damage to the esophagus that causes difficulty swallowing. Peptic ulcers can lead to internal bleeding and serious infections. Chronic constipation can lead to hemorrhoids and anal fissures, among other problems. </p>
<p> Crohn’s disease is associated with the most serious complications, including bowel obstructions and fistulas that require surgical repair. It can also increase your risk of colon cancer. </p>
<p> There are several things you may be able to do to prevent stomach pain after eating. </p>
<p> There are a lot of things that could be causing your stomach to hurt after eating. It’s likely that you have common indigestion or heartburn and will benefit from OTC medications. But if your symptoms have persisted for several weeks, you may have a chronic condition and should consult your doctor as soon as possible. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599619" filename="stop-food-guilt" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.health.com/food/stop-food-guilt">
<p> Account </p>
<p> More </p>
<p> Follow Us </p>
<p> How to Stop Beating Yourself Up About What You Eat </p>
<p> Still obsessing over that third slice of pizza? Get over it. Letting go of food guilt and eating what you want is the healthiest food move you can make. </p>
<p> Location: My house. Girls’ night. The scene: Cheese plate. Many bottles of wine. And a running commentary from all my friends: “I can’t stop eating this cheese.” “I can’t believe I’m still eating this cheese.” “I’ve been eating so much cheese this week. I’m so gross.” To me: “I’m so sorry I’m eating all your cheese.” </p>
<p> And then: “Do you have any more of this cheese?” </p>
<p> Of course, it’s not always cheese. Feel free to insert bread, pasta, cookies, chocolate, or chips into that scenario. In this age of clean eating, detox diets, and food phobias, there is an increasingly long list of foods that health-conscious women feel terrible about eating. If we eat them in private, we carry that shame around inside us, or maybe text a friend a picture of the crumb-covered aftermath. If we eat them in public, an apology accompanies every bite, as if we can indulge only through a kind of preemptive atonement. But why do we feel so guilty—or at least think we should feel guilty—about the simple act of eating food and daring to enjoy it? </p>
<p> Why we food shame </p>
<p> For me, for years, the foods that most inspired this kind of guilt were baked goods. Specifically, brownies. I love brownies, but I rarely let them in my house because when I did, the pan wouldn’t last more than a day. If I encountered them at a party, they could dominate my whole night: What should I eat before I let myself have a brownie? Can I have a second one? Maybe just this broken piece? Why is no one else at this party eating the brownies? </p>
<p> And underneath all those thoughts was another, even more insidious undercurrent: I was sure that I was so abnormally obsessed with the brownies because I was fat, possibly the fattest person in the room, and getting fatter with every bite. “As a culture, we’ve fully bought into this myth that if we eat the ‘right’ foods in the ‘right’ amounts, we will achieve the ideal body shape,” says Glenys Oyston, RDN, a Los Angeles–based dietitian and the founder of Dare to Not Diet. “We’re sure it’s just a matter of trying hard enough.” </p>
<p> The flip side is that eating any “wrong” food isn’t merely unhealthy—it’s considered a huge failure of willpower. When we categorize foods as good or bad, we’re really categorizing ourselves as good or bad, strong or weak, worthy or unworthy. </p>
<p> But our inability to resist forbidden foods isn’t a moral failing. It’s how we’re wired. “Our brains react really strongly to restriction,” notes Marci Evans, RDN, a dietitian in Cambridge, Massachusetts, who specializes in helping patients recovering from eating disorders. “The more we say ‘No, bad’ about a food, the more we can’t stop thinking about it.” And lately our catalogue of “bad” foods has been getting bigger and bigger—gluten! red meat! anything in a package!—until we’re apologizing for eating, period. </p>
<p> This kind of thinking happens even if your reasons to avoid certain foods ostensibly have more to do with health than weight. Stella is a 37-year-old elementary school teacher who tries not to eat cheese or ice cream because they can give her digestive trouble so embarrassing that she didn’t want to use her real name. But she also feels that if she’s worked out that day, the rules are different. “If I’ve gone for a run, I give myself permission to indulge in any and all foods,” she says. “Especially cheese.” Oyston calls this “healthism” and says it’s really just another manifestation of our diet mentality, in which feeling healthy depends on the activities or habits that we associate with being thin. In some instances, obsessing about whether you should restrict your intake of certain foods can be an early sign of a more severe disordered eating pattern. “Even if it never gets bad enough to be clinically diagnosable, it’s still a problem when your thoughts about food take up so much mental space that other parts of your life begin to suffer,” says Christy Harrison, RD, a dietitian and intuitive-eating counselor in Brooklyn, New York. Like when you think about brownies so much that you miss the actual fun other people are having at a party. </p>
<p> Breaking the habit </p>
<p> Most of us are not going to stop eating cheese or brownies—nor should we. Feeding your body what it wants and needs instead of restricting yourself is associated with lower rates of disordered eating, depression, and other mental health issues, says Harrison. The trick is to figure out how to end the apology cycle. </p>
<p> I became much more mindful of how I talked about food after my 3-year-old daughter told me that "cookies are yucky but carrots are good." I want her to find pleasure in eating both—but she’ll never get there if she’s coming home to find me self-flagellating around the baked goods. So I stopped apologizing, criticizing, or justifying what I was eating. Completely. </p>
<p> One cool thing about apologizing less out loud is that over time, I’ve found my internal monologue has quieted down as well. The brownies are just brownies now; I can eat them, love them, and have fun at a party all at the same time. </p>
<p> A less cool thing is that I’m now much more aware when I hear other people food shaming themselves. Jenny McGlothlin is a pediatric feeding therapist in Dallas who may also be part unicorn, because she’s never dieted and doesn’t food shame. So I asked her how she handles those fraught moments. “I usually go for a blend of humor and good-natured support," she says. "Like if a friend says she’s ‘being bad,’ I’ll say, ‘Well, you’re pretty awesome, so anything you choose to eat can’t be bad!’ " I don’t mind telling you that except for when she was pregnant, McGlothlin has stayed the same size for her entire adult life. But in so many ways, that’s beside the point. Eating without guilt is just a lot more fun. And it makes for a much better girls’ night. </p>
<p> Intuitive eating 101 </p>
<p> As you work to let go of food shame, you may also find yourself eating more intuitively, which means choosing foods in response to your body’s needs and wants. Here’s how to get started. </p>
<p> 1. Avoid nutritional mandates. "We rely way too much on our brains to tell us how to eat," says Evans. "Getting caught up in the number of calories or whether it’s a good or bad food can keep you stuck." Instead, she says, check in with your body for information. "After you eat a meal or snack, ask, ‘How am I feeling physically?’ and ‘Would I like to feel this way again?’ " she says. "Then listen with curiosity and without judgment.” </p>
<p> 2. Honor your hunger. Even if that means you need to eat lunch at 11 a.m. or have a second or third helping. "Reliably eating until you feel satiated teaches your brain and body to trust each other, which will help you feel more relaxed and in charge of your eating," explains Evans. </p>
<p> 3. Let your weight work itself out. Once you stop food shaming, you may find yourself eating more and even, yes, gaining some weight. On the other hand, many people find they lose weight in this process, probably because guilt was leading them to overindulge in forbidden foods. Either way, "we usually see weight stabilize over time," says Oyston. </p>
<p> Close this dialog window </p>
<p> Share & More </p>
<p> Close </p>
<p> Sign in </p>
<p> View image </p>
<p> How to Stop Beating Yourself Up About What You Eat </p>
<p> this link is to an external site that may or may not meet accessibility guidelines. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599528" filename="sweating-while-eating" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.healthline.com/health/sweating-while-eating">
<p> Sweating While Eating: What’s the Cause? </p>
<p> Sweating while eating can mean more than just that the temperature is too high in your dining room. </p>
<p> “Gustatory sweating,” as it’s medically referred to, is a symptom of a condition doctors call Frey syndrome. </p>
<p> The condition causes sweating even when you eat something cold, like ice cream. </p>
<p> Other times, sweating while eating is due to another medical condition you may have. </p>
<p> Keep reading to find out more about why you may sweat while you eat, plus what you and your doctor can do about it. </p>
<p> Some people report sweating while they’re actually eating. However, thinking or talking about food can also cause sweating while eating. </p>
<p> A doctor will consider factors like your symptoms and medical history when determining a potential underlying cause. </p>
<p> Idiopathic hyperhidrosis </p>
<p> Sometimes a doctor can’t identify the underlying cause of excessive sweating. Doctors call this idiopathic hyperhidrosis. Although doctors don’t know the cause, they can still treat it. </p>
<p> Head and neck surgery </p>
<p> One of the most common known causes of excessive sweating is a history of head and neck surgery, especially surgery to remove a parotid gland in the head. </p>
<p> People who’ve had head and neck surgery can experience trauma to close-knit tissues, especially in these regions. </p>
<p> It’s thought that parotid gland surgery can accidentally damage the nearby nerves, which mixes up certain nerve signals, such as those for sweating. This is Frey syndrome. </p>
<p> Usually, whether you know it or not, you salivate and typically produce extra saliva when you eat. This is your body’s way of aiding in the digestive process. </p>
<p> If nerves to your parotid glands are damaged, you may start sweating instead of salivating due to your body’s “mixed signals.” </p>
<p> A person with Frey syndrome may experience mild to severe sweating on the head. It’s usually mild. </p>
<p> Some foods and drinks are known to cause sweating while eating. These include hot and spicy foods. </p>
<p> Some people also find they sweat more when they drink alcohol. This is because alcohol naturally dilates, or widens, peripheral blood vessels, which causes the body to release heat. </p>
<p> However, if you have problems with sweating while eating due to Frey syndrome or another underlying medical condition, you may find a variety of foods or even just thinking about food causes sweating. </p>
<p> Some people find a particular food type affects them, such as: </p>
<p> To help determine the potential underlying cause, your doctor will consider where you have your symptoms. </p>
<p> For example, Frey syndrome usually causes facial flushing and sweating on only one side of the face when eating. </p>
<p> This is because head and neck surgery, especially to remove a parotid gland, is usually for only one side. As a result, this is the side that has potential nerve damage that can lead to sweating. </p>
<p> Sweating when eating due to an underlying medical condition like diabetes mellitus usually causes sweating on both sides of the face and other body areas. This includes the: </p>
<p> If you’ve had surgery to your head and neck, you may develop Frey syndrome within the first year after surgery. </p>
<p> According to the National Organization for Rare Disorders, an estimated 30 to 50 percent of people who’ve had parotid gland removal experience Frey syndrome. </p>
<p> But sometimes, sweating while eating is a side effect of a medical condition other than Frey syndrome. Examples of other conditions that doctors know can cause sweating while eating include: </p>
<p> cluster headaches </p>
<p> diabetes mellitus </p>
<p> facial herpes zoster (shingles) </p>
<p> Parkinson’s disease </p>
<p> Each of these conditions can affect how nerves transmit messages to each other. The messages may become “mixed up,” resulting in sweating instead of salivating, or sweating in addition to salivating. </p>
<p> One way you can start to help prevent sweating while eating is to keep a journal. For about a week, record: </p>
<p> when you sweat </p>
<p> where on the body you sweat </p>
<p> what you were eating when you started sweating </p>
<p> Review this information at the end of the week to determine whether there are any food patterns that cause you to sweat more. </p>
<p> You can try to eliminate these foods to see if refraining from eating thems reduce your sweating. If you find you’re having to severely restrict your diet, you may need to see your doctor. </p>
<p> Keeping some items on hand to reduce sweat and moisture on your face can help, too. Examples include tissues or blotting papers. </p>
<p> If you’ve tried at-home steps and still have concerns, talk to your doctor. </p>
<p> Several prescription approaches are available. Examples include prescription-strength antiperspirants applied to the face or other sweating areas, or taking medications called anticholinergics to reduce sweating. </p>
<p> Doctors may also use Botox in an off-label fashion. A doctor will inject Botox into key areas to keep sweating at bay. This may work anywhere from 9 to 12 months before you’d need another injection. </p>
<p> Doctors don’t usually recommend surgery as the first treatment to correct Frey syndrome. Surgery doesn’t always work, and it could make the condition worse instead of better. </p>
<p> Sweating while eating can occur under a number of circumstances. Sometimes it’s an isolated incident. Other times it’s due to an underlying condition. </p>
<p> You can try at-home measures and see your doctor for treatment ideas. The most important thing to remember is that there are interventions that can help you. </p>
<p> You shouldn’t have to change your regular activities due to fears over sweating while eating. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599476" filename="Ten-foods-safely-eat-use-dates-revealed.html" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/food/article-2978826/Ten-foods-safely-eat-use-dates-revealed.html">
<p> While we have all sniffed food to check whether it has gone off, it's sometimes difficult to know which produce can be safely consumed after its use-by date. </p>
<p> Whether it's chocolate that has developed a whitish bloom or bread that has gone slightly mouldy, it's confusing whether something is OK to eat or drink or whether it needs to be binned. </p>
<p> As one entrepreneur reveals he is making millions by selling out-of-date food, it's clear that when it comes to the timeline on our packaging, there is some leeway. </p>
<p> Scroll down for video </p>
<p> There are some foods which can be safely eaten even after use-by their dates have long gone </p>
<p> Dan Cluderay, from Worksop, Nottinghamshire, who runs Approved Food, appeared on Bargain Fever Britain on ITV1 last night, explaining how he sells his cheap products to busy mums and bargain hunters. </p>
<p> The 40-year-old says the secret to his success is that his business provides just what the savvy shopper is looking for - quality food at prices which save mums around £60 off their weekly bill compared to a similar shop at one of the big supermarkets. </p>
<p> He says there are only two dates shoppers need to know about: 'use-by' and 'best before' dates. </p>
<p> According to NHS guidelines, the use-by date means food has to be eaten by that time, otherwise it can cause you to be unwell. </p>
<p> However, when it comes to best before dates, it's a different story, with many produce safe to consume for sometimes weeks after this timeline. </p>
<p> Dan Cluderay's online business selling out-of-date food has proven to be a hit with busy mums </p>
<p> Cupboard staples bread, milk and eggs can all be consumed past their use-by dates </p>
<p> But while use-by dates do play a part in ensuring we don't make ourselves sick, there are some foods which can be safely eaten even after their dates have long gone. </p>
<p> In an article for the MailOnline, investigative food journalist Joanna Blythman revealed: 'Use-by dates are, of course, an integral part of our modern food distribution, whereby supermarkets like to promote the concept of the "weekly shop". </p>
<p> 'In this culture of "stocking up" for several days ahead, an illusion of freshness is provided by vast, high-tech fridges.' </p>
<p> Share this article </p>
<p> Share </p>
<p> 3.7k shares </p>
<p> She continues: 'But use-by dates are here to stay. They are an inevitable part of our urbanised, retail society and it is foolish to ignore them. What is crucial to understand, though, is the difference between use-by and best-before labels - something that often seems to confuse consumers.' </p>
<p> With so much information and advice around, how can we be certain what is safe to eat? </p>
<p> Chocolate (left) can keep past its use by date. It may however develop a 'bloom' which occurs when cocoa fats are exposed to air. It is also safe to eat hard cheese such as cheddar (right) after their use by dates </p>
<p> Dry aged steak (meat which sometimes has been hung for up to 120 days and becomes dry due to loss of water content) sees connoisseurs paying over the odds for consuming essentially what is mouldy meat </p>
<p> 'Foods which are very salty, for instance, are generally safe to eat. A good example of this is pickles, which, because it is preserved in vinegar, is safe to consume long after the date on the jar,' Joanna said. </p>
<p> 'The same rule applies to sugary foods such as honey or jam. Using large amounts of sugar is an effective method of preservation, which is the reason that very sweet products like fruitcake and fudge can be eaten well past their use by dates.' </p>
<p> According to Ms Blythman,fermented food such as German sauerkraut and Korean kimchi are safe as as they are essentially food which has been preserved through salting, curing or drying. </p>
<p> She also said that hard cheeses, such as cheddar, are safe to eat after their use-by dates. </p>
<p> 'Even if it's turned mouldy on the outside, the exterior can just be cut off and the interior consumed. The same principle applies to bread,' she said. </p>
<p> Hard cheeses, such as cheddar, are safe to eat after their use-by dates </p>
<p> The same, however, is not true of soft cheeses like brie or camembert, which can foster harmful bacteria once they have lost their freshness. </p>
<p> And surprisingly, use-by dates are not too much of a worry with eggs. </p>
<p> 'They can still be used in a sponge cake or hard-boiled in a salad long after the benchmark has been passed, though they should not be eaten scrambled, fried or soft-boiled if they have been left for too long,' she explained. </p>
<p> 'In the same vein, sour milk makes great pancakes. The act of cooking the milk will kill off any harmful bacteria present.' </p>
<p> However she advised to steer clear of consuming meats after their use-by dates. </p>
<p> 'Under no circumstances should any meats be consumed past their use-by dates,' she said. </p>
<p> 'Poultry and pork are by far the biggest sources of food poisoning in Britain, a problem worsened by factory farming methods that spread contamination.' </p>
<p> And while it may seem counterintuitive to cook meat such as steak when it's gone past it's use-by date, the current trend for dry aged steak (meat which sometimes has been hung for up to 120 days and becomes dry due to loss of water content) sees connoisseurs paying over the odds for consuming essentially what is mouldy meat. </p>
<p> If you don't mind the loss of crunch, both biscuits (left) and crisps (right) can be eaten after their use-by dates </p>
<p> At the 120-day hanging stage, the mould, which is very similar to what you would see on aged cheese such as blue cheese, starts to form. </p>
<p> 'Most simply, thoroughly cooking any product will destroy most bacteria, as they cannot survive extreme heat,' Ms Blythman said. </p>
<p> 'For example, where meat has darkened because of exposure to air, it needn’t be binned. Just cook it at a high heat and it should be absolutely fine.' </p>
<p> However, she does have a word of warning. </p>
<p> 'Despite what some people think, washing meat under a tap makes no difference to the bacteria contained within. Indeed, it can even be positively counter-productive, by spreading that bacteria to the kitchen sink, surfaces and cloths.' </p>
<p> TEN FOODS WHICH CAN BE CONSUMED AFTER THEIR USE-BY DATES </p>
<p> Milk: Pasteurised milk will keep 50 per cent longer if you store it at a lower temperature. Try storing at the back of the fridge rather than the fridge door. If your milk has gone sour, use it to make pancakes </p>
<p> Eggs: According to a report by food scientist Dana Gunders, eggs can last for three to five weeks. But they have to be kept at a temperature below 5C (41F), as that helps prevent potential growth of Salmonella enteritidis. </p>
<p> Sugary foods: Anything with a large amount of sugar, such as jams or honeys, are safe to be consumed. </p>
<p> German sauerkraut and Korean kimchi: Safe as as they are foods which has been preserved through salting, curing or drying. </p>
<p> Crisps: While they may have gone soft, crisps are highly processed and loaded with salt so are safe to be consumed. </p>
<p> Biscuits: Like crisps, biscuits are also highly processed and thus can be consumed long after their sell-by date. If they taste soft or soggy simply pop them in the oven to get them crunchy again. </p>
<p> Dry pasta: Dry goods such as uncooked pasta, as long as it is stored in airtight containers, can keep indefinitely </p>
<p> Bread: Keep it in the freezer and it will last for ages. Just make sure you cut out the mouldy bits if you spot any. </p>
<p> Canned foods: Extend the shelf life of canned products by storing them in a cool and dark area. </p>
<p> Packaged salad: As long as your salad leaves haven't gone mouldy (wilted and mouldy are very different) simply revive them in ice-cold water </p>
<p> Chocolate: Chocolate can last a long time often develops a white coating, known as the 'bloom', when it's exposed to the air. This happens because the fat melts and rises to the top. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Mr Cluderay told FEMAIL: 'Food is perfectly fine to be eaten way past its "best before" date, as people know, but the large supermarkets won't do that and that's where we come in. </p>
<p> 'We sell food, such as cans of baked beans, pasta sauce, tins of tuna, which may have gone past their 'best before' date by a few weeks, but everyone knows they will taste just the same as the products which have weeks left to run.' </p>
<p> Mr Cluderay said they dispatch around 600 orders a day with his average shopper spending around £40 a week buying cupboard staples such as pasta, pasta sauce, flour and toilet rolls. </p>
<p> 'By comparison, they'd be spending around £100 at one of the major supermarkets so they're actually saving around £60 which they can then spend on something else. </p>
<p> 'We don't touch food that has a limited shelf life such as fresh chicken and fresh fish, but we do sell hardy vegetables.' </p>
<p> THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN USE BY AND BEST BEFORE DATES: </p>
<p> USE BY... </p>
<p> You will see 'use by' dates on food that goes off quickly, such as smoked fish, meat products and ready-prepared salads. </p>
<p> Don't use any food or drink after the end of the 'use by' date on the label, even if it looks and smells fine. This is because using it after this date could put your health at risk. </p>
<p> For the 'use by' date to be a valid guide, you must follow storage instructions such as ‘keep in a refrigerator’. If you don't follow these instructions, the food will spoil more quickly and you may risk food poisoning. </p>
<p> Once a food with a ‘use by’ date on it has been opened, you also need to follow any instructions such as ‘eat within three days of opening’. </p>
<p> But remember, if the ‘use by’ is tomorrow, then you must use the food by the end of tomorrow, even if the label says ‘eat within a week of opening’ and you have only opened the food today. </p>
<p> If a food can be frozen its life can be extended beyond the ‘use by’ date. But make sure you follow any instructions on the pack, such as ‘cook from frozen’ or ‘defrost thoroughly before use and use within 24 hours’. </p>
<p> BEST BEFORE... </p>
<p> ‘Best before’ dates appear on a wide range of frozen, dried, tinned and other foods. </p>
<p> ‘Best before’ dates are about quality, not safety. When the date is passed, it doesn't mean that the food will be harmful, but it might begin to lose its flavour and texture. </p>
<p> Eggs can be eaten after their ‘best before’ date as long as they are cooked thoroughly until both yolk and white are solid, or if they are used in dishes where they will be fully cooked such as a cake. </p>
<p> Cooking eggs until both the white and yolk are solid will kill any bacteria, such as salmonella. People who are in ‘at-risk’ groups should only eat eggs, or food containing eggs, that have been thoroughly cooked. These groups include: babies and toddlers; elderly people; pregnant women; people who are already unwell. </p>
<p> Every year in the UK we throw away 7.2m tonnes of food and drink, most of which could have been eaten. So think carefully before throwing away food past its ‘best before’ date. </p>
<p> Remember, the ‘best before’ date will only be accurate if the food is stored according to the instructions on the label, such as ‘store in a cool dry place’ or ‘keep in the fridge once opened’. </p>
<p> DISPLAY UNTIL/ SELL BY... </p>
<p> Date marks such as ‘display until’ or ‘sell by’ often appear near or next to the ‘best before’ or ‘use by’ date. These are instructions for shop staff, not for shoppers. </p>
<p> The important dates for you to look for are the ‘use by’ and ‘best before’ dates. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599856" filename="ten-reasons-eat-meat" parent_folder="web2" url="https://alffarms.com/food/ten-reasons-eat-meat/">
<p> Ten reasons why you should eat meat </p>
<p> Ten reasons why you should eat meat </p>
<p> Generally, the perception in our society is that eating meat means a bad omen. However, this is not true at all. Meat is essential for the healthy mind and body and the lack of meat can cause obesity, depression, heart diseases, anxiety and hyperactivity. </p>
<p> Meat consumption is generally blamed for high cholesterol, high blood pressure, heart diseases and obesity. But it is not the meat which is the root cause of these problems, it is the sugar present in the meat which is harmful. So remember that you should not eat processed meat, as it contains lots of sugar, salt, additives, nitrates, hormones, pesticides, antibiotics and preservatives that will lead to disease. The meat should be antibiotic free, grass-fed and free-range. </p>
<p> Everybody must have heard the phrase “eat more veggies and stay fit for life”, but no such phrases are popular with meat. Now we are going to describe the top 10 reasons why eating meat can be healthy for you- </p>
<p> Meat helps keep blood sugar level stable due to its fat and protein content- Steady blood sugar is critical in preventing type 2 diabetes as well as other chronic diseases. With stable blood sugar level, you are less likely to go for snacks and sweets between meals. </p>
<p> Meat helps your muscles to grow- You can work out for tons of hours in the Gym but if you do not have a proper diet then the muscles in your body will not grow. You have to fuel your body with proper diet (which consists an item related to meat) to achieve sufficient muscle repair and recovery to make gains. </p>
<p> Meat is a complete source of protein- Meat and its by-products are the only complete sources of protein available to us. All other forms of protein are incomplete and don’t provide us with all the essential amino acids the body and mind need to function adequately. </p>
<p> Eating meat can give you long-lasting energy- Consuming meat protein leads to burning more calories and gives you more energy. Pair meat with any vegetable diet and you will feel energized the whole day. </p>
<p> Meat diet improves neurotransmitter health- Meat protein is very good for improving neurotransmitter efficiency in the brain. It is found that people having meat in their diet have better neurotransmitter ability especially as a person in old age. </p>
<p> Meat is an important part of any balanced diet- Meat contains some of the highly essential nutrients and vitamins like Vitamin B12, D, high-quality protein, Omega-3 fatty acids, several amino acids. Avoiding meat means avoiding these essential nutrients which can do harm to the body in the long run. </p>
<p> Meat helps to burn fat- Whether your goal is to increase body weight or lose it, eating meat is beneficial because animal protein provides a superior nutrient profile per calorie of food. In addition, meat helps preserve lean body mass, which is critical for maintaining your metabolism when trying to lose weight. </p>
<p> Meat is an excellent source of B12 vitamin- There are many nutrients in meat that are critical to our health. But meat has a greater concentration of all B vitamins than found in plants, and vitamin B-12 can only be found in animal sources. The B vitamins are critical to overall health, especially mental health. </p>
<p> Iron from meat is absorbed easily as compared to veggies- Iron from animal sources is more easily absorbed than iron from plant sources. This is because various substances contained in iron from plant sources can bind iron, reducing absorption. </p>
<p> No family meal is complete without the presence of any meat item- The vegans might feel left out here. </p>
<p> After listing the good things we might gain from eating meat, the social environmentalists will say that it is bad for the environment. But eating meat is essential for our body and we must find some other way to keep the environment protected. So, do one thing, order high quality, unadulterated meat from Alffarms and relish its exquisite taste. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599635" filename="that-sudden-urge-to-poop-your-pants-after-eating-and-what-you-can-do-about-it" parent_folder="web2" url="https://sureceta.com/that-sudden-urge-to-poop-your-pants-after-eating-and-what-you-can-do-about-it/">
<p> That sudden urge to poop your pants after eating and what you can do about it </p>
<p> Healthy Living </p>
<p> Have you ever experienced having to go to the bathroom right after eating, had digestion issues midway through a meal, or even gotten a whiff of coffee and had to go? Diarrhea immediately after eating is a symptom of several disorders that could be affecting your bowel movements. </p>
<p> You may think experiencing diarrhea immediately after eating your meal is caused by indulging in fast foods, but SuReceta’s integrative medicine expert, Dr. Joseph Mosquera asserts otherwise. </p>
<p> “Those sudden bathroom trips you may be experiencing are most likely symptoms of an underlying condition that happen to be exacerbated by poor food choices,” says Dr. Mosquera. </p>
<p> I did some research and partnered up with Dr. Joseph Mosquera to suss out the details of what could be triggering the need to poop right after eating, and what can be done to stop it. </p>
<p> First, let’s backtrack a little to learn about what gives us the urge to go to the bathroom in the first place. </p>
<p> The gastrocolic reflex </p>
<p> The all too familiar “trigger” sensation we feel to go to the bathroom is called the gastrocolic reflex. Once we begin eating, and have food moving into the stomach, the stomach signals the brain to in turn signal the colon to move out stuff because more stuff is coming down the pipe. </p>
<p> Once we begin eating, and have food moving into the stomach, the stomach signals the brain to in turn signal the colon to move out stuff because more stuff is coming down the pipe. </p>
<p> “Now people naturally have different gastrocolic reflexes,” explains Dr. Mosquera, “but this reflex can be affected by a number of factors from a food allergy to just feeling anxious.” </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599477" filename="The-10-foods-eat-safely-best-dates-long-last.html" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/food/article-3301683/The-10-foods-eat-safely-best-dates-long-last.html">
<p> The 10 foods you CAN eat safely after their best-before dates – and how long they last </p>
<p> Environment Secretary Elizabeth Truss regularly eats food past its date </p>
<p> NHS guidelines decree that people can ignore 'best before' labels </p>
<p> Bread, biscuits, honey and meat safe to consume after best before dates </p>
<p> If you have ever sniffed your food to check whether it has gone off, you are in good company. </p>
<p> Environment Secretary Elizabeth Truss recently revealed that she regularly eats food that is past its 'best before' date. </p>
<p> The Cabinet Minister and mother of two said she applied the sniff test to work out whether food was off before binning or eating it. </p>
<p> Scroll down for video </p>
<p> There are some foods which can be safely eaten even after the best before dates have long gone </p>
<p> Cupboard staples bread, milk and eggs can all be consumed past their best before dates </p>
<p> Asked whether she ate food that was past its best before date, she said: 'Definitely. I will just see if it smells OK and eat it. Absolutely.' </p>
<p> RELATED ARTICLES </p>
<p> Share this article </p>
<p> Share </p>
<p> She added: 'I'm of the school that if the cheese has got mould on it just cut the end off and eat the rest of the cheese.' </p>
<p> Environment Secretary Elizabeth Truss </p>
<p> Her actions are within NHS guidelines, which decree that people can ignore 'best before' labels but not 'use by' dates which could risk food poisoning. </p>
<p> Miss Truss also said she wanted to see fewer 'buy one get one free' offers from supermarkets to cut down on food waste. </p>
<p> She said every household had a responsibility to cut back on binning food. </p>
<p> Miss Truss said she liked 'wonky' vegetables that are often ditched by supermarkets and revealed she was in talks to keep more of them on the shelves. </p>
<p> While we have all sniffed food to check whether it has gone off, it's sometimes difficult to know which produce can be safely consumed after its 'best before' date. </p>
<p> Dan Cluderay, from Worksop, Nottinghamshire, who runs Approved Food says there are only two dates shoppers need to know about: 'use-by' and 'best before' dates. </p>
<p> According to NHS guidelines, the use-by date means food has to be eaten by that time, otherwise it can cause you to be unwell. </p>
<p> However, when it comes to best before dates, it's a different story, with many produce safe to consume for sometimes weeks after this timeline. </p>
<p> Mr Cluderay told FEMAIL: 'Food is perfectly fine to be eaten way past its 'best before' date, as people know, but the large supermarkets won't do that and that's where we come in. </p>
<p> 'We sell food, such as cans of baked beans, pasta sauce, tins of tuna, which may have gone past their 'best before' date by a few weeks, but everyone knows they will taste just the same as the products which have weeks left to run.' </p>
<p> Dry aged steak (meat which sometimes has been hung for up to 120 days and becomes dry due to loss of water content) sees connoisseurs paying over the odds for consuming essentially what is mouldy meat </p>
<p> Mr Cluderay said they dispatch around 600 orders a day with his average shopper spending around £40 a week buying cupboard staples such as pasta, pasta sauce, flour and toilet rolls. </p>
<p> 'By comparison, they'd be spending around £100 at one of the major supermarkets so they're actually saving around £60 which they can then spend on something else. </p>
<p> 'We don't touch food that has a limited shelf life such as fresh chicken and fresh fish, but we do sell hardy vegetables.' </p>
<p> But while use-by dates do play a part in ensuring we don't make ourselves sick, there are some foods which can be safely eaten even after their dates have long gone. </p>
<p> With so much information and advice around, how can we be certain what is safe to eat? </p>
<p> In an article for the MailOnline, investigative food journalist Joanna Blythman said: 'Foods which are very salty, for instance, are generally safe to eat. A good example of this is pickles, which, because it is preserved in vinegar, is safe to consume long after the date on the jar,' Joanna said. </p>
<p> Foods which are very salty or very sweet are usually okay to eat after after their best before date </p>
<p> If you don't mind the loss of crunch, biscuits (left) and crisps (right) can be eaten after their best before dates </p>
<p> 'The same rule applies to sugary foods such as honey or jam. Using large amounts of sugar is an effective method of preservation, which is the reason that very sweet products like fruitcake and fudge can be eaten well past their use by dates.' </p>
<p> According to Ms Blythman,fermented food such as German sauerkraut and Korean kimchi are safe as as they are essentially food which has been preserved through salting, curing or drying. </p>
<p> She also said that hard cheeses, such as cheddar, are safe to eat after their use-by dates. </p>
<p> 'Even if it's turned mouldy on the outside, the exterior can just be cut off and the interior consumed. The same principle applies to bread,' she said. </p>
<p> Hard cheeses, such as cheddar, are safe to eat after their use-by dates </p>
<p> The same, however, is not true of soft cheeses like brie or camembert, which can foster harmful bacteria once they have lost their freshness. </p>
<p> And surprisingly, use-by dates are not too much of a worry with eggs. </p>
<p> 'They can still be used in a sponge cake or hard-boiled in a salad long after the benchmark has been passed, though they should not be eaten scrambled, fried or soft-boiled if they have been left for too long,' she explained. </p>
<p> 'In the same vein, sour milk makes great pancakes. The act of cooking the milk will kill off any harmful bacteria present.' </p>
<p> FOODS WHICH CAN BE CONSUMED AFTER THEIR BEST BEFORE DATES </p>
<p> Freeze bread (left) and it can last for ages. Honey (right) is safe to be consumed after the best by date </p>
<p> Milk: Pasteurised milk will keep 50 per cent longer if you store it at a lower temperature. Try storing at the back of the fridge rather than the fridge door. If your milk has gone sour, use it to make pancakes. </p>
<p> Hard cheese can be eaten after its best before date </p>
<p> Eggs: According to a report by food scientist Dana Gunders, eggs can last for three to five weeks. But they have to be kept at a temperature below 5C (41F), as that helps prevent potential growth of Salmonella enteritidis. </p>
<p> Sugary foods: Anything with a large amount of sugar, such as jam or honey, is safe to be consumed. Honey never really expires although crystals, which are safe to consume, may start to form. </p>
<p> German sauerkraut and Korean kimchi: Safe as they are foods which has been preserved through salting, curing or drying. </p>
<p> Crisps: While they may have gone soft, crisps are highly processed and loaded with salt so are safe to be consumed. They can be eaten three weeks after the best by date. </p>
<p> Biscuits: Like crisps, biscuits are also highly processed and thus can be consumed long after their sell-by date. If they taste soft or soggy simply pop them in the oven to get them crunchy again. These can be eaten two months after the best by date. </p>
<p> Dry pasta: Dry goods such as uncooked pasta, if stored in airtight containers, can keep indefinitely. </p>
<p> Bread: Keep it in the freezer and it will last for ages. Just make sure you cut out the mouldy bits if you spot any. </p>
<p> Canned foods: Extend the shelf life of canned products by storing them in a cool and dark area. </p>
<p> Packaged salad: As long as your salad leaves haven't gone mouldy (wilted and mouldy are very different) simply revive them in ice-cold water. </p>
<p> Meat: As long as it is refrigerated properly, meat can be eaten two days after its best before date. It is still best to smell it to check it hasn't gone off. Dry aged steak (meat which sometimes has been hung for up to 120 days and becomes dry due to loss of water content) sees connoisseurs paying over the odds for consuming essentially what is mouldy meat </p>
<p> Cheese: Hard cheeses, such as cheddar, are safe to eat after their best before dates. Even if it's turned mouldy on the outside, the exterior can just be cut off and the interior consumed. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN USE BY AND BEST BEFORE DATES: </p>
<p> USE BY... </p>
<p> You will see 'use by' dates on food that goes off quickly, such as smoked fish, meat products and ready-prepared salads. </p>
<p> Don't use any food or drink after the end of the 'use by' date on the label, even if it looks and smells fine. This is because using it after this date could put your health at risk. </p>
<p> For the 'use by' date to be a valid guide, you must follow storage instructions such as 'keep in a refrigerator'. If you don't follow these instructions, the food will spoil more quickly and you may risk food poisoning. </p>
<p> Once a food with a 'use by' date on it has been opened, you also need to follow any instructions such as 'eat within three days of opening'. </p>
<p> But remember, if the 'use by' is tomorrow, then you must use the food by the end of tomorrow, even if the label says 'eat within a week of opening' and you have only opened the food today. </p>
<p> If a food can be frozen its life can be extended beyond the 'use by' date. But make sure you follow any instructions on the pack, such as 'cook from frozen' or 'defrost thoroughly before use and use within 24 hours'. </p>
<p> BEST BEFORE... </p>
<p> 'Best before' dates appear on a wide range of frozen, dried, tinned and other foods. </p>
<p> 'Best before' dates are about quality, not safety. When the date is passed, it doesn't mean that the food will be harmful, but it might begin to lose its flavour and texture. </p>
<p> Eggs can be eaten after their 'best before' date as long as they are cooked thoroughly until both yolk and white are solid, or if they are used in dishes where they will be fully cooked such as a cake. </p>
<p> Cooking eggs until both the white and yolk are solid will kill any bacteria, such as salmonella. People who are in 'at-risk' groups should only eat eggs, or food containing eggs, that have been thoroughly cooked. These groups include: babies and toddlers; elderly people; pregnant women; people who are already unwell. </p>
<p> Every year in the UK we throw away 7.2m tonnes of food and drink, most of which could have been eaten. So think carefully before throwing away food past its 'best before' date. </p>
<p> Remember, the 'best before' date will only be accurate if the food is stored according to the instructions on the label, such as 'store in a cool dry place' or 'keep in the fridge once opened'. </p>
<p> DISPLAY UNTIL/ SELL BY... </p>
<p> Date marks such as 'display until' or 'sell by' often appear near or next to the 'best before' or 'use by' date. These are instructions for shop staff, not for shoppers. </p>
<p> The important dates for you to look for are the 'use by' and 'best before' dates. </p>
<p> Share or comment on this article: </p>
<p> The 10 foods you CAN eat safely after their best-before dates – and how long they last </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599523" filename="The-foods-eat-safely-sell-date-never-risk-eating.html" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/food/article-3916300/The-foods-eat-safely-sell-date-never-risk-eating.html">
<p> Stop throwing it away! The foods you CAN eat safely after the best before dates (and what you should never risk eating) </p>
<p> Many items, including dairy products, are safe to eat after the expiry date </p>
<p> Whiskey, crisps, honey and jams won't make you ill if you consume them </p>
<p> But raw seafood and soft cheeses are dangerous after their use-by dates </p>
<p> About a third of the food produced in the world is thrown away needlessly every year - that's 1.3 billion tonnes. </p>
<p> The statistics are shocking, but we're often so scared of getting food poisoning that we would rather throw away perfectly good food than risk it, even if it looks and smells okay. </p>
<p> Femail Food&Drink can now reveal exactly what can and can't be eaten after the best-before dates - and what to watch out for if your food is on the turn. </p>
<p> ALCOHOL </p>
<p> British households throw away 3.5 million tonnes of food and drink every year - half of which is completely edible </p>
<p> Alcohol takes years to go off, but hard spirits such as vodka and whiskey (pictured) are perfectly safe to drink for years after the expiry date </p>
<p> Alcohol takes years to go off, but most hard spirits such as vodka and whiskey won't make you ill if you drink them after their best before date has expired. </p>
<p> Beer is also safe to drink once it's gone off - but it probably won't taste very nice. </p>
<p> But cream-based liqueurs and anything that's been in the sun for too long a time may be dangerous once they're past their expiry date, so watch out for those languishing old bottles on your booze shelf. </p>
<p> CHOCOLATE </p>
<p> Praise be, you can indeed eat that old Mars Bar you've found slightly squashed down the side of your sofa. </p>
<p> Old chocolate may grow white spots - called 'bloom' - where the sugar has crystallised but it's perfectly safe to eat. </p>
<p> It may not taste as good as the day you bought it, but it won't make you ill. </p>
<p> CRISPS </p>
<p> Old crisps may not be very crispy but they are safe to eat after the expiry date </p>
<p> They may not be as crispy as when they were newly bought, but old crisps aren't going to make you ill. </p>
<p> That's all thanks to the salt that often coats many potato snacks - but it's still best to eat them within three weeks of the expiry date passing. </p>
<p> EGGS </p>
<p> A report by food scientist Dana Gunders states that eggs can last for three to five weeks but they have to be kept at a temperature below 5C (41F), to prevent the growth of Salmonella enteritidis. </p>
<p> Share this article </p>
<p> Share </p>
<p> 1.4k shares </p>
<p> One way to check if your eggs are safe to eat is by putting them in a jug of cold water, according to Cosmopolitan magazine. If they sink, they're fresh; if they don't, throw them away. </p>
<p> If they sit on the bottom but point upwards, they're on the turn. </p>
<p> CHEESE </p>
<p> Hard cheeses are ok for three to six weeks after the expiry date (just chop off the mould) but avoid eating old soft cheeses as they could make you ill </p>
<p> Only hard cheese, such as cheddar and Parmesan, is safe to eat after its best-before date. </p>
<p> Even if these cheeses have turned mouldy, the inside will still be safe to eat, and can often last three to six weeks. </p>
<p> But never eat soft cheeses, such as cream cheese and Camembert, once their expiry date is up, and only consume them for a week once the packet has been opened. </p>
<p> MILK </p>
<p> Thought all dairy products were risky to eat once their use-by date is up? Not so. </p>
<p> Sour milk isn't going to make you ill, and you can actually use it in a few recipes, such as scones, spice cake and pancakes, to use it up instead of needlessly wasting it. </p>
<p> But if you want to keep it fresher for longer, store it in the coldest part of your fridge at the back rather than in the fridge door. </p>
<p> BISCUITS </p>
<p> Biting into a biscuit only to find it's gone stale and soft is surely one of life's most disappointing moments. </p>
<p> But the preservatives in these treats mean they're safe to eat long after the sell-by date has passed - up to two months after in fact. </p>
<p> And there is a way to make them crunchy again. Try popping them in the oven, and they should be crisp in no time. </p>
<p> HONEY AND JAM </p>
<p> The high sugar levels in honey and jam means they will be safe to eat indefinitely - despite any crystallisation that may have occurred </p>
<p> You may well have thrown away jars of honey when the bottom has formed a large sugary lump. </p>
<p> But the spread is still perfectly safe to eat, despite any crystallisation that has occurred. </p>
<p> The same applies to jam - the high levels of sugar preserve these items. </p>
<p> SAUERKRAUT AND KIMCHI </p>
<p> Korean kimchi is the hottest food of the moment, and it's safe to eat long past its sell-by date as it's been preserved through salting, curing or drying. </p>
<p> The same rule applies to German sauerkraut too if you're buying in jars for Christmas. </p>
<p> TINNED FOOD </p>
<p> As long as your tinned food has been in a cool and dark place, then it will be safe to eat for years </p>
<p> Have you still got that tin of artisan beans from years ago that you've never had a reason to use at the back of your cupboard? </p>
<p> As long as it's been in a cool and dark place, it'll be fine to use for years and years. </p>
<p> MEAT </p>
<p> Controversially, you can eat meat if it's past its expiry date for at least two days - but it is always worth having a smell to see if it's gone off before using, as off meat can make you incredibly ill. </p>
<p> Make sure it's been stored in a very cold part of your fridge, however. </p>
<p> PACKAGED SALAD LEAVES </p>
<p> Packets of salad seem to go off so quickly, leaving you with wilted and often slim leaves at the bottom of your fridge. </p>
<p> But don't throw them away too soon - they can be revived with some ice cold water. </p>
<p> They're safe to eat as long as there's no mould - otherwise they can be dangerous to consume. </p>
<p> RAW SEAFOOD </p>
<p> Never eat seafood once the use-by date has expired - it would make you seriously ill </p>
<p> Never eat seafood once the use-by date is up - if you do, you're asking for food poisoning. </p>
<p> This is one food group where it's better to be safe than sorry. </p>
<p> DRY PASTA </p>
<p> It doesn't matter how long you've had those packets of spaghetti and penne in the cupboard, they'll be fine to use indefinitely. </p>
<p> The trick is to make sure you store it in an airtight container if you've opened a packet - that way, no moisture can creep in and make it go off. </p>
<p> PROCESSED MEAT </p>
<p> Processed meat can harbour harmful listeria which could make you seriously ill so avoid eating it once the expiry date has passed </p>
<p> It's too risky to eat any processed meats such as salami, hot dogs or cured meats once the best before date is up. </p>
<p> That's because listeria - found at food processing plants where processed meats are packaged - thrives in cold environments. </p>
<p> So even if you've kept your meat in a cold part of your fridge, it's best to throw it away than risk a serious illness. </p>
<p> WHAT YOU SHOULD AND SHOULD NEVER EAT PAST THEIR EXPIRY DATES </p>
<p> THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN USE BY AND BEST BEFORE DATES </p>
<p> USE BY... </p>
<p> You will see 'use by' dates on food that goes off quickly, such as smoked fish, meat products and ready-prepared salads. </p>
<p> Don't use any food or drink after the end of the 'use by' date on the label, even if it looks and smells fine. This is because using it after this date could put your health at risk. </p>
<p> For the 'use by' date to be a valid guide, you must follow storage instructions such as 'keep in a refrigerator'. If you don't follow these instructions, the food will spoil more quickly and you may risk food poisoning. </p>
<p> Once a food with a 'use by' date on it has been opened, you also need to follow any instructions such as 'eat within three days of opening'. </p>
<p> But remember, if the 'use by' is tomorrow, then you must use the food by the end of tomorrow, even if the label says 'eat within a week of opening' and you have only opened the food today. </p>
<p> If a food can be frozen its life can be extended beyond the 'use by' date. But make sure you follow any instructions on the pack, such as 'cook from frozen' or 'defrost thoroughly before use and use within 24 hours'. </p>
<p> BEST BEFORE... </p>
<p> 'Best before' dates appear on a wide range of frozen, dried, tinned and other foods. </p>
<p> 'Best before' dates are about quality, not safety. When the date is passed, it doesn't mean that the food will be harmful, but it might begin to lose its flavour and texture. </p>
<p> Eggs can be eaten after their 'best before' date as long as they are cooked thoroughly until both yolk and white are solid, or if they are used in dishes where they will be fully cooked such as a cake. </p>
<p> Cooking eggs until both the white and yolk are solid will kill any bacteria, such as salmonella. People who are in 'at-risk' groups should only eat eggs, or food containing eggs, that have been thoroughly cooked. These groups include: babies and toddlers; elderly people; pregnant women; people who are already unwell. </p>
<p> Every year in the UK we throw away 7.2m tonnes of food and drink, most of which could have been eaten. So think carefully before throwing away food past its 'best before' date. </p>
<p> Remember, the 'best before' date will only be accurate if the food is stored according to the instructions on the label, such as 'store in a cool dry place' or 'keep in the fridge once opened'. </p>
<p> DISPLAY UNTIL/ SELL BY... </p>
<p> Date marks such as 'display until' or 'sell by' often appear near or next to the 'best before' or 'use by' date. These are instructions for shop staff, not for shoppers. </p>
<p> The important dates for you to look for are the 'use by' and 'best before' dates. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599633" filename="the-gastrocolic-reflex-food-goes-right-through-me" parent_folder="web2" url="https://inflammatoryboweldisease.net/living/the-gastrocolic-reflex-food-goes-right-through-me">
<p> The Gastrocolic Reflex: “Food Goes Right Through Me!” </p>
<p> By Sara Ringer </p>
<p> February 19, 2016 </p>
<p> 8 </p>
<p> 0 reactions </p>
<p> Have you ever eaten a meal and almost right after you’ve eaten it you are rushing to the bathroom to have a bowel movement? You’ve probably used the phrase, food goes right through me! Many patients who live with Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis have experienced this phenomenon. </p>
<p> Does food go right through you? </p>
<p> Let’s think about it: There are about 25 feet of the intestine in the digestive tract. If you ate a slice of pizza and stood up to go to the bathroom 5 minutes later, would it really be the pizza that had reached the end of your digestive system? Did it just go right through you? </p>
<p> The pizza would have had to travel through your esophagus, stomach, and 25 feet of intestine all in 5 minutes which would be some sort of record transit time. Even though you just ate a meal and had to use the bathroom shortly after, the food did not travel all the way through your digestive system in that short amount of time. </p>
<p> Why do you use the bathroom immediately after eating? </p>
<p> If you are eating a meal and very shortly afterward you need to use the bathroom, the cause is usually the gastrocolic reflex. The gastrocolic reflex is a reflex that stimulates contractions in the colon that can lead to using the bathroom shortly after eating a meal. </p>
<p> Basically the stomach and the colon are communicating1 - once the food you have just eaten reaches the stomach, the stomach sends a message to the colon to make room because more food is coming. The colon, being the polite guy he is, starts contracting which pushes it’s contents further down and this is why you have a bowel movement shortly after you have eaten the meal. It’s not the food that you just ate that is coming out of you, it’s waste from food that you had eaten earlier that was already further down in the digestive tract. </p>
<p> The gastrocolic reflex involves the stomach (gastro) and the colon (colic). </p>
<p> Over-reactive gastrocolic reflex </p>
<p> Research has shown that some patients with IBS have an over-reactive gastrocolic reflex with high pressure contractions in response to meals.2 Simply eating or drinking can trigger this exaggerated reflex resulting in pain, cramping, diarrhea or constipation. Several patients with IBD have coexistent symptoms of IBS3 so this exaggerated gastrocolic reflex can occur in patients who have Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis. </p>
<p> Do greasy foods make you have to go to the bathroom more often? </p>
<p> Greasy foods can trigger the gastrocolic reflex. Usually, large meals or foods that contain unhealthy fats can also increase the pressure of contractions of the gastrocolic reflex.4 This can explain why you feel like you need to use the bathroom right after you eat fried or greasy foods. </p>
<p> So there you have it! The reason why you feel like you have to use the bathroom shortly after eating is because of the gastrocolic reflex. Needing to use the bathroom right after eating a meal can make a patient assume that food travels extremely fast through their system - that food goes right through them. </p>
<p> Poll </p>
<p> Would you consider participating in a clinical trial for a new treatment if you had to see a different doctor during the study? </p>
<p> Yes, I would want to participate and be willing to see a different doctor </p>
<p> No, I would only participate if I could keep seeing my current doctor during the study </p>
<p> No, I have no interest in participating in a clinical trial </p>
<p> I'm not sure </p>

<p> Subscribe </p>
<p> By providing your email address, you are agreeing to our privacy policy. We never sell or share your email address. </p>

The InflammatoryBowelDisease.net team does not recommend or endorse any products or treatments discussed herein. Learn more about how we maintain editorial integrity here. </p>
