<doc id="file21599707" filename="why-do-catholics-eat-fish-on-friday" parent_folder="web2" url="https://uscatholic.org/articles/202004/why-do-catholics-eat-fish-on-friday/">
<p> Why do Catholics eat fish on Friday? </p>
<p> The Lent tradition is to abstain from meat, not necessarily to eat fish. Eating vegetables suffices. </p>
<p> Christians have fasted (gone without food) and abstained (gone without certain foods, especially meat) since the beginning. The Book of Genesis teaches that all the plants and animals that God created and entrusted to human beings are good, especially those given to us as food (Genesis 1:29). Jesus taught that nothing that a person eats makes him or her evil (Mark 7:18). So why then do Christians fast and abstain? </p>
<p> When the devil tempts Jesus in the desert with a comfortable life and a full stomach, Jesus recalls the wisdom of Deuteronomy: “One does not live by bread alone but by every word that comes from the mouth of God” (8:3). Fasting and abstaining makes this real. It also hones our appetite, training us for the basic stance of a baptized person in this world: gratitude. Doesn’t something taste better once you’ve truly hungered for it? Aren’t we more grateful for what we’ve hungered and thirsted for? </p>
<p> Jesus recommended fasting, but not as a mere formality—and certainly not as a burden to be imposed on the poor who have to eat when they can, even if in violation of religious tradition. Instead Jesus recommended fasting when one fails to sense that God is near. </p>
<p> What then is the significance of abstaining from meat? And why eat fish? The tradition suggests a number of reasons. Some say that forgoing meat was forgoing a luxury, as meat was relatively rare for most people. This certainly would have been true in the ancient Mediterranean world in late winter—our time of Lent. Today this hardly seems true, since seafood is the luxury and hamburger costs pennies. And besides, the tradition is to abstain from meat, not necessarily to eat fish. Eating vegetables suffices. </p>
<p> The practice of eating fish is related to the day we typically abstain from meat: Friday. This is the day that Christ died, so abstaining from the shedding (and consuming) of blood seems appropriate. Friday, the sixth day, was also the day that God created animals, so abstaining from meat is a symbolic “stay of execution” for cows, pigs, and sheep—just as the cross saves us from eternal death. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> The Hebrew scriptures also tell of Leviathan, a primordial gigantic enigmatic sea-creature (think Jonah’s whale) that represents death. So carving up and eating Leviathan on the day that Christ killed death makes great sense to the biblical imagination. Because of Christ’s victory, the great monster death is now nothing more than fish sticks on your plate! Think of that next time you skip that Friday hamburger for a tuna fish sandwich. </p>
<p> This article appeared in the March 2007 issue of U.S. Catholic. Click here to subscribe to the magazine. </p>
<p> About the author </p>
<p> David Philippart is the liturgy director at Old Saint Patrick’s Church in downtown Chicago. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599715" filename="why-do-vegetarians-eat-fish" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.thezoologicalworld.com/why-do-vegetarians-eat-fish/">
<p> Why Do Vegetarians Eat Fish? Updated 2021 </p>
<p> Why Do vegetarians eat fish? </p>
<p> If you acknowledge a Lent in your company, then you may be familiar with the saying “No meat on Fridays, but fish is okay”. The thing I am trying to explain here is that fish is not considered as meat in various cultures. </p>
<p> For various people, fish is an underwater creature that is present in abundance, and it is not comparable to some cute-fluffy hen or a big-eyed cow. Because extinction of animals or killing them are the main reasons why someone opt for a vegetarian diet. </p>
<p> So the question is valid “Do vegetarians eat fish?”. For traditional vegetarians there is an obvious statement which they swear by. It states that they won’t eat meat of any kind including fish, no poultry, no game animal, and they also cannot eat any other aquatic life. </p>
<p> These days there are some vegetarians that eat fish too along with the floral diet. But they are not true vegetarians, there is another that is used for such a group of people and that is “Pesco-vegetarians”, or “Pesectarians”. </p>
<p> Sea food is rich in essential nutrients and vitamins which we do not find collectively in most of the food sources. It contains healthy proteins, full of healthy heart fats, and also consists of a lot of iron and a lot of Vitamin B. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat fish and eggs? </p>
<p> Yes! There are groups of people in the world that are vegetarians but they also eat fish. There are also those vegetarians who may not eat fish but they do consume eggs in their daily routine. </p>
<p> The vegetarians that eat eggs and other dairy items are known as “Lacto-ovo” vegetarians. However, the choice of eating eggs depends on a lot of factors like culture, religion, ethnicity and personal reasons. </p>
<p> Most nutritionists explain that consuming eggs and fish while being vegetarian is better than being a full-fledged vegetarian. Seafood and eggs provide all the nutrients that are found in chicken, mutton, and beef and other types of meat. So they not only satisfy the taste buds but they also complete the nutritional requirement of a person. </p>
<p> Why do some vegetarians eat fish? </p>
<p> Vegetarians eat fish because of the nutritional factors mainly, seafood provides healthy fatty acids like Omega-3, that is an excellent thing for people who are suffering with heart disease. </p>
<p> Eggs are one of those foods that are classified as “superfoods”. They are loaded with nutrients, which modern foods usually lack. There are some amazing health factors that even make vegetarians eat fish or eggs. They are incredibly nutritious, containing components like Vitamin A, B5, B12, Folate, Selenium, Phosphorus, Rich fatty acids, and Omega 3. </p>
<p> Another important aspect that makes vegetarians add fish in their normal diet is that it provides more variety and the food does not remain boring all the time. </p>
<p> Why do vegetarians eat fish but not meat? </p>
<p> Most of the vegetarians do not see fish meat as the proper meat. By definition, strict vegetarians do not consume any kind of poultry, meat and eggs. But fish is an exception. </p>
<p> The pescatarians believe that fish for them holds a place below meat but above bugs, and they also hold this stance that fishes are abundant animals as more than 3rd part of the Earth is covered in water. </p>
<p> So, there is not any chance of their extinction. Despite these reasons, they also want to bring more variety on the table instead of the boring lettuce and broccoli. </p>
<p> Moreover, many vegetarians also consume fish in their diet to supplement their nutritional requirements which a floral diet alone cannot fulfil. As we all know fish is jam packed with several essential nutrients, vitamins, and minerals. It provides healthy proteins, healthy heart fatty acids, and Omega 3 which is found in abundance in fish oil. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat chicken and fish? </p>
<p> Different people follow different trends and patterns of vegetarian diet. However, a true vegetarian swears by to not eat any kind of poultry, eggs, chicken or any kind of meat. </p>
<p> However, there are certain groups of vegetarians that do not follow this strict vegetarian diet. The people who consume only fish and do not eat any other meat are called “”Pesectarians”, while those who consume dairy products and eggs along with fish are known as “Lacto-ovo Vegetarians.” </p>
<p> Some people follow a strict vegan diet which can lead to nutritional deficiencies. Therefore, nutritionists always advise people to follow a moderate manner. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat fish and seafood? </p>
<p> Yes! Pesetarain vegetarians eat fish and other seafood diets. Vegetarians do so because in that way they can bring versatility to their diet and can also fulfil their nutritional deficiencies. </p>
<p> Fish is loaded with nutrients and if one does not eat other types of meat, eating fish is definitely a better and brilliant resource. Along with other nutrients and minerals fish provide Vitamin B12 and Zinc which are crucially essential for your immune and nervous system. </p>
<p> For instance if you eat a single oyster per day it fulfils 85% of your daily requirement of zinc and also fulfils 78% daily DV requirement. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat fish and shrimp? </p>
<p> Strict vegetarians do not eat any kind of meat including fish, crustaceans, or any shellfish. So, if you invite your vegetarian friends for dinner do not serve any chicken or fish meat unless you ask them if they are okay with it. </p>
<p> It is a simple fact that fishes live in water. Fish and any other meat diet is not for true vegetarians. However, pescetarians opt fish in their diet along with the vegetarian diet. </p>
<p> Being a vegetarian is a choice, and any true vegetarian does not eat any kind of fish, shrimp, lobster, or shellfish or any other seafood. Being vegetarian depends upon several factors like ethnicity, religion, cultural norms. </p>
<p> Do vegans or vegetarians eat fish? </p>
<p> As you know being a vegetarian is totally up to you, though you can eat whatever you want from chicken burger to potato fries. But when you say you are a vegetarian or vegan then you do not consume any type of dairy, poultry or meat diet. </p>
<p> There are several reasons for being a vegetarian, most of the people do it for animal welfare, betterment of the environment, saving animals from getting extinct, and to also decrease global warming. </p>
<p> However, some vegetarians simply just do not want to consume any kind of meat either chicken or fish, and when they make up their mind, they do the same for major portions in their lives. </p>
<p> Do some vegetarians eat fish? </p>
<p> Fish and other meat is not included in a vegetarian diet. However, there are some group of people that do consume fish, eggs and dairy products in their daily diet. </p>
<p> These people are known as “pescetarians”. The diet of these people contain major portions of plant diet and they also consume fish and seafood along with the plant diet. </p>
<p> People who follow a pescetarian diet do so to have more variety in their diet and they are also inspired by the nutritional benefits of marine diet. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat fish and chicken? </p>
<p> There are also some vegetarians that consume chicken along with fish in their daily diet. Such groups of people are known as ” Pollotarians”. There are several reasons for choosing this pattern of diet. For the majority being a Pollotarian, is considered as the first step towards a vegan diet. </p>
<p> However, some people may opt for this diet because of the environmental and health effects of consuming red meat. </p>
<p> Pollotarian diet is a a semi-vegetarian diet, in which some forms of animal meat are allowed and other animal products are prohibited. The word “pollo” means “Chicken” in Spanish, Pollotarians eat all kinds of poultry that include turkey and ducks as well. </p>
<p> People following this diet do not consume red meat or any pork products. However some may include eggs or dairy diet in their routine while others won’t. </p>
<p> Do vegetarians eat tuna fish? </p>
<p> Pesetarians eat fish along with their vegan diet to fulfil their nutritional requirements and also to bring colors on their table. People eat different kinds of fishes mainly for their health benefits. Vegetarians also believe that fish is an abundant animal present on the Earth which does not face dangers of extinction. </p>
<p> That is also one of the reasons why vegetarians shift to a Pesetarians diet. </p>
<p> Do any vegetarians eat fish? </p>
<p> Yes some vegetarians do eat fish and they are known as “Pesetarians”. Though a true vegetarian diet does not include any kind of poultry or meat. However, choosing either kind of diet is a personal option. </p>
<p> Fishes are a treasure of vitamins, protein and several other essential nutrients. Therefore, most of the vegetarians do so by adding fish to their diet so that they can be healthy and active. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599790" filename="why-eat-fish-good-friday" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.the-sun.com/news/2613631/why-eat-fish-good-friday/">
<p> News Corp is a network of leading companies in the worlds of diversified media, news, education, and information services. </p>
<p> Why do we eat fish on Good Friday? </p>
<p> EASTER comes around every spring and brings with it a number of traditions. </p>
<p> While thousands of chocolate eggs and rabbits get scoffed over the bank holiday weekend, another thing that many eat is fish on Good Friday. But why? </p>
<p> Why do we eat fish on Good Friday? </p>
<p> Christians believe that Jesus was crucified on Good Friday, sacrificing his flesh for our sins. </p>
<p> For centuries, those who follow the religion have abstained from eating meat on the day. </p>
<p> Meat was seen as a delicacy in ancient cultures, and was generally linked with celebrations and feasts. </p>
<p> So instead, Christians choose to eat fish on Good Friday. </p>
<p> The rule of not eating meat does not extend to fish, as the Church order states "land animals". </p>
<p> Fish shapes were also used a secret symbol by Christians to identify each other when their religion was temporarily banned, and many of Jesus' followers were fishermen. </p>
<p> What happened on Good Friday? </p>
<p> Easter is a Christian tradition that celebrates the resurrection of Jesus and marks the end of Lent. </p>
<p> Those who follow the Bible believe that Christ was crucified at Calvary on Good Friday. </p>
<p> Accounts of the Gospel state that the son of God was betrayed by Judas, before he was sentenced to death. </p>
<p> Christians believe Jesus sacrificed himself to save mankind from sin. </p>
<p> After the crucifixion, the scriptures say that Jesus’ body was taken from the cross and placed in a tomb guarded by Roman soldiers. </p>
<p> When does Lent end? </p>
<p> Lent began on Ash Wednesday – which in 2021 was February 17. </p>
<p> Its exact date changes each year because it is determined by when Easter is. </p>
<p> Easter falls on the first Sunday following the first full moon after the vernal equinox. </p>
<p> Ash Wednesday is always the day after Shrove Tuesday, or Pancake Day. </p>
<p> Lent lasts 40 days with the Sundays seen as celebrations and not counted. </p>
<p> It officially ends on Maundy Thursday, which in 2021 is April 1. </p>
<p> Maundy Thursday marks Jesus Christ’s last supper and the initiation of the Eucharist. </p>
<p> It was a tradition for the monarch in England to wash the feet of the poor and kiss them on Maundy Thursday. </p>
<p> Nowadays the monarch hands out Maundy Money on the day. </p>
<p> Despite its significance in the Christian calendar it is not a bank holiday. </p>
<p> We test Easter eggs from supermarkets including Aldi, Tesco and M&S to see which ones are best </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599567" filename="Why-eat-food-s-dropped-floor-Doctor-busts-five-second-rule-myth.html" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/food/article-3837850/Why-eat-food-s-dropped-floor-Doctor-busts-five-second-rule-myth.html">
<p> Why you CAN eat food after it's been dropped on the floor: Doctor busts the five-second rule myth (and reveals the kitchen counter is much dirtier) </p>
<p> Indiana professor Aaron Carroll says he eats food that's been on the floor </p>
<p> He says kitchen counter is 'dirtier' but we don't worry if food has touched it </p>
<p> Agrees with recent study that says food can pick up bacteria immediately </p>
<p> But explians we shouldn't be concerned as our immune systems are hardy </p>
<p> Do you follow the five-second rule - the guideline that says it's okay to eat food from the floor if you pick it up straight away? </p>
<p> If so, then you may welcome the advice of one doctor, who says we shouldn't be remotely worried about eating anything that's been on the floor - no matter how long it's been there. </p>
<p> Aaron E Carroll, Indiana University's professor of pediatrics, says he eats food that's been on the floor - rejecting the advice of a recent study that suggests food dropped on the floor will pick up any bacteria in just one second, rather than five. </p>
<p> Indiana university professor Dr Aaron E Carroll says we shouldn't be too worried about dropping food on the floor - as other household surfaces are much dirtier </p>
<p> Dr Carroll told the New York Times that we should instead be more concerned with how much bacteria is on other household surfaces compared to the floor. </p>
<p> He says there are far dirtier places in a typical house than the floor - such as the handle of a fridge, the kitchen sink and the kitchen counter, highlighting several studies that back up his claims. </p>
<p> And while he acknowledges that food does pick up bacteria as soon as it's come into contact with it, he says food could be contaminated just as easily as the floor by touching other household items before handling food. </p>
<p> RELATED ARTICLES </p>
<p> Share this article </p>
<p> Share </p>
<p> But before you reach for the bleach and anti-bacterial wipes in a panic, the professor says this revelation is no cause for alarm. </p>
<p> Dr Carroll wrote: 'People react to news like this in one of two ways. </p>
<p> 'One is to become paranoid about everything...The alternative is to realize that for most of us, our immune systems are pretty hardy. </p>
<p> 'We've all been touching this dirty stuff for a long time, without knowing it, and doing just fine.' </p>
<p> To back up his point, he pointed to a study by Charles Gerba, a professor of microbiology and environmental sciences at the University of Arizona. </p>
<p> Relax if you've dropped food on the floor and eaten it - Dr Carroll says our immune systems are hardy enough to cope with any bacteria picked up from the ground </p>
<p> In 1998, he and a team of researchers ran tests to see how dirty common household surfaces and items were. </p>
<p> While the kitchen floor harboured, on average, about three colonies of coliform bacteria, the fridge handle had just over five colonies per square inch, while the kitchen counter had even more at 5.75 colonies per square inch. </p>
<p> So while the floor does harbour bacteria, we should probably be more worried about food touching our disgusting kitchen counters before eating it, he says. </p>
<p> Dr Carroll says the same principle applies to the bathroom. </p>
<p> Most people believe the toilet seat is the dirtiest surface in the bathroom. </p>
<p> But the same study found that it only harboured 0.68 colonies per square inch on average, while the the flush handle had a disgusting 34.65 colonies per square inch, with the tap on the sink harbouring 15.84 colonies per square inch. </p>
<p> Dr Carroll says the best way to ensure you don't get ill from these bacteria is to simply wash your hands before eating food. </p>
<p> He wrote: 'If I drop food on the floor, I still eat it. </p>
<p> 'I do that because the harm I might get from the floor is not worth my concern compared with many, many other things. You may feel differently. </p>
<p> 'Either way, make an informed judgment based on relative risks, not on any arbitrary span of time that one thing has been touching another.' </p>
<p> Share or comment on this article: </p>
<p> Why you CAN eat food after it's been dropped on the floor: Doctor busts the five-second rule myth </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599585" filename="Why-EAT-water-not-drink-obsessed-rehydrating-drop-bottle-reach-fruit-veg.html" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3451899/Why-EAT-water-not-drink-obsessed-rehydrating-drop-bottle-reach-fruit-veg.html">
<p> Why you should EAT water, not drink it - If you're obsessed with rehydrating, drop that bottle and reach for the fruit and veg </p>
<p> Experts believe we should turn off the tap and start eating our water </p>
<p> Doctor says that healthy hydration is about the water you hold in the body, not the water you drink that passes straight through </p>
<p> Fruit and veg can hydrate the body twice as effectively as a glass of water </p>
<p> We are always being told that we don’t drink enough water - the recommended amount is two litres, or eight large glasses, a day - which has led many women to try to dramatically increase their consumption. </p>
<p> Indeed, a lot of people today seem to be ‘aquaholics’, rarely separated from their bulging plastic bottles as they sip, slurp and glug their way through the day. </p>
<p> But now it seems they could be wasting their time. </p>
<p> The ‘drink more water’ health message might have been somewhat over-played. In an average day, a quarter of our liquid comes from our food. Almost all food has some water in it (even a slice of bread can be as much as 33 per cent H2O), but fruit and vegetables are the most water-laden (stock image) </p>
<p> That’s because experts believe we should all turn off the tap and start eating our water instead. </p>
<p> It is clear our bodies need water to function - anything from 1½ litres to three litres a day depending on body size and exertion. </p>
<p> It is essential for keeping moist delicate tissues (such as those in the mouth, eyes and nose), it lubricates joints, carries nutrients around the body, regulates body temperature and digestion, and helps flush out toxins and waste products. </p>
<p> Many beauty experts also say that getting plenty of water is the secret to plump, glowing skin - particularly in middle age. </p>
<p> It is clear our bodies need water to function - anything from 1½ litres to three litres a day depending on body size and exertion. It is essential for keeping moist delicate tissues (such as those in the mouth, eyes and nose) </p>
<p> This is because while we’re made up of 75 to 80 per cent water at birth, the cells throughout our body gradually dry up with age, and by the time we reach 50 we are closer to 50 per cent water. </p>
<p> However, the ‘drink more water’ health message might have been somewhat over-played. </p>
<p> In an average day, a quarter of our liquid comes from our food. Almost all food has some water in it (even a slice of bread can be as much as 33 per cent H2O), but fruit and vegetables are the most water-laden, with cucumbers, lettuce, courgettes and radishes boasting more than 95 per cent. </p>
<p> Now health enthusiasts are arguing we should be eating more of these water-rich foods and drinking less. </p>
<p> ‘Healthy hydration is about the water you hold in the body, not the water you drink that passes straight through,’ says Dr Howard Murad, associate clinic professor of medicine at the University of California, Los Angeles, and author of The Water Secret. </p>
<p> A tomato contains 109ml of water and a portion of Iceberg lettuce contains 300ml. The water you eat is different to the water you drink because the water in food is surrounded by other molecules that help it get into our cells more easily, and ensure it stays in our system for long enough to be put to good use (stock image) </p>
<p> Drinking too much water can, he says, actually deplete your body of vitamins and minerals if they are flushed out of the body too quickly. </p>
<p> ‘There’s nothing wrong with drinking water, but if we don’t improve the capacity to get it into our cells and keep it there, it goes straight into the toilet without doing us any good,’ he says. </p>
<p> ‘You can drink eight glasses of water - and while that is still a way of putting water into your body, it could mean eight trips to the bathroom without it actually reaching your cells.’ </p>
<p> He warns that puffy eyes, swollen ankles and a bloated stomach are signs of a body that is not handling water efficiently. </p>
<p> ‘It floats between our cells, ageing us and making us feel fat and sluggish.’ </p>
<p> Many beauty experts also say that getting plenty of water is the secret to plump, glowing skin - particularly in middle age. This is because while we’re made up of 75 to 80 per cent water at birth, the cells throughout our body gradually dry up with age, and by the time we reach 50 we are closer to 50 per cent water (stock image) </p>
<p> However, the water you eat is different. This is because the water in food is surrounded by other molecules that help it get into our cells more easily, and ensure it stays in our system for long enough to be put to good use. </p>
<p> ‘When we eat water-rich foods, we absorb water more slowly because it is trapped in the structure of these foods,’ says Dr Murad. ‘That slow absorption means the water in food stays in our bodies longer, and brings a multitude of additional benefits.’ </p>
<p> In fact, studies show that fruit and vegetables can hydrate the body twice as effectively as a glass of water. </p>
<p> One study, by researchers at the University of Aberdeen Medical School, found that the natural sugars, proteins, mineral salts and vitamins in water-rich fruits and vegetables means they also supplement the nutrients lost through exercise. Dr Murad calls this type of hydration ‘structured water’. </p>
<p> A cucumber contains 100ml of water in it. ‘Foods with a high water content tend to be low calorie,’ says dietitian Dr Sarah Schenker, explaining that substituting water-based foods for high-calorie foods is one clever way to subtract calories and fat from your diet (stock image) </p>
<p> So an entire cucumber (which weighs 100g and is 96 per cent water) might deliver only just under 100 ml of liquid (just over a quarter of a pint). </p>
<p> However, by ‘drinking’ your water in cucumber form, you’ll get 100ml of liquid that your body can really use, and you’ll be stocking up on fibre and plant nutrients at the same time. </p>
<p> As a further bonus, if you set out to eat as much water as you can and opt for a variety of plant sources, you’ll be massively increasing your consumption of fruit and vegetables beyond the minimum five portions a day recommended by cancer experts to protect you against disease. </p>
<p> You might also lose weight. </p>
<p> Healthy hydration is about the water you hold in the body, not the water you drink that passes straight through </p>
<p> ‘Foods with a high water content tend to be low calorie,’ says dietitian Dr Sarah Schenker, explaining that substituting water-based foods for high-calorie foods is one clever way to subtract calories and fat from your diet. Furthermore, studies show that watery foods keep you feeling fuller for longer. </p>
<p> ‘The water content aids the digestive process, which keeps you sated,’ says Dr Schenker. ‘Water-rich foods can help bulk up your diet while delivering nutrients and water.’ </p>
<p> She recommends putting the consumption of water-filled vegetables before fruit, as eating too much fruit can push your blood sugar levels up. </p>
<p> She also advises eating them raw or only lightly cooked. </p>
<p> This is because the cooking process breaks down the cell membranes of plants and allows water to leak out, depleting your potential water supply and leaching precious nutrients, too. </p>
<p> But before you throw away your water filter and fill the fridge with salad instead, Dr Schenker warns that you might want to ease yourself slowly from drinking water to eating it. </p>
<p> A too swift switch could give your body an unfamiliar fibre boost, which could see you running to the lavatory for an entirely different reason... </p>
<p> Share or comment on this article: </p>
<p> Why you should EAT water, not drink it - If you're obsessed with rehydrating, drop that bottle and reach for the fruit and veg </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599875" filename="why-i-eat-fruit-first-thing-in-the-morning" parent_folder="web2" url="http://fromscratchmostly.com/from-scratch-mostly-home-page/why-i-eat-fruit-first-thing-in-the-morning">
<p> I haven't mentioned yet that a few weeks ago I decided to start eating fruit before anything else in the morning. I basically wake up and start the day with my daily routine. While making everyone's meal I nosh on mango or a few chunks of watermelon (2 of my favorites) and head over to Selah's room for her morning routine. This totals up to about 30 minutes before I actually eat my meal, which gives me plenty of time to digest the fruit I had just eaten. </p>
<p> So why am I being so particular with fruit, you ask? </p>
<p> Well, there are countless of rumors going around the health community stating that the consumption of fruit first thing in the morning, or simply on an empty stomach, is beneficial for weight loss, cancer prevention, and the treatment of chronic illnesses! Although I may not be an RD, I have done some research on the benefits of eating fruit before anything else. Much to my dismay, I ended up with a "virtual" headache due to the myriad of contradicting information which almost had me give up on the whole idea. Thankfully that didn't happen! </p>
<p> In order to break it down for us, I will talk about the few things I have found on the internet so we can look at it collectively--then we can make a judgment call on the topic and decide whether or not we even want to follow this practice. Ultimately, I just want to share how the consumption of {certain} fruits first thing in the morning has affected me personally, because we are all suckers for real-life testimonies, aren't we? :) </p>
<p> Mixing fruit with other things cancels its benefits due to lack of nutrient absorption, therefore leading to lack of proper nutrition and vitamins. But something is still better than nothing and the only truth that this claim holds up to is the fact that some foods can make us more indigested than others. </p>
<p> Fruit on an empty stomach promotes a higher metabolism and produces a detoxifying effect. However, there isn't too much scientific proof on this claim. </p>
<p> My Experience with Eating Fruit First Thing in the Morning </p>
<p> Although my experience with this shows me that mayyyyybe the above bits of information might have some truth to them, I can't say for sure that they are 100% responsible for the changes in my body and health. This is my personal experience though, so please remember to take it in with a grain of salt, as with anything. </p>
<p> I only eat fruits that are non-acidic when I have an empty stomach, as in they don't make my intestines burn, especially due to my indigestion problems. </p>
<p> I eat a main meal shortly after because of my sensitive stomach. </p>
<p> Fruit is beneficial in any form, in my opinion, so I still mix it with my food as I please because it can't hurt. That is, unless, the fruit is extremely sour like an underripe orange or strawberry. Cant eat those! Blechhh. </p>
<p> Noticed a boost of energy and I don't feel as tired throughout the day. I still need my 3 PM java fix, though. :) </p>
<p> Easier time digesting food! </p>
<p> People have noticed that I have dropped some weight, although it's hard for me to tell personally. I can't say that it is exclusively due to this way of eating fruit (as the articles state), but I noticed that my appetite is a bit more under control. By the time I start my meal I don't feel ravenous, thus, I don't end up eating as much as usual and I feel more attuned to my body's signals. </p>
<p> Finals Thoughts to Take Home </p>
<p> I realize that this is an overwhelming amount of information, and trust me....this is nothing compared to the hundreds of articles out there! </p>
<p> My thought is this...As with anything related to dietary practices, please do what feels good for your body. While I do believe that the above statements might have some truth to them, I do not think that they can dramatically change our health or help us shed 100 lbs. Sure, they can always be beneficial and they certainly can't hurt...but if you have a hypersensitive stomach then eating sour fruit probably isn't the best idea. On the other hand, you might be lucky to be able to control your appetite a lot better if you were to eat fruit on an empty stomach. </p>
<p> So do trial and error if this is of interest to you. Don't do it just because Victoria Beckham swears by this way of eating, and don't do it just because it has benefited me. Try it out and see for yourself if it helps you thrive, or whether it makes things more complicated for you. </p>
<p> Although I hate extreme dietary practices, adding a bit of fruit before anything else in the morning has done preeettyyyy good things for me! I just treat it like regular supplements. And whether or not you try this out, do so with wisdom and discretion. I like what Michael Pollan says: "Eat Food. Not too Much. Mostly Plants (In Defense of Food)". Simple is good! </p>
<p> Cheers to health, guys! </p>
<p> Have you ever heard of these claims? What are your thoughts on them? </p>
<p> Do you eat strategically? </p>
<p> What are some "different" ways of eating that have helped you in the long run? </p>
</doc>

<p> Feeding your children is our ‘bread and butter’ </p>
<p> There’s everything in place for a safe return to school, from special training to a ‘grab and go’ menu. </p>
<p> What we do </p>
<p> Serving meals with the right nutritional balance boosts children’s development, behaviour and ability to learn. Our eats development chef creates two exciting menus per academic term, taking into account freshness, seasonality of ingredients, tastes, and trends. Reducing sugar and fat is a priority, as is ensuring ingredients are ethically sourced from local suppliers with the highest standards. Increasing fruit and vegetable intake is another commitment, and we often use natural sweetness (eg from parsnips and beetroots) in our delicious desserts. We have been nationally recognised at the Cost Sector Catering Awards with short listings in the Innovation and Education categories for our ‘Pick & Mix’ offer, allowing children to create a bag or box suiting their individual tastes. </p>
<p> How we do it </p>
<p> Highly experienced </p>
<p> Our catering management team bring over 100 years worth of experience to eats. Meet us and you’ll experience our passion for school meals first hand. </p>
<p> Home baked </p>
<p> The majority of meals are freshly prepared in our kitchens. Visit our kitchens to experience the aroma of homemade bread and pizza bases made with flour from a family-owned local producer. </p>
<p> Healthy meals </p>
<p> All of our menus follow the School Food Standards and are made with the healthiest ingredients. Sample our food to see how we cut sugar and saturated fat without compromising any taste or enjoyment. </p>
<p> Why choose Eats? </p>
<p> Sustainable </p>
<p> Through reduced packaging, spot-on portion sizes, local procurement, and initiatives such as converting used cooking oil into biodiesel, we reduce the amount of waste going to landfill. </p>
<p> Consistent </p>
<p> We have an award-winning team of brand champions who work hard to ensure our unashamedly high standards are met every day, throughout all our schools. </p>
<p> Integrity </p>

<p> Partnership </p>
<p> Our curriculum-enriched theme days and events tie in with your school’s calendar. We become part of your learning environment, supporting with parents evenings, sports days and hosting school barbecues. </p>
<p> Agility </p>
<p> Our success is built upon offering the flexibility to make changes within our kitchens as and when you need it, quickly with the minimum of fuss. </p>
<p> Our food </p>
<p> Our award-winning development chef works to the School Food Standards and Food for Life guidelines to hand-craft menus that are nutritious and tasty. Our experienced, dedicated catering teams then prepare and cook these meals knowing that your children will love them. </p>
<p> Here at eats, we are proud to have pledged our commitment to the Peas Please initiative. We have pledged to develop our menus to ensure that a minimum of six varieties of vegetables and salads are available each week in children’s meal experiences. </p>

<doc id="file21599826" filename="www.islandeats.ca" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.islandeats.ca/">
<p> We've helped save Atlantic Canadian Restaurants over Half a Million Dollars in fees over the last year! </p>

<doc id="file21599827" filename="www.realeats.com" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.realeats.com/">
<p> Real food, made simple. </p>
<p> Healthy chef-prepared meals that save you time, reduce food waste, and support local farmers. </p>
<p> Get started </p>
<p> Real food, made simple. </p>
<p> Healthy chef-prepared meals that save you time, reduce food waste, and support local farmers. </p>
<p> Get started </p>
<p> No cooking, no compromises. </p>
<p> Personalize your plan </p>
<p> Pick your plan and individually portioned meals - perfect for singles, couples and families. </p>
<p> We cook and deliver </p>
<p> Dig into chef-prepared meals made with premium ingredients, delivered fresh to your door. </p>
<p> Heat in minutes </p>
<p> Pop your fresh packed-meal pouches into boiling water, or plate them and microwave. </p>
<p> Save time. Live better. </p>
<p> Love your farm-fresh meals and the hour you saved! Order again, skip a week or cancel anytime. </p>
<p> Did you know that ordering from RealEats supports farmers? </p>
<p> Many of the ingredients in our meals come from small independent farms located close to our kitchen in upstate New York and other local agricultural communities. </p>

<p> All our meals are designed to serve one average-sized adult. You can click on any meal to view the calorie counts and nutritional facts. RealEats meals are all less than 700 calories and work great for dinner or lunch. And with a variety of add-ons available for purchase, we can cover your breakfast and snacks, too! </p>
<p> We include full nutritional panels for all of our meals so you can choose which menu items are best for you! Whether you’re gluten-free, paleo, low-calorie or full-on carnivore, you’ll always have options. Our meals are made with high-quality real ingredients, but we are not a diet plan. If you have health concerns, please consult a health professional before making your selections. Details for all meals can be found on the On The Menu page. </p>

<p> Best Fruits to Eat If You Have Diabetes </p>
<p> Tips for Incorporating Fruit Into Your Meal Plan </p>
<p> Barbie Cervoni MS, RD, CDCES, CDN, is a registered dietitian and certified diabetes care and education specialist. </p>
<p> Ana Maria Kausel, MD, is double board-certified in internal medicine and endocrinology/diabetes and metabolism. She works in private practice and is affiliated with Mount Sinai St. Luke's/Mount Sinai West. </p>
<p> You may have heard at some point that you cannot eat fruit if you have diabetes. Perhaps someone even told you that watermelon and bananas are off limits because they are too sweet. Neither of these is entirely true. You can enjoy fruit, you simply need to make smart decisions about which fruits and how much you eat. </p>
<p> Fruits and Diabetes </p>
<p> Fruits have many health benefits—they contain vitamins, minerals, filling fiber and antioxidants. Fruit can be beneficial to a diabetes meal plan if eaten in moderation. The key to eating fruit is to make sure you eat the right kinds in the appropriate portions. </p>
<p> The fiber found in fruit can help to prevent blood sugar spikes, may aid in pulling cholesterol away from your heart, and increase feelings of fullness, resulting in less food intake. Fruit is also an excellent source of vitamins and minerals, such as potassium, which can help reduce your blood pressure.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> On the flip side, fruit is a carbohydrate and it contains a natural sugar called fructose. Carbohydrates, whether from bread, milk, yogurt, potatoes, or fruit, get broken down during digestion and turn into sugar or glucose. For this reason, it's recommended that people who have diabetes monitor how many carbohydrates they eat, including fruit servings.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> When choosing fruit you'll want to take a few tips into consideration: </p>
<p> Avoid Dried Fruit and Fruit Juices </p>
<p> Dried fruit, especially if it is sweetened, is higher in carbohydrates per serving than natural whole fruit. It also contains more sugar because sugars are often added for flavor and can be lower in fiber if the skin has been removed. Just four tablespoons of raisins (1/4 cup) will cost you: 120 calories, 32 grams of carbohydrates, and 24 grams of sugar.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> It's also best to avoid all fruit juices. Even 100% fruit juice causes instant spikes in blood sugars because the flesh of the fruit, which contains fiber, is discarded. It is also easy to drink an excess amount of calories without realizing it. For example, 1 cup of 100% fruit juice contains 130 calories, 33 grams of carbohydrates, and 28 grams of sugar.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Instead of dried fruit or fruit juice, opt for whole fruit—fresh, frozen, or canned—without added syrups or sugars. </p>
<p> Keep Portions in Check </p>
<p> The American Diabetes Association recommends about 45% of total daily calorie intake come from carbohydrates.﻿﻿ If you are following a fixed, consistent carbohydrate meal plan, you need to factor in fruit as a carbohydrate choice. When choosing fruit, try to stick with one fruit serving per meal or snack and limit your fruit servings to no more than about two to three per day.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Keep in mind that one fruit serving is about 15 grams of carbohydrates. How much of each fruit you can eat within that one-serving limit will depend on the type of fruit. Here is a list of what is considered one serving for common whole fruits:﻿﻿ </p>
<p> 1 small-sized (4 ounces) apple, orange, peach, pear, or plum </p>
<p> 1 cup raspberries and blackberries (contains 8 grams of fiber) </p>
<p> There are some fruits that you should be more cautious about. For instance, it's recommended that bananas, cherries, grapes, mango, and pineapple be eaten only in the limited quantities noted, as they can cause a fast spike in blood sugars due to their higher carbohydrate content. </p>
<p> If you are looking to get the most value for the biggest portion, you will want to choose fruits that are very high in fiber, such as berries. For example, you can eat 1 1/4 cup of strawberries for 15 grams carbohydrates.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Choose Fruits With a Lower Glycemic Index </p>
<p> The American Diabetes Association suggests that you choose fruits that have a low glycemic index.﻿﻿ The glycemic index, or GI, is used as a reference to measure how a carbohydrate-containing food raises blood glucose. </p>
<p> Foods are rated based on how they raise blood sugars in comparison to a reference food such as sugar or white bread. A food with a high GI will raise blood glucose more than that of a food with a medium or low GI.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Most fruits have a low to moderate GI, with the exception of pineapple and watermelon.﻿﻿ That doesn't mean you can never eat pineapple and watermelon, but if you notice that your blood sugar spikes after eating either, it's best to avoid them in the future. It's also important to note that the GI of a food is different when eaten alone than it is when combined with other foods. For example, if you are eating a high GI fruit, such as watermelon, pairing it with a low GI index food, such as low-fat cheese can help to balance out the effect on blood sugar levels. Here are some examples of low, moderate, and high GI fruits: </p>
<p> Low GI fruits (55 or less): apples, pears, mango, blueberries, strawberries, kiwi, grapefruit, pear, nectarine, orange </p>
<p> High GI fruits (70 or greater): watermelon, pineapple </p>
<p> Note this information, while also keeping in mind that everyone has their own trigger foods which will spike blood sugars more than others. Additionally, the riper a fruit is, the more it affects your blood sugar. </p>
<p> Lastly, consider this: some nutritious foods have a higher GI than foods with little nutritional value. For example, oatmeal has a higher GI than chocolate. When using the GI, balance it with basic nutrition principals and eat a variety of healthy foods and less of foods with few nutrients. </p>
<p> Pair it With Protein </p>
<p> Some people find that pairing fruit with a protein can help slow down a rise in the blood sugars.﻿﻿ You can do this by incorporating fruit into your meal allotment for carbohydrates or add protein to your fruit snack. </p>
<p> For example: </p>
<p> 1 4-ounce apple slice with 1 tablespoon almond butter </p>
<p> 1 cup raspberries with 1 small non-fat Greek yogurt </p>
<p> 1 small peach with 1/2 cup low-fat cottage cheese </p>
<p> Get the Most Out of Your Fruit Choices </p>
<p> When choosing fruit, you'll want to think about portion size, convenience, cost, and flavor, but also health benefits. Certain types of fruit, such as berries and citrus fruits, can be beneficial for people with diabetes. </p>
<p> Berries are rich in vitamin C, folic acid, fiber, and disease-fighting phytochemicals. Vitamin C is an important water-soluble vitamin that is involved in repairing cells (particularly important for wound healing), slowing down aging, and boosting immunity.﻿﻿ Additionally their rich color—red, blue, and black comes from anthocyanins. Research suggests that anthocyanins may help fend off certain chronic disease, including cardiovascular disease.﻿﻿ </p>
<p> Citrus fruits, such as tangerines, also contain vitamin C, and potassium (which can reduce blood pressure) and are a good source of fat soluble vitamin A, an important vitamin for eye health. Citrus fruits, also contain phytonutrients which can protect cells from damage, reduce inflammation, lower the risk of cardiovascular disease, and provide other health benefits.﻿﻿ But, if you are on a potassium restricted diet or take cholesterol-lowering medication you may have to watch your intake of citrus fruits so make sure you discuss intake with your physician before adding them to your meal plan. </p>
<p> A Word From Verywell </p>
<p> The notion that you have to avoid fruit on a diabetic diet is a myth. However, it is important that you make the best choices and always consider the carbohydrates in fruits, which will convert to sugar and may cause a spike in your blood sugar. Choose wisely and keep your portions under control and you should be able to enjoy some fruits. If you have questions, be sure to ask a member of your healthcare team. </p>
<p> Was this page helpful? </p>
<p> Thanks for your feedback! </p>
<p> We know healthy eating is key to help manage diabetes, but that doesn't make it easy. Our free nutrition guide is here to help. Sign up and receive your free copy! </p>

<p> Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Diabetes and carbs. Updated September 19, 2019. </p>
<p> U.S. Department of Agriculture. Raisins. Updated March 11, 2018. </p>
<p> U.S. Department of Agriculture. 100% fruit juice. Updated June 2, 2018. </p>
</doc>
<doc id="file21599869" filename="you-should-eat-fish-eyes" parent_folder="web2" url="https://www.esquire.com/food-drink/food/a19598699/you-should-eat-fish-eyes/">
<p> Every product was carefully curated by an Esquire editor. We may earn a commission from these links. </p>
<p> If You're Not Eating the Eyeballs, You're Missing the Tastiest Part of the Fish </p>
<p> Consider popping one of these umami-flavored suckers right in your piehole. You won't regret it. </p>
<p> By Maxine Wally </p>
<p> Mar 27, 2018 </p>
<p> Getty Images </p>
<p> Growing up with a Chinese mother and a Jewish father, I was exposed to a range of practices and beliefs that varied in their levels of hilarity and veracity. One custom from the Chinese side stated that at mealtime, in the event that a whole fish—head and tail on for good luck and fortune—was on the table, the most honorable guest received the eyeballs to eat. Thanks to my voracious appetite and my sister's total disinterest in munching on slimy fish eyes, that honor was bestowed upon me. (I still felt special, even if I won by default.) </p>
<p> This content is imported from {embed-name}. You may be able to find the same content in another format, or you may be able to find more information, at their web site. </p>
<p> After scooping the eye from the socket of whichever unlucky mackerel or sea bass that landed on our table, I'd hold it in my mouth and savor the gooey outer layer before biting into the crispy, wafer-like center, letting the rich umami flavor of the ocean floor dance across my tongue. Slurp, yum. Hungry yet? </p>
<p> I know how it sounds. Outside the home, I was embarrassed to admit to my classmates or friends that I ate eyeballs—I thought they might see it as gross or barbaric. The eyes are part of the face, which cradles the brain, the ultimate provider of identity; eyes are the windows into the soul. I figured people would squirm at the prospect of consuming something that reminded them of being human. </p>
<p> But my days of hiding the unconventional stuff I eat are over, and I urge you to give eyeballs a hearty go. </p>
<p> Beyond the best reason to eat fish eyes—they're delicious—Chinese folks swear by their nutritional advantages as well. The eyeball is said to stimulate brain cells and stave off memory loss, courtesy of a pair of unsaturated fatty acids called DHA and EPA. My mom, of course, fully bought into this theory: "Eat the eye and you'll be smart!" Additionally, the head itself (another part you should eat) is chock full of omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin A, and protein. </p>
<p> The Chinese aren’t the only ones throwing back eyeballs. Russians use fish heads—peepers and all—in a soup called ukha. In Iceland, they serve a traditional dish called svio, or boiled sheep’s head, and every appendage must be consumed by the end of the meal. Any Sri Lankan will tell you it’s customary to eat the entire fish to avoid waste, and yes, that includes the eyes. </p>
<p> Maybe they'll make you smarter. You'll likely feel a little more cultured. But you'll definitely stimulate your tastebuds with saline flavor like you’ve never experienced before. So the next time you’re presented with a whole fish, tell the plebs sitting around you to fall back, because you’re the honorable guest, and this eye’s for you. </p>
<p> This content is created and maintained by a third party, and imported onto this page to help users provide their email addresses. You may be able to find more information about this and similar content at piano.io </p>
</doc>
